question_text: Q68. In a case scenario of a patient with acute onset weakness and loss of pain and temperature sensation, sparing of vibration sense is noted. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Acute myelopathies can be vascular, inflammatory, compressive or degenerative. The anterior spinal artery (ASA) supplies the anterior two-thirds of the cord including:
• Corticospinal tracts (motor control)
• Spinothalamic tracts (pain & temperature)
The dorsal columns (vibration & proprioception) are spared, as they are supplied by the posterior spinal arteries.
In ASA syndrome (spinal cord infarction), patients present with sudden flaccid paralysis below the lesion, loss of pain/temperature, but preserved vibration/proprioception. Differentiation from multiple sclerosis, peripheral neuropathy or anterior horn cell disease relies on time course (hyperacute vs subacute/chronic), sensory dissociation, reflex changes and imaging findings.
(This section: 102 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Spinal cord infarction due to ASA occlusion classically causes a flaccid-then-spastic paraparesis with dissociated sensory loss. MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) demonstrates hyperintensity in the anterior cord (“owl’s eyes” on axial T2) within hours.
• AHA/ASA Scientific Statement (Rabinstein et al., Stroke 2019) recommends emergent MRI with DWI for suspected spinal cord stroke (Level C-LD).
• In a multicenter series (Masson et al., Neurology 2017), 85% of ASA infarcts showed anterior horn hyperintensity and spared dorsal columns on T2.
Prompt recognition guides supportive management—maintain mean arterial pressure to optimize cord perfusion—and avoids unnecessary immunotherapies used in inflammatory myelopathies.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Multiple sclerosis
• MS lesions evolve subacutely over days to weeks, often with remissions.
• Demyelinating plaques frequently involve dorsal columns, causing proprioceptive deficits.
• Oligoclonal bands, MRI shows multifocal lesions in brain/cord, not isolated ASA territory.

C. Peripheral neuropathy
• Presents with distal, symmetric “stocking-glove” sensory loss including vibration sense.
• Motor weakness is mild, predominantly involves distal muscles rather than a spinal level.
• No clear acute spinal level or sensory level.

D. Anterior horn cell disease
• Pure motor neuron involvement (e.g., ALS, poliomyelitis) causes LMN signs without sensory loss.
• Pain and temperature pathways remain intact.
• Onset may be subacute to chronic; fasciculations and muscle atrophy are prominent.

Comparison Table

FeatureSpinal Cord Infarction (ASA)Multiple SclerosisPeripheral NeuropathyAnterior Horn Cell Disease
OnsetHyperacute (minutes–hours)Subacute (days–weeks)Insidious (months–years)Subacute–chronic
Motor deficitsFlaccid → spastic paraparesisVariable weaknessMild distal weaknessLMN weakness
Pain & temperature sensationLost below lesionOften preserved earlyLost in distal distributionPreserved
Vibration/proprioceptionPreservedOften impairedImpairedPreserved
ReflexesAreflexia acutely, later hyperreflexiaMixedHyporeflexiaHyporeflexia
MRI findingsAnterior cord hyperintensityMultifocal demyelinating plaquesNormal cord imagingNormal cord imaging

Clinical Pearls

- Acute dissociated sensory loss (pain/temperature ↓, vibration ↑) localizes to ASA territory.
• “Owl’s eyes” sign on axial T2 MRI is highly specific for ASA infarction.
• Maintain mean arterial pressure ≥85 mm Hg acutely to improve spinal perfusion.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing ASA syndrome with central cord syndrome: central cord involves upper extremities > lower and spares most trunk sensation.
2. Assuming any acute paraplegia is inflammatory myelitis and administering high-dose steroids without imaging.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Rabinstein AA et al. “Spinal Cord Infarction: A Scientific Statement from the American Heart Association.” Stroke. 2019;50(1):e23–e41.
• Recommendation: Emergent spinal MRI with DWI in suspected spinal cord stroke (Class I; Level C-LD).
2. Flanagan EP et al. “Practice Advisory: Diagnostic Approach to Acute Myelopathies.” Neurology. 2021;97(7):347–358.
• Suggestion: Distinguish vascular from inflammatory myelopathy by onset <12 h, pain, MRI pattern (anterolateral lesions for infarction) (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Anterior spinal artery arises from vertebral arteries, runs along ventral surface, supplying anterior two-thirds of cord.
• Spinothalamic fibers cross near entry level and ascend anterolaterally; corticospinal tracts descend in anterolateral columns.
• Dorsal columns (fasciculus gracilis/cuneatus) lie posteriorly, supplied by paired posterior spinal arteries.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Occlusion or hypoperfusion of the ASA—due to aortic surgery, dissection, hypotension or embolism—leads to ischemic necrosis of anterior horn cells, lateral corticospinal tracts and spinothalamic pathways. Secondary injury cascades involve excitotoxicity and inflammation, but dorsal columns remain intact.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical: Acute (<12 h) paraplegia + dissociated sensory loss.
2. Urgent MRI spine with T2 and DWI sequences.
3. Exclude compressive etiologies (epidural hematoma, abscess).
4. Vascular imaging (MR angiography) if dissection suspected.
5. Supportive care: hemodynamic optimization, early rehabilitation.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- T2-weighted “owl’s eyes” hyperintensity in anterior horns.
• DWI: restricted diffusion within anterior cord within 3 h of onset.
• Absence of contrast enhancement differentiates from inflammatory lesions.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- No specific neuroprotective agents proven.
• Antiplatelet therapy (aspirin 81–325 mg daily) recommended to reduce recurrent vascular events (Level C-EO).
• Hemodynamic support: maintain systolic BP 140–160 mm Hg in acute phase.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Acute myelopathies, especially anterior spinal artery syndrome, are tested via sensory dissociation patterns and imaging correlates.
Frequency: Annual Part 1 exams include 1–2 vascular myelopathy questions, often in single-best-answer format.

question_text: A CT brain scan shows right PICA territory infarction. What finding would you expect on examination?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] • The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) supplies the lateral medulla, inferior cerebellar peduncle, vestibular nuclei, nucleus ambiguus (IX, X), and spinal trigeminal nucleus.
• Infarction in this territory produces Wallenberg (lateral medullary) syndrome: ipsilateral facial pain/temp loss, contralateral body pain/temp loss, ipsilateral ataxia, nucleus ambiguus signs (dysphagia, hoarseness, uvula deviation away from lesion).
• Uvula deviation occurs because lesion of nucleus ambiguus impairs ipsilateral palatal elevation (via vagus), so intact contralateral side pulls uvula away from lesion.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Left uvula deviation is characteristic of a right lateral medullary (PICA) infarct due to nucleus ambiguus involvement. The nucleus ambiguus gives motor fibers to the ipsilateral palate via the vagus nerve; when lesioned on the right, the left palate elevates unopposed, deviating the uvula to the left. AHA/ASA 2019 stroke guidelines emphasize bedside cranial nerve examination to localize posterior circulation strokes (Class I, Level B–NR). Neuroimaging corroborates vascular territory: CT/MRI angiography will show PICA infarction. Studies of brainstem stroke localization (Kim JS, Brain 2003) confirm that contralateral uvular deviation has >90% specificity for nucleus ambiguus lesions in lateral medullary syndrome.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Left side ptosis
– PICA infarct can cause ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (miosis, mild ptosis) on the right, not contralateral; left ptosis would indicate a left-sided sympathetic lesion.
– Misconception: equating ptosis with PICA always but ignoring side.
C. Right body decreased sensation
– Spinothalamic fibers in lateral medulla carry contralateral pain/temp: a right-sided lesion causes left body loss. Right body involvement suggests a left-sided lesion or spinal cord lesion.
– Common error: confusing ipsilateral facial vs body sensory loss.
D. Left limb ataxia
– Cerebellar peduncle involvement causes ipsilateral ataxia: right-sided lesion gives right limb ataxia. Left limb ataxia would reflect a left cerebellar or left spinocerebellar issue.
– Pitfall: reversing ipsi- versus contralateral signs.

Comparison Table

FeatureLeft Uvula Deviation (Correct)Left Side PtosisRight Body Decreased SensationLeft Limb Ataxia
Affected StructureNucleus ambiguus (CN IX,X)Sympathetic chainAnterolateral (spinothalamic) tractInferior cerebellar peduncle
Side Relative to Right LesionContralateral (uvula deviates away from right lesion)Contralateral (should be ipsilateral if present)Ipsilateral (wrong for spinothalamic)Contralateral (wrong for cerebellar signs)
Typical in PICA InfarctionYesNoNoNo

Clinical Pearls

• In Wallenberg syndrome, nucleus ambiguus signs (dysphagia, hoarseness, contralateral uvula deviation) distinguish PICA from lateral pontine infarcts (AICA).
• Ipsilateral facial analgesia with contralateral body analgesia is pathognomonic for lateral medullary involvement.
• Always test palate elevation and uvula position in suspected brainstem strokes; mislocalization leads to delayed diagnosis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming uvula deviates toward the lesion rather than away (students often invert).
2. Confusing PICA vs AICA: only PICA lesions involve nucleus ambiguus, AICA lesions involve facial nucleus (facial paralysis).
3. Mixing up ipsilateral vs contralateral cerebellar signs in brainstem strokes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke, 2019
– Recommendation: Use noncontrast CT ± CT angiography/MRI to identify posterior circulation infarcts and guide reperfusion strategies. (Class I, Level B–NR)
2. AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Prevention of Stroke in Patients With Stroke and Transient Ischemic Attack, 2014
– Recommendation: In minor noncardioembolic stroke (NIHSS ≤3), dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin plus clopidogrel for 21 days reduces recurrence. (Class I, Level A)

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The PICA arises from the vertebral artery and supplies lateral medulla structures: nucleus ambiguus (CN IX, X), spinal trigeminal nucleus, vestibular nuclei, inferior cerebellar peduncle, and spinothalamic tract. Lesion of nucleus ambiguus spares accessory nucleus (CN XI) but impairs vagal fibers to palate.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemia of the vertebral artery/PICA leads to infarction of the dorsolateral medulla. Loss of nucleus ambiguus output causes palatal droop on lesion side; intact contralateral palatal fibers pull uvula toward healthy side.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Posterior circulation stroke localization—especially differentiating PICA vs AICA syndromes—is frequently tested as multiple-choice items focusing on ipsilateral nucleus ambiguus signs and ipsilateral vs contralateral sensory/ataxic deficits.

question_text: In a case scenario of a patient with left eye amaurosis fugax and transient dysarthria, what is your next step?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] • Transient ischemic attack (TIA) represents a brief episode of neurological dysfunction without infarction; amaurosis fugax indicates retinal ischemia via the ipsilateral ophthalmic artery branch of the internal carotid.
• Dysarthria suggests involvement of cortical or subcortical motor pathways in the carotid distribution.
• The primary goal in TIA is rapid identification of large‐vessel stenosis: carotid duplex ultrasound noninvasively quantifies plaque burden and flow velocity, guiding urgent interventions (e.g., endarterectomy).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Carotid duplex ultrasound is the recommended first test in symptomatic TIA with anterior circulation features. The 2018 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention guidelines advise vascular imaging (duplex, CTA, or MRA) within 24 hours of presentation to detect ≥50 % internal carotid stenosis (Class I, Level of Evidence A). The NASCET trial demonstrated that patients with 70–99 % symptomatic stenosis reduce stroke risk by >50 % with endarterectomy. Duplex has high sensitivity (88–94 %) and specificity (85–90 %) for moderate‐to‐severe stenosis. Brain MRI and echocardiography are important but follow vascular imaging. Routine anticoagulation without a cardioembolic source is not indicated and increases hemorrhagic risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Brain MRI
• While diffusion‐weighted MRI identifies acute infarction, it does not assess extracranial carotid stenosis.
• Misconception: imaging for infarction must precede vascular imaging; in fact, urgent vessel assessment guides revascularization.

C. Echocardiography
• Used to detect cardiac embolic sources (e.g., PFO, left atrial appendage thrombus) after excluding large‐vessel disease.
• Does not address the high‐risk carotid plaque causing amaurosis fugax.

D. Initiate anticoagulation therapy
• Full anticoagulation is reserved for confirmed cardioembolic or dissection etiologies.
• In noncardioembolic TIA, dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) is indicated short term; anticoagulation may increase bleeding without benefit.

Comparison Table

FeatureCarotid DuplexBrain MRIEchocardiographyAnticoagulation
Primary PurposeQuantify carotid stenosisDetect acute cerebral infarctionIdentify cardiac embolic sourcePrevent cardioembolic events
Timing PriorityWithin 24 h of TIAWithin 24–48 hAfter vascular imagingAfter embolic source identified
Diagnostic YieldHigh for ≥50 % stenosis (88–94 %)High for infarction but no vesselModerate for intracardiac thrombiNot diagnostic
Impact on Immediate ManagementGuides carotid revascularizationGuides secondary preventionGuides anticoagulation decisionsTherapeutic, not diagnostic

Clinical Pearls

• Amaurosis fugax (“curtain coming down”) is a retinal TIA indicating ipsilateral carotid artery disease.
• Vascular imaging within 24 hours reduces early recurrent stroke risk by enabling timely endarterectomy.
• Symptomatic 70–99 % carotid stenosis benefits most from surgical intervention; <50 % stenosis is managed medically.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prioritizing MRI over carotid imaging leads to delayed revascularization in high‐risk patients.
2. Automatically starting anticoagulation for all TIAs ignores etiology, risking hemorrhage without reducing stroke recurrence.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• 2018 AHA/ASA TIA/Stroke Guideline: “Perform cervical vascular imaging within 24 hours of TIA” (Class I, Level A).
• 2021 ESO Guidelines: “First‐line evaluation of symptomatic carotid disease with duplex ultrasound, CTA, or MRA” (Level A).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Carotid duplex evaluation in amaurosis fugax and TIA scenarios is frequently tested on neurology boards, often emphasizing timing and indications for endarterectomy.

question_text: In the same case scenario [likely related to Q68, spinal cord infarction], what investigation should be performed?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Spinal cord infarction arises when arterial supply—most often the anterior spinal artery (ASA)—is compromised, producing acute myelopathic deficits. Early imaging is essential to distinguish ischemia from compressive, inflammatory, or infectious myelopathies.
Core concepts:
• Vascular anatomy: ASA supplies anterior two-thirds of cord; occlusion yields bilateral motor and pain/temperature loss below lesion.
• Diagnostic urgency: Timely MRI detects ischemic changes before irreversible injury develops.
• Imaging modalities: MRI (T2‐weighted, diffusion‐weighted imaging) outperforms CT in soft-tissue contrast and sensitivity for acute infarction.

Evidence-Based Analysis

MRI is the gold standard for suspected spinal cord infarction. T2‐weighted sequences detect cord edema within hours; diffusion‐weighted imaging (DWI) demonstrates restricted diffusion in acute ischemia. The American College of Radiology Appropriateness Criteria (2019) rates emergent spine MRI “usually appropriate” (rating 8/9) for suspected cord ischemia. AHA/ASA 2018 scientific statement (Class I; Level B) recommends MRI with DWI to confirm diagnosis and rule out mimic conditions. Early MRI guides prognosis and management—identifying lesion level, excluding compressive etiologies, and informing potential interventions (e.g., blood pressure augmentation).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRV (to rule out CVT)
• Targets cerebral venous sinuses, not spinal vasculature.
• Spinal cord venous thrombosis is exceedingly rare; venous imaging yields no data on arterial infarction.
Common misconception: conflating intracranial with spinal vascular evaluation.

C. Lumbar puncture
• May delay definitive imaging; risks exacerbating cord edema or herniation if mass lesion is present.
• CSF in spinal infarction can be normal or show nonspecific mild protein elevation—does not confirm ischemia.
Common misconception: overreliance on CSF to distinguish causes of acute myelopathy.

D. CT scan
• CT myelography or non-contrast CT lacks sensitivity for early cord infarction and fails to detect intraparenchymal changes.
• CT angiography may visualize major vessels but misses small ASA branches and intramedullary pathology.
Common misconception: equating CT’s utility in stroke with spinal cord ischemia.

Comparison Table

ModalityPrimary TargetSensitivity for Acute Spinal InfarctionKey Notes
MRICord parenchyma (T2, DWI)High (>90% within 24 h)Detects edema, diffusion restriction
MRVVenous sinusesN/A for cord ischemiaUsed for cerebral CVT, not spinal
LPCSF analysisLowMay rule out infection/inflammation but not ischemia
CT scanBone, acute hemorrhagePoorMisses intramedullary changes; limited soft-tissue contrast

Clinical Pearls

- In acute myelopathy, always obtain MRI before invasive procedures (e.g., LP) to exclude compressive lesions.
• Diffusion-weighted imaging of the spinal cord can reveal ischemia within hours—look for focal restricted diffusion and “owl’s eyes” sign on axial.
• The artery of Adamkiewicz typically arises between T9–T12; infarcts at this level often present with lumbar motor deficits.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering LP first: delays diagnosis and risks herniation if a compressive lesion exists.
2. Relying on CT: misses early parenchymal changes; CT angiography visualizes large arteries but not intramedullary infarcts.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American College of Radiology Appropriateness Criteria, “Suspected Spinal Cord Ischemia” (2019): Recommends emergent MRI spine with DWI as “usually appropriate” (rating 8/9; Level C evidence).
• AHA/ASA Scientific Statement, Spinal Cord Ischemia (2018): Class I recommendation (Level B) for MRI with DWI to confirm diagnosis and exclude mimics.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The ASA arises from vertebral arteries and segmental radiculomedullary branches (notably the artery of Adamkiewicz). It supplies anterior two-thirds of the cord—motor tracts (corticospinal) and spinothalamic fibers. Posterior columns, supplied by paired posterior spinal arteries, are often spared.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Spinal cord infarction results from ASA occlusion or hypoperfusion. Mechanisms include aortic pathology (dissection, aneurysm repair), thromboembolism, and hypotension. Ischemia leads to cytotoxic edema, axonal injury, and neuronal death within hours.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: acute bilateral motor/pain‐temperature loss with preserved proprioception.
2. Emergent MRI spine (T2, DWI, contrast) to identify ischemia and rule out compressive lesions.
3. Vascular imaging (MR angiography) to assess aortic or radiculomedullary vessels if indicated.
4. Laboratory: exclude vasculitis/coagulopathy once compression is ruled out.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- T2-weighted MRI: hyperintense intramedullary signal within hours.
• DWI: true restricted diffusion in acute infarction (bright on DWI, low ADC).
• Axial “owl’s eyes” pattern: bilateral anterior horn involvement specific for ASA territory infarct.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Spinal cord infarction questions frequently test the urgency and specificity of MRI (vs CT or lumbar puncture) in acute myelopathy, often emphasizing vascular anatomy and imaging sequences.

question_text: A patient with Horner’s syndrome (ptosis, miosis) presents with a thunderclap headache. A CT brain and lumbar puncture were performed within 4 hours and were normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Patients with sudden-onset “thunderclap” headache require rapid evaluation to exclude subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and other vascular emergencies. Horner’s syndrome—ptosis, miosis, and facial anhidrosis—indicates ipsilateral disruption of the oculosympathetic pathway, which ascends in the carotid sheath. Key concepts:
• Anatomy of the sympathetic chain in the neck, accompanying the internal carotid artery (ICA).
• Mechanism of arterial dissection: an intimal tear allows blood to create an intramural hematoma, expanding the vessel wall and compressing adjacent structures.
• Differential diagnosis of thunderclap headache with negative CT and lumbar puncture includes carotid dissection, reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS), and rare vascular pathologies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

ICA dissection classically presents with ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome from compression of the sympathetic fibers in the adventitia. Thunderclap headache occurs acutely when the intimal tear propagates. CT angiography or MR angiography demonstrates a “crescent sign” or double lumen. A normal noncontrast head CT and LP <6 hours rule out SAH; normal LP and CT also make aneurysmal rupture unlikely. RCVS can cause thunderclap headaches but does not produce Horner’s syndrome. Clinical guidelines (AHA/ASA 2019) recommend prompt vascular imaging in suspected cervical dissection. The CADISS trial (Lancet Neurol 2015) supports either antiplatelet or anticoagulation without superiority, underscoring the diagnosis’s importance for management.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Pcom aneurysm rupture
• Rupture causes SAH with xanthochromia or hyperdense blood on CT; presents with oculomotor palsy (blown pupil, not miosis).
• Misconception: any aneurysm rupture = thunderclap headache, but Horner’s points to sympathetic chain involvement.

B. Reversible Cerebral Vasoconstriction Syndrome (RCVS)
• Features recurrent thunderclap headaches over days–weeks; imaging shows segmental vasoconstriction on angiography. Does not produce Horner’s syndrome.
• Misconception: all thunderclap headaches with normal CT/LP are RCVS, but focal neuro signs differentiate.

D. Subarachnoid hemorrhage
• SAH typically shows blood on CT within 6 hours or xanthochromia on LP if delayed; does not cause isolated Horner’s syndrome.
• Misconception: a negative initial CT/LP always excludes dissection, but dissection is non-hemorrhagic.

Comparison Table

FeatureICA DissectionPcom Aneurysm RuptureRCVSSAH
Headache onsetThunderclap (sudden)ThunderclapRecurrent thunderclapThunderclap
Horner’s syndromePresent (sympathetic chain)AbsentAbsentAbsent
CT brainNormalMay show acute SAHNormal earlyHyperdensity in subarachnoid cisterns
LPNormalXanthochromia if CT negativeNormalXanthochromia if CT negative
Angiography“Crescent sign,” double lumenAneurysmal sacSegmental vasoconstrictionNo vascular constriction (unless vasospasm)

Clinical Pearls

• Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome in a thunderclap headache is virtually pathognomonic for cervical carotid dissection.
• MRI with fat-suppressed T1 sequences is highly sensitive for detecting intramural hematoma.
• Early antithrombotic therapy reduces ischemic stroke risk; choice between antiplatelet vs anticoagulant guided by CADISS trial findings.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming a negative noncontrast CT and LP exclude all vascular etiologies—CT angiography is required to evaluate arterial dissection.
2. Misattributing ptosis in headache patients to migraine or eyelid swelling rather than investigating for sympathetic chain disruption.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2019 Scientific Statement on Cervical Artery Dissection:
– Recommendation: Use either antiplatelet or anticoagulant therapy for 3–6 months. (Class IIa; Level of Evidence B)
2. CADISS Trial (Lancet Neurology 2015):
– Randomized comparison of antiplatelet vs anticoagulation in cervical dissection—no difference in stroke recurrence at 3 months, supporting flexibility in antithrombotic choice.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The oculosympathetic pathway ascends from the hypothalamus to the ciliospinal center (C8–T2), then follows the sympathetic chain alongside the ICA in the carotid sheath. Dissection-induced hematoma compresses these fibers, causing ptosis and miosis without extraocular muscle involvement.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Intimal tear in the ICA allows blood to enter the vessel wall, forming a subintimal hematoma. This expands the vessel wall outward, compressing adjacent sympathetic fibers and sometimes reducing lumen diameter, risking thromboembolism.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT → if negative,
2. Lumbar puncture → if no xanthochromia,
3. CT or MR angiography of cervical and intracranial vessels → look for dissection signs (crescent sign/double lumen).
4. Confirm with high-resolution vessel wall MRI if needed.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• “Crescent sign” on T1 fat-suppressed MRI indicates intramural hematoma.
• CT angiography may show tapering (“string sign”) or pseudoaneurysm at dissection site.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Carotid dissection with ipsilateral Horner’s is a classic high-yield scenario, frequently tested in single-best-answer format emphasizing neuroanatomical correlation and diagnostic imaging.

question_text: Q24. A patient underwent carotid endarterectomy due to severe symptomatic stenosis and the next day he deteriorated. A brain CT shows right frontal cortical subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). What is the likely cause?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Cerebral autoregulation maintains consistent blood flow across mean arterial pressures of 60–150 mmHg. Chronic high-grade carotid stenosis induces maximal distal arteriolar dilation and loss of vasoreactive reserve. After carotid endarterectomy (CEA), sudden restoration of normal perfusion pressure can overwhelm these dilated vessels, causing blood–brain barrier breakdown and cortical capillary rupture. The resulting convexity subarachnoid hemorrhage typically appears 24–72 hours post-CEA. Recognizing this timing and the sulcal distribution helps distinguish hyperperfusion syndrome from other intracranial hemorrhages.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Hyperperfusion syndrome complicates 0.2–3% of CEAs and is a leading cause of postoperative cortical SAH (Schoser et al., Neurosurgery 2019). Impaired autoregulatory capacity in chronically underperfused territories means that normalized perfusion pressure leads to endothelial injury and hemorrhage. The AHA/ASA 2021 guidelines on extracranial carotid disease (Class I, Level B) mandate postoperative systolic BP <140 mmHg for at least 48 hours to mitigate hyperperfusion risk. Transcranial Doppler studies detect middle cerebral artery velocities >200 cm/s as an early marker of hyperperfusion. CT findings in hyperperfusion syndrome—isolated convexity sulcal blood—contrast sharply with basal cistern involvement in aneurysmal SAH or parenchymal collections of surgical hematoma.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Rupture of undiagnosed aneurysm
• Aneurysmal SAH classically fills basal cisterns and sylvian fissures; isolated cortical sulcal hemorrhage after CEA with no aneurysm risk history is improbable.
C. Post-operative hematoma
• Surgical bleeding produces intraparenchymal or subdural collections adjacent to the endarterectomy site, not an isolated convexity SAH.
D. Venous sinus thrombosis
• Causes hemorrhagic venous infarcts with edema and infarction patterns on imaging; does not present as pure cortical subarachnoid blood.

Comparison Table

FeatureHyperperfusion SyndromeAneurysmal SAHSurgical HematomaVenous Sinus Thrombosis
Timing post-CEA24–72 hoursUnrelated to CEA timingImmediate post-opVariable (days–weeks)
CT distributionConvexity sulcal SAHBasal cisterns, sylvian fissuresParenchymal/subdural bleedHemorrhagic infarcts, edema
MechanismImpaired autoregulation, BBB breakdownVessel wall ruptureSurgical vessel injuryVenous outflow obstruction
Key risk factorsHigh-grade stenosis, HTN, contralateral occlusionHypertension, smoking, aneurysmTechnical error, coagulopathyThrombophilia, dehydration

Clinical Pearls

1. Peak onset of hyperperfusion syndrome is 1–3 days post-CEA; maintain systolic BP <140 mmHg to prevent.
2. Transcranial Doppler monitoring of MCA flow velocities (>200 cm/s) can predict hyperperfusion before hemorrhage.
3. Convexity SAH in postoperative CEA patients is virtually diagnostic of hyperperfusion syndrome when aneurysm is excluded.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming any postoperative intracranial bleed is due to anticoagulation or technical error, rather than impaired autoregulation.
2. Misinterpreting basal cistern SAH as hyperperfusion hemorrhage—location and vessel territory guide differentiation.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2021 Guidelines on Extracranial Carotid and Vertebral Artery Disease: Recommend strict BP control (systolic <140 mmHg) for 48–72 hours post-CEA to prevent hyperperfusion (Class I, Level B).
• ESVS 2023 Clinical Practice Guidelines: Advocate routine transcranial Doppler surveillance and perioperative hemodynamic management to reduce hyperperfusion syndrome risk (Grade A).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic carotid stenosis leads to maximal arteriolar dilation and loss of vasodilatory reserve. Post-CEA, sudden normalization of luminal diameter and pressure causes capillary stress failure, endothelial disruption, and extravasation of blood into the subarachnoid space over cerebral convexities.

Neuroimaging Pearls

CT shows isolated cortical sulcal hyperdensities without basal cistern or deep parenchymal involvement—distinct from aneurysmal or traumatic patterns. MR perfusion can detect regional cerebral blood flow surges (>150% baseline) preemptively.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Carotid endarterectomy complications, especially hyperperfusion syndrome manifesting as convexity SAH, are frequently tested in vascular neurology and neurosurgery sections.

question_text: In a patient post motor vehicle accident (MVA) presenting with symptoms of lateral medullary syndrome, what is the likely mechanism of stroke?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome results from infarction of the dorsolateral medulla supplied by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), a branch of the vertebral artery. Trauma, such as an MVA, can cause an intimal tear in the vertebral artery leading to dissection, intramural hematoma, and subsequent thrombosis with vessel occlusion. Key concepts:
• Anatomy: PICA arises from vertebral artery; infarction affects nucleus ambiguus, spinothalamic tract, vestibular nuclei.
• Pathophysiology: Dissection-induced thrombosis differs from embolic occlusion (cardiac or artery-to-artery) and from small vessel (lacunar) disease.
• Clinical correlation: Trauma history raises suspicion for cervical artery dissection leading to thrombosis.

(Word count: 113)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Vertebral artery dissection with resultant thrombosis is the most common mechanism of lateral medullary infarction after cervical trauma. Dissection creates an intimal flap and intramural hematoma, promoting local thrombus formation and occlusion of PICA origin (Schievink WI, Lancet Neurol 2006). The 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Class I; Level B) recommend vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) in suspected cervical dissections. MRI-DWI localizes the medullary lesion, while CTA reveals vessel wall abnormalities and “string sign.” Large-vessel thrombosis explains the sudden onset of brainstem deficits in trauma patients, distinguishing it from gradual-onset lacunar strokes or episodic emboli.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Artery-to-artery thrombus
• Incorrect because this implies thrombosis at one atherosclerotic plaque lodging distally; post-traumatic dissections cause local thrombosis, not plaque rupture.
• Misconception: equating any thromboembolism with trauma-induced stroke.
• Differentiator: artery-to-artery emboli typically originate from carotid atheroma, not vertebral dissection.

C. Embolic stroke
• Incorrect: cardioembolic strokes arise from atrial fibrillation or ventricular thrombus; no arrhythmia or cardiac source here.
• Misconception: assuming all brainstem strokes are embolic.
• Differentiator: imaging in embolism often shows multiple territorial infarcts, not isolated PICA territory.

D. Lacunar infarct
• Incorrect: lacunes are <15 mm, due to lipohyalinosis in small penetrating arteries; they spare dorsolateral medulla.
• Misconception: confusing any brainstem infarct with lacunar syndrome.
• Differentiator: lacunar strokes present with pure motor/sensory deficits without cranial nerve involvement seen in Wallenberg.

Comparison Table

FeatureVertebral Artery ThrombosisArtery-to-Artery ThrombusEmbolic StrokeLacunar Infarct
Typical CauseDissection after traumaAtherosclerotic plaque in carotidCardiac source (AF, LV thrombus)Small vessel lipohyalinosis
Vessel SizeLarge vessel (vertebral/PICA)Large/medium arteryLarge artery occlusionSmall penetrating arteriole
Infarct LocationLateral medulla (PICA territory)Variable distal territoriesMultiple cortical or subcorticalDeep structures (basal ganglia)
ImagingCTA: intimal flap, occlusionCTA: plaque with distal filling defectMRI/MRA: wedge‐shaped infarctsDWI: small (<15 mm) lacune
Clinical ContextRecent neck traumaVascular risk factors, carotid bruitCardiac history, AF on ECGHypertension, diabetes, insidious

Clinical Pearls

• Always perform CTA/MRA in Wallenberg syndrome post-trauma to rule out vertebral dissection.
• Vertebral artery dissections may present with neck pain or headache before neurological signs.
• Antithrombotic therapy (antiplatelet vs anticoagulation) for cervical dissection is chosen based on bleeding risk; CADISS trial showed similar outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling lateral medullary syndrome as lacunar infarct due to small lesion size; lacunes do not involve cranial nerves.
2. Assuming any brainstem stroke is cardioembolic without correlating with clinical context or vascular imaging.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2019 Update on Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke:
– Recommendation: CTA/MRA for suspected cervical dissection (Class I; Level B).
2. Cervical Artery Dissection in Stroke Study (CADISS), Lancet Neurol 2015:
– Compared anticoagulation vs antiplatelet therapy in cervical dissection; no significant difference in stroke recurrence at 3 months.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lateral medullary infarction involves PICA territory affecting: nucleus ambiguus (dysphagia, hoarseness), spinal trigeminal nucleus (ipsilateral facial pain/temp loss), spinothalamic tract (contralateral body pain/temp loss), inferior cerebellar peduncle (ataxia), and sympathetic fibers (Horner syndrome).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Traumatic neck hyperextension/flexion causes an intimal tear in the vertebral artery, leading to intramural hematoma, luminal narrowing, platelet aggregation, and thrombus formation, which occludes the PICA origin and causes lateral medullary ischemia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: Wallenberg signs + trauma history
2. MRI brain with DWI to confirm dorsolateral medullary infarction
3. CTA or MRA of cervical vessels to detect dissection/thrombosis
4. Initiate antithrombotic therapy and neurosurgical/endovascular consult if needed

Neuroimaging Pearls

• CTA “string sign” or double‐lumen indicates dissection.
• MRI T1‐weighted fat-suppressed sequences may show intramural hematoma.
• DWI reliably localizes acute infarct in PICA territory.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Antiplatelet therapy (aspirin 81–325 mg daily) preferred in low-bleeding-risk dissections.
• Anticoagulation (e.g., heparin to warfarin) considered if high-risk features; guided by CADISS trial.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam.
Traumatic vertebral artery dissection causing PICA thrombosis in lateral medullary syndrome is a high-yield topic tested in both single-best-answer and clinical vignette formats on neurology boards.

question_text: Q40. Which of the following is a common neurologic deficit associated with AICA (Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery) infarction?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] The anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) arises from the basilar artery and supplies the lateral pons, flocculus, middle cerebellar peduncle and inner ear via the labyrinthine artery. Key concepts:
• Vascular territories: AICA vs PICA (posterior inferior cerebellar artery) vs SCA (superior cerebellar artery).
• Cranial nerve involvement: AICA infarcts often injure the facial (VII) and vestibulocochlear (VIII) nerve nuclei or their fibers.
• Labyrinthine artery: an end‐artery branch of AICA, responsible for cochlear perfusion; occlusion causes ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Unilateral sensorineural hearing loss in AICA infarction is due to ischemia of the labyrinthine artery. AHA/ASA 2018 Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines (Class IIa, Level B-NR) note that 30–60% of AICA strokes present with auditory symptoms. In a multicenter cohort (Kumral et al., Stroke 2015), 42% of patients with lateral pontine infarcts had hearing loss, whereas PICA strokes almost never affect the cochlea. DWI-MRI is the gold standard for detecting small pontine infarcts; audiometry confirms cochlear involvement. The specificity of hearing loss for AICA territory localization exceeds 85% (Smith and Jones, J Neurol Sci 2021).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Headache
• Nonspecific prodrome in any stroke subtype; lacks localizing value.
• Misconception: “All strokes present with headache”—many are painless.
B. Unilateral hearing loss [CORRECT]
C. Nausea/vomiting
• Common in cerebellar lesions (e.g., PICA) but not specific to AICA.
• Reflects vestibular‐cerebellar axis involvement rather than cochlear ischemia.
D. Vertigo
• Occurs in both AICA and PICA infarcts and in peripheral vestibulopathies; not unique.
• Key differentiator: hearing loss is present only when the labyrinthine artery (AICA branch) is involved.

Comparison Table

FeatureAICA InfarctPICA Infarct (Lateral Medullary)
Ipsilateral hearing lossPresent (labyrinthine artery occlusion)Absent
Facial paralysis (VII)Often presentAbsent
Nausea/vomitingOccasional (cerebellar peduncle)Common (vestibular nuclei)
VertigoCan occurCan occur
Spinothalamic pain/temp lossContralateral body, ipsilateral faceContralateral body, ipsilateral face

Clinical Pearls

- “Facial droop means AICA’s pooped”– facial paralysis plus hearing loss localizes to AICA.
• Always assess hearing in posterior circulation strokes; bedside audiometry can be rapid.
• Distinguish AICA from PICA by presence of cochlear signs: hearing loss favors AICA.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming vertigo alone indicates peripheral vestibulopathy—check hearing to avoid misdiagnosis.
2. Overreliance on non‐contrast head CT, which often misses small pontine infarcts; MRI DWI is essential.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guidelines on Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (2018):
– Recommendation IIa, Level B-NR: Use MRI DWI for suspected posterior fossa infarcts; include audiometric evaluation if AICA infarct suspected.
2. European Stroke Organisation Guidelines (2019):
– Level B evidence: In lateral pontine infarcts, perform vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) of the AICA territory to guide reperfusion strategies.
3. Kumral et al., Stroke (2015): Multicenter retrospective cohort showing 42% incidence of hearing loss in AICA strokes versus <5% in other posterior strokes.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The AICA supplies:
• Lateral pons (facial nucleus, spinal trigeminal nucleus)
• Middle cerebellar peduncle (ataxia)
• Flocculus (gaze stabilization)
• Labyrinthine artery branch to inner ear (cochlea and vestibular apparatus)

Pathophysiology Breakdown

AICA occlusion → ischemia of lateral pons and cochlea → cytotoxic edema in cranial nerve nuclei (VII, VIII) → sensorineural hearing loss + facial weakness + ataxia

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical triad: facial paralysis, hearing loss, ataxia/vertigo
2. Urgent non‐contrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage
3. MRI DWI of posterior fossa for infarct confirmation
4. CTA/MRA to visualize AICA patency
5. Bedside audiometry to quantify hearing loss

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Small lateral pontine infarcts may be occult on CT; DWI-MRI within 24 h yields >95% sensitivity.
• Labyrinthine infarcts appear as hyperintense signal in the internal auditory canal on high-resolution T2.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- IV alteplase within 4.5 h if no contraindications; mechanical thrombectomy not routinely indicated for AICA.
• Antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) for secondary prevention per AHA/ASA (2018) guidelines.
• Statin therapy to achieve LDL <70 mg/dL.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Posterior circulation stroke localization is frequently tested via cranial nerve findings and vascular anatomy; hearing loss as a discriminator for AICA vs PICA infarcts is a high-yield concept on neurology board exams.

question_text: In a case of subacute stroke with a CT brain showing no abnormalities, a normal transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE), and a normal 48-hour Holter monitor, what is the next best step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] - Cryptogenic stroke: defined as ischemic stroke without identified source after standard evaluation (CT/MRI, vascular imaging, echocardiography, 24–48 h ECG).
• Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (AF) often asymptomatic, intermittent, and missed on short‐term monitoring.
• Extended cardiac monitoring (external event recorder or implantable loop recorder) increases detection of occult AF and guides anticoagulation for secondary prevention.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Prolonged cardiac monitoring is the correct next step because multiple trials demonstrate its superior yield for detecting occult AF in cryptogenic stroke:

• The EMBRACE trial (Hart et al., 2015) randomized 572 patients to 30-day external event recording vs 24-h Holter; AF detection was 16.1% vs 3.2% (p < 0.001).
• The CRYSTAL-AF trial (Sanna et al., 2014) compared implantable loop recorders (ILR) vs standard care; detection at 12 months was 12.4% vs 2.0% (HR 7.3; 95% CI 2.6–20.8).
• 2019 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines give a Class I, Level A recommendation for extended (≥30 days) ECG monitoring in patients with cryptogenic stroke to detect AF.

Detecting AF directs initiation of oral anticoagulation, which reduces recurrent stroke risk by approximately 60% versus antiplatelet therapy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Carotid ultrasound
• Incorrect: While carotid duplex is part of initial stroke evaluation, in cryptogenic stroke after normal neurovascular and cardiac studies, its incremental yield for an embolic source is low. Unlike prolonged ECG, it will not uncover intermittent AF.
• Misconception: Assuming extracranial stenosis is most common embolic source in all stroke subtypes.

C. Coagulation workup
• Incorrect: A hypercoagulable panel is indicated in young patients (<50 years) or those with suggestive history (recurrent thromboembolism, miscarriages). In typical cryptogenic stroke without these features, low pretest probability makes extensive coagulation studies low yield.
• Misconception: Performing broad thrombophilia testing without clinical context.

D. Brain MRI
• Incorrect: MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging is more sensitive than CT for acute infarcts, but in a subacute window it confirms lesion but does not change immediate secondary prevention strategy. The key gap is detecting occult AF, not lesion visualization.
• Misconception: Equating diagnostic imaging of lesion with identifying the etiology that guides therapy.

Comparison Table

FeatureProlonged MonitoringCarotid UltrasoundCoagulation WorkupBrain MRI
PurposeDetect paroxysmal AFAssess extracranial stenosisIdentify hypercoagulable stateVisualize infarct anatomy
Diagnostic yield (cryptogenic)12–16% for AF over ≥30 days–12 months<5% significant stenosis<5% positive in absence of riskConfirms infarct but not etiology
Impact on managementAnticoagulation if AF foundCarotid endarterectomy if ≥70%Rarely alters acute therapyMay guide rehabilitation planning
EvidenceEMBRACE, CRYSTAL-AF, AHA/ASA 2019NASCET, ECST trialsExpert opinionAHA/ASA imaging guidelines

Clinical Pearls

- In cryptogenic stroke, AF is most often discovered after 48 h; consider ≥30 days external monitor or ILR.
• An ILR offers long-term (up to 3 years) monitoring with higher patient compliance.
• Early detection of AF enables timely anticoagulation, reducing recurrent stroke risk by >60%.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming a normal 24–48 h Holter excludes AF forever.
2. Ordering hypercoagulable panels in older patients without risk factors—leads to false positives and unnecessary anticoagulation.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2019 Secondary Stroke Prevention (Guideline): Class I, Level A recommendation for extended (≥30 days) ECG monitoring in cryptogenic stroke to detect AF.
• European Stroke Organisation 2021 Position Paper: Recommends ILR implantation in ESUS (Embolic Stroke of Undetermined Source) patients younger than 60 years or without contraindications.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam.
Secondary prevention of cryptogenic stroke with prolonged rhythm monitoring is frequently tested, often in scenarios with normal initial ECG/TTE and non‐revealing vascular imaging.

question_text: Q9. A patient presented with hemianopia and alexia without agraphia. What is the likely location of the lesion?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] Pure alexia (“alexia without agraphia”) is characterized by loss of reading with preserved writing. Core concepts:
• Visual pathways: a lesion in the dominant occipital cortex causes contralateral homonymous hemianopia.
• Callosal transfer: involvement of the splenium of the corpus callosum prevents right‐hemisphere visual information from reaching left‐hemisphere language areas.
• Reading vs. writing dissociation: writing remains intact because language production areas (including angular and supramarginal gyri) are spared.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The classic syndrome of homonymous hemianopia plus pure alexia stems from an infarct in the dominant occipital lobe extending into the splenium of the corpus callosum (PCA territory). Dejerine first described this in 1892: destruction of left visual cortex severs input to Wernicke’s area, intact writing reflects preserved language output pathways. Modern diffusion‐weighted MRI correlates confirm that lesions isolated to the left occipital pole and splenium reliably produce this dissociation (Plantón et al., Brain, 2019). Guidelines (AHA/ASA 2018) recognize alexia without agraphia as a cortical sign of PCA infarction, warranting urgent imaging (Class I; Level B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Infra sylvan temporal
• Lesion here (fusiform gyrus) produces visual object agnosia or prosopagnosia, not isolated reading deficits plus hemianopia.
• Misconception: equating any visual association cortex with pure alexia.

B. Supra sylvan frontal
• Frontal lobe lesions cause motor deficits, executive dysfunction or transcortical motor aphasia; do not produce homonymous hemianopia or pure alexia.
• Differentiator: no primary visual field loss.

C. Angular
• Angular gyrus lesions classically produce alexia with agraphia and Gerstmann syndrome. Reading and writing are both impaired, without a homonymous field cut.
• Misconception: assuming lateral parietal damage alone causes pure alexia.

Comparison Table

FeatureOccipital lobe + splenium (Correct)Angular gyrusInfra-Sylvian temporalSupra-Sylvian frontal
Visual field deficitContralateral homonymous hemianopiaTypically noneRarely; may have visual agnosiaNone
Reading (alexia)Present (without agraphia)Present (with agraphia)Possible object agnosia, not pure alexiaAbsent
Writing (agraphia)AbsentPresentAbsentAbsent
MechanismDisconnection of visual input to language areasDirect language association cortex damageAssociation cortex damageFrontal language output disruption

Clinical Pearls

• Always perform formal visual field testing in patients with new reading deficits.
• Finger‐spelling therapy and cross‐modal reading strategies can aid recovery in pure alexia.
• The “letter by letter” reading pattern is pathognomonic for pure alexia.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing pure alexia with Wernicke’s aphasia (patients with Wernicke’s can’t comprehend written language but also have auditory comprehension deficits).
2. Attributing reading loss to occipito-temporal prosopagnosia syndromes rather than callosal disconnection.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke:
– Recommendation: Recognize cortical signs (e.g., pure alexia) as indicators of posterior cerebral artery involvement; urgent neuroimaging with MRI-DWI is Class I, Level of Evidence B.
2. European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 Guidelines on Stroke Rehabilitation:
– Recommendation: Initiate targeted reading rehabilitation programs for pure alexia patients within 2 weeks post‐stroke (Level B evidence based on small RCTs).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

• Lesion in left occipital pole damages primary visual cortex (BA 17), causing right homonymous hemianopia.
• Extension into splenium interrupts interhemispheric transfer of visual information to the language‐dominant hemisphere (BA 39, angular gyrus).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PCA infarction leads to ischemic necrosis of cortical gray matter in the occipital lobe and adjacent splenial fibers. The visual signal from the contralateral field cannot traverse to language centers, yet written language motor output pathways remain intact.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical evaluation: assess reading and writing separately.
2. Formal perimetry to document homonymous hemianopia.
3. MRI with DWI and FLAIR to localize occipital and splenial infarct.
4. Rule out alternative causes (tumor, demyelination) if imaging atypical.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• DWI will show restricted diffusion in the medial occipital cortex and splenium.
• CT may miss early infarcts in the splenium; MRI is preferred.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2024 exam. Lesion localization questions combining visual field deficits with language dissociations are frequently tested in single-best-answer format.

question_text: A case scenario of a post-RTA patient presents with brain stem symptoms and findings. What is the most likely mechanism of injury?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] 1. Posterior circulation anatomy: The vertebral arteries ascend through the cervical transverse foramina and form the basilar artery, supplying the brainstem via perforators (PICA, AICA, pontine arteries).
2. Dissection pathophysiology: Trauma-induced intimal tear allows blood to enter the vessel wall, forming an intramural hematoma that narrows the lumen, promotes thrombus formation, and leads to distal embolism or occlusion.
3. Clinical presentation: Brainstem infarcts manifest as dysphagia, dysarthria, ipsilateral facial numbness, contralateral body pain/temperature loss—features of lateral medullary or pontine syndromes.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Traumatic vertebral artery dissection (VAD) is a well-recognized cause of posterior circulation stroke after road traffic accidents. Biffl et al. (J Trauma 2002) found 0.5–2% incidence of VAD in blunt cervical trauma with 30–50% leading to infarction. Hyperextension–rotation injuries tear the intima, creating an intramural hematoma and thrombus that embolizes to brainstem perforators. CT angiography has >90% sensitivity for VAD (Biousse et al., Neurology 1998). The 2019 AHA/ASA stroke guidelines (Class I, Level B) recommend antithrombotic therapy for extracranial cervical dissections to prevent secondary stroke. The focal onset (hours–days post-injury), characteristic lateral brainstem signs, and vascular imaging findings confirm dissection as the etiology.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Cardioembolic
• Lacks cardiac source (e.g., atrial fibrillation) in trauma context.
• Cardioembolic strokes typically involve multiple vascular territories and cortical signs, unlike isolated brainstem involvement here.

C. Direct traumatic brainstem contusion
• Would present immediately post-injury with hemorrhagic lesions on head CT and altered consciousness.
• Contusions produce parenchymal bleeding rather than delayed focal ischemia.

D. Hypoxic-ischemic injury
• Systemic hypoxia causes diffuse cortical and deep gray matter damage, not localized brainstem infarct.
• MRI diffusion-weighted imaging would show bilateral symmetric changes, not focal lateral medullary lesions.

Comparison Table

FeatureArtery-to-Artery Dissection (VAD)CardioembolicDirect ContusionHypoxic-Ischemic Injury
MechanismIntimal tear → intramural hematoma → thromboembolismCardiac source embolusShear injury → hemorrhagic parenchymal lesionGlobal hypoperfusion
Clinical contextRTA with neck hyperextension/rotationAtrial fibrillation, valvular diseaseSevere blunt head traumaCardiac arrest, respiratory failure
OnsetHours to days post traumaSuddenImmediateMinutes to hours
ImagingCTA/MRA: vessel irregularity, double lumenMRI DWI: cortical infarctsCT: hyperdense hemorrhagesDWI: bilateral cortical, basal ganglia

Clinical Pearls

1. In any blunt cervical trauma with focal brainstem signs, obtain cervical vessel imaging (CTA/MRA) even if head CT is normal.
2. Fat-suppressed T1 MRI can detect intramural hematoma in VAD before luminal changes appear.
3. The CADISS trial (Lancet Neurol 2015) found no significant difference between antiplatelet and anticoagulation for cervical dissection, allowing individualized treatment.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overlooking VAD because initial head CT is normal.
2. Misattributing new focal deficits to cerebral edema or concussion rather than vascular injury.
3. Confusing lateral medullary syndrome with direct cerebellar injury in trauma.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines for Early Management of Ischemic Stroke: Class I, Level B—initiate antithrombotic therapy (antiplatelet or anticoagulation) in extracranial cervical artery dissection.
• CADISS Trial (Lancet Neurol 2015): Randomized comparison of antiplatelet vs. anticoagulation for cervical artery dissection; no significant difference in recurrent stroke at 3 months (Level IB evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Vertebral arteries supply lateral medullary region via PICA branches; occlusion produces Wallenberg syndrome (nucleus ambiguus, spinothalamic, vestibular nuclei involvement).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Hyperextension–rotation trauma causes an intimal tear; blood tracks into the media forming an intramural hematoma, leading to vessel narrowing, thrombus formation, and distal embolic infarction.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect VAD with neck trauma + focal posterior signs.
2. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
3. CTA/MRA of neck to identify dissection.
4. MRI DWI to confirm acute infarction.

Neuroimaging Pearls

CTA shows “string sign,” intimal flap, pseudoaneurysm; T1 fat-sat MRI highlights intramural hematoma.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Start aspirin 75–100 mg daily; consider anticoagulation (e.g., LMWH → warfarin) for high-grade stenosis or expanding pseudoaneurysm, balancing hemorrhage risk.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Vertebral artery dissection after blunt cervical trauma is a frequently tested etiology of posterior circulation stroke, often requiring integration of clinical context and vascular imaging.

question_text: A young female postpartum presents with headache associated with new onset generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Her exam shows bilateral papilledema, and a CT was unremarkable. What is the best next step?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) occurs when a thrombus occludes dural sinuses or cortical veins, leading to impaired venous drainage, elevated intracranial pressure (ICP), and venous infarcts. Postpartum women are at high risk due to hypercoagulability (elevated fibrinogen, platelet activation). Key signs—headache, papilledema, seizures—reflect raised ICP rather than primary parenchymal disease. Noncontrast CT is normal in ~30% of CVT cases. CT venography (CTV) rapidly visualizes filling defects in dural sinuses and is widely available. Recognize “empty delta sign” on CTV. Understanding Virchow’s triad, venous sinus anatomy, and imaging sensitivities underpins accurate, timely diagnosis in high-risk settings. (Approx. 120 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

CT venogram is the gold-standard initial test for suspected CVT when noncontrast CT is inconclusive. The 2017 European Stroke Organization guideline recommends urgent CT or MR venography (Grade 1C) to confirm sinus thrombosis. In the International Study on Cerebral Vein and Dural Sinus Thrombosis (ISCVT; n=624), CTV demonstrated sensitivity >95% and specificity >90% for major sinus occlusions. Compared to MRI brain alone, CTV has shorter acquisition times, wider availability in acute settings, and fewer contraindications. Lumbar puncture, while diagnostic in some intracranial hypertension syndromes, risks herniation in CVT with elevated ICP and provides no direct visualization of venous occlusion. Acetazolamide targets CSF production but does not address thrombosis. Plain MRI fails to delineate venous flow alterations without dedicated venography sequences.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Lumbar puncture
• Incorrect: Invasive, risk of cerebral herniation in raised ICP from CVT.
• Misconception: Believing CSF opening pressure confirms diagnosis; LP cannot visualize sinus occlusion.
• Differentiator: Imaging venous anatomy is required before altering CSF volume.

C. Acetazolamide
• Incorrect: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor reduces CSF production in idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), not CVT.
• Misconception: Equating all papilledema headaches to IIH.
• Differentiator: CVT management centers on anticoagulation, not diuresis.

D. MRI of the brain
• Incorrect: Non-contrast MRI identifies parenchymal lesions but misses venous flow; dedicated MR venography (MRV) is needed.
• Misconception: Assuming MRI brain is comprehensive for all intracranial pathologies.
• Differentiator: Venous imaging sequence (CTV/MRV) is essential for CVT.

Comparison Table

FeatureCT Venogram (Correct)Lumbar PunctureAcetazolamideMRI Brain (Plain)
Primary purposeVisualize dural sinuses, detect thrombusMeasure CSF pressure, sample CSFReduce CSF productionEvaluate parenchymal lesions
Sensitivity for CVT>95%N/A0% for thrombosis~60% without MRV
ContraindicationsIodine allergy, renal failureElevated ICP, coagulopathySulfa allergyClaustrophobia, pacemaker
Time to perform<10 minutes30+ minutesN/A30–60 minutes
Risk in elevated ICPLow (non-invasive)High (herniation)LowLow

Clinical Pearls

- Postpartum CVT often presents with isolated headache before neurological deficits; maintain high suspicion.
• Noncontrast CT may miss CVT in up to one-third of cases; proceed to venography if clinical suspicion is high.
• Early anticoagulation (even with hemorrhagic infarction) improves outcomes; don’t delay treatment pending MRI.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering lumbar puncture first in papilledema without imaging can precipitate brain herniation.
2. Mistaking CVT for idiopathic intracranial hypertension and initiating acetazolamide without confirming venous patency.
3. Believing a normal noncontrast MRI rules out CVT; venography sequences are mandatory.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2011 Scientific Statement on CVT: Recommends prompt CT or MR venography for suspected CVT and anticoagulation with heparin regardless of hemorrhage (Class I, Level B).
• European Stroke Organization 2017 Guidelines: Advocate urgent CTV/MRV to confirm diagnosis (Grade 1C) and highlight safety of anticoagulation in acute CVT.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Thrombosis commonly involves the superior sagittal sinus and transverse sinuses, impairing cortical venous outflow. Elevated venous pressure reduces CSF absorption at arachnoid granulations, leading to papilledema.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Postpartum hypercoagulability (elevated clotting factors, reduced anticoagulants) plus venous stasis and endothelial injury (Virchow’s triad) trigger sinus thrombosis. Reduced drainage raises ICP, precipitating headache and seizures.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: headache + seizure + papilledema in high-risk patient
2. Noncontrast CT to exclude hemorrhage or mass
3. If CT negative or equivocal → CT venogram (or MR venogram)
4. Confirm CVT → initiate anticoagulation, evaluate prothrombotic workup

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Empty delta sign on contrast CTV indicates superior sagittal sinus thrombosis.
• Cortical vein hyperintensity on T1 MRI suggests subacute clot; T2*/SWI may reveal blooming.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Initial low-molecular-weight heparin transitioning to warfarin (target INR 2.0–3.0) for 3–12 months is standard. Direct oral anticoagulants (e.g., apixaban) show promise in recent trials but await guideline endorsement.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. CVT is frequently tested in scenarios of headache with papilledema, especially postpartum; students must distinguish imaging modalities and contraindications to lumbar puncture.

question_text: A patient with an acute stroke has a CT image with no established stroke ASPECT score of 8. After being treated with tPA, the patient vomits and becomes lethargic with a blood pressure of 180/110. What should be done next?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] Acute ischemic stroke may be treated with intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) within 4.5 hours of onset. The Alberta Stroke Program Early CT Score (ASPECTS) quantifies early ischemic changes; an ASPECTS ≥8 implies limited core infarct and lower hemorrhage risk. Post-tPA, sudden neurologic deterioration—especially vomiting, lethargy, or headache—raises suspicion for symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage (sICH). Emergent noncontrast head CT is the gold standard to distinguish hemorrhagic transformation from progression of ischemia or cerebral edema. Blood pressure control and reversal agents follow imaging confirmation. Immediate imaging prevents delay in life‐saving interventions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines state that any neurologic worsening after tPA mandates immediate discontinuation of infusion (if ongoing) and an emergent noncontrast CT to assess for sICH (Class I, Level C). Rapid identification via CT enables prompt reversal with cryoprecipitate and FFP as per stroke protocols. Lowering blood pressure below 180/105 mm Hg is advised after hemorrhage confirmation. Skipping CT and focusing solely on BP or continued observation delays definitive diagnosis and management, worsening outcomes (Hacke et al., 2008; Demchuk et al., 2012).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Decrease blood pressure
• Incorrect because the priority is diagnostic imaging; empiric BP lowering without knowing hemorrhagic status may reduce perfusion in ischemic penumbra.
• Misconception: all post-tPA hypertensive readings require immediate reduction.
• Differentiator: BP control is secondary, post‐CT confirmation of bleed.

B. Stop tPA
• If the infusion is already complete, there is nothing to stop.
• Misconception: “stop everything” is the next step; in reality, confirm hemorrhage first.
• Differentiator: diagnostic confirmation precedes hemostatic interventions.

D. Monitor neurologic status closely
• Passive monitoring alone fails to address potential sICH.
• Misconception: observation is sufficient for mild declines.
• Differentiator: clinical decline post-tPA mandates imaging, not watchful waiting.

Comparison Table

InterventionRoleTimingPriority
Noncontrast CT scanDiagnose sICH vs. ischemic progressionImmediateHighest
Blood pressure loweringPrevent expansion of hemorrhageAfter bleed confirmationSecondary
Stop tPA infusionHalt further fibrinolysisIf infusion still runningConcurrent with CT order
Close neurologic monitoringTrack clinical changesContinuousSupportive, not definitive

Clinical Pearls

- Vomiting and rapid mental status change are classic red flags for hemorrhagic transformation.
• ASPECTS ≥8 lowers but does not eliminate hemorrhage risk; vigilance remains crucial.
• Cryoprecipitate is the first-line reversal agent for tPA-related bleeding.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Waiting to image until after blood pressure is normalized, delaying diagnosis.
• Believing that cessation of tPA infusion alone suffices without imaging.
• Underestimating the significance of IV hypertension in the post-thrombolysis period.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (2018): “Suspected sICH after tPA requires immediate noncontrast CT” (Class I, Level C).
2. European Stroke Organisation (ESO) Guidelines (2021): “In case of symptomatic hemorrhagic transformation, administer cryoprecipitate 10 units plus FFP and target BP <140/90 mm Hg post-confirmation” (Level B).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemic brain tissue is vulnerable to reperfusion injury; tPA–induced fibrinolysis can disrupt the blood–brain barrier, leading to vessel leakage and parenchymal hemorrhage, typically within 24 hours of administration.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Noncontrast CT shows hyperdense “blush” or frank hematoma in sICH.
• Early CT signs of ischemia (loss of gray–white differentiation) do not reliably predict hemorrhagic transformation.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- tPA has a two-phase half-life (bolus ~5 min, infusion ~40 min); reversal requires fibrinogen replacement (cryoprecipitate) rather than protamine or vitamin K.
• Maintain post-tPA BP <180/105 mm Hg to reduce hemorrhage risk.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2019 exam. Hemorrhagic transformation after thrombolysis is frequently tested in clinical vignettes requiring urgent CT and management steps. Physicians must recognize red-flag symptoms (vomiting, altered mental status) and apply guideline-driven imaging protocols.

question_text: A brain CT shows right SCA territory infarction at the level of the midbrain. Which artery is affected?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] - The superior cerebellar artery (SCA) arises from the basilar artery at the pontomesencephalic junction and supplies the superior cerebellar hemisphere, dentate nucleus, superior cerebellar peduncle, and parts of the dorsolateral midbrain.
• Computed tomography localizes infarcts by axial level—lesions at the midbrain level in the superior cerebellar region implicate the SCA territory.
• Differentiating SCA from anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) and posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) infarcts relies on anatomical landmarks: AICA lesions localize to the lateral pons, PICA to the lateral medulla.

Evidence-Based Analysis

SCA infarctions classically produce hypoattenuation on noncontrast CT in the superior cerebellar hemisphere adjacent to the midbrain. The 2018 AHA/ASA Acute Stroke Guidelines recommend noncontrast CT within 20 minutes of arrival and CTA/MRA for vessel mapping to confirm SCA occlusion (Class I, Level A). Anatomical dissection studies (Kawashima et al., Stroke 2015) demonstrate penetrating SCA branches supply the superior cerebellar peduncle and dorsal midbrain, correlating with imaging at this axial level. Prompt identification guides management of cerebellar edema risk; up to 60% of large SCA infarcts develop secondary hydrocephalus (Hong et al., J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2017).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. AICA
• Incorrect because AICA arises lower on the basilar artery and supplies the lateral pons, flocculus, and labyrinthine structures.
• Common misconception: conflating lateral pontine signs (facial paralysis, hearing loss) with cerebellar hemisphere infarction.
• Key differentiator: AICA infarcts on CT appear at the level of the pons, not the midbrain.

C. PICA
• Incorrect because PICA branches from the vertebral artery to supply the lateral medulla and inferior cerebellum.
• Misconception: any posterior fossa infarct equals PICA; in reality, PICA infarcts cause Wallenberg syndrome (dysphagia, vertigo).
• Key differentiator: PICA lesions localize to the medullary level on imaging.

D. Basilar Artery
• Incorrect because the basilar artery supplies mainly ventral pons via paramedian branches.
• Misconception: large‐vessel stroke in posterior circulation is always basilar occlusion.
• Key differentiator: basilar infarcts produce ventral pontine changes and “locked‐in” features, not isolated superior cerebellar deficits.

Comparison Table

FeatureSCAAICAPICABasilar Artery
OriginBasilar at pontomesencephalic jct.Basilar lower ponsVertebral arteryUnion of vertebrals
Main supplySuperior cerebellum, midbrainLateral pons, flocculus, inner earLateral medulla, inferior cerebellumVentral pons
Typical CT levelMidbrain/cerebellar pedunclePonsMedullaPons
Clinical syndromeIpsilateral ataxia, dysmetriaFacial paralysis, hearing lossDysphagia, hoarseness (Wallenberg)Quadriplegia, “locked‐in” syndrome

Clinical Pearls

- SCA infarcts may lead to life‐threatening cerebellar edema; monitor for hydrocephalus and consider suboccipital decompression if indicated.
• Early vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) per 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines confirms SCA occlusion and aids in planning endovascular or surgical interventions.
• Superior cerebellar peduncle involvement can manifest as contralateral Holmes tremor days to weeks post‐infarct due to dentatorubrothalamic tract disruption.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Over‐reliance on clinical signs alone: cerebellar ataxia appears in all three cerebellar artery infarcts—imaging level is critical.
2. Assuming basilar artery lesions always present with crossed brainstem signs; small SCA occlusions spare cranial nerves III–XII but still produce midbrain‐level findings.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommend noncontrast CT within 20 minutes and CTA/MRA for suspected posterior circulation occlusion (Class I, Level A).
2. ESO 2021 Guidelines on Posterior Circulation Stroke: Endorse diffusion‐weighted MRI for accurate localization of brainstem and cerebellar infarcts; high sensitivity within the first 6 hours (Level A).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- On axial CT at the level of the midbrain, SCA infarction appears as a wedge‐shaped hypoattenuation extending into the superior cerebellar peduncle.
• MRI DWI within 2 hours of symptom onset is >90% sensitive for detecting small SCA infarcts that may be occult on CT.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Vascular territory identification using axial imaging is a high-yield concept tested frequently on neurology and internal medicine board examinations.

question_text: In a patient with a hemorrhagic stroke, what is the recommended blood pressure target?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] Acute intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) leads to increased intracranial pressure and secondary injury from hematoma expansion.
• Cerebral autoregulation is impaired around the bleed, so systemic hypertension drives further bleeding.
• Hematoma growth occurs primarily in the first 6 hours; timely BP reduction mitigates expansion.
• Excessive lowering risks perihematomal ischemia, due to already compromised local perfusion.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The AHA/ASA 2015 ICH guidelines (Class I, LOE A) recommend lowering systolic BP (SBP) to 140 mm Hg in patients presenting with SBP 150–220 mm Hg, as intensive reduction reduces hematoma expansion (INTERACT2, NEJM 2013) and yields improved functional outcomes (ordinal shift in mRS, OR 0.87, 95% CI 0.75–1.01; p=0.06 trend). The ATACH-II trial (NEJM 2016) confirmed safety of SBP lowering to 110–139 mm Hg without significant additional benefit over standard (<180 mm Hg) but no increase in adverse events. Thus, a target of ~140 mm Hg (with corresponding diastolic ~90 mm Hg) balances efficacy and cerebral perfusion.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. 160/100 – Above the recommended threshold; permissive hypertension at this level is linked to ongoing hemorrhage expansion (misconception: “mild hypertension is harmless”).
C. 180/110 – Exceeds guideline upper limit; associated with higher rebleeding risk and worse outcomes (misconception: “only extreme pressure needs treatment”).
D. 120/80 – Overly aggressive lowering can drop cerebral perfusion pressure below the autoregulatory range around the hematoma, precipitating perihematomal ischemia (misconception: “lower is always better”).

Comparison Table

BP TargetMechanistic RationaleClinical Impact
140/90Reduces transmural stress on vessels, limits hematoma growthImproved functional outcome, safe (INTERACT2/ATACH-II)
160/100Insufficient to reverse high transmural pressureContinued hematoma expansion, worse prognosis
180/110Very high pressure sustains bleedingIncreased morbidity and mortality
120/80Potential to lower cerebral perfusion below autoregulatory thresholdRisk of ischemic injury around hematoma

Clinical Pearls

• Initiate continuous infusion (e.g., nicardipine) to titrate SBP rapidly to 140 mm Hg within 1 hour.
• Monitor neurologic status and ICP; avoid SBP <120 mm Hg.
• If initial SBP >220 mm Hg, more aggressive reduction may be considered on a case-by-case basis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Equating ICH BP management with ischemic stroke: ischemic stroke often tolerates permissive hypertension, whereas ICH mandates early lowering.
• Focusing on diastolic rather than systolic pressure: SBP is the primary determinant of transmural stress in acute ICH.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2015 Guidelines for ICH: SBP target of 140 mm Hg in patients with initial SBP 150–220 mm Hg (Class I, Level A evidence).
• ATACH-II Trial (2016): Intensive SBP lowering to 110–139 mm Hg versus standard 140–179 mm Hg; confirmed safety, no significant additional benefit (NEJM).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2019 exam. Blood pressure management in acute intracerebral hemorrhage is a high-yield topic, frequently tested as guideline-based target values and trial outcomes.

question_text: Q37. A case scenario about an acute ischemic stroke occurred in the morning, and the patient presented in the evening with a high blood pressure of 190/90. What should be done regarding his blood pressure?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Acute ischemic stroke creates an irreversibly infarcted core surrounded by a potentially salvageable penumbra. In ischemic tissue, cerebral autoregulation is impaired, making systemic blood pressure the primary driver of collateral perfusion. Permissive hypertension up to a systolic blood pressure (SBP) of 220 mmHg (or diastolic ≤120 mmHg) is recommended in patients who are not candidates for reperfusion therapy, to optimize penumbral blood flow and minimize infarct expansion. Overly aggressive blood pressure reduction can precipitate hypoperfusion and worsen neurological outcomes. Key terms: ischemic penumbra, cerebral autoregulation, permissive hypertension, reperfusion window.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A is correct: for acute ischemic stroke patients presenting outside the thrombolysis or thrombectomy window, the 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines (“Guidelines for the Early Management of Patients with Acute Ischemic Stroke,” Powers et al., Stroke 2018) recommend avoiding antihypertensive therapy unless SBP > 220 mmHg or DBP > 120 mmHg (Class IIa, Level C-LD). The SCAST trial (Sandset et al., Lancet 2011) showed no benefit—and possible harm—when acute lowering of blood pressure with candesartan was attempted in ischemic stroke. Meta­analyses confirm that maintaining higher blood pressures in the acute phase supports collateral perfusion without increasing hemorrhagic transformation in non-reperfusion candidates.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Oral amlodipine
• Incorrect because oral dihydropyridine calcium-channel blockers have a slow onset and unpredictable absorption in acute stroke; they may overshoot and risk penumbral hypoperfusion.
• Misconception: any hypertensive patient should be treated; fails to recognize permissive hypertension.

C. IV labetalol
• While IV labetalol is indicated for acute BP lowering in tPA candidates (target <185/110 mmHg), this patient is outside the window; unnecessary BP reduction may worsen ischemia.
• Misconception: equating labetalol’s use in hypertensive emergencies with routine stroke care.

D. IV nicardipine
• Also effective for controlled BP lowering, but like labetalol it risks reducing perfusion in a penumbra when SBP is below 220 mmHg and no reperfusion is planned.
• Misconception: assuming intravenous agents should always be used for high BP in stroke, regardless of thresholds.

Comparison Table

OptionOnset / RouteStroke IndicationEffect on PerfusionGuideline Threshold
No management (A)N/ASBP ≤220 mmHg in non-reperfusion candidatesMaintains collateral perfusionDo not treat if SBP ≤220/DBP ≤120 (2018 AHA/ASA)
Oral amlodipine (B)Slow / oralNot indicated for acute ischemic BP managementRisk of overshoot and hypoperfusionNo guideline support in acute ischemic stroke
IV labetalol (C)Rapid / IVFor thrombolysis candidates >185/110 mmHgLowers BP rapidly, may reduce penumbral flowOnly if SBP >185/DBP >110 in tPA candidates
IV nicardipine (D)Titrateable / IVSimilar to labetalol in tPA candidatesRisks hypoperfusion if SBP <220 mmHgOnly if SBP >185/DBP >110 in tPA candidates

Clinical Pearls

- Maintain SBP up to 220 mmHg in acute ischemic stroke patients not receiving reperfusion to optimize penumbral flow.
• Thresholds differ: <185/110 mmHg for IV thrombolysis eligibility vs ≤220/120 mmHg if not undergoing reperfusion.
