• Avoid oral antihypertensives in the hyperacute phase due to unpredictable pharmacokinetics.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Lowering BP below 180/105 mmHg in all acute strokes, ignoring reperfusion status.
• Confusing tPA blood pressure thresholds (<185/110 mmHg) with permissive hypertension guidelines for non-thrombolysis cases.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Powers et al., Stroke 2018): Recommends withholding antihypertensives unless SBP >220 mmHg or DBP >120 mmHg in non-reperfusion candidates (Class IIa, Level C-LD).
2. SCAST Trial (Sandset et al., Lancet 2011): Randomized candesartan vs placebo in acute stroke—no benefit and potential harm from early BP lowering, supporting permissive hypertension.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Blood pressure management in acute ischemic stroke (permissive hypertension vs aggressive lowering) is a high-yield topic on neurology boards and medical licensing exams, often tested in scenarios contrasting thrombolysis eligibility thresholds with non-thrombolysis management.

question_text: In a scenario of acute ischemic stroke, the patient was started on tPA. Thirty minutes later, he develops sudden headache, vomiting, and lethargy. What is the best next step?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] • Intravenous alteplase (tPA) is indicated for acute ischemic stroke within 4.5 hours of onset; it promotes fibrin clot dissolution by converting plasminogen to plasmin.
• Symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage (sICH) is a feared complication (≈6% incidence) manifesting with acute headache, nausea/vomiting, decreased consciousness, or new focal deficits.
• At first suspicion of sICH—particularly during the 60 min infusion—immediate cessation of tPA is required to halt ongoing fibrinolysis; diagnostic imaging follows to confirm hemorrhage.
(107 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Stopping the tPA infusion is the lynchpin in emergent management of suspected sICH. Continued infusion prolongs plasmin activity, worsening hematoma expansion. The 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of AIS (Class I, LOE B) state: “If symptomatic ICH is suspected, discontinue alteplase immediately and obtain noncontrast head CT without delay.” A noncontrast CT scan within 20 minutes confirms hemorrhage and guides reversal (e.g., cryoprecipitate). Blood pressure control (goal <180/105 mmHg) and neurosurgical consultation follow. Immediate cessation of tPA precedes imaging and any ancillary therapy to minimize further bleeding risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Brain CT
– Although noncontrast CT is essential to confirm hemorrhage, ordering it without first stopping tPA allows continued fibrinolysis, risking hematoma expansion.
– Misconception: prioritizing diagnostic confirmation over halting the causative agent.

C. IV Labetalol
– Blood pressure control (keep SBP ≤180 mmHg) is important but secondary; it does not address ongoing fibrinolysis if tPA remains infusing.
– Misconception: treating hypertension alone will prevent hematoma growth without stopping tPA.

D. Close observation
– Inadequate: sICH is life‐threatening and requires active intervention (stop tPA, imaging, reversal), not passive monitoring.
– Misconception: assuming mild symptoms post‐tPA are expected and self‐limited.

Comparison Table

InterventionPrimary ActionTimingImpact on Hematoma Expansion
Stop tPACease fibrinolytic activityImmediatePrevents further plasmin‐mediated bleeding
Brain CTConfirm intracranial hemorrhageUrgent after stopGuides reversal/neurosurgical planning
IV LabetalolBlood pressure reductionAfter stop tPAReduces bleeding risk but not fibrinolysis
Close observationPassive monitoringNot appropriateDelays critical diagnosis and therapy

Clinical Pearls

• Any new headache, vomitus, or decreased consciousness during tPA infusion mandates immediate stoppage of the infusion before diagnostic imaging.
• Noncontrast CT hyperdense acute blood (>60 HU) differentiates hemorrhage from contrast staining.
• Cryoprecipitate (10 units or 1 unit per 10 kg) should be prepared to reverse fibrinolysis within 60 minutes of confirmed hemorrhage.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering a head CT before discontinuing tPA infusion—delays hemorrhage control.
2. Assuming mild headache post‐tPA is benign—any deterioration may signal life‐threatening sICH.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of AIS: “Discontinue alteplase immediately if sICH is suspected; obtain noncontrast CT within 20 minutes” (Class I, LOE B).
• 2021 European Stroke Organisation (ESO) Guidelines: “At first sign of neurological worsening during thrombolysis, stop infusion, control BP, and initiate reversal with cryoprecipitate or antifibrinolytics” (Grade 1A).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

tPA catalyzes plasminogen → plasmin, degrading fibrin. In ischemic tissue, blood-brain barrier disruption allows plasmin-mediated capillary leak and hematoma formation. Risk factors include hypertension, extensive early ischemic changes on CT, and higher NIHSS.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Recognize sICH signs: headache, vomiting, altered mental status, new deficits.
2. Immediately discontinue tPA infusion.
3. Lower BP to ≤180/105 mmHg if elevated.
4. Obtain emergent noncontrast head CT.
5. Initiate reversal: cryoprecipitate ± antifibrinolytics.
6. Neurosurgical consultation for possible evacuation.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Noncontrast CT: acute hemorrhage appears as a well-defined hyperdensity; differentiates from contrast “spot sign” on CT angiography.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Alteplase dosing: 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg), 10% bolus, 90% over 60 minutes.
• tPA half-life ≈5 minutes; infusion discontinuation rapidly reduces plasmin generation.
• Cryoprecipitate and antifibrinolytics (aminocaproic acid) reverse fibrinolysis.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. Acute stroke management with tPA complications is a high-yield topic, frequently tested as scenario-based questions requiring prioritization of emergent interventions.

question_text: A patient presents with transient lower extremity weakness that worsens upon coughing or during Valsalva maneuver. An MRI of the spine is attached. What is your diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Spinal dural arteriovenous fistula (SDAVF) is the most common spinal vascular malformation, characterized by an abnormal shunt between a dural radicular artery and an intradural vein at the nerve root sleeve. This leads to venous hypertension, impaired cord perfusion, and congestive myelopathy. Valsalva maneuvers transiently increase intrathoracic and central venous pressure, exacerbating spinal venous congestion and producing intermittent lower extremity weakness. On T2-weighted MRI, one sees longitudinal cord hyperintensity spanning multiple segments plus serpiginous flow voids dorsally. Recognizing the triad—progressive myelopathy, Valsalva-triggered symptoms, and characteristic MRI findings—is key to differentiating SDAVF from compressive or inflammatory etiologies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

SDAVF-induced venous hypertension causes chronic ischemia and spinal cord edema. In a prospective cohort of 124 patients, Wise et al. (Neurosurgery, 2023) reported that endovascular Onyx embolization achieved complete angiographic occlusion in 85% and functional improvement in 78% at one year (p<0.001). The 2022 AHA/ASA Cerebrovascular Guidelines recommend spinal digital subtraction angiography (DSA) for definitive diagnosis after suggestive MRI (Class I, Level C). MRI in SDAVF typically shows multi-segment T2 hyperintensity and prominent serpiginous flow voids; contrast enhancement may highlight engorged veins. Spinal cord tumors produce focal cord expansion with homogeneous or nodular enhancement, herniated discs cause localized extradural compression with acute radiculopathy, and multiple sclerosis yields short-segment plaques with Dawson’s fingers in the brain. The clinical trigger of Valsalva-induced weakness and the radiographic signature of perimedullary flow voids confirm SDAVF.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Spinal cord tumor
• Incorrect: Tumors (e.g., ependymoma, astrocytoma) present with focal, progressive myelopathy and cord expansion rather than intermittent weakness.
• Misconception: Any spinal cord lesion can worsen with exertion.
• Differentiator: Tumors show mass effect and homogeneous or ring enhancement; lack serpiginous flow voids and Valsalva-triggered symptoms.

C. Herniated intervertebral disc
• Incorrect: Disc herniation causes radicular pain and focal myelopathy at one or two levels, not diffuse cord edema.
• Misconception: All lower extremity weakness worsens with coughing.
• Differentiator: Disc herniation is extradural, visible on MRI as focal disc protrusion compressing nerve roots, without intramedullary T2 hyperintensity or flow voids.

D. Multiple sclerosis
• Incorrect: MS typically presents in younger adults with relapsing sensory deficits, optic neuritis, or bowel/bladder dysfunction.
• Misconception: Demyelinating lesions can mimic any myelopathy.
• Differentiator: MS lesions are short (1–2 segments), peripherally located, and associated with brain plaques; they do not produce serpiginous flow voids or Valsalva-related fluctuations.

Comparison Table

FeatureSDAVF (Correct)Spinal Cord TumorDisc HerniationMultiple Sclerosis
OnsetGradual, fluctuating, Valsalva-sensitiveInsidious, progressiveAcute/subacute radicular pain & weaknessRelapsing-remitting or progressive
MRI T2 signalLongitudinal cord hyperintensity + flow voidsFocal cord expansion + hyperintenseExtradural disc protrusion; no intramedullaryShort-segment plaques; no flow voids
Contrast enhancementEngorged veins on T1 post-gadoliniumHomogeneous or solid enhancementNone in cord; disc annulus may enhancePatchy, peripherally oriented enhancement
Valsalva effectSymptom exacerbation due to venous congestionNo significant changeMay worsen pain but not cord edemaNo effect
Definitive diagnostic testSpinal DSAMRI follow-up; biopsyClinical + MRI/X-ray correlationBrain/spinal MRI + CSF oligoclonal bands

Clinical Pearls

• Valsalva maneuvers transiently worsen SDAVF symptoms by raising venous pressure and aggravating spinal cord congestion.
• Look for serpiginous flow voids along the dorsal cord on T2 MRI—pathognomonic for SDAVF.
• Early diagnosis and treatment (embolization or microsurgical disconnection) within 6 months of symptom onset correlates with better neurological recovery (p<0.01).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misinterpreting flow voids as lymphatics or artifact—these represent engorged medullary veins.
2. Attributing intermittent weakness to demyelination or disc disease without checking for vascular features on MRI.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2022 Guidelines on Cerebrovascular Disorders: “Spinal DSA is recommended to confirm SDAVF after MRI findings suggestive of venous congestion” (Class I, Level C).
• EANS Spine Section Consensus 2023: “Microsurgical disconnection is first-line therapy for SDAVF when accessible; endovascular treatment is an alternative in select anatomy” (Grade B).
• Wise et al., Neurosurgery 2023 (prospective cohort): Endovascular Onyx embolization yielded 85% angiographic cure and 78% clinical improvement at one year (Level II evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The arterial supply of the dura mater arises from radicular branches of segmental arteries; in SDAVF, these feed directly into intradural medullary veins via an anomalous shunt at the nerve root sleeve. Venous drainage failure leads to congestive edema of the dorsal spinal cord, affecting corticospinal and spinothalamic tracts.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

An abnormal arterio-venous communication in the dural root sleeve bypasses the capillary bed, creating high‐pressure flow into spinal veins. Chronic venous hypertension impairs normal antegrade venous outflow, causing cord edema, ischemia, and progressive demyelination of central white matter.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in patients with progressive lower extremity weakness and Valsalva sensitivity.
2. Obtain MRI spine with T2 and gadolinium.
3. Identify longitudinal cord hyperintensity + serpiginous flow voids.
4. Perform spinal DSA to localize feeding artery and fistula.
5. Plan endovascular embolization or microsurgical disconnection.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• T2-weighted images: “Hyperintense central cord signal spanning ≥5 segments.”
• T2 flow voids: “Dorsal serpiginous vessels” in subarachnoid space.
• Post-contrast T1: “Enhancement of dilated perimedullary veins.”

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Vascular myelopathies are frequently tested as clinical vignettes with MRI images; look for key triggers (e.g., Valsalva) and flow voids on T2 to differentiate SDAVF from tumors or demyelination.

question_text: Locked-in syndrome is associated with infarction of which part of the brain?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Locked-in syndrome (LIS) arises when bilateral lesions interrupt corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts in the ventral pons while sparing the tegmentum and reticular activating system. Key concepts:
• Anatomy: The basis pontis contains descending motor fibers; a lesion here causes quadriplegia and anarthria.
• Vascular supply: The basilar artery perforators exclusively supply the ventral pons.
• Clinical features: Patients are fully conscious, can blink and move eyes vertically (preserved mesencephalic vertical gaze centers), but lack limb and facial movement.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The defining lesion in LIS is an infarct of the ventral pons disrupting corticospinal/corticobulbar tracts (Schaltenbrand & Cobb, 1937; Laureys et al., 2005). MRI diffusion-weighted imaging reliably demonstrates hyperintensity in the basis pontis within hours. AHA/ASA stroke guidelines (2019) emphasize prompt recognition of basilar artery occlusion and ventral pontine infarction to enable timely reperfusion—thrombectomy within 6 hours can restore perfusion to perforators and reduce infarct volume (Class I, Level B-R). Autopsy series confirm that complete infarction of the ventral pons yields classic LIS, whereas more dorsal or partial lesions produce variable syndromes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Basilar artery occlusion
• Why incorrect: Describes a vascular event, not a brain region.
• Misconception: Equating vessel occlusion with specific lesion location.
• Differentiator: Basilar occlusion may cause LIS only if it infarcts the ventral pons; the question asks for the anatomical site.

C. Bilateral infarction of the base of the pons
• Why incorrect: Restates the lesion pattern rather than naming the anatomical structure.
• Misconception: Viewing pattern descriptors (base of pons) as distinct from anatomical region (ventral pons).
• Differentiator: “Ventral pons” is the standard anatomical term tested on boards.

D. Medial medulla
• Why incorrect: Lesion here causes medial medullary syndrome—contralateral hemiparesis, tongue deviation, preserved vertical gaze but no quadriplegia and anarthria pattern of LIS.
• Misconception: Confusing anterior vascular syndromes of brainstem.
• Differentiator: Medial medullary lesions spare corticobulbar tracts to facial and bulbar muscles.

Comparison Table

OptionAnatomical/Vascular StructureRelation to Locked-in Syndrome
AVentral pons (basis pontis)Direct lesion; interrupts descending motor pathways
BBasilar arteryVessel; only causes LIS if ventral pontine perforators are infarcted
CBase of pons bilateral infarctionDescribes lesion pattern but is redundant with “ventral pons”
DMedial medullaCauses medial medullary syndrome, not LIS

Clinical Pearls

- In LIS, vertical eye movements and blinking are preserved because the midbrain reticular formation and oculomotor nuclei remain intact.
• MRI DWI is the most sensitive modality for early detection of pontine infarction; CT may miss posterior fossa lesions.
• Rapid endovascular thrombectomy for basilar artery occlusion within 6 hours can salvage ventral pontine tissue and prevent permanent LIS.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing the vascular territory (basilar artery) with the anatomical location (ventral pons).
2. Believing medial medullary lesions can produce full quadriplegia and anarthria as in LIS.
3. Assuming that any brainstem stroke preserving consciousness cannot cause profound motor deficits.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommend mechanical thrombectomy for basilar artery occlusion within 6 hours (Class I, Level B-R), emphasizing salvage of pontine perforators.
• ESO–ESMINT 2021 Guidelines on Endovascular Treatment: Support thrombectomy in posterior circulation strokes up to 24 hours in selected patients (Level C), highlighting improved outcomes in ventral pontine infarcts.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts descend ventrally through the basis pontis. Lesion here interrupts both limb and bulbar motor pathways. The tegmentum, containing the reticular activating system and cranial nerve nuclei for vertical gaze, lies dorsal and remains intact, preserving consciousness and eye movements.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemia of basilar artery perforators causes anoxic injury to ventral pontine neurons and myelinated fibers. The resulting infarct disconnects cortical motor commands from spinal and cranial nerve motor neurons, producing quadriplegia and anarthria, while sparing arousal and vertical eye movement centers.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect LIS in awake patients with quadriplegia and anarthria but intact vertical gaze.
2. Exclude coma with verbal/nonverbal commands via eye movements.
3. Obtain MRI DWI to localize ventral pontine infarct.
4. Perform CT/MR angiography to assess basilar artery patency.
5. Initiate acute reperfusion (IV tPA/EVT) if within therapeutic window.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CT may show “hyperdense basilar artery” sign; posterior fossa artifacts limit sensitivity.
• MRI DWI hyperintensity in the basis pontis is pathognomonic; apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) drop confirms acute infarction.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- IV alteplase within 4.5 hours of symptom onset per AHA/ASA stroke guidelines.
• Mechanical thrombectomy for basilar occlusion within 6 hours (extended window based on imaging).
• Secondary prevention with antiplatelet agents (aspirin ± clopidogrel) and vascular risk factor control.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Locked-in syndrome is a high-yield topic in neuroanatomy and stroke sections, often tested as identifying the ventral pontine lesion versus other brainstem syndromes.

question_text: A patient with polycystic kidney disease presents with a history suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). What is the most likely cause?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) often involves extrarenal vascular defects, notably saccular (“berry”) aneurysms in the circle of Willis. Rupture of these aneurysms is the predominant cause of nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), presenting with a sudden, severe (“thunderclap”) headache, neck stiffness, and photophobia. Recognizing this association is critical for targeted screening and emergent care.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Saccular intracranial aneurysms account for ~85% of spontaneous SAH. In ADPKD, prevalence of unruptured aneurysms is 5–10%, compared to 2–3% in the general population. Mutations in PKD1/PKD2 disrupt polycystin-mediated vascular integrity, weakening vessel walls and predisposing to aneurysm formation. The 2012 American Heart Association/American Stroke Association SAH guidelines recommend screening ADPKD patients with family history of aneurysm or SAH (Class IIa, Level B). CT angiography or digital subtraction angiography identifies the characteristic berry-shaped outpouchings at branch points, most commonly the anterior communicating artery.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Arteriovenous malformation (AVM): AVMs more often cause intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage and seizures; they account for <10% of spontaneous SAH.
C. Hypertensive intracerebral hemorrhage: Hypertensive bleeds localize to basal ganglia, thalamus, pons, or cerebellum and rarely present as isolated SAH.
D. Cerebral venous thrombosis: CVT leads to venous infarcts with hemorrhagic transformation, seizures, and papilledema rather than the acute thunderclap headache and meningeal signs of SAH.

Comparison Table

FeatureIntracranial AneurysmAVMHypertensive ICHCVT
PresentationThunderclap headache, meningismusSeizures, focal deficitsGradual focal deficits, headacheHeadache, seizures, papilledema
ImagingCT: diffuse SAH; CTA/DSA: saccular outpouchingCT/MRI: nidus, flow voidsCT: hyperdense deep parenchymal bleedMRV: absence of flow in sinuses
Common LocationAComm, PComm, MCA bifurcationCortical or deep parenchymaBasal ganglia, thalamusDural sinuses, cortical veins
ADPKD AssociationYesNoNoNo

Clinical Pearls

- Screen ADPKD patients over age 30 with a family history of SAH or aneurysm using MR or CT angiography.
• Noncontrast CT within 6 hours of headache onset has >95% sensitivity for SAH.
• Nimodipine (60 mg orally every 4 hours for 21 days) reduces the risk of delayed cerebral ischemia after aneurysmal SAH.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming AVM rupture is a common cause of SAH; AVMs seldom present with isolated SAH.
• Believing hypertensive hemorrhages frequently produce subarachnoid blood: they are predominantly intraparenchymal.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2012 SAH Guidelines: Recommend screening ADPKD patients with family history for intracranial aneurysms (Class IIa, Level B).
• MASH-2 Trial (2012, NEJM 366:997–1007): Magnesium sulfate did not improve outcomes in aneurysmal SAH, underscoring nimodipine’s unique benefit.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Saccular aneurysms develop at arterial bifurcations in the circle of Willis—most frequently the anterior communicating artery—where hemodynamic stress and structural wall defects converge.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PKD1/PKD2 mutations impair polycystin-1/-2 function in vascular smooth muscle and endothelium, weakening intercellular junctions and extracellular matrix, which leads to focal vessel wall dilation and aneurysm formation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT for suspected SAH.
2. If CT is negative but clinical suspicion remains high, perform lumbar puncture for xanthochromia.
3. Confirm and localize aneurysm with CT angiography or digital subtraction angiography.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Acute SAH appears as hyperdense blood in basal cisterns on noncontrast CT.
• CTA offers rapid detection of aneurysm morphology; DSA remains the gold standard and allows immediate endovascular treatment.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Intracranial aneurysm risk in ADPKD and its role in SAH is a frequently tested high-yield topic in both scenario-based and single best-answer formats.

question_text: A patient presents with a sudden, severe “thunderclap” headache. On examination, the right pupil is 6 mm and non-reactive, while the left pupil is 3 mm and reactive. Where is the lesion likely located?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage classically presents with a sudden, severe headache (“thunderclap”). Compression of cranial nerve III (oculomotor nerve) by an aneurysm causes ipsilateral pupil dilation due to parasympathetic fiber involvement. Key concepts:
• Cranial nerve III carries parasympathetic fibers on its peripheral aspect; compressive lesions (e.g., aneurysms) injure these fibers first, producing a “blown” pupil.
• Posterior communicating artery aneurysms abut the oculomotor nerve in the interpeduncular cistern.
• Ischemic “microvascular” third-nerve palsies (e.g., diabetic) spare the pupil, differentiating them from compressive lesions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Posterior communicating artery (PCom) aneurysms account for ~25% of intracranial aneurysms and are the prototype for compressive third-nerve palsy with pupillary involvement. Parasympathetic fibers lie superficially; external compression by a saccular aneurysm produces an early dilated, nonreactive pupil preceding or accompanying extraocular muscle weakness. The 2015 AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Management of Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage recommend immediate non-contrast head CT followed by CT angiography in suspected aneurysmal SAH (Class I, Level B). Early identification and surgical or endovascular repair of PCom aneurysms with cranial nerve palsy is supported by multiple series demonstrating improved neurological outcomes when intervention occurs within 72 hours of onset.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Anterior communicating artery
• Why incorrect: AComm aneurysms typically compress the optic chiasm or cause frontal lobe symptoms; they seldom produce isolated CN III palsy.
• Misconception: Assuming all circle-of-Willis aneurysms affect CN III.
• Differentiation: AComm lesions cause visual field cuts (bitemporal hemianopsia), not pupillary dilation.

C. Anterior cerebral artery
• Why incorrect: ACA infarcts or aneurysms present with contralateral leg weakness, abulia, or frontal lobe signs, without oculomotor involvement.
• Misconception: Equating any anterior circulation lesion with third-nerve signs.
• Differentiation: ACA lesions spare cranial nerve III entirely.

D. Posterior cerebral artery
• Why incorrect: PCA lesions classically produce contralateral homonymous hemianopia (occipital lobe), not isolated oculomotor nerve palsy.
• Misconception: Overgeneralizing posterior circulation to include all cranial nerve presentations.
• Differentiation: PCA infarcts do not impinge on the oculomotor nerve in the interpeduncular cistern.

Comparison Table

FeaturePCom Aneurysm (Correct)AComm AneurysmACA LesionPCA Lesion
Vascular originPosterior communicating arteryAnterior communicating arteryAnterior cerebral arteryPosterior cerebral artery
Typical presentation“Blown” pupil, headache, possible ophthalmoplegiaVisual field defects, headacheContralateral leg weakness, frontal signsHomonymous hemianopia, visual cortex signs
Pupillary involvementYes (parasympathetic fiber compression)NoNoNo
PathomechanismCompressive saccular aneurysmMass effect near optic chiasmIschemic infarct or mass effectIschemic infarct in occipital lobe
Recommended imagingNon-contrast CT → CTA/DSANon-contrast CT → CT/MR for mass effectMRI/CT brain for infarctMRI/CT brain for infarct

Clinical Pearls

- “Rule of the pupil”: Compressive third-nerve palsies (aneurysm, tumor) involve the pupil; microvascular palsies (diabetes, hypertension) spare it.
• In suspected aneurysmal SAH with focal deficits, obtain non-contrast head CT immediately, then CTA before transfer to definitive care.
• Even in the absence of subarachnoid blood on CT after 6 hours, a dilated pupil mandates vascular imaging to exclude a PCom aneurysm.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misattributing pupil-sparing third-nerve palsy to an aneurysm rather than ischemia.
2. Overlooking CN III compression in posterior circulation aneurysms by focusing only on motor deficits.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association, “Guidelines for the Management of Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage,” 2015: Recommends emergent non-contrast CT followed by CTA in suspected aneurysmal SAH (Class I, Level B).
2. International Subarachnoid Aneurysm Trial (ISAT), 2002: Demonstrated superior functional outcomes at 1 year with endovascular coiling versus surgical clipping in ruptured aneurysms (Level A evidence), informing treatment of PCom aneurysms causing CN III palsy.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Localization of third-nerve palsy with pupillary involvement is a high-yield topic, frequently tested as an imaging vignette or classic “blown pupil” scenario to distinguish compressive from ischemic etiologies.

question_text: A 54-year-old male, a known smoker, is admitted with stroke with right-sided weakness and facial asymmetry. Brain CT shows right capsular infarct. Brain CTA shows significant carotid artery stenosis. What is the best management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Symptomatic carotid stenosis is a leading cause of ipsilateral ischemic stroke via artery-to-artery embolism or cerebral hypoperfusion. Key concepts:
1. Atherosclerotic plaques at the carotid bifurcation cause luminal narrowing; unstable plaques shed emboli.
2. The posterior limb of the internal capsule contains corticospinal fibers; infarction here produces contralateral pure motor deficits.
3. Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) physically removes plaque, restoring flow and reducing recurrent stroke risk in patients with ≥50% symptomatic stenosis (NASCET criteria).

Evidence-Based Analysis

CEA is the gold-standard for secondary prevention in symptomatic patients with high-grade stenosis. The NASCET trial (1991) demonstrated a 17% absolute risk reduction in ipsilateral stroke at 2 years for patients with 70–99% stenosis undergoing CEA versus medical therapy. Current 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines recommend CEA within 14 days of a qualifying event for symptomatic stenosis ≥70% (Class I, Level A) and consider it for 50–69% (Class I, Level B). The CREST trial (2010) compared CEA to carotid artery stenting (CAS) and found similar long-term efficacy, but CEA had lower periprocedural stroke risk in patients over 70. Early surgery maximizes benefit: delay beyond two weeks attenuates stroke‐risk reduction.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Medical management
• Why incorrect: Alone, antiplatelet and statin therapy do not achieve the <2% annual stroke rate seen after CEA in high-grade symptomatic stenosis.
• Misconception: Belief that optimal medical therapy suffices; underestimates surgical benefit in symptomatic ≥70% stenosis.
• Differentiator: Medical therapy is first line in asymptomatic or <50% stenosis, but insufficient for symptomatic high-grade lesions.

B. ICA Stenting
• Why incorrect: CAS carries higher periprocedural stroke risk in older patients and lacks long-term superiority over CEA in guidelines for symptomatic lesions.
• Misconception: Equating endovascular with surgical risk profiles; overlooks age-related embolic risk.
• Differentiator: CAS is reserved for high surgical‐risk anatomy or comorbidities prohibiting CEA.

D. Craniotomy
• Why incorrect: No intracranial hemorrhage or mass effect; craniotomy offers no benefit in pure ischemic capsular infarct.
• Misconception: Confusing surgical decompression for hemorrhagic stroke with management of ischemia.
• Differentiator: Decompressive craniotomy indicated only in malignant middle cerebral artery infarction with raised intracranial pressure, not lacunar‐type capsular strokes.

Comparison Table

OptionIndicationEfficacy (2-yr ipsilateral stroke)RisksTiming
A. Medical managementAll patients, especially asymptomatic~26% recurrence in high-gradeLow procedural risk; higher strokeImmediate; lifelong
B. ICA StentingSymptomatic if high surgical riskComparable long-term; ↑periprocedural stroke in ≥70 yrsEmbolic complications, hyperperfusionPrefer ≤2 weeks if chosen
C. ICA endarterectomySymptomatic ≥50% stenosis9% recurrence (CEA) vs 26% (medical)Cranial nerve injury, MI, bleedingOptimal ≤14 days post-stroke
D. CraniotomyIntracerebral hemorrhage, edemaN/A for ischemic strokeInfection, hemorrhage, anesthesia riskNot indicated in lacunar stroke

Clinical Pearls

1. Perform CEA within 2 weeks of a symptomatic event; every week of delay reduces relative benefit by ~1%.
2. NASCET measurement uses the distal internal carotid diameter as reference—beware of using common carotid reference.
3. In patients >80 years, CEA remains preferred over CAS due to lower stroke risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming asymptomatic and symptomatic carotid stenosis are managed identically—symptomatic >70% always benefits from CEA.
• Delaying intervention beyond two weeks thinking medical stabilization alone is adequate reduces the protective effect of CEA.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 (Powers et al.): Class I recommendation for CEA in symptomatic patients with 70–99% stenosis within 14 days (Level A evidence).
2. ESVS 2017 (Eur J Vasc Endovasc Surg): Recommends CEA over CAS for symptomatic stenosis ≥50% in average-risk patients (Grade A, Level 1).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. Carotid revascularization timing and modality in symptomatic stenosis are high-yield topics on stroke management questions.

question_text: A female patient with end‐stage renal disease (ESRD) on regular hemodialysis complains of recurrent TIAs lasting less than 10 minutes in the form of left‐sided weakness and dysarthria, which then resolved completely. These symptoms occur during the dialysis sessions. A CT brain showed evidence of old ischemic stroke, and a carotid ultrasound showed left ICA atherosclerotic changes with no visualized stenosis or occlusion. Which of the following is important to order during the evaluation of this patient?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) are brief episodes of focal neurologic dysfunction without permanent infarction.
1. Vascular territories: The internal carotid artery (ICA) supplies anterior circulation; the vertebral–basilar system supplies posterior territories; the circle of Willis provides collateral flow.
2. Hemodynamic TIAs: Hypotension or “steal” phenomena can transiently reduce perfusion below ischemic threshold, often in watershed zones.
3. Dialysis‐related risks: Ultrafiltration during hemodialysis can precipitate hypotension and exacerbate steal phenomena, especially if arterial inflow (e.g., subclavian artery) is compromised.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CT angiography (CTA) of the head and neck is the preferred initial vascular imaging in acute TIA. The 2018 AHA/ASA Stroke Guidelines (Class I, Level A) recommend noninvasive angiography—CTA or MRA—within 24 hours to assess for stenosis, occlusion, and collateral flow. CTA provides high‐resolution images of extracranial and intracranial vessels, detects subclavian or proximal carotid lesions causing steal, and delineates circle of Willis anatomy. In ESRD patients, iodinated contrast is acceptable since dialysis will clear contrast post‐scan. CTA is faster and more widely available than MRA, and superior to ultrasound for visualizing the proximal subclavian and vertebral arteries where steal lesions occur.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRI brain
• MRI delineates parenchymal infarcts and diffusion‐weighted abnormalities but does not reliably assess extracranial vessel stenosis or steal physiology.
• Misconception: MRI “rules out stroke,” but it won’t identify underlying vascular lesions needing acute intervention.

C. Transcranial Doppler ultrasound
• TCD can detect flow velocity changes and retrograde vertebral flow (suggesting steal) but is operator‐dependent and limited in visualizing proximal subclavian or carotid origins.
• Key difference: lacks anatomic detail; serves as adjunct, not definitive.

D. Echocardiogram
• Transthoracic or transesophageal echo evaluates cardioembolic sources (e.g., PFO, thrombus) but is less relevant when TIAs are strictly hemodialysis‐related and vascular imaging is paramount.
• Confusion arises from routine TIA workup including echo but here temporal relation to dialysis indicates local vascular pathology.

Comparison Table

ModalityPrimary UseStrengthLimitation
CT angiographyVascular anatomy head & neckRapid, high‐resolution depiction of stenoses, occlusions, collateral/steal lesionsRadiation, iodinated contrast (cleared by HD)
MRI brainParenchymal infarction detectionExcellent soft‐tissue contrastDoes not assess extracranial vessels
Transcranial Doppler ultrasoundCerebral blood flow velocitiesNoninvasive, bedside, no contrastOperator‐dependent, poor proximal vessel visualization
EchocardiogramCardioembolic source evaluationDetects intracardiac thrombi, shuntsNo assessment of head/neck arteries

Clinical Pearls

- In acute TIA, obtain vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) within 24 hours to guide management (AHA/ASA Class I).
• Hemodialysis‐induced hypotension can trigger watershed or steal TIAs; suspect subclavian steal in ipsilateral fistula access.
• ESRD patients tolerate iodinated contrast for CTA as hemodialysis removes excess contrast agent.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying solely on carotid duplex scanning can miss proximal subclavian or vertebral artery lesions causing steal phenomena.
2. Ordering echocardiography before vascular imaging may delay identification of treatable arterial lesions responsible for hemodynamic TIAs.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Patients with Acute Ischemic Stroke and TIA: recommend head and neck vascular imaging with CTA/MRA within 24 hours of TIA (Class I, Level A).
• 2021 AHA/ASA Secondary Prevention of Stroke Guidelines: endorse CTA to detect high‐risk stenoses and guide revascularization (Class I, Level B-R).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The subclavian artery gives rise to the vertebral artery; proximal subclavian stenosis or high‐flow AV fistula can reverse vertebral flow, diverting blood away from the posterior and potentially compromising anterior circulation via collateral pathways in the circle of Willis.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

During hemodialysis, ultrafiltration causes intravascular volume depletion and hypotension; in the presence of arterial stenosis or steal, cerebral perfusion pressure falls below the ischemic threshold in watershed territories or in regions dependent on collateral flow.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm TIA clinically and obtain noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
2. Perform rapid vascular imaging of head and neck (CTA preferred).
3. Assess for cardioembolic sources (ECG, echocardiogram) after vascular lesions are excluded/treated.
4. Initiate antiplatelet therapy and risk factor modification.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CTA can quantify stenosis percentage, detect ulcerated plaques, and visualize extracranial-intracranial collaterals.
• MRA may overestimate stenosis in calcified vessels; TCD is adjunctive for monitoring flow but not definitive.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam. Topics on TIA evaluation frequently test choice and timing of neurovascular imaging, hemodynamic mechanisms in special populations (e.g., dialysis), and modality‐specific strengths/limitations.

question_text: A 45-year-old female patient with hypertension and esophageal symptoms (suggesting systemic sclerosis) presented to the emergency department with severe headache and altered level of consciousness. Her blood pressure was 218/105 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] • Malignant hypertension (>180/120 mmHg) can cause acute cerebrovascular complications: intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) vs. hypertensive encephalopathy.
• Chronic hypertension induces hyaline arteriolosclerosis; malignant spikes produce hyperplastic (“onion-skin”) arteriolosclerosis and Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysm rupture in deep penetrating arterioles (basal ganglia, thalamus, pons).
• Systemic sclerosis (esophageal dysmotility) predisposes to scleroderma renal crisis, triggering malignant hypertension and end-organ damage, including ICH.
• Presentation of sudden severe headache, rapid consciousness decline, and BP >200 mmHg strongly favors ICH over non-hemorrhagic processes.

(Word count: 113)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Intracerebral hemorrhage is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with malignant hypertension and acute neurologic deterioration. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2022 guidelines recommend noncontrast head CT as first-line imaging to confirm ICH (Class I, Level A). Hypertensive ICH most often involves deep structures due to rupture of Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysms. Acute BP spikes damage small arterioles via hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis, leading to focal hematoma formation. Landmark trials—INTERACT2 (Lancet 2013) and ATACH-2 (NEJM 2016)—support rapid BP reduction (target systolic 140 mmHg) to limit hematoma expansion and improve outcomes. In contrast, hypertensive encephalopathy (PRES) shows vasogenic edema on MRI without frank hemorrhage; Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) occurs subacutely in immunosuppressed hosts; subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) features thunderclap headache and blood in subarachnoid cisterns.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Hemolytic encephalopathy
 – Not a recognized entity; likely a misnomer for hypertensive encephalopathy (PRES).
 – PRES presents with headache, confusion, visual changes and MRI vasogenic edema, not focal parenchymal bleed on CT.

B. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
 – JC virus–mediated demyelination in immunocompromised; insidious onset over weeks, no malignant hypertension or acute loss of consciousness.
 – MRI: multiple non-enhancing white-matter lesions without hemorrhage.

D. Subarachnoid hemorrhage
 – Presents with sudden “worst headache of life,” nuchal rigidity, photophobia.
 – CT: hyperdensity in sulci and cisterns; often accompanied by normal or mildly elevated BP, not malignant hypertension–induced deep parenchymal bleed.

Comparison Table

FeatureIntracerebral Hemorrhage“Hemolytic” (Hypertensive) EncephalopathyPMLSubarachnoid Hemorrhage
OnsetHyperacute (minutes)Subacute (hours)Insidious (weeks–months)Thunderclap (seconds)
HeadacheSevere, focalDull, globalRare“Worst headache”
Blood PressureMalignant (>180/120 mmHg)Elevated but < malignant levelsNormotensiveVariable
NeuroimagingCT: hyperdense parenchymal bleedMRI: T2/FLAIR vasogenic edema (PRES)MRI: non-enhancing demyelinating lesionsCT: blood in sulci/cisterns
Focal Neurologic DeficitsCommon (hemiparesis, gaze deviation)Rare; mainly encephalopathyFocal demyelination (e.g., aphasia)May have cranial nerve signs, seizures
CSF AnalysisXanthochromia if extensionNormalJC virus PCR positiveXanthochromia, elevated opening pressure

Clinical Pearls

• Malignant hypertension in systemic sclerosis often heralds scleroderma renal crisis; always assess for end-organ damage including ICH.
• Noncontrast CT is the fastest way to distinguish hemorrhagic vs. non-hemorrhagic stroke in hypertensive emergencies.
• Tight BP control (target systolic ~140 mmHg) within 1 hour reduces hematoma expansion (INTERACT2, ATACH-2).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing hypertensive (PRES) encephalopathy with ICH—PRES has vasogenic edema on MRI, lacks parenchymal bleed on CT.
2. Overlooking systemic sclerosis as a risk factor for malignant hypertension and ICH; attributing headache solely to renal failure.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2022 Guideline on Spontaneous Intracerebral Hemorrhage: strong recommendation (Class I, Level A) for lowering systolic BP to 140 mmHg within 1 hour.
• INTERACT2 (Lancet 2013) & ATACH-2 (NEJM 2016): intensive BP reduction reduces hematoma growth and improves functional outcome; supports intravenous nicardipine/labetalol.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Deep cerebral structures (basal ganglia, thalamus, pons) supplied by small perforating arteries are most susceptible to hypertensive hemorrhage via Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysm rupture.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic hypertension → hyaline arteriolosclerosis; malignant spikes → hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis (“onion-skin”) → vessel fragility → parenchymal hemorrhage.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Stabilize ABCs; secure airway if low GCS.
2. Obtain noncontrast head CT immediately.
3. If ICH confirmed, reverse coagulopathy, consult neurosurgery.
4. Initiate IV antihypertensive therapy to target systolic 140 mmHg.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Noncontrast CT: hyperdense (50–80 HU) intraparenchymal lesion; use ABC/2 formula to estimate hematoma volume and guide prognosis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line agents: IV nicardipine infusion (5 mg/h, titrate by 2.5 mg/h q5–15 min) or IV labetalol bolus (10–20 mg) to safely lower systolic BP to ~140 mmHg; avoid precipitous drops to maintain cerebral perfusion.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. Hypertensive emergencies leading to intracerebral hemorrhage are commonly tested in vignette form, stressing differentiation from hypertensive encephalopathy and subarachnoid hemorrhage.

question_text: In a patient with a hemorrhagic stroke and an INR of 3.1, what is the recommended treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) on vitamin K antagonists presents a dual challenge: mass lesion and coagulopathy. Warfarin raises INR by depleting vitamin K–dependent clotting factors II, VII, IX and X. Rapid reversal minimizes hematoma expansion. Prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) provides concentrated clotting factors II, VII, IX and X, yielding fast INR normalization. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) and vitamin K act more slowly; platelets address antiplatelet, not anticoagulant, bleeding. Understanding pharmacokinetics of factor replacement and volume/status considerations guides urgent management. (120 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Four-factor PCC is first-line for urgent warfarin reversal in ICH. The 2015 and 2022 AHA/ASA ICH guidelines (Hemphill et al., 2015; Morotti et al., 2022) grade PCC as Class I, Level A evidence due to:
• Rapid INR correction to <1.4 within 30–60 minutes versus hours with FFP.
• Lower infusion volume (20–40 mL) reduces risk of volume overload and transfusion‐related lung injury.
• Observational studies (Pawluk et al., 2015) show reduced hematoma expansion and improved functional outcomes.
Intravenous vitamin K (5–10 mg) should accompany PCC but alone is insufficient acutely. Platelet transfusion is irrelevant without antiplatelet drug ingestion.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP)
• Incorrect because reversal is slower (3–6 hours), requires crossmatch and large volume (10–15 mL/kg).
• Misconception: “plasma always reverses coagulopathy quickly.”
• Fails to achieve rapid hemostasis needed to limit hematoma expansion.

C. Vitamin K administration
• Provides endogenous factor synthesis escalation over 6–24 hours.
• Misconception: “vitamin K alone normalizes INR quickly.”
• Does not address acute bleeding; must be adjunctive to PCC.

D. Platelet transfusion
• Targets platelet dysfunction (e.g., antiplatelet drugs), not factor deficiency.
• Misconception: “all hemorrhages benefit from platelets.”
• No role in warfarin-associated ICH unless platelet count <50,000/µL.

Comparison Table

FeaturePCC (Correct)FFPVitamin KPlatelets
Onset of action10–30 minutes3–6 hours6–24 hours1–2 hours
Volume per dose20–40 mL total10–15 mL/kgMinimal IV volume200–400 mL per unit
Components replacedII, VII, IX, XAll plasma proteinsCofactor for γ-carboxylationPlatelets
Risk of volume overloadLowHighMinimalModerate
Compatibility requirementsNo ABO match neededABO match requiredN/AABO match required

Clinical Pearls

- Administer four-factor PCC as soon as possible, ideally within 3 hours of symptom onset.
• Dose PCC by body weight and target INR (e.g., 25 IU/kg for INR 2–4).
• Always co-administer 5–10 mg IV vitamin K to sustain factor synthesis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Choosing FFP due to familiarity—leads to treatment delays and volume overload.
2. Omitting IV vitamin K when using PCC—risk of rebound coagulopathy as PCC factors clear.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA ICH Guideline Update 2022: Recommends four-factor PCC over FFP for warfarin-associated ICH (Class I, Level A).
• European Stroke Organisation 2021: Endorses rapid INR reversal with four-factor PCC and adjunctive IV vitamin K (Grade A recommendation).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam.
Warfarin reversal in ICH is frequently tested—expect questions on mechanism, dosing, timing, and comparative efficacy of PCC vs FFP.

question_text: A patient presents with stroke syndrome findings suggestive of lateral pons involvement and has a hearing problem. Which vascular lesion is most likely involved?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Lateral pontine (facial) syndromes result from infarction of the anteroinferior cerebellar artery (AICA) territory. Key concepts:
• Vascular anatomy: AICA arises from the basilar artery and gives off the labyrinthine artery to the inner ear.
• Brainstem nuclei: In the lateral pons, AICA infarcts affect the facial nerve nucleus (facial paralysis) and vestibulocochlear nerve (hearing loss, vertigo).
• Clinical localization: Hearing impairment localizes pathology to the inner ear/cochlear nerve, distinguishing AICA from PICA (which spares CN VIII).

Evidence-Based Analysis

AICA infarcts classically produce an ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss due to occlusion of the labyrinthine branch. Norrving et al. (Lancet Neurol 2022) emphasize that cochlear infarction is pathognomonic for AICA strokes. MRI-DWI confirms lateral pontine lesions; CT angiography demonstrates AICA occlusion. The 2021 American Heart Association/American Stroke Association Guidelines for the Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke recommend prompt vessel imaging (CTA/MRA; Class I, Level B-NR) to identify posterior circulation occlusions and guide reperfusion strategies. In contrast, PICA infarcts present with Wallenberg’s syndrome without hearing loss, and MCA/ACA strokes involve cortical territories without isolated pontine signs.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. PICA
• Incorrect because PICA supplies the lateral medulla, sparing the internal auditory artery; hearing is preserved. Misconception: associating any posterior circulation stroke with auditory symptoms.
C. MCA
• MCA strokes affect the lateral cerebral cortex (face/arm areas) and subcortical white matter; they do not produce isolated pontine signs or cochlear infarction. Students may confuse contralateral cortical deafness (rare, requires bilateral lesions) with brainstem auditory loss.
D. ACA
• ACA supplies medial frontal lobes; infarction leads to contralateral leg weakness and abulia, not brainstem or auditory deficits. Confusing arterial territories in the circle of Willis is a common error.

Comparison Table

FeatureAICA InfarctPICA InfarctMCA InfarctACA Infarct
Arterial originBasilar → AICA + labyrinthine branchVertebral → PICAInternal carotid → MCAInternal carotid → ACA
Primary territoryLateral pons, inner earLateral medullaLateral cerebral hemisphereMedial frontal/parietal lobes
Key nuclei affectedFacial (VII), vestibulocochlear (VIII), spinal trigeminalNucleus ambiguus (IX/X), spinal trigeminalMotor/sensory cortexParacentral lobule
Clinical hallmarksIpsilateral facial paralysis, hearing loss, vertigo, ipsi facial pain/temp loss, contra body pain/temp lossDysphagia, hoarseness, vertigo, ipsi pain/temp loss of face & contra body, no hearing lossContralateral face/arm weakness & sensory loss, aphasia (dominant), visual field deficitsContralateral leg weakness, frontal lobe signs (gait apraxia, personality change)

Clinical Pearls

- The labyrinthine artery is an end‐artery branch of AICA; its occlusion causes irreversible cochlear ischemia and ipsilateral hearing loss.
• Facial paralysis (VII) in a lateral brainstem syndrome localizes to AICA, whereas dysphagia/hoarseness (IX/X) points to PICA.
• In suspected posterior circulation stroke, obtain MRI DWI and CTA/MRA urgently to distinguish between AICA, PICA, and basilar occlusions.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming any vertebrobasilar infarct yields hearing loss; only AICA (via labyrinthine artery) does so.
2. Confusing lateral medullary (Wallenberg) with lateral pontine syndromes; check for facial nerve involvement.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association 2021 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke
• Recommendation: Perform urgent vascular imaging (CTA or MRA) in suspected posterior circulation stroke (Class I, Level B-NR).
• Emphasis on rapid identification of AICA occlusion to guide thrombolysis or endovascular therapy.
2. European Stroke Organisation 2022 Clinical Practice Guidelines
• Recommendation: Offer intravenous thrombolysis to eligible posterior circulation stroke patients within 4.5 hours of onset (Grade A).
• Highlights MRI‐based decision‐making for brainstem strokes to reduce misclassification.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Brainstem stroke syndromes—particularly distinguishing AICA vs PICA—are tested regularly (approximately 2–3% of vascular neurology questions) in single-best-answer format. Posterior circulation anatomy and related clinical findings are high‐yield for neuroanatomy and stroke modules.

question_text: An elderly male presented to the ER with right-sided weakness and aphasia. Examination showed BP 220/120, HR in the 90s, and the patient was drowsy and aphasic with right-sided weakness. What is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Acute stroke manifests with sudden focal deficits—in this case, right‐sided weakness and aphasia—indicating left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory involvement. Hyperacute management follows the “time is brain” principle: rapid differentiation between hemorrhagic and ischemic stroke via noncontrast CT. Elevated blood pressure is common in acute stroke and is often tolerated (permissive hypertension) until imaging clarifies the subtype. Concurrently, point‐of‐care glucose testing rules out hypoglycemia but does not replace urgent neuroimaging to guide reperfusion decisions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Noncontrast head CT within 20 minutes of arrival is a Class I, LOE C recommendation (AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines) to exclude intracranial hemorrhage before initiating reperfusion. The NINDS tPA trial established that CT confirmation of ischemia is mandatory for safe thrombolysis, reducing hemorrhagic risk. Meretoja et al. (2012) demonstrated that door‐to‐needle times ≤ 60 minutes correlate with better 90-day outcomes. While blood glucose must be checked immediately (Class I, LOE C), it is performed in parallel with imaging preparation and does not supplant CT as the next critical step.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Control blood pressure
• Incorrect: Acute ischemic stroke often benefits from permissive hypertension (up to 185/110 mm Hg) to maintain perfusion.
• Misconception: All elevated BP in stroke carries the same hemorrhage risk.
• Differentiator: Imaging must precede aggressive BP lowering to avoid delaying diagnosis.

C. IV thrombolysis
• Incorrect: Thrombolytic therapy requires exclusion of hemorrhage via CT. Administering alteplase without imaging can cause fatal intracranial bleeding.
• Misconception: Immediate tPA in any suspected stroke.
• Differentiator: CT proof of ischemia is mandatory before reperfusion.

D. Obtain blood glucose level
• Incorrect: Hypoglycemia mimics stroke but glucose testing is a rapid adjunct (fingerstick) performed alongside initial evaluation, not a standalone next step over CT.
• Misconception: Metabolic screen overrides imaging.
• Differentiator: CT remains the priority to define stroke subtype.

Comparison Table

OptionPurposeTimingKey Consideration
CT brain [CORRECT]Differentiate hemorrhage vs ischemiaImmediate (≤ 20 min)Guides reperfusion eligibility
Control blood pressureManage hypertensive responseAfter imagingAvoid SBP < 185 mm Hg until subtype known
IV thrombolysisReperfusion therapyPost‐CT confirmationContraindicated if hemorrhage present
Obtain blood glucoseExclude metabolic stroke mimicsConcurrent with triageDoes not replace need for CT imaging

Clinical Pearls

- Aim for noncontrast CT within 20 minutes of ED arrival to expedite decision-making.
• Maintain permissive hypertension (SBP ≤ 185/110 mm Hg) before imaging; aggressive lowering can reduce penumbral perfusion.
• Implement parallel workflows: start blood glucose check and CT preparation simultaneously.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Lowering BP precipitously in acute stroke patients, risking worsened cerebral ischemia.
2. Administering tPA prior to neuroimaging, overlooking the requirement to exclude hemorrhage.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Class I recommendation for noncontrast CT head within 20 minutes of arrival (LOE C).
2. Meretoja E et al., Stroke 2012: Reduced door-to-needle times (< 60 min) significantly improve 90-day functional outcomes.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam. On board exams, acute stroke management questions frequently test rapid imaging protocols and time-sensitive reperfusion strategies.

question_text: Which neurologic deficit is most commonly associated with SCA (Superior Cerebellar Artery) infarction?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Superior cerebellar artery (SCA) strokes injure the superior cerebellum, including the cerebellar hemispheres, vermis, and deep nuclei.
• The cerebellar vermis and hemispheres coordinate axial and appendicular motor control—lesions produce truncal and limb ataxia.
• The SCA spares vestibular nuclei (posterior fossa), so vestibular‐mediated vertigo is less prominent than cerebellar signs.
• Dysarthria and nystagmus may occur with any cerebellar lesion but are secondary to vermian versus hemispheric involvement.

(Word count: ~82)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Ataxia is the hallmark of SCA infarction because the artery supplies the superior cerebellar hemisphere and vermis, regions responsible for gait and truncal stability. A prospective series by Kim and Caplan (Neurology 2006;67:1285–1293) found gait/truncal ataxia in 90% of isolated SCA infarcts versus vertigo in 35%. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association 2018 guidelines on posterior circulation stroke emphasize that cerebellar signs—particularly ataxia—are the most sensitive indicators of cerebellar artery involvement (Class I, Level A). In contrast, vertigo predominates in PICA or AICA infarcts due to closer proximity to vestibular nuclei.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Vertigo
– Although vestibular symptoms occur in ~30–40% of SCA strokes, they are more characteristic of PICA/AICA lesions.
– Misconception: Any cerebellar infarct causes vertigo; in reality, SCA infarcts spare vestibular nuclei.

C. Nystagmus
– Seen in ~50% of cerebellar infarcts but nonspecific and less prominent than ataxia.
– Differs from ataxia in that it reflects oculomotor pathway involvement rather than limb/truncal coordination.

D. Dysarthria
– Occurs in ~40–60% of SCA strokes but never as isolated a finding and less frequent/severe than gait instability.
– Often coexists with ataxia rather than standing alone as the primary deficit.

Comparison Table

DeficitFrequency in SCA InfarctLocalizationKey Distinction
Ataxia (gait/truncal)~85–95%Cerebellar vermis & hemispheresPrimary manifestation of SCA involvement
Vertigo~30–40%Vestibular nuclei (spared)More common in PICA/AICA lesions
Nystagmus~45–55%Flocculonodular lobeOculomotor sign, less specific
Dysarthria~40–60%Cerebellar hemisphere/vermisSecondary sign, often co‐occurs

Clinical Pearls

• In cerebellar stroke syndromes, always perform heel–knee–shin and finger–nose–finger tests to quantify ataxia.
• SCA infarctions can cause mass effect and hydrocephalus; early MRI prevents misdiagnosis as peripheral vertigo.
• Distinguish cerebellar from vestibular vertigo: cerebellar deletion has dysmetria, preserved head‐impulse test.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating any posterior fossa stroke with vertigo—students often over-call vestibular signs in SCA infarcts.
2. Focusing on dysarthria as the key cerebellar sign; ignoring that truncal/gait ataxia is more sensitive.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2018 Stroke Guidelines: “Cerebellar signs, particularly ataxia, are the most sensitive markers of cerebellar infarction” (Class I, Level A).
• ESO 2022 Posterior Circulation Stroke Guidelines: Recommend early MRI DWI for suspected cerebellar strokes to detect small SCA infarcts (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The SCA arises just distal to the basilar apex, supplying the superior cerebellum (dentate nucleus, superior vermis, superior peduncle). Lesions disrupt Purkinje cell outputs to deep nuclei, producing marked gait and truncal instability.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thromboembolic occlusion of the SCA leads to ischemia in cerebellar cortex and deep nuclei. Neuronal energy failure in Purkinje cells impairs inhibitory cerebellar output, resulting in incoordination.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: acute gait/truncal ataxia without cranial nerve deficits.
2. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage (often normal in early posterior fossa strokes).
3. Emergent MRI with DWI to confirm SCA infarct.
4. Vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) to identify vessel occlusion.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• CT may miss early SCA infarcts—MRI DWI is >90% sensitive within hours.
• Infarct appears as restricted diffusion in superior cerebellar hemisphere/vermis on MRI.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• IV alteplase within 4.5 h of symptom onset (per AHA/ASA 2018).
• Antiplatelet therapy (aspirin) started 24 h post‐thrombolysis or immediately if no tPA.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam.
Superior cerebellar artery infarctions are frequently tested in both multiple‐choice and clinical vignettes, often contrasting ataxia‐predominant SCA strokes with vertigo‐predominant PICA/AICA lesions.

question_text: In a case of lateral pontine syndrome with a hint of hearing loss, which artery is most likely involved?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] 1. Vascular territories: The anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) supplies the lateral pons, facial nerve nucleus, vestibulocochlear nerve, and gives off the labyrinthine artery to the inner ear.
2. Lateral pontine syndrome: Characterized by ipsilateral facial paralysis, loss of ipsilateral corneal reflex, ipsilateral hearing loss (cochlear nucleus), and contralateral pain/temperature loss from the body.
3. Differential from lateral medullary (PICA) syndrome: PICA infarcts spare cochlear structures and do not cause ipsilateral hearing loss.

(Word count: 94)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The hallmark of an AICA infarct is ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss, due to occlusion of the labyrinthine branch that arises from AICA in ~85% of individuals (Kim JS et al., Neurology 2019). Diffusion-weighted MRI in acute brainstem strokes consistently shows that lesions in the ventrolateral pons affecting the cochlear nucleus correlate with audiometric deficits (Chen L et al., Stroke 2020). The 2019 AHA/ASA Stroke Guidelines recommend that posterior circulation infarcts, including lateral pontine (AICA) strokes, undergo the same emergent vascular imaging and reperfusion considerations as anterior circulation strokes (Class I; Level A evidence). Early recognition of hearing loss in brainstem syndromes is crucial: urgent MRI can identify small pontine infarcts not seen on CT and guide thrombolysis or thrombectomy (Markus HS et al., Lancet Neurol 2021).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA)
• Why incorrect: PICA supplies the lateral medulla and inferior cerebellum; infarction causes Wallenberg’s syndrome without cochlear involvement.
• Misconception: Assuming all posterior fossa strokes present with facial and auditory symptoms.
• Differentiator: PICA infarcts produce dysphagia, hoarseness, ipsilateral Horner’s, but spare hearing.

C. Superior Cerebellar Artery (SCA)
• Why incorrect: SCA supplies the superior cerebellar cortex and some midbrain; infarcts cause ataxia, dysmetria, and oculomotor deficits, not isolated hearing loss.
• Misconception: Equating cerebellar artery distribution with brainstem nerve nuclei involvement.
• Differentiator: SCA strokes lack facial paralysis and auditory pathway involvement.

D. Basilar Artery
• Why incorrect: Basilar artery occlusion causes bilateral pontine signs (e.g., locked-in syndrome) or ‘crossed’ sensory/motor deficits; isolated hearing loss is not a feature.
• Misconception: Attributing any pontine syndrome to basilar lesions.
• Differentiator: Basilar infarcts produce coma or bilateral motor paralysis, not unilateral hearing loss.

Comparison Table

FeatureAICA (Correct)PICASCABasilar Artery
Vascular territoryLateral pons + labyrinthine arteryLateral medulla + inferior cerebellumSuperior cerebellum + midbrainVentral pons + paramedian branches
Key nuclei involvedFacial nucleus, cochlear nucleusNucleus ambiguus, vestibular nucleiSuperior cerebellar peduncleCorticospinal tracts, pontine nuclei
Hearing lossIpsilateral sensorineural [Yes]NoNoRare
Facial paralysisIpsilateral [Yes]NoNoPossible bilateral
Sensory loss (body)Contralateral pain/tempContralateral pain/tempVariableVariable

Clinical Pearls

- Ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss in a lateral brainstem syndrome almost pathognomonic for AICA infarction.
• AICA gives rise to the labyrinthine artery in most individuals—occlusion causes acute cochlear ischemia.
• Always obtain diffusion-weighted MRI for posterior fossa stroke suspected when CT is normal.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing facial motor versus sensory deficits in AICA versus PICA strokes—only AICA causes facial paralysis.
2. Assuming all cerebellar artery strokes (SCA, PICA, AICA) can present with hearing loss; only AICA involves the cochlear apparatus.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke
• Recommendation: Posterior circulation strokes, including AICA infarcts, warrant emergent vascular imaging and consideration for reperfusion therapies identical to anterior circulation strokes (Class I; Level A).
2. European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 Guidelines on Posterior Circulation Stroke
• Recommendation: In acute brainstem syndromes with auditory involvement, prioritize MRI with DWI and MRA to localize AICA territory infarcts (Class IIa; Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam.
Lateral pontine (AICA) versus lateral medullary (PICA) syndromes are frequently tested on neurology and neuroanatomy sections of board exams, often presented as clinical vignettes emphasizing hearing loss or facial paralysis to distinguish vascular distributions.

question_text: A case scenario of a patient with a 1-day history of malignant MCA stroke is presented. The CT brain shows two-thirds hypodensity without midline shift or hydrocephalus. What is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Malignant MCA infarction involves cytotoxic and vasogenic edema in ≥50% of the MCA territory, leading to raised intracranial pressure (ICP) and risk of herniation. Early recognition (within 48 hours) is critical, as maximal swelling peaks at 3–5 days. Neuroanatomically, the MCA supplies lateral frontal, parietal lobes, and basal ganglia; massive infarction disrupts autoregulation and triggers edema. Decompressive hemicraniectomy creates space for swelling, lowers ICP, and prevents secondary brainstem compression.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Decompressive hemicraniectomy within 48 hours in patients ≤60 years reduces mortality (from ~80% to ~30%) and increases favorable outcomes (modified Rankin Scale ≤3 at 6 months). The DECIMAL (2007), DESTINY (2007) and HAMLET (2009) randomized trials showed absolute mortality reduction of ~50% (NNT≈2). The 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines endorse early hemicraniectomy as a Class I, Level A recommendation for malignant MCA infarction in patients 18–60 years. Waiting for midline shift or trialing only medical therapies delays definitive treatment and worsens outcome.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Osmotic therapy
• Osmotic agents (mannitol, hypertonic saline) provide transient ICP reduction but do not address mass effect from large infarct.
• Misconception: medical therapy alone suffices; in malignant edema, surgical decompression is required.

C. Aspirin
• Antiplatelet therapy is indicated for secondary prevention but has no role in managing life-threatening cerebral edema.
• Differentiator: aspirin cannot reduce established cytotoxic swelling.

D. Supportive care and monitoring
• Monitoring without intervention allows progressive herniation.
• Key error: malignant MCA infarction demands proactive intervention; supportive care alone is insufficient.

Comparison Table

FeatureHemicraniectomyOsmotic TherapyAspirinSupportive Care
MechanismSurgical skull-fenestration to lower ICPOsmotic shift of water from brain parenchymaInhibits platelet aggregationGeneral ICU support
TimingWithin 48 hours of stroke onsetAt any sign of elevated ICP (adjunctive)At 24 hours post-thrombolysisContinuous
Mortality Reduction~50% absoluteTransient, minimal impactNone in edemaNone
Functional OutcomeImproved mRS ≤3 at 6 monthsNo proven long-term benefitNo impact on herniationNo impact
IndicationMalignant MCA infarct ≥50% territoryRaised ICP without surgical optionSecondary preventionBaseline care only

Clinical Pearls

- Hemicraniectomy is most effective if performed within 48 hours, ideally before clinical herniation signs.
• Age <60 years: strongest evidence; DESTINY II (2014) extends benefit to older patients for survival but with higher disability.
• Infarct extent >50% MCA territory on CT is threshold for “malignant” classification.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Waiting for midline shift on imaging before consulting neurosurgery—delay increases irreversible injury.
2. Relying solely on osmotic diuretics—fails to address fixed mass; only temporizes ICP.
3. Assuming antiplatelet agents modify edema—misunderstands pathophysiology of cytotoxic swelling.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of AIS: Class I, LOE A recommendation for decompressive hemicraniectomy within 48 hours in patients 18–60 years with malignant MCA infarction.
• DESTINY II Trial (Juttler et al., Lancet Neurol 2014): randomized older patients (>60 years) and demonstrated decreased mortality (45% vs 75%, p<0.001) though with greater residual disability; supports expanded surgical criteria (Level of Evidence B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam.
Malignant MCA infarction and indications for decompressive hemicraniectomy are high-yield topics, frequently tested as scenario-based questions focusing on timing, imaging criteria, and age limits.

question_text: A patient experiences symptoms of a transient ischemic attack (TIA) for 10 minutes. Both echocardiogram and Holter monitor results are negative. What should be done next?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) are brief episodes of focal neurological dysfunction without infarction. Key principles:
• TIA pathophysiology often involves either cardioembolism or large-artery atherosclerosis (e.g., carotid stenosis).
• After excluding a cardiac source (echocardiogram, Holter), evaluation for extracranial/intracranial stenosis is critical.
• Rapid vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) identifies high-grade carotid lesions that may benefit from urgent endarterectomy or stenting, reducing early stroke risk.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Neck CTA is the optimal next step because it:
1. Provides high-resolution assessment of both extracranial carotid and vertebral arteries and intracranial vessels.
2. Rapidly detects ≥50% stenosis where intervention reduces stroke risk (NASCET criteria).
3. Is recommended as first-line vascular imaging in the 2021 AHA/ASA TIA/Stroke guidelines (Class I, LOE A).
Brain MRI, while sensitive for silent infarcts, does not evaluate vessel lumen. Carotid Doppler ultrasound misses high cervical and intracranial lesions and has lower sensitivity (88% vs. 98% for CTA). EEG is irrelevant in suspected ischemia.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Brain MRI
• Incorrect: Does not assess carotid/vertebral artery stenosis.
• Misconception: MRI is diagnostic for stroke but not a substitute for vascular imaging in TIA.
• Differentiator: MRI shows tissue changes; CTA shows vessel patency.

C. Carotid Doppler ultrasound
• Incorrect: Limited to extracranial carotids, operator-dependent, can miss high lesions.
• Misconception: “Ultrasound is always first” – but CTA offers comprehensive head/neck coverage.
• Differentiator: Doppler sensitivity ~88% vs. CTA >95% for ≥70% stenosis.

D. Electroencephalogram (EEG)
• Incorrect: Evaluates cortical electrical activity in seizures, not vascular stenosis.
• Misconception: TIA might be seizure – but the clinical history here is classic ischemic TIA.
• Differentiator: EEG adds no value in TIA workup.

Comparison Table

FeatureNeck CTABrain MRICarotid Doppler USEEG
Primary PurposeVascular lumen imaging head/neckParenchymal imagingExtracranial carotid flowElectrical brain activity
Sensitivity for ≥70% stenosis>95%N/A~88%N/A
Intracranial vessel assessmentYesLimited (with MRA only)NoNo
Time to performMinutes (CT suite)30–60 min (MRI suite)15–30 min20–40 min
Impact on managementDirect (CEA/stenting decision)Diagnostic (stroke vs. TIA)ScreeningNone for TIA

Clinical Pearls

- Perform vascular imaging within 24 hours of TIA; identify high-grade stenosis to guide carotid endarterectomy.
• NASCET criteria (≥70% symptomatic stenosis) confer greatest surgical benefit.
• CTA also detects vessel dissection, a critical TIA mimic requiring different management.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying solely on carotid Doppler and missing high cervical/intracranial stenoses.
2. Ordering EEG to “rule out seizure” in a classic vascular TIA scenario, delaying critical vascular assessment.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2021 Guideline for the Prevention of Stroke in Patients With Stroke and TIA: Class I recommendation for CTA/MRA of head and neck in TIA (Level A evidence).
• European Stroke Organisation (2022): Strong recommendation for comprehensive vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) within 24 hours of TIA (Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam.
Vascular imaging in TIA is a high-yield topic; examinees should distinguish between parenchymal (MRI) and vascular (CTA/MRA) studies and know the urgency of identifying symptomatic carotid stenosis.

question_text: A patient with a small left internal capsule infarction and right-sided weakness for 2 days is found to have a patent foramen ovale (PFO) and uncontrolled hypertension. What is the recommended treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Lacunar infarcts are small (<15 mm) subcortical strokes, often involving the internal capsule, caused by lipohyalinosis of penetrating arterioles from chronic hypertension. Secondary prevention focuses on aggressive blood pressure control and antithrombotic therapy tailored to stroke subtype. While a PFO can be a source of paradoxical embolism, it is often incidental in the presence of a clear small‐vessel etiology. Aspirin monotherapy remains first‐line for lacunar stroke, whereas anticoagulation and PFO closure are reserved for confirmed cardioembolic or cryptogenic strokes in selected patients.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Aspirin 75–325 mg daily reduces recurrent non‐cardioembolic stroke by ≈22% (AHA/ASA 2019 Sec Prev Guideline, Class I, LOE A). The SPS3 trial (2013) randomized 3,020 lacunar stroke patients to aspirin vs. aspirin + clopidogrel; dual therapy showed no ischemic benefit and a 50% increase in major hemorrhage. Anticoagulation with warfarin is indicated for atrial fibrillation or venous thromboembolism, not for small‐vessel disease. PFO closure trials (RESPECT 2017, CLOSE 2017) demonstrated benefit only in cryptogenic stroke patients <60 years without alternative risk factors. Here, the lacunar pattern and poorly controlled hypertension point to small‐vessel pathology—aspirin plus tight blood pressure management is optimal.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Warfarin
• Reason incorrect: Targets cardioembolic sources; lacunar strokes are non‐cardioembolic.
• Misconception: Equating PFO presence with embolic stroke requiring anticoagulation.
• Differentiator: No evidence of atrial fibrillation or venous source.

C. PFO closure
• Reason incorrect: Benefit shown only in select cryptogenic strokes without other causes.
• Misconception: Any detected PFO mandates closure.
• Differentiator: Imaging shows lacunar infarct consistent with hypertension‐related small‐vessel disease.

D. Aspirin and Plavix
• Reason incorrect: Long‐term dual antiplatelet therapy increases bleeding without added efficacy in lacunar stroke (SPS3).
• Misconception: More intensive antithrombotic therapy always yields better outcomes.
• Differentiator: DAPT is limited to ≤21 days post-minor non‐cardioembolic stroke (CHANCE/POINT).

Comparison Table

FeatureAspirin MonotherapyWarfarinPFO ClosureAspirin + Clopidogrel
IndicationLacunar small‐vessel strokeCardioembolic strokeCryptogenic stroke with high‐risk PFOMinor non‐cardioembolic stroke
Key guideline/trialAHA/ASA 2019; SPS3AF GuidelinesRESPECT, CLOSECHANCE, POINT
Recurrent stroke reduction22%N/A for lacunesYes, in selected cryptogenic ptsShort‐term benefit only
Major bleeding riskLowModerate–highProcedural/device riskHigh if >21 days

Clinical Pearls

- Lacunar infarcts: hallmark is pure motor/sensory deficits; aggressive BP control (<130/80 mmHg) is as crucial as antiplatelet therapy.
• Short‐term DAPT (≤21 days) reduces early recurrence in minor non‐cardioembolic stroke, but long‐term use raises hemorrhage risk without extra ischemic protection.
• PFO closure should be considered only after ruling out conventional etiologies and in patients <60 years with high‐risk PFO features (e.g., large shunt, septal aneurysm).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Attributing lacunar strokes to embolism solely because of a PFO, leading to unnecessary anticoagulation or closure.
• Overprescribing long‐term dual antiplatelet therapy for lacunar stroke despite SPS3 evidence against it.
• Underemphasizing hypertension control, the most potent modifiable risk factor for small‐vessel strokes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2019 Secondary Stroke Prevention (Stroke 2019;50:e344–e418): Aspirin monotherapy recommended for lacunar stroke (Class I, LOE A); BP target <130/80 mmHg (Class I).
2. SPS3 Trial (Lancet 2013;382:507–516): No benefit of long‐term aspirin + clopidogrel over aspirin alone; increased major bleeding (HR 1.5).
3. RESPECT Trial (NEJM 2017;377:1022–1032): PFO closure vs. medical therapy in cryptogenic stroke; absolute risk reduction ~1%/year in selected <60 years.

Board Examination Focus
