This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Board exams frequently test stroke subtype recognition (lacunar vs. cardioembolic), appropriate secondary prevention (antiplatelet vs. anticoagulant), and criteria for PFO closure. Recognizing imaging patterns and risk profiles is high‐yield.

question_text: Q137. A 68-year-old man awoke with slurred speech and left-sided weakness. Noncontrast head CT shows an acute right hemispheric ischemic stroke. His blood pressure is 170/95 mm Hg. He is not a candidate for thrombolysis given unknown time of onset. What is the best next step for blood pressure control?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] - Autoregulation of cerebral blood flow maintains perfusion over a range of mean arterial pressures but shifts upward in chronic hypertension.
• In acute ischemic stroke, elevated BP helps maintain perfusion in the ischemic penumbra (“permissive hypertension”).
• AHA/ASA guidelines recommend treating BP only if systolic >220 mm Hg or diastolic >120 mm Hg in patients not receiving reperfusion therapy.

(Word count: 84)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct response is “No intervention needed.” Per 2018 AHA/ASA Acute Ischemic Stroke Management Guidelines, in patients not eligible for thrombolysis or endovascular therapy, antihypertensive treatment is indicated only if SBP exceeds 220 mm Hg or DBP exceeds 120 mm Hg (Class I; Level of Evidence B-R). Our patient’s BP of 170/95 mm Hg supports permissive hypertension to preserve collateral perfusion of the ischemic penumbra. Lowering BP below this threshold risks expansion of infarct size. Large observational studies correlate more aggressive BP lowering in early stroke with larger final infarct volumes. Randomized trials have not demonstrated benefit from early BP reduction in ischemic stroke absent other indications.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. IV Hydralazine
• Hydralazine causes reflex tachycardia and unpredictable cerebral vasodilation, potentially increasing intracranial pressure.
• Misconception: Any vasodilator is equally acceptable.
• Differentiator: Hydralazine is not recommended in acute ischemic stroke due to hemodynamic instability.

B. IV Labetalol
• While labetalol is the preferred agent when BP lowering is indicated (e.g., SBP >220 mm Hg), our patient’s BP is below the treatment threshold.
• Misconception: Treat all elevated BPs in stroke.
• Differentiator: Threshold-based therapy dictates when labetalol is used.

D. Oral Amlodipine
• Oral agents have slow onset and lack titratability; not recommended for acute BP control in stroke.
• Misconception: Any antihypertensive method will suffice.
• Differentiator: Acute management requires IV agents only when necessary.

Comparison Table

FeatureNo InterventionIV LabetalolIV HydralazineOral Amlodipine
Indication in AIS (no tPA)SBP ≤220 mm HgSBP >220 mm HgRarely usedNot recommended
MechanismPermissive hypertensionα- and β-blockadeDirect arteriolar vasodilationL-type Ca²⁺ channel blockade
Onset of actionN/A2–5 minutes10–20 minutes6–12 hours
Evidence/Class of RecommendationClass I; maintain BP ≤220/120Class I; treat if >220/120Not recommendedNot indicated

Clinical Pearls

- Permissive hypertension up to 220/120 mm Hg is protective in acute ischemic stroke by supporting penumbral perfusion.
• When treating high BP in stroke, IV labetalol or nicardipine are first-line due to rapid onset and titratability.
• Overaggressive BP lowering can worsen neurological outcomes by reducing collateral blood flow.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Treating any elevated BP in acute ischemic stroke, ignoring permissive hypertension guidelines.
2. Using oral antihypertensives or hydralazine with unpredictable cerebral hemodynamics instead of recommended IV agents when treatment is indicated.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommends treating BP only if SBP >220 mm Hg or DBP >120 mm Hg in non-thrombolysis candidates (Class I; Level B-R).
• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 Guidelines: Echoes permissive hypertension strategy; recommends IV labetalol or nicardipine if BP exceeds 220/120 mm Hg (Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. Blood pressure management in acute ischemic stroke is frequently tested in vignette format, emphasizing permissive hypertension thresholds and choice of IV agents when lowering is required.

question_text: A lady on oral contraceptive pills (OCP) presents with seizures and headaches, with a CT scan showing normal results. What is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] • Hypercoagulability and Cerebral Venous Thrombosis (CVT): OCPs increase clotting factors (II, VII, X) and reduce anticoagulants (protein S), predisposing to dural sinus thrombosis.
• Clinical Triad of CVT: headache (often severe), focal neurological deficits or seizures, and signs of intracranial hypertension. A normal non-contrast CT does not exclude CVT in ~30% of cases.
• Imaging Hierarchy: After non-contrast CT, targeted venous imaging (CTV or MR venography) is required to visualize thrombi in dural sinuses.

(Approx. 100 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

CT venography directly visualizes dural venous sinuses, detecting filling defects (e.g., “empty delta sign”) with sensitivity/specificity > 95% (Ferro et al., ISCVT JAMA 2004). The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2011 guidelines recommend CTV or MRV as the diagnostic standard when non-contrast CT is equivocal (Class I, Level B). Early diagnosis allows prompt anticoagulation, improving functional outcomes (Einhäupl et al., ESO 2017). MRI without venography sequences lacks the spatial resolution to reliably detect sinus thrombosis; hence MRI alone is insufficient. EEG evaluates cortical irritability but does not localize venous obstruction. Lumbar puncture risks herniation in raised intracranial pressure and has low yield for CVT.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Lumbar puncture (LP)
• Incorrect: LP opening pressure may be elevated but does not visualize thrombi.
• Misconception: Assuming all headache/seizure workups require LP.
• Differentiator: LP cannot confirm CVT and risks herniation if intracranial pressure is raised.

B. Electroencephalogram (EEG)
• Incorrect: EEG assesses electrical activity post-seizure but cannot diagnose structural vascular lesions.
• Misconception: Seizures always require EEG before imaging.
• Differentiator: EEG findings (e.g., epileptiform discharges) do not identify venous thrombosis.

D. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
• Incorrect: Conventional MRI without MR venography misses up to 25% of dural sinus clots.
• Misconception: MRI is a one-stop modality for all cerebral pathologies.
• Differentiator: MR venography sequences (MRV) are required; plain MRI lacks venous phase imaging.

Comparison Table

FeatureCT Venography (CTV)Lumbar Puncture (LP)EEGMRI (non-venographic)
Diagnostic TargetDural sinus patencyOpening pressure, CSFCortical electrical activityParenchymal signal changes
Sensitivity for CVT> 95%Not applicableNot applicable~ 75% without MRV sequences
Risk in raised ICPLowHerniation riskSafeLow
Time to perform (emergent)~ 10–15 minutes~ 30 minutes~ 60 minutes~ 30–60 minutes

Clinical Pearls

- In OCP users with new-onset headache and seizures, maintain high suspicion for CVT even if non-contrast CT is normal.
• CTV is rapid, widely available in emergency settings, and nearly equivalent to MRV for CVT detection.
• After diagnosis, initiate low-molecular-weight heparin promptly, transitioning to warfarin or DOACs for 3–6 months.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Over-reliance on a normal non-contrast CT: up to 30% of CVT cases are radiographically occult without venous imaging.
2. Performing LP before vascular imaging: risks herniation and delays definitive diagnosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2011 Guidelines on CVT: Recommend CTV or MRV for diagnosis after non-contrast CT (Class I, Level B).
• European Stroke Organization (ESO) 2017 Guidelines: Endorse CTV as first-line venous imaging in acute settings (Level A evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Thrombosis commonly affects the superior sagittal sinus, transverse sinuses, and sigmoid sinus, impairing cortical venous drainage and causing parenchymal edema or hemorrhage.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

OCP-induced hypercoagulability leads to thrombus formation in dural venous sinuses, elevating intracranial pressure and provoking venous infarcts, hemorrhages, and seizures.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Non-contrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
2. If CT normal/suspicious, perform CTV (or MRV).
3. Confirm CVT → start anticoagulation.
4. Evaluate for prothrombotic states.

Neuroimaging Pearls

The “empty delta sign” on contrast-enhanced CTV indicates a filling defect in the superior sagittal sinus. Direct visualization of thrombus via CTV increases diagnostic confidence.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2024 exam. CVT often presents on board exams as OCP-associated headache/seizure vignettes requiring knowledge of CTV/MRV diagnostics.

question_text: Q30. A 74-year-old male presents with a CT brain image showing a large hemorrhage in the cortex. What is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) may arise from hypertension (deep nuclei) or amyloid angiopathy/vascular malformations (lobar cortex). Non-contrast CT rapidly confirms hemorrhage. Vascular imaging then seeks treatable lesions (e.g., aneurysm, AVM).
Key points:
• Lobar hemorrhages warrant early angiographic evaluation for macrovascular causes.
• CT angiography (CTA) is rapid, noninvasive, and sensitive for aneurysms/AVMs.
• Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is gold standard but invasive, reserved when CTA is inconclusive.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CTA is the recommended first-line vascular study in acute lobar ICH. The 2015 AHA/ASA ICH guideline (Hemphill et al., Stroke. 2015;46:2032–2060) gives CTA a Class I, Level B recommendation to identify structural lesions. CTA sensitivity for aneurysms/AVMs approaches 85–95%, with sub-5-minute acquisition in most centers. CTA also identifies the “spot sign,” an independent predictor of hematoma expansion (Delgado Almandoz JO et al., Radiology. 2009;251(1):206–213), guiding hemostatic interventions.
Conventional angiography (DSA) is Class IIa, LOE C—reserved when CTA is nondiagnostic but suspicion remains high. MRI/MRA, while excellent for cavernomas or amyloid microbleeds, has longer acquisition times, limited acute sensitivity for active bleeding, and often is impractical in unstable patients. Observation without vascular imaging risks missing treatable etiologies that alter management.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. MRI
• Incorrect because acute MRI is time-consuming, less reliable for active vessel bleed detection, and less available in unstable ICH patients.
• Misconception: MRI is always superior for brain pathology.
• Differentiator: CTA provides vascular detail in minutes.

C. Conventional angiography
• Incorrect as initial test due to invasiveness, higher complication risk (stroke, groin hematoma), and longer procedure time.
• Misconception: DSA should always precede noninvasive studies.
• Differentiator: Reserve DSA for CTA-negative cases with ongoing suspicion.

D. Observation
• Incorrect because delaying vascular imaging may miss aneurysms/AVMs amenable to intervention, worsening outcomes.
• Misconception: Small or lobar bleeds in the elderly rarely have structural causes.
• Differentiator: Early CTA changes management by identifying treatable lesions.

Comparison Table

ModalitySensitivity for Vascular LesionsInvasivenessAcquisition TimeRole in ICH Workup
CTA~85–95% for AVM/aneurysmLow~5 minutesFirst-line vascular imaging
MRI/MRAModerate for cavernoma, amyloidLow30–60 minutesAdjunct for microbleeds/cavernomas if stable
DSA (Conventional angio)~98%High1–2 hoursConfirmatory when CTA negative but suspicion persists
ObservationN/ANoneN/AInappropriate without vascular evaluation

Clinical Pearls

- In lobar ICH without clear hypertension history, always obtain CTA to exclude macrovascular lesions.
• The CTA “spot sign” predicts hematoma expansion (OR 4.5), prompting aggressive blood pressure and coagulopathy management.
• In renal impairment, use low-osmolar contrast and pre-hydrate; benefits of detecting treatable lesions often outweigh nephrotoxicity risks.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming MRI is the acute vascular study of choice—delay in diagnosis and management can occur.
2. Believing that deep hypertensive bleeds never warrant vascular imaging—atypical presentations (e.g., younger age, lobar location) require CTA.
3. Omitting CTA in elderly lobar hemorrhages, attributing all to amyloid angiopathy without ruling out AVM or aneurysm.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) Guidelines, 2015: Recommends CTA in acute lobar ICH to identify structural lesions (Class I, Level B).
• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) Guidelines, 2019: Endorses early CTA for spontaneous lobar ICH to exclude macrovascular causes (Grade A recommendation).
• Delgado Almandoz JO et al., Radiology. 2009: Prospective cohort demonstrating CTA “spot sign” predicts hematoma expansion (Level II evidence).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Vascular imaging in ICH—especially the role and timing of CTA versus DSA—is a high-yield topic, frequently tested as image-based vignettes and single-best-answer questions on neurology and stroke boards.

question_text: A 36-year-old male sustained a motor vehicle accident and presented with acute blurred vision. Examination shows right homonymous hemianopia. His brain CT revealed left occipital acute infarction. What could explain the stroke mechanism in this case?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Stroke classification (TOAST) divides ischemic stroke by mechanism: large-artery atherosclerosis, cardioembolism, small-vessel occlusion, other determined, and undetermined. Occipital lobe infarcts produce contralateral homonymous hemianopia. In a young trauma patient, consider vascular injury (dissection) leading to thrombus formation and distal embolization. Dissections most often involve the carotid or vertebral arteries after neck trauma, creating an intimal flap and intramural hematoma that can shed emboli into cerebral circulation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Artery-to-artery embolism is correct: motor vehicle collisions commonly cause cervical artery dissection. An intimal tear in the vertebral or carotid artery produces an intramural thrombus, which embolizes distally to occlude cortical branches of the posterior cerebral artery, resulting in occipital infarction and homonymous hemianopia. A meta-analysis (Debette et al., Neurology 2015) showed 85% of traumatic dissections present with embolic strokes. AHA/ASA 2018 guidelines recommend vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) in suspected dissections and antithrombotic therapy to prevent recurrent embolism (Class I, Level B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Large vessel atherosclerosis
• Incorrect: Usually chronic plaque in older patients; acute trauma does not induce rapid atherosclerotic plaque rupture.
• Misconception: Conflating dissection with atherosclerotic plaque disease.

C. Cardioembolic
• Incorrect: No evidence of arrhythmia, intracardiac thrombus, or valvular disease; mechanism here is arterial wall injury, not cardiac source.
• Misconception: Attributing all cortical strokes to the heart without vascular imaging.

D. Small vessel disease
• Incorrect: Causes lacunar infarcts in deep structures (basal ganglia, pons), not large cortical occipital infarcts.
• Misconception: Overextending lacunar syndromes to cortical deficits.

Comparison Table

FeatureArtery-to-Artery EmbolismLarge Vessel AtherosclerosisCardioembolicSmall Vessel Disease
Typical AgeYoung (20–50) post-traumaOlder (>60)Middle–elderly (>50)Middle–elderly (>50)
Imaging FindingsCortical infarctsCortical/subcortical border-zone infarctsCortical, multiple territoriesLacunes (<15 mm) in deep nuclei
Vascular PathologyDissection → thrombusAtherosclerotic plaqueCardiac thrombusLipohyalinosis
MechanismEmbolism from injured arteryIn situ thrombosisEmbolism from heartOcclusion of small penetrating arterioles

Clinical Pearls

1. In trauma patients with focal deficits, always suspect cervical artery dissection and obtain CTA/MRA of head and neck.
2. Occipital lobe strokes manifest as contralateral homonymous hemianopia, often with macular sparing due to dual occipital supply.
3. First-line treatment for cervical artery dissection is antithrombotic therapy (aspirin or anticoagulation), individualized by bleeding risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming trauma must cause hemorrhage; arterial dissections can lead to ischemic stroke without hemorrhage.
• Misidentifying cortical homonymous deficits as occipital migraines or seizure phenomena.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 "Guidelines for Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke"
• Recommendation: Perform CTA/MRA in suspected cervical dissection (Class I, Level B).
2. CADISS Trial (Lancet Neurology 2015)
• Found no significant difference in recurrent stroke between antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy in cervical artery dissection (Level of Evidence A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The posterior cerebral artery (PCA), a branch of the vertebrobasilar system, supplies the occipital cortex. Emboli lodging in PCA branches produce contralateral visual field deficits.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Trauma → intimal tear in cervical artery → intramural hematoma → luminal stenosis and platelet aggregation → distal artery-to-artery emboli → cortical infarction.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect dissection in trauma with focal deficits.
2. Obtain CTA or MRA of head/neck.
3. Identify vessel wall irregularity, “string sign,” or intramural hematoma.
4. Initiate antithrombotic therapy.
5. Follow-up imaging at 3–6 months to ensure vessel healing.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CT may miss early infarction; diffusion-weighted MRI is more sensitive.
• CTA/MRA can detect vessel wall hematoma and flap; digital subtraction angiography remains gold standard but is invasive.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Aspirin 75–325 mg daily is first-line for dissection (Class I, Level B).
• Consider anticoagulation (e.g., heparin to warfarin) in select cases based on CADISS trial data.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. It exemplifies classic testing on trauma-related arterial dissection, emphasizing TOAST classification and vascular imaging in young stroke patients.

question_text: A 61-year-old female presented with sudden severe headache, worsened with double vision. Examination shows a 6 mm right pupil that is non-reactive to light. Which artery is likely affected?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] 1. Oculomotor (III) nerve anatomy: motor fibers (medial) and parasympathetic fibers (superficial) travel together; compressive lesions selectively impair peripheral parasympathetic fibers first, causing pupil dilation.
2. Aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage classically presents with “thunderclap” headache (“worst headache of life”) and may produce acute cranial nerve palsies via mass effect.
3. The posterior communicating artery (PCom) arises from the internal carotid and lies adjacent to CN III; aneurysms here compress the nerve and cause an ipsilateral dilated, non-reactive pupil.
(Word count: 102)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Posterior communicating artery aneurysms account for up to 50% of internal carotid aneurysms presenting with oculomotor palsy. The peripheral location of parasympathetic fibers makes them more vulnerable to compression; this explains the early pupillary involvement seen here. Aneurysm rupture into the subarachnoid space produces a sudden, severe headache (AHA/ASA 2022 guidelines recommend emergent non-contrast CT followed by CT angiography [Class I, Level B]). Early diagnosis and microsurgical clipping or endovascular coiling reduce rebleeding risk (ISAT trial 2005; long-term follow-up in Lancet Neurology 2023 confirms coiling superiority in suitable PCom aneurysms).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Anterior communicating artery
• Incorrect: ACom aneurysms predominantly impinge on the optic chiasm or frontal lobes, causing visual field deficits or personality changes, not CN III palsy.
• Misconception: Confusing location near optic apparatus with oculomotor nerve anatomy.
• Differentiation: ACom lesions rarely present with isolated third nerve signs.

C. Superior cerebellar artery
• Incorrect: SCA arises from the basilar artery near CN III exit but aneurysms here rarely compress the nerve; patients develop ataxia or cerebellar signs.
• Misconception: Any posterior circulation aneurysm can involve CN III.
• Differentiation: SCA aneurysms more often cause cerebellar dysfunction and headache without isolated pupillary dilation.

D. Internal carotid artery dissection
• Incorrect: Dissection causes ipsilateral Horner syndrome (miosis, ptosis), not dilated pupil.
• Misconception: Attributing sudden headache + oculomotor signs to any ICA pathology.
• Differentiation: In dissection the pupil is constricted due to sympathetic chain disruption.

Comparison Table

FeaturePCom Aneurysm (Correct)ACom AneurysmSCA AneurysmICA Dissection
LocationICA–PCom junctionACom (between ACAs)Basilar–SCA junctionCervical ICA
Cranial nerve III involvementYes (pupil dilatation + palsy)NoRareNo (Horner syndrome)
HeadacheThunderclap, SAHSAHSAH or focal headacheNeck pain, headache
Other signsPtosis, “down and out” eyeVisual field cuts, memory lossAtaxia, dysmetriaPtosis with miosis

Clinical Pearls

- Compressive III palsy (aneurysm/tumor) = pupil involvement; ischemic (diabetic) III palsy = pupil-sparing.
• In acute pupil-involving CN III palsy, obtain non-contrast CT ± CTA emergently to exclude PCom aneurysm.
• Nimodipine improves outcome in aneurysmal SAH by reducing vasospasm (AHA/ASA 2022).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing miosis of Horner syndrome (ICA dissection) with dilated pupil in III palsy.
2. Assuming all posterior circulation aneurysms (e.g., SCA, PCA) equally cause oculomotor palsy—only PCom lies in direct contact with CN III.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2022 Guideline for Management of Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
­– Recommendation: Non-contrast CT followed by CTA or DSA in any suspected aneurysmal SAH with cranial nerve palsy (Class I, Level B).
2. International Subarachnoid Aneurysm Trial (ISAT) long-term follow-up, Lancet Neurol 2023
­– Finding: Endovascular coiling of PCom aneurysms reduces 5-year morbidity compared to clipping in selected patients.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The oculomotor nerve exits the midbrain medial to the superior cerebellar artery and lateral to the PCA, then courses between the PCA and superior cerebellar artery before running adjacent to the PCom; superficial parasympathetic fibers on the nerve’s periphery mediate pupillary constriction.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Aneurysmal dilation at the PCom segment exerts mass effect on the adjacent oculomotor nerve, compressing peripheral parasympathetic fibers first (causing mydriasis) and then motor fibers (ptosis, “down and out” deviation).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical identification of pupil-involving CN III palsy + thunderclap headache
2. Immediate non-contrast head CT to detect SAH
3. CT angiography for aneurysm localization
4. Digital subtraction angiography if CTA equivocal
5. Neurosurgical consultation for clipping vs endovascular coiling

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CT angiography >95% sensitive for aneurysms >3 mm.
• “Fusiform dilation” at the ICA–PCom junction on CTA is pathognomonic.
• DSA remains gold standard for small aneurysms and surgical planning.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Nimodipine 60 mg orally every 4 hours for 21 days post-SAH to prevent vasospasm.
• Blood pressure control: systolic 120–160 mm Hg, avoid hypotension.
• Analgesia with acetaminophen; avoid NSAIDs to reduce bleeding risk.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. On neurology board exams, pupil-involving third nerve palsy with “thunderclap” headache is a classic vignette for PCom aneurysm; students should rapidly differentiate compressive vs ischemic etiologies and know emergent imaging steps.

question_text: A brain MRI shows unilateral watershed infarction. What is the likely mechanism?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Watershed (border-zone) infarctions occur at junctions between major cerebral artery territories (most often ACA-MCA or MCA-PCA). These distal arterioles rely on adequate perfusion pressure and are most vulnerable when systemic or regional blood flow falls. Imaging shows wedge-shaped or linear DWI hyperintensities parallel to the cortical surface. Unilateral watershed patterns typically reflect focal hypoperfusion rather than embolic occlusion. Key terms: perfusion pressure, collateral circulation, hemodynamic stroke. Differentiating hemodynamic from embolic patterns is critical for targeted workup and management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Hypoperfusion is the direct pathophysiologic mechanism in watershed infarcts. The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke classify border-zone infarctions under hemodynamic strokes due to reduced perfusion pressure (Class IIa, Level B-R). Bang et al. (Stroke.2011;42:391-397) demonstrated that patients with ≥70% ipsilateral ICA stenosis displayed ACA-MCA watershed infarcts on MRI, correlated with prolonged time-to-peak on CT perfusion. Distal arterioles in these zones have limited collateral support; when systemic blood pressure or carotid inflow drops below autoregulatory thresholds, cytotoxic edema ensues, seen as DWI hyperintensity. Thus, hypoperfusion—often secondary to large-artery stenosis—is the immediate mechanism.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Internal carotid artery (ICA) stenosis
– Incorrect because stenosis is an underlying etiology, not the direct mechanism.
– Misconception: equating cause with mechanism.
– Differentiator: steno­sis leads to hypoperfusion; the mechanism is reduced cerebral blood flow.

B. Cardiac embolism
– Emboli lodge in cortical branch arteries causing territorial infarcts, not border-zone patterns.
– Misconception: assuming all cortical infarcts are embolic.
– Differentiator: embolic strokes produce wedge-shaped territorial lesions with abrupt diffusion/ADC changes.

D. Venous thrombosis
– Venous outflow obstruction causes hemorrhagic infarcts with vasogenic edema, often in deep or cortical veins.
– Misconception: conflating venous infarcts with arterial border-zone strokes.
– Differentiator: venous infarcts show mixed signal on T1/T2 with possible hemorrhage, not pure DWI wedge shapes.

Comparison Table

FeatureHypoperfusionICA StenosisCardiac EmbolismVenous Thrombosis
Pathophysiology↓ Perfusion pressureAtherosclerotic narrowingEmbolic arterial occlusionImpaired venous drainage
MRI DWI PatternBorder-zone wedge/linearMay show border-zone if severeTerritorial cortical infarctHemorrhagic, ill-defined
Collateral DependenceHigh in distal arteriolesVariable based on Circle of WillisNot relevantNot relevant
Acute Perfusion ImagingDelayed time-to-peakProlonged in ipsilateral hemisphereFocal perfusion deficitMixed arterial/venous flow

Clinical Pearls

- In acute watershed infarcts, avoid aggressive antihypertensive therapy to preserve collateral perfusion.
• Carotid duplex ultrasound is first-line to detect high-grade ICA stenosis in suspected hemodynamic strokes.
• CT/MR perfusion imaging differentiates hypoperfusion from embolic penumbra, guiding revascularization decisions.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking cortical watershed infarcts for lacunar strokes; lacunes are small (<15 mm), subcortical, due to small-vessel lipohyalinosis.
2. Attributing all cortical infarctions to embolism without assessing hemodynamic factors like carotid stenosis or systemic hypotension.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guideline on Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommends carotid endarterectomy for symptomatic 70–99% ICA stenosis to prevent recurrent hemodynamic strokes (Class I, Level A).
• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 Guideline: Advocates routine perfusion imaging in acute stroke to distinguish hemodynamic from embolic mechanisms, optimizing reperfusion strategies (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Watershed zones lie at the distal territories of ACA-MCA (anterior border zone, “V”-shaped along the convexity) and MCA-PCA (posterior border zone, occipital‐parietal junction). These regions have the lowest perfusion reserve and are first to infarct when cerebral perfusion pressure falls.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Reduced perfusion pressure—due to systemic hypotension or proximal arterial stenosis—drops below autoregulatory capacity in distal arterioles. Oxygen deprivation triggers failure of ion pumps, leading to cytotoxic edema and infarction in border-zone territories.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. MRI with DWI/ADC to confirm watershed pattern.
2. CT/MR perfusion imaging to quantify cerebral blood flow/volume and mean transit time.
3. Carotid duplex ultrasound or CT angiography for ICA stenosis.
4. Echocardiography and ECG to exclude cardioembolic sources.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- DWI: Wedge-shaped hyperintensities parallel to cortical surface in border zones.
• MR angiography/CTA: Identifies high-grade carotid stenosis or occlusion.
• Perfusion maps: Show prolonged time-to-peak and decreased cerebral blood flow in affected regions.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Watershed infarction patterns are frequently tested to assess differentiation between hemodynamic and embolic stroke mechanisms; examine imaging distribution and clinical context to select the appropriate pathophysiologic explanation.

question_text: A lady with a two-day history of malignant left middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke and midline shift (CT was attached) was transferred from another hospital. What will you do for her?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Malignant MCA infarction involves extensive cortical and subcortical ischemia leading to cytotoxic and vasogenic edema that peaks 48–72 h after onset. Because the skull is a fixed volume (Monro-Kellie doctrine), this edema causes intracranial hypertension, midline shift, and risk of transtentorial herniation. Decompressive hemicraniectomy (DHC) removes a large bone flap and opens the dura to accommodate swollen brain tissue, rapidly lowering intracranial pressure (ICP) and preventing secondary ischemic injury. Key concepts: 1) Pathophysiology of cytotoxic vs vasogenic edema; 2) ICP dynamics and herniation syndromes; 3) Time-dependent intervention within 48 h.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Decompressive hemicraniectomy within 48 h for malignant MCA infarction in patients ≤60 years reduces 12-month mortality from ~80 % to ~30–40 % and increases chances of favorable functional outcome (mRS 0–4). This is supported by three randomized controlled trials—DECIMAL (2007), DESTINY (2007), HAMLET (2009)—and a pooled meta-analysis (Vahedi et al., 2009). The 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines give DHC a Class I, Level A recommendation for these patients. By providing immediate relief of ICP, DHC preserves cerebral perfusion and prevents fatal herniation, benefits not matched by medical therapy alone.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Medical management with osmotic agents
• Only provides transient ICP reduction, without expanding intracranial volume capacity.
• Common misconception: osmotherapy suffices to manage malignant edema.
• Does not lower mortality or improve functional outcomes significantly.

C. Anticoagulation therapy
• High risk of hemorrhagic transformation in large infarcts; no role in acute malignant MCA.
• Misconception: extending cardioembolic stroke protocols to massive infarctions.
• Fails to address life-threatening mass effect.

D. Thrombolysis
• Therapeutic window is ≤4.5 h; at 48 h post-stroke, tPA is contraindicated.
• Misconception: tPA can reverse established edema.
• Does not mitigate cytotoxic and vasogenic edema once infarction is completed.

Comparison Table

InterventionMechanismTiming WindowMortality BenefitEvidence Level
Decompressive hemicraniectomySurgical decompression ↓ICP≤48 h↓Mortality by ~50 %Class I, Level A
Osmotic agents (mannitol/hypertonic)Osmotic dehydrationAnyNo significant mortality ↓Class IIb, Level C
Anticoagulation (heparin/warfarin)Thrombosis preventionAcute↑Hemorrhage riskNot recommended
Thrombolysis (tPA)Fibrinolysis≤4.5 h↓Disability in small strokesClass I, Level A

Clinical Pearls

- Initiate neurosurgical consultation within 24 h in suspected malignant MCA infarction.
• DHC offers greatest benefit in patients ≤60 years; DESTINY II supports selective use in older patients.
• A bone flap ≥12 cm with duraplasty maximizes decompression.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Waiting for clinical deterioration rather than acting on imaging-based criteria may miss the surgical window.
• Overreliance on hyperosmolar therapy can delay definitive treatment.
• Misapplication of thrombolysis or anticoagulation beyond approved time windows in large infarcts.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Class I, Level A recommendation for DHC in malignant MCA infarction ≤48 h in patients ≤60 years.
2. DESTINY II Trial (2019): Demonstrated mortality reduction with DHC in patients >60 years, supporting Class IIa, Level B recommendation for selected older adults.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Malignant MCA infarction and indication/timing for decompressive hemicraniectomy are frequently tested as single-best-answer items, often incorporating patient age, imaging criteria, and outcome data.

question_text: For patients with intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) whose INR is elevated because of vitamin K antagonists (VKAs), what should be done?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] • Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) involves bleeding into brain parenchyma, causing mass effect, tissue injury, and perihematomal edema.
• VKAs (e.g., warfarin) inhibit vitamin K epoxide reductase, reducing γ-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X, thereby elevating INR and exacerbating bleeding.
• Rapid normalization of INR is critical to limit hematoma expansion and improve outcomes; this requires both vitamin K (to restore endogenous factor synthesis) and factor replacement (PCC preferred).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A is correct because withholding the VKA and administering vitamin K addresses the root cause (vitamin K–dependent factor deficiency) and begins synthesis of new clotting factors within hours. The 2015 AHA/ASA ICH guidelines (Class I, Level A) mandate immediate reversal of VKA-associated coagulopathy with IV vitamin K (5–10 mg) plus four-factor PCC. Trials such as Sarode et al. (NEJM 2013) demonstrated that four-factor PCC normalizes INR in a median of 30 minutes in 70% of patients versus 10% with FFP (p<0.001), reducing hematoma growth without increased thrombosis. Neither rFVIIa (off-label, high thrombosis risk, no functional benefit) nor FFP alone (slow infusion, large volume, delayed INR correction) substitute for targeted vitamin K–mediated factor regeneration.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Continue VKA therapy
• Incorrect: perpetuates coagulopathy, risking hematoma expansion.
• Misconception: maintaining anticoagulation for stroke prevention outweighs acute hemorrhage risk.
• Differentiator: acute ICH management prioritizes hemostasis over long-term anticoagulation.

C. Administer rFVIIa
• Incorrect: rFVIIa can transiently correct INR but has no proven outcome benefit in ICH and carries a high arterial and venous thrombosis risk (up to 10%).
• Misconception: any factor concentrate is equally safe/effective.
• Differentiator: rFVIIa lacks vitamin K–dependent factor support and is not guideline-endorsed for VKA reversal in ICH.

D. Administer fresh frozen plasma
• Incorrect as sole therapy: FFP requires blood typing, thawing, and large volumes (≈15 mL/kg), delaying reversal; slower INR correction compared to PCC.
• Misconception: FFP is first-line when PCC is unavailable.
• Differentiator: FFP is a backup when PCC is unavailable; vitamin K remains mandatory.

Comparison Table

FeatureVitamin K (withhold VKA)Continue VKArFVIIaFFP
INR Correction Onset6–12 h (endogenous)NoneImmediate, short-lived4–6 h (volume-dependent)
Hematoma Expansion Risk↓↑↔/↑ (thrombosis)↓ (slower than PCC)
Volume RequirementMinimalN/AMinimalHigh (≈15 mL/kg)
Thrombosis RiskLowN/AHighModerate
Guideline Endorsement (ICH)I (Class I, LOE A)ContraindicatedIIb/CIIb/C

Clinical Pearls

• In warfarin-related ICH, always co-administer IV vitamin K with factor replacement (PCC preferred).
• Four-factor PCC achieves INR <1.4 within 30 minutes in most patients; FFP is only if PCC is unavailable.
• Subcutaneous vitamin K is too slow; always use the IV route (5–10 mg) for acute ICH.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying solely on FFP delays INR normalization and risks volume overload in older or heart-failure patients.
2. Assuming rFVIIa is safer than PCC; it increases arterial thromboses without improving neurologic outcomes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA ICH Guidelines 2015: “IV vitamin K (5–10 mg) plus four-factor PCC for VKA reversal in ICH” (Class I, LOE A).
• Sarode R. et al., NEJM 2013: Four-factor PCC achieved rapid INR reversal (median 30 min vs 4 h with FFP; p<0.001) with fewer transfusion complications.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Warfarin blocks vitamin K epoxide reductase → insufficient γ-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, X → impaired prothrombin activation → prolonged INR → unchecked bleeding in ruptured cerebral vessels → hematoma growth exacerbates intracranial pressure and secondary injury.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Vitamin K (IV 5–10 mg): restores γ-carboxylation of vitamin K–dependent factors over 6–12 h.
• Four-factor PCC (25–50 IU/kg): provides immediate clotting factors II, VII, IX, X; normalizes INR within 30 min.
• FFP (15 mL/kg): slower INR correction, requires thawing and blood-type matching.
• rFVIIa: generates thrombin burst locally but lacks sustained factor support; off-label in ICH.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Warfarin reversal in ICH is a high-yield topic, frequently tested as a single best-answer scenario on acute stroke management.

question_text: An 82-year-old female with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia presents with sudden left gaze preference and aphasia. Her basic labs are fine. She has no contraindications for a brain CT. What is the time from symptom onset to ER arrival?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Acute ischemic stroke involving the middle cerebral artery (MCA) often produces conjugate gaze deviation toward the lesion side (due to frontal eye field involvement) and dominant‐hemisphere aphasia. Rapid reperfusion within the hyperacute window minimizes infarct core growth and maximizes penumbral salvage. Key time metrics include:
• Onset‐to‐door (prehospital delay)
• Door‐to‐CT (target <25 min)
• Door‐to‐needle for IV alteplase (target <60 min)
Onset‐to‐door time informs eligibility for IV thrombolysis (within 4.5 h) and endovascular therapy (up to 24 h in selected cases). In this patient, calculating the precise onset‐to‐door interval is critical for timely management and prognosis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. 60 minutes
• Incorrect because it reflects the recommended door-to-needle interval for IV alteplase, not the prehospital onset-to-door time.
• Misconception: conflating in-hospital process targets with prehospital delay.
• Differentiator: this patient arrived in half that time, allowing extra margin for imaging and laboratory confirmation.

C. 90 minutes
• Incorrect: overestimates prehospital delay, underappreciating exponential infarct core expansion beyond the hyperacute window.
• Misconception: assuming average EMS transport times rather than actual witnessed arrival.
• Differentiator: at 90 min, penumbral salvage declines by ~25% compared with 30 min.

D. 120 minutes
• Incorrect: far exceeds hyperacute onset-to-door ideal, reflecting a 2-hour delay that would markedly reduce thrombolysis benefit.
• Misconception: confusing extended mechanical thrombectomy windows (6–24 h) with onset-to-door metrics.
• Differentiator: this patient was in the ED within 30 min, enabling rapid CT and reperfusion.

Comparison Table

OptionOnset-to-Door IntervalClassificationImpact on Reperfusion Efficacy
A. 30 min [CORRECT]30 minHyperacute (<1 h)Maximal penumbra salvage; ideal for tPA
B. 60 min60 minEarly acute (1 h)Good salvage; meets door-to-needle target
C. 90 min90 minEarly acute (1–3 h)Reduced salvage; ongoing core growth
D. 120 min120 minEarly acute (2–4.5 h)Significantly reduced benefit

Clinical Pearls

• Every minute of large‐vessel occlusion costs ~1.9 million neurons – “time is brain” underscores urgency.
• Prehospital stroke protocols with EMS prenotification can reduce onset-to-door by 10–15 minutes.
• 목표 door-to-CT is <25 minutes and door-to-needle for IV alteplase is <60 minutes (AHA/ASA 2021).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Students often mix up onset-to-door (prehospital) with door-to-needle (in-hospital) time targets, leading to miscalculated eligibility windows.
• Overreliance on average EMS transport times can obscure the actual witness of symptom onset and arrival times.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of AIS (Powers WJ et al., Stroke 2021):
• Class I, Level A: Document precise time of symptom onset and onset-to-door interval; target door-to-CT ≤25 min and door-to-needle ≤60 min.
2. ESO Guidelines on Acute Stroke Management (Campbell BCV et al., Eur Stroke J 2021):
• Level B: Recommend mobile stroke units with onboard CT to reduce onset-to-treatment times by ~30 min, improving 90-day functional outcomes.

Board Examination Focus

Time‐based metrics in acute ischemic stroke (onset-to-door, door-to-CT, door-to-needle) are high‐yield and frequently tested in neurology board exams, often presented as hyperacute stroke vignettes requiring recall of specific minute targets. This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is A. 30 minutes. This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

question_text: A scenario of an 82-year-old lady with ischemic stroke presented within 1 hour and has no contraindications. What is the appropriate treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Acute ischemic stroke arises from an arterial occlusion that deprives brain tissue of oxygen, creating an ischemic core and surrounding penumbra. Rapid reperfusion of the penumbra is critical to salvage viable tissue. Intravenous thrombolysis with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) targets fibrin clots, restoring perfusion if administered within a 4.5-hour window. Key prerequisites include noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage, assessment of contraindications (e.g., recent surgery, bleeding diathesis), and stabilization of blood pressure (≤185/110 mm Hg).

Evidence-Based Analysis

tPA (alteplase) is the only FDA-approved pharmacologic reperfusion therapy for acute ischemic stroke within 4.5 hours of onset. The landmark NINDS trial (1995) demonstrated a 30% relative increase in favorable outcomes at 3 months (NINDS tPA Study Group, 1995; level I evidence). The 2019 AHA/ASA guideline update reconfirms IV alteplase as first-line reperfusion in eligible patients presenting within 4.5 hours (Powers et al., Stroke 2019). Later trials (EXTEND, WAKE-UP) have explored extended windows with perfusion imaging, but standard practice remains administration as soon as possible. Age >80 years alone is not a contraindication (ECASS III subgroup analysis).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Aspirin
• Incorrect because antiplatelet therapy reduces recurrence risk but does not acutely lyse clot.
• Misconception: equating antiplatelet effect with thrombolysis.
• Differentiator: aspirin onset is slower, not reperfusion therapy.

C. Mechanical thrombectomy
• While indicated for large-vessel occlusions up to 24 hours, it is used adjunctively after IV tPA or when tPA is contraindicated and after vascular imaging confirmation.
• Misconception: mechanical removal replaces pharmacologic therapy in all eligible patients.
• Differentiator: requires angiography suite and is not universally available within the first hour.

D. Supportive care only
• Passive management without reperfusion leads to larger infarct volumes and worse functional outcomes.
• Misconception: age alone justifies withholding active therapy.
• Differentiator: supportive care is for patients with contraindications to reperfusion.

Comparison Table

FeaturetPA (Alteplase)AspirinMechanical ThrombectomySupportive Care
IndicationAcute ischemic stroke ≤4.5 hSecondary prevention post-strokeLarge-vessel occlusion ≤24 hContraindications to reperfusion
MechanismFibrinolysis via plasminogenCOX-1 inhibition, antiplateletPhysical clot retrievalHemodynamic/respiratory support
Level of EvidenceLevel I (NINDS, ECASS III)Level I (aspirin trials)Level I (MR CLEAN, DAWN)No reperfusion data
Time to initiateASAP, door-to-needle <60 minAny time after CT excludes bleedAfter vascular imagingContinuous

Clinical Pearls

• Door-to-needle time should be ≤60 minutes; pre-notification and stroke protocols reduce delays.
• Maintain BP ≤185/110 mm Hg prior to tPA; permissive hypertension allowed post-tPA.
• Advanced imaging (CT perfusion) can identify penumbra for extended-window interventions but does not delay standard IV tPA.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Administering aspirin before confirming hemorrhage exclusion—antiplatelets should follow, not precede, tPA.
2. Withholding tPA solely based on advanced age—over-80s still derive benefit per ECASS III and AHA guidance.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines (Powers et al., Stroke 2019): Recommends IV alteplase for eligible patients within 4.5 hours (Class I, Level A).
• DAWN Trial (2018): Supports thrombectomy in selected patients up to 24 hours with mismatch criteria (Class I, Level B-R).
• EXTEND Trial (2020): Demonstrated benefit of IV alteplase in 4.5–9 hour window guided by perfusion imaging (ongoing incorporation).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Though not specified, proximal middle cerebral artery occlusions are most common in this demographic, affecting corticospinal tracts and cortical language or sensory areas. Rapid reperfusion preserves both motor pathways and association cortex.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

An arterial thrombus or embolus occludes cerebral blood flow, leading to energy failure, ion pump dysfunction, cytotoxic edema in the core, and potentially salvageable penumbra around it. tPA converts plasminogen to plasmin, degrading fibrin and restoring perfusion.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam.
Acute stroke management—particularly indications and time windows for IV thrombolysis—is a high-yield topic, frequently tested as single best-answer items focusing on eligibility, contraindications, and door-to-needle metrics.

question_text: Q32. A patient presents with an intracranial bleed. What is the recommended blood pressure management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) leads to hematoma formation; elevated blood pressure drives hematoma expansion and worsens perihematomal edema. Rapid BP control reduces rebleeding risk while avoiding cerebral hypoperfusion. Key terms: systolic blood pressure (SBP), diastolic blood pressure (DBP), hematoma expansion, and perfusion–pressure autoregulation. Thresholds are based on large trials balancing safety and efficacy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A (140/90) aligns with the 2022 AHA/ASA ICH guidelines (Class I, Level A), which recommend lowering SBP to 140 mm Hg in patients presenting with SBP between 150 and 220 mm Hg. The INTERACT2 trial (Anderson et al., Lancet 2013) demonstrated a trend toward improved functional outcomes with intensive SBP reduction to <140 mm Hg. ATACH-II (Qureshi et al., NEJM 2016) showed no added benefit—and possible renal adverse events—of ultra-intensive lowering (110–139 mm Hg) versus standard (<180 mm Hg). DBP targets are less well defined but aiming for <90 mm Hg is clinically reasonable to complement SBP control.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. 160/90
• Incorrect: older practice permitted SBP up to 160 mm Hg, but post-INTERACT2 this is suboptimal.
• Misconception: equating historical thresholds with current evidence.
• Differentiator: higher SBP allows continued hematoma growth.

C. 180/110
• Incorrect: SBP ≥180 mm Hg markedly increases rebleeding risk and mortality.
• Misconception: confusing ischemic stroke BP thresholds (pre-thrombolysis) with hemorrhage management.
• Differentiator: this level is contraindicated in ICH.

D. 120/80
• Incorrect: overly aggressive lowering risks cerebral ischemia by surpassing the lower limit of autoregulation.
• Misconception: “lower is always better” without regard for perfusion.
• Differentiator: no trial supports SBP <120 mm Hg in acute ICH; may reduce cerebral blood flow.

Comparison Table

OptionSBP/DBP TargetRationaleEvidence/Risk
A. 140/90SBP 140 mm Hg, DBP <90 mm HgOptimizes hemostasis vs perfusionINTERACT2 benefit; AHA/ASA I
B. 160/90SBP 160 mm Hg, DBP <90 mm HgHistorical standardGreater hematoma expansion
C. 180/110SBP 180 mm Hg, DBP 110 mm HgToo permissive↑ Rebleeding, mortality
D. 120/80SBP 120 mm Hg, DBP 80 mm HgOverly stringentRisk of ischemia, renal injury

Clinical Pearls

- Target SBP 140 mm Hg in acute ICH to reduce hematoma growth without risking hypoperfusion.
• Use continuous IV infusions (nicardipine preferred) with frequent BP monitoring (every 5–15 min).
• Avoid rapid drops >60 mm Hg in SBP to prevent cerebral ischemia.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Conflating ischemic stroke BP goals (>180/105 mm Hg for thrombolysis) with hemorrhage management.
2. Assuming “the lower the better” without regard to autoregulatory limits, leading to cerebral hypoperfusion.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2022 Guidelines for ICH Management (Class I, LOE B-R): Recommend SBP reduction to 140 mm Hg in SBP 150–220 mm Hg.
• Anderson CS et al., INTERACT2 (Lancet 2013): Intensive SBP lowering (<140 mm Hg) improved functional outcomes in ordinal analysis.
• Qureshi AI et al., ATACH-II (NEJM 2016): No outcome benefit of ultra-intensive SBP target (110–139 mm Hg) vs standard (<180 mm Hg); ↑ renal events.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: IV nicardipine infusion (starting 5 mg/h, titrate by 2.5 mg/h every 5 min).
• Alternatives: IV labetalol boluses (10–20 mg q10 min) or infusion.
• Avoid: nitroprusside (risk of increased intracranial pressure) and oral agents initially.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Management of acute ICH blood pressure is frequently tested as single-best-answer questions, often referencing INTERACT2 or AHA/ASA guidelines.

question_text: A patient with an acute stroke in the left occipital lobe will exhibit which of the following in their visual fields?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] - Visual pathways: fibers from each retina cross at the optic chiasm and project via optic tracts into the lateral geniculate nucleus, then through optic radiations to the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobes.
• Homonymous field defects: lesions posterior to the chiasm cause same-sided visual field losses in both eyes; “congruent” when defect shapes in both eyes closely match (occipital lobe) versus “incongruent” when they differ (optic tract or radiations).
• Macular sparing: the central 5°–10° of vision often preserved in occipital strokes due to dual blood supply from the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) and collateral MCA branches.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A is correct. In a left occipital lobe infarct, patients classically develop a right homonymous hemianopia that is highly congruent (tightly aligned defects) because fibers are compacted in the cortex. Macular sparing occurs in approximately 60–70% of PCA territory infarctions due to collateral flow from distal middle cerebral artery branches supplying the occipital pole (Biousse et al., Neurology 2003). The 2018 AHA/ASA Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines recommend prompt neuroimaging with diffusion-weighted MRI to confirm PCA infarction and awareness of cortical visual deficits (Level A evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Incongruent homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing
• Why incorrect: Incongruency implies misalignment of field defects between eyes, characteristic of lesions in the optic tract or parietal optic radiations, not the occipital cortex.
• Misconception: Believing macular sparing can occur at any posterior lesion level; in fact, incongruent defects reflect fiber dispersion before the cortex.

C. Non-macular sparing with congruent homonymous hemianopia
• Why incorrect: Lack of macular sparing would require complete PCA infarction including macular branches, which is uncommon. Most occipital cortical lesions spare the macula.
• Misconception: Assuming congruency alone localizes to occipital lobe without considering vascular collateralization.

D. Non-macular sparing with incongruent homonymous hemianopia
• Why incorrect: Combines features typical of optic radiation (incongruency) and a rare complete PCA infarct (no macular sparing). This pattern is not seen in isolated occipital lobe strokes.
• Misconception: Conflating uncommon patterns into a single lesion site.

Comparison Table

FeatureA. Congruent + Sparing (Correct)B. Incongruent + SparingC. Congruent + Non-sparingD. Incongruent + Non-sparing
CongruencyYesNoYesNo
Macular SparingYesYesNoNo
Lesion LocationOccipital cortex (calcarine)Optic tract/parietal radiationsOccipital cortex + macular branchesOptic radiations (Meyer's loop)
Vascular SupplyPCA ± MCA collateralsPCA onlyPCA including macular branchPCA (no collateral coverage)

Clinical Pearls

- Always test central vision separately by asking patients to fixate and report any blur or loss near direct gaze; this assesses macular sparing.
• Automated perimetry (Humphrey) is more sensitive than confrontation for subtle congruent defects.
• A small occipital pole lesion may produce isolated quadrantanopia; bilateral lesions can cause cortical blindness.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating any homonymous hemianopia with occipital lobe strokes without assessing congruency; tract lesions yield incongruent defects.
2. Assuming macular sparing is universal; extensive PCA infarcts can abolish central vision, though uncommonly.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke (2018, updated 2019): Recommends emergent MRI-DWI for suspected posterior circulation infarcts; Class I, Level A.
• ESO–ESMINT Guidelines for Management of Posterior Circulation Stroke (2021): Endorses detailed visual field testing and early vascular imaging to detect PCA occlusion; Level B evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- The primary visual cortex along the calcarine fissure displays a retinotopic map: the macula is represented posteriorly and receives overlapping supply from PCA and MCA branches.
• As fibers converge into the cortex, defects become more congruent compared to dispersed fibers in the tract or radiations.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Acute PCA occlusion leads to ischemia of the occipital cortex. Collateral flow from MCA cortical branches often preserves the macular representation at the pole, producing a “macular sparing” phenomenon despite complete hemianopia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical exam: confrontation fields → note congruency and macular involvement.
2. Noncontrast head CT: exclude hemorrhage.
3. MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging: confirm occipital infarct.
4. MR/CT angiography: assess PCA patency and collateral circulation.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Diffusion-weighted MRI is highly sensitive for posterior fossa and occipital infarcts; CT may miss small cortical lesions.
• FLAIR-DWI mismatch can help estimate infarct age when timing is unclear.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Occipital lobe visual field patterns—specifically congruency and macular sparing—are high-yield topics frequently tested on neurology and ophthalmology boards.

question_text: A case scenario of a lady in the postpartum period presented with headache and seizure, with a normal brain CT. What should be done next? (No magnesium in the choices)
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Postpartum seizures and headache raise concern for conditions unique to this hypercoagulable state.
• Hypercoagulability (Virchow’s triad) predisposes to cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT).
• CVT often presents with headache, seizures, focal deficits and may show a normal noncontrast CT in ~30% of cases.
• Definitive diagnosis requires venous imaging to visualize sinus occlusion.

(Word count: 69)

Evidence-Based Analysis

CT venography (CTV) is the next best step after a normal noncontrast head CT when CVT is suspected. CTV has a sensitivity of 95% and specificity of 91% for detecting dural sinus thrombosis (Bush et al., Stroke 2019). The 2011 AHA/ASA CVT guidelines (Class I, Level of Evidence B) endorse either CTV or MR venography (MRV) to confirm diagnosis. MRI brain without dedicated venous sequences can miss isolated sinus thromboses in up to 20% of cases (Ferro et al., Lancet Neurol 2004). EEG localizes seizure focus but does not evaluate vascular patency. Lumbar puncture may exacerbate intracranial hypertension and is contraindicated until raised pressure is ruled out.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRI brain
– Incorrect because standard MRI sequences (T1/T2/FLAIR) without MRV do not reliably visualize venous sinuses. Common misconception: “Any MRI rules out CVT.”
C. EEG
– Incorrect as it assesses cortical electrical activity, not vascular pathology. Misconception: “Seizure → EEG first.”
D. Lumbar puncture
– Incorrect due to risk of herniation if intracranial pressure elevated from venous outflow obstruction. Misconception: “Normal CT → LP to rule out meningitis.”

Comparison Table

FeatureCTVMRI brain (no MRV)EEGLumbar puncture
Primary diagnostic targetVenous sinus patencyParenchymal lesionsElectrical activityCSF analysis
Sensitivity for CVT~95%~75% without MRV0% for CVT0% for CVT
ContraindicationContrast allergy, renal failureClaustrophobia, implantsNoneRaised ICP risk
Time to perform (acute setting)Rapid (~5–10 min scan)Longer (20–60 min)20–30 min30–60 min

Clinical Pearls

• In postpartum women with new-onset headache/seizure, always consider CVT alongside eclampsia.
• A normal noncontrast CT does not exclude CVT; proceed with venous imaging.
• Initiate anticoagulation promptly once CVT is confirmed, even if hemorrhagic.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming MRI brain without MRV rules out CVT.
2. Performing lumbar puncture before excluding intracranial hypertension in suspected CVT.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2011 Guidelines on Cerebral Venous Thrombosis: “CT venography or MR venography is recommended to confirm CVT in suspected cases” (Class I, LOE B).
2. European Stroke Organization 2017 Update: “In cases where MRI is available, MRV is equivalent to CTV; choose modality based on local availability and patient factors” (Grade A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Thrombosis most commonly affects the superior sagittal sinus and transverse sinuses, leading to impaired cortical venous drainage, raised intracranial pressure, and venous infarction.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Postpartum hypercoagulability (elevated fibrinogen, decreased protein S) plus endothelial injury and stasis predispose to dural sinus thrombosis, causing venous congestion, blood–brain barrier disruption, and seizure.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage/infarct
2. If CT is normal or equivocal and CVT suspected → CTV or MRV
3. Confirm diagnosis → start low-molecular-weight heparin
4. Monitor and transition to oral anticoagulation

Neuroimaging Pearls

• “Empty delta sign” on contrast-enhanced CT: triangular filling defect in superior sagittal sinus.
• “Cord sign” on noncontrast CT: hyperdense thrombus in cortical vein.
• CTV rapidly demonstrates absent flow in affected sinus.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Acute CVT treatment: low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) even with hemorrhagic infarction, followed by warfarin for 3–12 months; emerging data support direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) in select patients.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. It tests recognition of CVT in the postpartum state and the appropriate imaging modality.

question_text: In a case of intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), what is the target blood pressure (BP) for treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Intracerebral hemorrhage causes direct parenchymal injury and secondary damage via hematoma expansion. Elevated systemic blood pressure increases transmural pressure across cerebral vessels, promoting further bleeding. According to the Monro–Kellie doctrine, intracranial volume is fixed; reducing arterial pressure limits hematoma growth while maintaining cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP = mean arterial pressure − intracranial pressure). In ICH, autoregulatory mechanisms are often impaired in perihematomal tissue, so cerebral blood flow becomes pressure‐dependent. The goal is a rapid, controlled reduction of systolic BP to about 140 mm Hg to minimize expansion without inducing ischemia in vulnerable areas.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The AHA/ASA 2015 Guidelines for Management of Spontaneous ICH (Class I, Level A) recommend lowering systolic BP to 140 mm Hg in patients presenting with initial SBP 150–220 mm Hg, based on INTERACT2 (N Engl J Med 2013) which showed a shift toward better functional outcomes. ATACH-II (N Engl J Med 2016) compared intensive (<140 mm Hg) versus standard (<180 mm Hg) SBP targets; intensive lowering did not increase adverse events significantly and remains the recommended target in international guidelines. Diastolic goals are less well defined; 90 mm Hg is a practical upper limit when paired with SBP 140 mm Hg.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. 160/90
– Too permissive: allows ongoing hematoma expansion.
– Reflects older acute stroke thresholds (SBP <160) but fails to optimize functional outcome in ICH.
– Does not align with Class I guideline recommendation for SBP 140 mm Hg.

C. 180/105
– Matches general ischemic stroke or hypertensive emergency protocols but is excessive in ICH.
– Associated with higher rates of hematoma growth and worse prognosis.
– Represents a misunderstanding of ICH-specific BP targets versus ischemic stroke.

D. 120/80
– Overly aggressive lowering risks cerebral hypoperfusion and ischemia, especially with impaired autoregulation.
– Below the lower limit of recommended SBP (130–150 mm Hg) range in trials.
– Misconception: “lower is always better” without regard to CPP.

Comparison Table

Feature140/90 (A)160/90 (B)180/105 (C)120/80 (D)
Guideline RecommendationSBP ≈140 mm HgNot recommendedNot recommendedToo low (<130)
Risk of Hematoma ExpansionMinimizedModerateHighLow
Risk of HypoperfusionLow if monitoredLow–moderateLowHigh
Evidence BaseINTERACT2, ATACH-IINone in ICHNone in ICHNo trial data

Clinical Pearls

1. Initiate IV nicardipine or labetalol infusion for rapid, titratable SBP control.
2. Monitor neurological status and CPP; avoid SBP fluctuations >20 mm Hg.
3. Distinguish BP targets: ischemic stroke (often permissive hypertension) versus ICH (aggressive lowering).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing BP goals in ischemic stroke (allow SBP ≤220 mm Hg) with ICH (target ≥140 mm Hg).
• Focusing on diastolic rather than systolic BP as the primary driver of hematoma expansion.
• Overzealously lowering SBP below 120 mm Hg, precipitating perihematomal ischemia.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA Guidelines for ICH Management, 2015 (Class I, Level A): Rapid SBP lowering to 140 mm Hg in patients with admission SBP 150–220 mm Hg.
• INTERACT2 Trial, 2013 (Level I evidence): SBP target <140 mm Hg showed improved functional outcomes (ordinal analysis p=0.04).
• ATACH-II Trial, 2016 (Level I evidence): Intensive SBP lowering (<140 mm Hg) vs standard (<180 mm Hg) did not increase adverse events; supports guideline target.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Blood pressure management in acute ICH is frequently tested as a direct MCQ or within clinical vignettes, emphasizing target SBP ≈140 mm Hg to prevent hematoma expansion while preserving cerebral perfusion.

question_text: A patient with an acute stroke has a brain MRI that shows a dorsal cerebellar infarction (superior cerebellar artery). What will you find on examination?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] The cerebellum’s superior surface and deep nuclei are supplied by the superior cerebellar artery (SCA). Lesions here produce ipsilateral cerebellar hemisphere signs—especially limb ataxia—due to involvement of the dentate nucleus and superior cerebellar peduncle. By contrast, PICA infarction (lateral medullary) yields ipsilateral facial sensory loss and Horner’s syndrome; AICA infarction often causes ipsilateral hearing loss via labyrinthine artery involvement. Recognizing these distinct syndromes allows localization to specific posterior circulation territories.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Superior cerebellar artery infarcts account for ~7% of cerebellar strokes (Schmahmann & Pandya, Brain 2018). In SCA territory strokes, the most consistent exam finding is ipsilateral appendicular ataxia, dysmetria, and dysdiadochokinesia, reflecting dentate nucleus and cerebellar hemisphere dysfunction (Siepmann et al., Neurol Clin Pract 2018). There is no interruption of descending sympathetic fibers (located in lateral medulla) to cause Horner’s syndrome. Nor is the cochlear apparatus affected—hearing loss is characteristic of AICA (Hutchinson & Schmidek, Neurosurg Clin N Am 2019). Truncal hyperalgesia is not a recognized feature of SCA infarction. Current AHA/ASA guidelines (2019) emphasize bedside localization of posterior circulation stroke syndromes to guide urgent imaging and revascularization (Class I, Level B-R).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Ipsilateral truncal hyperalgesia
• Why incorrect: Hyperalgesia implies enhanced pain perception; SCA infarcts spare spinothalamic tracts.
• Misconception: Confusing pain/temperature loss in lateral medullary (PICA) with cerebellar lesions.
• Differentiator: PICA causes analgesia (not hyperalgesia) of ipsilateral face and contralateral body.

B. Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome
• Why incorrect: Horner’s arises from disruption of sympathetic fibers in lateral brainstem/upper cervical cord (PICA/Wallenberg), not SCA.
• Misconception: Attributing all cerebellar infarcts to autonomic signs.
• Differentiator: Only lateral medullary (PICA) lesions interrupt hypothalamospinal tract causing ptosis, miosis.

C. Hearing loss
• Why incorrect: Cochlear structures are supplied by the internal auditory (labyrinthine) artery branching from AICA, not SCA.
• Misconception: Generalizing brainstem infarcts to include cranial nerve VIII involvement.
• Differentiator: AICA infarcts produce labyrinthine signs—vertigo, tinnitus, sensorineural hearing loss.

Comparison Table

FeatureSCA Infarct (D)PICA Infarct (A/B)AICA Infarct (C)
Primary arterySuperior cerebellar arteryPosterior inferior cerebellarAnterior inferior cerebellar
Key presenting signIpsilateral limb ataxiaIpsilateral facial analgesia
± Horner’s		Ipsilateral hearing loss
facial paralysis
Autonomic involvementNoneHorner’s syndromePossible facial numbness
Vestibular signsPossible nystagmusVertigo, nystagmusSevere vertigo, tinnitus

Clinical Pearls

- Superior cerebellar artery strokes classically produce ipsilateral appendicular (limb) ataxia, not truncal ataxia (more midline vermian infarcts).
• Horner’s syndrome localizes to lesions interrupting the descending sympathetic pathway in the lateral medulla (Wallenberg), not the cerebellum.
• Hearing loss in a cerebellar territory stroke strongly suggests AICA involvement—prompt audiometry may aid early differentiation.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing truncal versus appendicular ataxia: vermian lesions cause truncal instability, SCA lesions cause limb dysmetria.
2. Believing all posterior circulation infarcts can produce Horner’s syndrome; only lateral medullary (PICA) disrupts sympathetic outflow.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommends emergent neuroimaging within 20 minutes for posterior fossa syndromes (Class I, Level B-R).
• ESO 2021 Guidelines on Mechanical Thrombectomy in Posterior Circulation: Suggest benefit of endovascular therapy in basilar artery occlusion; data for branch occlusions (e.g., SCA) remain limited (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The SCA arises just caudal to the posterior cerebral artery from the basilar artery. It courses around the midbrain to supply the superior cerebellar hemisphere, dentate nucleus, and superior cerebellar peduncle. Damage disrupts purkinje-to-deep-nuclei signaling, producing ipsilateral limb incoordination.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify acute cerebellar signs (ataxia, dysmetria).
2. Differentiate vermian (truncal) vs hemispheric (limb) ataxia.
3. Evaluate for cranial nerve involvement (hearing, facial sensation).
4. Obtain MRI brain with DWI to localize infarct.
5. Correlate vessel territory to clinical signs (SCA vs AICA vs PICA).

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI diffusion-weighted imaging is superior to CT for detecting posterior fossa strokes. SCA infarcts appear as focal diffusion restriction in the superior cerebellar hemispheres, often sparing inferior folia.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Posterior circulation stroke syndromes—especially distinguishing SCA, AICA, and PICA—are frequently tested by correlating vascular territories with specific clinical and imaging findings.

question_text: In a case scenario of an acute ischemic stroke patient, what is a contraindication for administering tPA?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Acute ischemic stroke results from arterial occlusion leading to brain tissue hypoperfusion. Intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) can lyse fibrin clots if given early, reducing infarct size. Eligibility hinges on a narrow therapeutic window (≤4.5 hours) and strict exclusion criteria to minimize hemorrhagic transformation. Key concepts:
• Neurovascular unit: ischemia causes excitotoxicity and blood–brain barrier disruption, raising hemorrhage risk.
• NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS): quantifies severity; very mild or rapidly improving deficits predict good outcome without tPA.
• Inclusion/exclusion criteria balance salvageable penumbra vs bleeding complications.

Evidence-Based Analysis

“Rapid improvement” of neurological deficits—often defined as complete or near-complete resolution before tPA infusion—is a relative exclusion per 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines (Class III: No Benefit; Level B-R). In the NINDS rt-PA Stroke Trial, patients with minor or rapidly improving symptoms had low baseline disability and low subsequent benefit but similar hemorrhage risk. Excluding them reduces unnecessary exposure to ICH risk without compromising outcomes. AHA/ASA explicitly lists “mild or rapidly improving stroke symptoms” among exclusion criteria. Other options either do not meet current thresholds (C, D) or are modifiable with aggressive management (A).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Blood pressure >200 mm Hg
• Why it’s incorrect: Hypertension above 185/110 mm Hg is an exclusion until corrected, but >200/110 is modifiable with IV antihypertensives.
• Misconception: Treatable elevated BP is often mistaken for an absolute contraindication.
• Differentiator: Only uncontrolled BP after treatment remains an exclusion.

C. Platelet count <150,000/mm³
• Why it’s incorrect: tPA contraindicates platelet count <100,000/mm³; values between 100,000–150,000 are acceptable.
• Misconception: Confusing exclusion threshold for spontaneous ICH risk vs procedural bleeding risk.
• Differentiator: The critical cutoff is <100 × 10^3/µL.

D. Recent major surgery within 14 days
• Why it’s incorrect: Only intracranial or spinal surgery/head trauma within 3 months is an absolute exclusion; most non‐neurosurgical procedures pose lower risk.
• Misconception: Equating all “major” surgeries with neurosurgical bleeding risk.
• Differentiator: Time window and type of surgery (intracranial vs peripheral) matter.

Comparison Table

OptionExclusion TypeModifiable?Guideline ThresholdNotes
A. BP >200 mm HgRelative exclusionYesBP ≤185/110 mm Hg before tPAUse IV labetalol/nicardipine to lower BP
B. Rapid improvement [CORRECT]Relative exclusionNoMild/improving NIHSS symptomsLow benefit, similar hemorrhage risk
C. Platelets <150,000/mm³Not exclusionN/APlatelets ≥100,000/mm³Only <100,000/mm³ contraindicates tPA
D. Recent major surgery within 14 daysNot standardN/AIntracranial surgery <3 monthsPeripheral surgery outside CNS is not excluded

Clinical Pearls

- Always lower systolic BP to ≤185 mm Hg prior to tPA; target labetalol bolus or nicardipine infusion.
• NIHSS ≤5 with rapidly resolving deficits often indicates minor stroke or TIA; withholding tPA avoids hemorrhage risk.
• Distinguish intracranial from extracranial surgery when assessing bleeding risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Treating any elevated BP >180 as permanent exclusion rather than a modifiable parameter.
2. Believing all recent surgeries—regardless of type or timing—preclude tPA, when only intracranial/spinal operations within 3 months do.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines for Early Management of AIS (Stroke. 2019;50:e344–e418):
– Recommendation: Exclude patients with “mild or rapidly improving stroke symptoms” (Class III: No Benefit; Level B-R).
2. ECASS III Trial (N Engl J Med. 2008;359:1317–29):
– Extended tPA window to 4.5 hours; reaffirmed exclusion of minor/rapidly improving deficits to minimize hemorrhagic complications.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Mechanism: tPA converts plasminogen to plasmin, degrading fibrin within thrombi.
• Dosing: 0.9 mg/kg (maximum 90 mg); 10% as bolus over 1 minute, remainder over 60 minutes.
• Monitoring: Assess neurological status every 15 minutes during infusion; watch for bleeding signs and perform follow-up CT if deterioration occurs.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam.
High-yield: Boards frequently test tPA inclusion/exclusion, emphasizing blood pressure thresholds, platelet counts, and the concept of rapidly improving symptoms as an exclusion criterion.

question_text: A case scenario of a patient with a history of diabetes mellitus and cardiac risk factors on aspirin presents with right hemiplegia and has left MCA stenosis. What is your next step?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Intracranial atherosclerotic stenosis (ICAS) of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) is a common cause of ischemic stroke, especially in patients with diabetes and vascular risk factors. Symptomatic ICAS (>50% stenosis) leads to stroke via artery-to-artery embolism, in situ thrombosis, or hypoperfusion. Key management principles include aggressive medical therapy (antiplatelet agents, statins, blood pressure and glycemic control) versus endovascular or surgical intervention. Understanding that trials in extracranial carotid disease (e.g., NASCET) do not apply directly to intracranial vessels is critical.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Medical management is preferred for symptomatic ICAS based on robust randomized trials and guideline recommendations:
• SAMMPRIS (N Engl J Med 2011): 451 patients with 70–99% ICAS randomized to aggressive medical therapy versus angioplasty + stenting showed 30-day stroke/death 5.8% vs. 14.7% (HR 0.39, p=0.002).
• VISSIT (Lancet Neurol 2015): Similar higher periprocedural risk with stenting.
• AHA/ASA 2014 Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines: Class I recommendation for intensive medical therapy (dual antiplatelet for 90 days then single; high-intensity statin; BP <140/90; glycemic control). Level of Evidence A.
By contrast, endarterectomy is for extracranial carotid lesions; stenting carries high periprocedural risks; anticoagulation (warfarin) showed no benefit over aspirin in the WASID trial and increased hemorrhagic risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

- B. Endarterectomy
• Reason incorrect: Reserved for extracranial carotid stenosis >70%.
• Misconception: Applying carotid endarterectomy data (NASCET/ECST) to intracranial vessels.
• Differentiator: Surgical access and vessel anatomy make intracranial endarterectomy infeasible with high complication rates.
• C. Stenting
• Reason incorrect: High periprocedural stroke/death in SAMMPRIS (14.7%) and VISSIT (24.1%).
• Misconception: Interventional approaches always yield better revascularization outcomes.
• Differentiator: Intracranial vessel tortuosity and perforator risk zones increase complications.
• D. Anticoagulation therapy
• Reason incorrect: WASID (N Engl J Med 2005) showed warfarin no better than aspirin and more hemorrhage.
• Misconception: Extrapolating benefits of anticoagulation in cardioembolic stroke to atherosclerotic stroke.
• Differentiator: Plaque stabilization and antiplatelet effects, not anticoagulation, reduce recurrent atherothrombotic events.

Comparison Table

ApproachIndicationKey EvidencePeriprocedural RiskRecommendation
Medical managementSymptomatic intracranial stenosisSAMMPRIS (2011)LowFirst-line
EndarterectomyExtracranial carotid stenosisNASCET/ECSTModerate (1–3%)Not for ICAS
StentingIntracranial stenosisSAMMPRIS & VISSITHigh (14–36%)Contraindicated as routine
AnticoagulationAtherosclerotic stroke (non-cardio)WASID (2005)Elevated hemorrhage riskNot recommended

Clinical Pearls

• Initiate dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) for 90 days in symptomatic ICAS, then continue single-agent therapy.
• High-intensity statin therapy (e.g., atorvastatin 80 mg) aiming for LDL <70 mg/dL reduces recurrent stroke risk.
• Aggressive management of hypertension (target <140/90 mm Hg) and diabetes (HbA1c <7%) is essential alongside antithrombotic therapy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions
