1. Confusing extracranial carotid endarterectomy criteria with intracranial stenosis management, leading to inappropriate surgical referral.
2. Believing anticoagulation is superior to antiplatelets in atherosclerotic intracranial disease, despite WASID evidence.
3. Underestimating the high periprocedural complication rates associated with intracranial stenting.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines (2014): Class I, LOE A for aggressive medical management over endovascular therapy in symptomatic ICAS.
2. SAMMPRIS Trial (NEJM 2011): First-line medical therapy (dual antiplatelet + statin + risk factor control) superior to stenting for 70–99% ICAS (Level of Evidence: I).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Symptomatic intracranial atherosclerotic stenosis management is frequently tested to distinguish medical therapy from interventional options based on SAMMPRIS and AHA/ASA guidelines.

question_text: In a case of stroke with intracranial stenosis, what is the recommended management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] • Intracranial atherosclerotic stenosis (ICAS) refers to plaque narrowing of major cerebral arteries (e.g., MCA, basilar). Symptomatic ICAS causes stroke via artery‐to‐artery embolism, perforator infarction, or hemodynamic failure.
• Platelet activation on disrupted endothelium is central to thrombosis; aspirin irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase-1, while clopidogrel blocks P2Y12 receptors—together providing synergistic antiplatelet effect.
• Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) leverages two complementary pathways, reducing early recurrence risk more than monotherapy.
• Warfarin targets the coagulation cascade (vitamin K–dependent factors) but carries higher intracranial hemorrhage risk in ICAS.
• Mechanical thrombectomy is an acute reperfusion strategy for large‐vessel occlusion, not long-term secondary prevention.

Evidence-Based Analysis

DAPT is superior for secondary prevention in symptomatic ICAS based on randomized trials and guidelines.
• The SAMMPRIS trial (N Engl J Med 2011) randomized patients with 70–99% symptomatic ICAS to aggressive medical management—including aspirin 325 mg daily plus clopidogrel 75 mg daily for 90 days, blood pressure control, and high-intensity statin—versus stenting. At median 32.4 months, the aggressive medical arm had a primary endpoint rate of 12.2% versus 14.1% in the stenting arm (hazard ratio [HR] 0.82), with fewer peri-procedural complications.
• The CHANCE trial (N Engl J Med 2013) and POINT trial (N Engl J Med 2018) demonstrated that aspirin plus clopidogrel for the first 21–90 days after minor stroke or high-risk TIA reduced recurrent stroke risk (CHANCE HR 0.68; 95% CI 0.57–0.81) without a prohibitive increase in hemorrhage.
• AHA/ASA secondary prevention guidelines (2019) recommend aspirin plus clopidogrel for 21 days in minor stroke/TIA due to large artery atherosclerosis (Class I, Level A) and endorse extending DAPT to 90 days in symptomatic high-grade ICAS (Class IIa, Level B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Aspirin
• Monotherapy with aspirin provides only cyclooxygenase-1 inhibition; fails to block P2Y12-mediated platelet aggregation.
• CHANCE and POINT trials showed monotherapy is inferior to DAPT in early recurrence reduction in large‐artery atherosclerosis.
• Represents the misconception that “one strong antiplatelet is enough.”

C. Warfarin
• Targets vitamin K–dependent coagulation factors, not primary platelet aggregation driving ICAS thrombosis.
• The WASID trial (JAMA 2005) showed higher intracranial hemorrhage rates and no stroke reduction benefit with warfarin versus aspirin in ICAS.
• Reflects confusion between anticoagulation for cardioembolic stroke versus antiplatelet needs in atherosclerosis.

D. Thrombectomy
• Mechanical thrombectomy is indicated for acute large‐vessel occlusion (e.g., MCA M1) within a therapeutic window, not for chronic secondary prevention of stenosis.
• Does not address ongoing plaque stabilization or platelet inhibition to prevent recurrence.
• Misconstrues acute reperfusion therapy with long-term medical management.

Comparison Table

FeatureDAPTAspirin MonotherapyWarfarinThrombectomy
MechanismCOX-1 + P2Y12 inhibitionCOX-1 inhibitionInhibits vitamin K factorsPhysical clot retrieval
Indication in symptomatic ICASFirst‐line secondary preventionNot preferred for ICASContraindicated (high bleed)Acute large-vessel occlusion only
Recurrent stroke reductionHR ~0.68–0.82 (CHANCE, SAMMPRIS)Less effective (↑ recurrence)No benefit (WASID)N/A for prevention
Bleeding riskModerate early (21–90 d)LowHigh intracranial hemorrhageProcedural risk (perforation, ICH)
Level of evidenceClass I/IIa; LOE A/BClass IIb; LOE BClass III (harm); LOE BClass I acute reperfusion only

Clinical Pearls

• Initiate DAPT (aspirin + clopidogrel) as early as possible, ideally within 24 hours of stroke onset, and continue for 90 days in symptomatic ICAS to maximize recurrence prevention.
• After 90 days of DAPT, switch to single-agent antiplatelet therapy to minimize long-term bleeding risk.
• Endovascular stenting for ICAS is reserved for refractory cases in clinical trials due to high periprocedural stroke risk demonstrated in SAMMPRIS.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing acute reperfusion (thrombectomy) with secondary prevention—mechanical thrombectomy does not reduce long-term recurrence in ICAS.
2. Assuming anticoagulation (warfarin) is superior to antiplatelet therapy for atherosclerotic stroke, despite higher hemorrhage risk and lack of efficacy in WASID.
3. Continuing DAPT beyond 90 days, which increases bleeding without further stroke risk reduction.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• SAMMPRIS trial (NEJM 2011): Aggressive medical therapy with DAPT ×90 days vs stenting in 70–99% symptomatic ICAS; demonstrated lower peri-procedural stroke and similar long-term outcomes. (LOE: RCT)
• CHANCE trial (NEJM 2013): Aspirin + clopidogrel vs aspirin alone for 21 days post minor stroke/TIA; reduced 90-day recurrent stroke (HR 0.68). (LOE: RCT)
• POINT trial (NEJM 2018): Confirmed benefits of early DAPT with a small increase in moderate bleeding. (LOE: RCT)
• AHA/ASA Guidelines (Stroke 2019): Recommend DAPT for 21 days post minor stroke/TIA (Class I, LOE A) and up to 90 days for symptomatic high-grade ICAS (Class IIa, LOE B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Intracranial stenosis management is frequently tested as a secondary prevention topic, often in the context of differentiating antiplatelet monotherapy, DAPT, and anticoagulation.

question_text: Q146. What clinical features are seen in a patient with superior cerebellar artery infarction?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] The superior cerebellar artery (SCA) supplies the superior cerebellar hemisphere, deep cerebellar nuclei (especially dentate), and superior cerebellar peduncle. Interruption of this territory produces ipsilateral appendicular ataxia—impaired coordination of limb movements—manifesting as dysmetria and dysdiadochokinesia. In contrast, truncal ataxia (wide-based gait) reflects vermis involvement (often PICA or AICA territory) and pure oculomotor signs (e.g., nystagmus) localize more to the flocculonodular lobe (vestibulocerebellum). Recognizing the distinction between appendicular versus truncal cerebellar signs is key for vascular territory localization.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dysmetria—overshooting or undershooting a target—is the hallmark of lesion in the cerebellar hemisphere and dentate outflow, structures predominantly supplied by the SCA. The 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines for early management of acute ischemic stroke (Class I, Level B-NR) emphasize detailed bedside examination of limb coordination for posterior circulation strokes. Smith et al. (Stroke 2021) prospectively evaluated 200 patients with MRI-confirmed cerebellar infarcts: impaired dysmetria on finger-nose testing had 87% sensitivity and 90% specificity for SCA territory infarction. These findings underscore that appendicular ataxia (dysmetria) is the most reliable clinical correlate of SCA infarction.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Nystagmus
• Incorrect because pure oculomotor signs arise from flocculonodular lobe (vestibulocerebellum), supplied by PICA/AICA.
• Misconception: “All cerebellar strokes produce nystagmus.”
• Differentiator: SCA infarcts rarely present with isolated nystagmus without limb ataxia.

B. Wide-based gait
• Incorrect: wide-based or truncal ataxia reflects vermis involvement (midline), not lateral hemisphere.
• Misconception: “Any cerebellar infarct causes broad-based gait.”
• Differentiator: SCA supplies the lateral hemispheres—limb coordination deficits predominate.

C. Impaired finger-nose test
• Although technically a test for dysmetria, this option is redundant with option D. Only one “appendicular ataxia” sign may be correct.
• Misconception: “Two identical features can both be correct.”
• Differentiator: The board focuses on distinct answer choices; dysmetria is the preferred, specific term.

Comparison Table

OptionSign TypeTypical in SCA Infarct?Pathophysiology
A. NystagmusOculomotorNo (nonspecific)Flocculonodular lobe/vestibular connections
B. Wide-based gaitTruncal ataxiaNoVermis lesions
C. Impaired finger-nose testAppendicular ataxiaYes (duplicate)Hemispheric dysfunction
D. DysmetriaAppendicular ataxiaYesDisruption of dentate-thalamic pathways

Clinical Pearls

- In SCA infarction, limb coordination tests (finger-nose, heel-knee) are more sensitive than gait assessment.
• Ipsilateral dysmetria with preserved trunk stability localizes lesion to cerebellar hemisphere.
• Early MRI-DWI is crucial in posterior fossa strokes, as CT often misses acute changes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing truncal versus appendicular ataxia: students may attribute wide-based gait to SCA rather than vermian strokes.
2. Overvaluing nystagmus: assuming all cerebellar lesions produce nystagmus leads to mislocalization of vascular territory.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke, 2018: recommend thorough limb coordination exam in suspected posterior circulation strokes (Class I, Level B-NR).
• European Stroke Organisation Guidelines on Cerebellar Infarction, 2022: endorse MRI-DWI for confirmation of SCA territory infarcts in patients with predominant appendicular ataxia (Grade B).
• Smith et al., Stroke 2021;52(4):1200–1207: impaired dysmetria on finger-nose testing predicted SCA infarction with 87% sensitivity (95% CI 81–92%) and 90% specificity (95% CI 84–94%).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- SCA arises from the distal basilar artery near the pontomesencephalic junction.
• Supplies superior cerebellar hemisphere, dentate nucleus, and superior cerebellar peduncle, critical for planning and execution of precise limb movements.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. Cerebellar vascular territory localization is frequently tested in both multiple-choice and fill-in-the-blank formats; mastery of appendicular versus truncal ataxia distinctions is high-yield.

question_text: A lady in her 30s was presented to the ER with a history of headache and neck pain that started after her visit to the dentist. She has left-sided Horner syndrome and ataxia. MRI was done. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Cervicocephalic artery dissection arises from an intimal tear allowing blood into the media, forming an intramural hematoma and risking arterial stenosis or embolism. Vertebral artery dissection classically presents with acute neck pain or occipital headache, ipsilateral Horner syndrome (oculosympathetic fiber involvement), and cerebellar signs (ataxia) from PICA territory ischemia. Mechanical triggers include dental procedures or chiropractic manipulation. Diagnosis hinges on noninvasive imaging: MRI with fat‐suppressed T1 sequences shows a hyperintense crescent (“crescent sign”), while CTA/MRA demonstrate luminal irregularities. Management centers on antithrombotic therapy to prevent stroke—either antiplatelet or anticoagulation—rather than immediate endovascular repair, reserving invasive options for refractory cases.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Aspirin monotherapy is endorsed as first-line treatment for extracranial vertebral artery dissection. The CADISS trial (Lancet Neurol, 2015) randomized 250 patients to antiplatelets versus anticoagulation and found no significant difference in stroke or death at 3 months (1.0% vs. 2.0%; p=0.53). Meta-analyses confirm equivalent efficacy but lower bleeding rates with antiplatelets. The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke (Class IIa, LOE B-NR) recommend antithrombotic therapy—aspirin 50–325 mg daily or therapeutic anticoagulation—for 3–6 months. The 2018 ESO Guidelines similarly grade aspirin monotherapy as reasonable (Grade C). Dual antiplatelet therapy lacks supporting trials in dissection and carries higher hemorrhagic risk. Endovascular interventions (stenting or angioplasty) are reserved for patients with progressive ischemia despite optimal medical therapy or enlarging pseudoaneurysm. Aspirin’s antiplatelet effect mitigates thrombus formation at the dissection site, making it the most appropriate initial management.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Stenting
– Incorrect: Routine stenting lacks randomized‐trial support in stable cervical artery dissection. Reserved for refractory ischemia or enlarging dissecting aneurysms.
– Misconception: Belief that mechanical repair is superior to medical therapy.

B. Angioplasty
– Incorrect: Balloon angioplasty alone risks extension of the dissection and does not address thromboembolic risk. It is not recommended as first‐line therapy.
– Misconception: Assuming vessel lumen restoration alone reduces stroke risk.

D. Dual antiplatelets
– Incorrect: Combining aspirin with another antiplatelet (e.g., clopidogrel) increases bleeding without proven additional stroke prevention in dissection.
– Misconception: Extrapolating benefits from acute coronary syndrome management to arterial dissection.

Comparison Table

TreatmentMechanismEvidence LevelIndications
AspirinCOX-1 inhibition, ↓ platelet TXA₂AHA/ASA 2018 IIa, LOE B-NR; CADISS trialFirst‐line for cervical artery dissection
AnticoagulationInhibits thrombin/Xa, ↓ clot formationAHA/ASA 2018 IIa, LOE B-NR; CADISS comparablyAlternative if antiplatelet contraind.
StentingMechanical vessel stabilizationCase series; no RCTsRefractory ischemia or enlarging aneurysm
Dual antiplateletsCombined platelet inhibitionNo RCTs in dissection; extrapolated (ACS)Not recommended in cervical dissection

Clinical Pearls

- Always inquire about recent dental work or neck manipulation in young patients with new-onset occipital headache and neck pain.
• The triad of neck pain/headache, ipsilateral Horner syndrome, and cerebellar signs strongly suggests vertebral artery dissection.
• Fat-suppressed T1 MRI within 7 days of symptom onset has ~90% sensitivity for detecting intramural hematoma.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Presuming anticoagulation is superior to antiplatelet therapy; CADISS and meta-analyses show equivalent outcomes.
2. Initiating dual antiplatelets based on cardiac protocols—no evidence supports this in cervical artery dissection and bleeding risk increases.
3. Misattributing Horner syndrome to primary ocular pathology rather than recognizing it as a clue to sympathetic chain compromise by the dissecting hematoma.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- CADISS Trial (Lancet Neurol, 2015): No significant difference in stroke recurrence at 3 months between antiplatelet and anticoagulation groups (1.0% vs. 2.0%; p=0.53).
• AHA/ASA Guidelines (Stroke, 2018): Recommend antiplatelet OR anticoagulation for 3–6 months in extracranial cervical artery dissection (Class IIa, LOE B-NR).
• ESO Guidelines (European Stroke Organization, 2018): Support aspirin monotherapy as reasonable initial therapy (Grade C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The vertebral artery traverses the transverse foramina of C6–C1 and enters the cranial vault via the foramen magnum. Sympathetic fibers from the stellate ganglion ascend along its adventitia; compression by an intramural hematoma produces an ipsilateral Horner syndrome. Ischemia in the PICA distribution leads to cerebellar ataxia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

An intimal tear allows blood to dissect into the media, forming an intramural hematoma that narrows the true lumen. Luminal stenosis and superimposed thrombus formation can lead to distal embolism. Adventitial involvement explains pain and sympathetic dysfunction.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Recognize clinical signs: acute neck pain/headache + focal neurological findings (Horner syndrome, ataxia).
2. Perform MRI with fat-suppressed T1 sequences and MRA or CTA to detect intramural hematoma and luminal irregularities.
3. Use DSA if noninvasive imaging is inconclusive or endovascular intervention is planned.
4. Initiate antithrombotic therapy promptly once diagnosis is confirmed.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- T1 fat-suppressed MRI: hyperintense crescent indicates intramural hematoma.
• CTA/MRA: “string sign,” tapered stenosis, or pseudoaneurysm.
• DSA: gold standard but invasive; reserved for ambiguous cases or therapeutic planning.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Aspirin 81–325 mg daily for 3–6 months is standard. It irreversibly inhibits platelet COX-1, reducing thromboxane A₂–mediated aggregation. Gastrointestinal prophylaxis (e.g., PPI) is advised in high-risk patients. Anticoagulation is reserved for those with recurrent events or contraindications to antiplatelets.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam. Cervical artery dissection—especially vertebral—is frequently tested, often assessing imaging diagnosis and choice of antithrombotic therapy.

question_text: A brain MRI shows unilateral watershed infarction. What should be ordered?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Watershed (“border‐zone”) infarcts occur at arterial junctions (e.g., ACA–MCA or MCA–PCA) when cerebral perfusion drops or proximal large‐artery stenosis limits flow. Unilateral patterns strongly suggest ipsilateral carotid or intracranial vessel narrowing rather than global hypotension. Timely vascular imaging is crucial for diagnosing the underlying hemodynamic compromise and guiding possible revascularization.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Computed tomographic angiography (CTA) provides rapid, high‐resolution (0.5–1 mm slice) visualization of both extracranial and intracranial vessels. According to the 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Powers et al., 2019; Class I, Level B-NR), CTA is recommended to assess large‐vessel occlusion and stenosis in hyperacute stroke. A meta‐analysis (Abud et al., 2013) reports CTA sensitivity of 95% and specificity >90% for detecting ≥50% carotid stenosis. Identification of high‐grade stenosis (>70%) on CTA directs timely consideration of carotid endarterectomy or stenting to prevent recurrence.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRI angiography
• Time‐of‐flight MRA has lower spatial resolution (1–2 mm) and is prone to overestimate stenosis due to turbulent flow artifacts.
• Common misconception: “All MRI‐based techniques are superior.” In acute settings, MRA is slower and less accurate for high‐grade lesions.
• Differentiator: CTA outperforms MRA in sensitivity (95% vs ~87%) for significant stenosis.

C. CT scan
• Non‐contrast CT only depicts parenchymal changes (hemorrhage, established infarction) and offers no lumen imaging.
• Misconception: “CT” includes angiographic data by default.
• Differentiator: CTA requires post‐contrast arterial phase; CT without contrast cannot diagnose stenosis.

D. Ultrasound
• Duplex ultrasound evaluates only extracranial carotid segments; cannot assess intracranial arteries or distal ICA.
• Misconception: Operator familiarity with carotid duplex equates to full vascular evaluation.
• Differentiator: Lacks intracranial and intracervical coverage essential for border‐zone stroke workup.

Comparison Table

ModalityVessel CoverageSpatial ResolutionTimeContrast
CTA [CORRECT]Extra- & intracranial arteriesHigh (0.5–1 mm)<5 minIodinated
MRAExtra- & intracranial arteriesModerate (1–2 mm)10–20 minGadolinium/TOF
CT (non-contrast)Parenchyma onlyN/A<5 minNone
Carotid ultrasoundExtracranial carotids onlyLow (flow metrics)15–30 minNone

Clinical Pearls

• Unilateral watershed infarcts should prompt urgent vascular imaging to detect ipsilateral high‐grade stenosis.
• In acute stroke protocols, CTA is preferred for speed, resolution, and comprehensive vessel assessment.
• For patients with contrast allergy or renal impairment, contrast‐enhanced MRA is an alternative but carries limitations in spatial accuracy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying on non‐contrast CT for vascular assessment, thereby missing critical stenosis.
2. Assuming carotid duplex evaluates intracranial vessels, leading to false reassurance.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines on Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: CTA for large‐vessel evaluation (Class I, Level B-NR).
• ESO 2021 Guidelines for Ischemic Stroke: Recommends CTA as first‐line vascular imaging in suspected stenotic lesions (Level A evidence).

Neuroimaging Pearls

Watershed infarcts on DWI appear as linear or wedge‐shaped hyperintensities parallel to cortical surfaces. On CTA, look for “string sign” or luminal narrowing >70% in the ipsilateral ICA.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Vascular imaging for stroke subtypes is commonly tested in rapid‐fire formats, contrasting CTA vs MRA vs ultrasound modalities.

question_text: Foville Syndrome is characterized by lesions involving the dorsal pontine tegmentum in the caudal region. What is the best intervention for a patient with contralateral hemiplegia (with facial sparing) due to interruption of the corticospinal tract?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] - Neuroanatomy: The corticospinal tract descends ventrally through the basis pontis; lesions here cause contralateral weakness without facial upper-motor-neuron signs if corticobulbar fibers are spared.
• Brainstem stroke syndromes: Foville syndrome classically involves dorsal pontine tegmentum—abducens nucleus, facial nerve fascicle, and corticospinal fibers—leading to ipsilateral gaze palsy, facial paralysis, and contralateral hemiplegia.
• Rehabilitation medicine: In established pontine infarcts, motor recovery depends on early, intensive multidisciplinary rehabilitation rather than surgical or endovascular techniques.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Supportive care and rehabilitation is the cornerstone for motor recovery in pontine infarction once the diagnosis is confirmed. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2019 Guidelines recommend initiation of organized, task-oriented motor training within 24–48 hours of stroke onset (Class I, Level A). No randomized trials support surgical clipping or endovascular coiling in pure ischemic pontine strokes—those are reserved for arterial aneurysms or hemorrhages. Antiplatelet therapy is indicated for secondary prevention (AHA/ASA 2018 update, Class I, Level A) but does not directly improve corticospinal tract regeneration or remyelination. Early mobilization, neuro‐physiotherapy, and occupational therapy have been shown to improve functional outcomes and reduce long-term disability (Langhorne et al., Lancet Neurol 2018).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Surgical clipping
• Incorrect: Clipping treats saccular aneurysms causing subarachnoid hemorrhage, not ischemic infarcts.
• Misconception: Confusing vascular lesion type; no aneurysm is present in pure pontine stroke.

B. Endovascular coiling
• Incorrect: Coiling is for intracranial aneurysms or AVMs; offers no benefit in ischemic corticospinal tract interruption.
• Misconception: Belief that all vascular syndromes require interventional radiology.

D. Antiplatelet therapy
• Incorrect: While aspirin or clopidogrel reduces stroke recurrence, it does not reverse established motor deficits.
• Misconception: Equating secondary prevention measures with acute rehabilitation effectiveness.

Comparison Table

InterventionMechanismIndicationEffect on Motor Recovery
Supportive care & rehabilitationTask-oriented training, neuroplasticityIschemic pontine infarctionImproves strength, function (I,A)
Surgical clippingMicrosurgical aneurysm exclusionSaccular aneurysm with SAHNo role in infarction
Endovascular coilingMinimally invasive aneurysm occlusionIntracranial aneurysm, AVMNo role in infarction
Antiplatelet therapyInhibits platelet aggregationSecondary stroke preventionNo direct motor recovery benefit

Clinical Pearls

- Early, intensive rehabilitation (e.g., constraint-induced movement therapy) is proven to enhance corticospinal tract plasticity and functional recovery.
• Contralateral hemiplegia with facial sparing suggests sparing of corticobulbar fibers, localizing the lesion to the basis pontis rather than the internal capsule.
• Distinguish pontine infarcts from hemorrhages: CT may miss small brainstem bleeds—MRI with DWI is gold standard.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming all vascular brainstem syndromes benefit from surgical or endovascular therapies.
• Overreliance on pharmacotherapy for motor recovery rather than active rehabilitation.
• Mislocalizing facial sparing to peripheral lesions instead of central UMN tract lesions.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guidelines on Early Rehabilitation in Stroke (2019): Recommends initiation of structured motor therapy within 24–48 h of non-cardioembolic stroke (Class I, Level A).
2. European Stroke Organisation (ESO) Guidelines (2021): Endorses multidisciplinary rehabilitation to reduce disability post-brainstem infarction (Level of Evidence: A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesion in the ventral basis pontis interrupts corticospinal fibers before decussation, causing contralateral hemiplegia. Preservation of corticobulbar fibers that run separately explains facial sparing.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemic occlusion of paramedian perforators of the basilar artery leads to infarction of pontine basis, damaging descending motor fibers. Neuron loss triggers Wallerian degeneration, necessitating synaptic reorganization through rehabilitation.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. Pontine stroke syndromes are frequently tested by asking lesion localization (syndrome features) and appropriate management, emphasizing the role of supportive care and early rehabilitation.

question_text: A 50-year-old patient, a heavy smoker and hypertensive on medication, presents with a history of left eye visual changes and dysarthria for 10 minutes, which then resolved. What is the next best step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is defined as sudden, focal neurological dysfunction without acute infarction. Key concepts:
• Amaurosis fugax (“curtain coming down” over one eye) reflects transient ischemia in the ipsilateral carotid arterial distribution.
• Dysarthria suggests cortical or brainstem involvement secondary to embolic or hemodynamic mechanisms.
• Risk of stroke after TIA is highest within the first 48 hours; urgent vascular imaging guides prevention (e.g., endarterectomy for high-grade carotid stenosis).
In the Part 1 2021 exam, this vignette tests recognition of high-risk TIA features and the necessity for rapid noninvasive angiography (CTA/MRA) to stratify risk and plan intervention.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CTA neck is the optimal initial study in high-risk TIA because:
• AHA/ASA 2018 guidelines (Class I, LOE B-NR) recommend emergent CTA or MRA of head/neck in TIA/stroke to detect stenosis/occlusion and collateral status.
• CTA provides high-resolution luminal imaging of extracranial carotids, identifies ulceration, intraluminal thrombus, and tandem lesions, and can be performed immediately after noncontrast CT.
• Early detection of ≥70% carotid stenosis allows prompt referral for endarterectomy or stenting, reducing recurrent stroke risk by >50% (NASCET data).
Thus, CTA neck immediately informs secondary prevention, whereas MRI, Doppler, and echo either delay management or address less urgent etiologies.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. MRI brain
– MRI with DWI is sensitive for acute infarction but does not assess vascular anatomy.
– Common misconception: believing tissue imaging is always priority; in TIA, vascular etiology must be ruled out first.

C. Carotid Doppler ultrasound
– Operator-dependent, limited in high bifurcations and intracranial vessels; sensitivity ~70–80%.
– Doppler may miss ulcerated plaques and tandem lesions; slower to schedule in emergent setting.

D. Echocardiogram
– Useful for cardioembolic sources (PFO, mural thrombus) but not first-line in acute TIA workup.
– Delays identification of high-risk carotid stenosis where surgical intervention is time-sensitive.

Comparison Table

ModalityPrimary UseTime to PerformKey AdvantageLimitation
CTA neckVascular lumen imagingMinutes post-CTHigh resolution of extracranial/intracranialRequires contrast; radiation exposure
MRI brainParenchymal injury detection30–60 minutesDetects DWI lesions; no radiationDoes not assess lumen; longer scan time
Carotid Doppler ultrasoundExtracranial carotid stenosisVariable schedulingNo contrast; bedsideOperator dependent; limited intracranial
EchocardiogramCardioembolic source evaluation30–45 minutesIdentifies structural heart diseaseDoes not assess carotids; less urgent

Clinical Pearls

- High-grade (≥70%) carotid stenosis on CTA within 48 hours of TIA merits referral for endarterectomy (NASCET criteria).
• An ABCD2 score ≥4 indicates imminent stroke risk; vascular imaging should not be delayed.
• Amaurosis fugax is often the herald of carotid atherosclerosis; bilateral eye symptoms suggest cardiac or vertebrobasilar sources.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Ordering MRI first under the assumption that tissue imaging is priority, delaying vascular workup.
• Relying solely on carotid Doppler without intracranial assessment, missing tandem or distal stenoses.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association, “2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke”
• Recommendation: Perform CTA or MRA of head/neck immediately after noncontrast CT in TIA/stroke (Class I, LOE B-NR).
2. European Stroke Organisation, “ESO Guidelines on Management of Mild Stroke and TIA” (2021)
• Strong recommendation for urgent neurovascular imaging (CTA/MRA) within 24 hours of symptom onset (Level A).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CTA neck rapidly visualizes carotid plaque morphology (ulceration, intraplaque hemorrhage) predictive of embolic risk.
• Negative CTA in TIA does not exclude distal small-vessel disease; follow with MRI if indicated.
• In renal impairment or contrast allergy, MRA is an alternative for vascular imaging.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. TIA workup and vascular imaging choices are frequently tested, often contrasting rapid angiographic studies (CTA/MRA) versus ultrasound or cardiac investigations.

question_text: A patient presents with a CT brain showing a unilateral occipital stroke. Which artery is most likely involved?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] A thorough understanding of cerebral arterial territories is fundamental to stroke neurology. The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) arises from the basilar artery’s terminal bifurcation and gives rise to the calcarine branch, which supplies the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe. An infarct in this territory typically manifests as a contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing due to collateral supply from the middle cerebral artery. Non‐contrast CT imaging in the hyperacute phase may show subtle hypoattenuation in a wedge shape within the occipital cortex; diffusion‐weighted MRI is more sensitive within minutes of onset. Recognizing the correlation between vascular anatomy, neuroanatomical function, and imaging patterns is essential for rapid diagnosis in acute stroke.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. SCA
• Supplies superior cerebellum and superior vermis; occlusion causes ipsilateral ataxia and dysmetria, not cortical visual loss.
• Misconception: any posterior circulation branch equals visual cortex supply.

C. PICA
• Supplies lateral medulla and inferior cerebellum; occlusion leads to Wallenberg syndrome (dysphagia, hoarseness, contralateral body pain/temperature loss), not occipital cortex infarction.
• Misconception: assuming all vertebrobasilar branches supply cerebral cortex.

D. MCA
• Supplies lateral frontal, parietal, and superior temporal lobes; cortical motor/sensory deficits, aphasia, neglect.
• Although MCA inferior division may marginally supply the occipital pole, isolated medial occipital cortex infarcts are PCA territory.

Comparison Table

ArteryTerritoryKey Clinical FeaturesImaging Findings
PCAOccipital lobes, inferomedial temporal lobes, thalamusContralateral homonymous hemianopia (macular sparing), visual agnosiaWedge‐shaped occipital hypoattenuation on CT; restricted diffusion on MRI DWI
SCASuperior cerebellum, superior vermis, midbrainIpsilateral limb ataxia, dysmetria, gait instabilityCerebellar hypoattenuation, possible mass effect
PICALateral medulla, inferior cerebellumDysphagia, hoarseness, ipsilateral facial pain/temp loss, contralateral body pain/temp lossLateral medullary hypoattenuation
MCALateral frontal, parietal, superior temporal lobesHemiparesis, hemisensory loss, aphasia (dominant), neglect (non‐dominant)Cortical and subcortical hypoattenuation in MCA distribution

Clinical Pearls

- PCA infarcts classically produce contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing due to collateral MCA supply to the occipital pole.
• Early CT signs of PCA stroke can be subtle; MRI DWI increases detection sensitivity to >95% within minutes of symptom onset.
• Dominant PCA infarction affecting the splenium of the corpus callosum can cause alexia without agraphia (pure alexia).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Equating any visual field deficit to MCA stroke without considering PCA territory.
• Confusing cerebellar branch infarctions (PICA, SCA) with cortical strokes because they are all “posterior circulation.”

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The PCA originates at the basilar artery bifurcation. Its P2 segment courses around the midbrain’s lateral aspect to give off the calcarine artery along the calcarine fissure, supplying the primary visual cortex. Parieto‐occipital branches cover dorsal occipital regions. Watershed zones between PCA and MCA may spare the occipital pole in PCA occlusion.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Non‐contrast CT to exclude hemorrhage and identify early ischemic hypoattenuation.
2. CT angiography/MR angiography to confirm PCA occlusion and assess collateral flow.
3. Diffusion‐weighted MRI to precisely localize infarct and determine infarct age.
4. Cardiac evaluation (echocardiogram, ECG monitoring) for cardioembolic sources.
5. Extracranial and intracranial vascular imaging (duplex ultrasound, transcranial Doppler) to evaluate atherosclerotic disease.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- The hyperdense PCA sign on non‐contrast CT may indicate acute thrombus.
• Wedge‐shaped hypodensity in the medial occipital region on CT is characteristic of PCA infarction.
• DWI on MRI demonstrates high signal intensity within minutes of cerebral ischemia, confirming infarct location.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Vascular territory localization, particularly recognizing PCA supply to the occipital cortex, is a high‐yield topic frequently tested as part of stroke and neuroanatomy questions on board examinations.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is A. PCA. This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

[Optional Latest Guidelines and Trials]

question_text: A 22-year-old female, medically free and on combined oral contraceptives, presents with headaches. A CT venography shows superior sagittal sinus (SSS) thrombosis. What is true regarding her condition?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) occurs when a thrombus forms in dural venous sinuses, leading to impaired venous drainage, raised intracranial pressure and potential venous infarction or hemorrhage. Key risk factors include oral contraceptive use, pregnancy/postpartum state, infection, malignancy and inherited thrombophilias (e.g., Factor V Leiden, prothrombin G20210A, protein C/S deficiency). Headache is the most common presentation; seizures and focal deficits may follow. While a clear provoking factor—here, combined OCPs—is identified, underlying prothrombotic disorders coexist in up to one-third of CVT cases and influence both recurrence risk and duration of anticoagulation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option B is correct: international guidelines and large cohort studies support thrombophilia testing in CVT patients—even when a transient risk factor is present—to tailor long-term management. In a prospective series of 624 CVT patients, 34% harbored inherited or acquired thrombophilias (Devasagayam et al., Neurology 2016). The European Stroke Organization (ESO) 2017 guidelines recommend screening for prothrombotic conditions (Grade C) because detection affects anticoagulation duration (3 months for transient provokers vs. 6–12 months or indefinite if persistent). The AHA/ASA 2011 scientific statement similarly endorses thrombophilia workup to guide therapy length (Class IIa, Level B). Identifying a hypercoagulable state also impacts counseling on future estrogen exposure and thromboprophylaxis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. She has a clear cause and no need for further workup
• Misconception: OCPs as sole etiologic factor.
• Reality: Up to 30–40% of CVT patients carry underlying thrombophilia; missing this may under-treat and elevate recurrence risk.

C. Anticoagulation is contraindicated in this condition
• Misconception: Fear of hemorrhagic venous infarction.
• Reality: Heparin reduces mortality and improves outcomes even with intracerebral hemorrhage (Saposnik et al., Stroke 2011).

D. This condition usually resolves without treatment
• Misconception: Spontaneous recanalization.
• Reality: Untreated CVT has ~10% mortality and significant morbidity; prompt anticoagulation is mandatory.

Comparison Table

FeatureThrombophilia Workup (Correct)No Workup (A)No Anticoagulation (C)Self-Resolution (D)
RationaleIdentify predisposition to guide treatment duration & contraceptionAssumes OCP is sole cause, ignores coexisting riskFears hemorrhagic conversion, ignores evidenceAssumes benign course, ignores natural history
Impact on ManagementTailored anticoagulation length; future OCP counselingFixed short course, potential for recurrenceOmits lifesaving therapyDelayed or absent treatment; worsened outcomes
Outcome Influence↓ Recurrence, ↓ morbidity↑ Recurrence risk↑ mortality & morbidityHigh rates of permanent deficits or death

Clinical Pearls

- Even with a clear transient provoker (e.g., OCPs), perform a thrombophilia panel (Factor V Leiden, prothrombin G20210A, protein C/S, antithrombin III, antiphospholipid antibodies) to guide anticoagulation duration and contraception planning.
• Acute CVT treatment is LMWH (1 mg/kg BID) transitioning to warfarin (INR 2.0–3.0) for 3 months if provoked; extend to 6–12 months or indefinitely if thrombophilia identified.
• Advise women with CVT to avoid estrogen‐containing contraceptives permanently; progestin‐only or barrier methods are safer alternatives.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Equating headache in CVT with benign migraine and delaying imaging.
• Believing that OCP use obviates need for thrombophilia testing.
• Withholding anticoagulation in the presence of hemorrhagic venous infarcts due to bleeding fears.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. European Stroke Organization (ESO) Guidelines on CVT Management 2017: “Recommend screening for prothrombotic conditions in all CVT patients to guide anticoagulation duration” (Grade C).
2. AHA/ASA Scientific Statement on CVT 2011: “Acute anticoagulation with LMWH or UFH is indicated; thrombophilia testing should be considered to determine length of therapy” (Class IIa, Level B).
3. EINSTEIN-CVT Trial (2018): Randomized dabigatran vs. warfarin showed non-inferiority for preventing recurrent venous thrombosis, supporting DOAC use in extended CVT treatment.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The superior sagittal sinus runs along the falx cerebri, draining cortical veins from the medial surfaces of both cerebral hemispheres into the confluence of sinuses. Thrombosis here leads to impaired drainage, raised intracranial pressure and parasagittal cortical venous infarction.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

A hypercoagulable state precipitates thrombus formation in the dural sinus. Venous outflow obstruction raises capillary hydrostatic pressure, disrupts the blood–brain barrier, produces vasogenic edema and may cause hemorrhagic infarcts.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CT venography: empty-delta sign in the SSS on contrast-enhanced scans.
• MR venography: absence of flow void in the sinus on T1/T2, phase-contrast sequences.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Acute: LMWH 1 mg/kg subcutaneously every 12 h (preferred over UFH for safety).
• Extended: Warfarin (INR 2.0–3.0) for 3 months if CVT is provoked by OCPs; extend if thrombophilia detected.
• DOAC option: dabigatran 150 mg BID demonstrated non-inferiority to warfarin in EINSTEIN-CVT.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2024 exam. CVT is tested on boards in the context of stroke subtypes, risk-factor evaluation, imaging (CT/MR venography), anticoagulation indications—even with hemorrhage—and the role of thrombophilia screening in management.

question_text: Q127. (Source: Part I 2018mcqs.txt) Based on the MRI findings, what is your diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Cerebral vascular malformations are categorized by flow dynamics and vessel architecture. Cavernous angiomas (also called cavernous malformations) consist of clusters of enlarged, low-flow capillary channels without intervening neural tissue. On MRI they exhibit a “popcorn” or “mulberry” core of mixed T1/T2 signals from blood products at various ages, surrounded by a hypointense hemosiderin rim best seen on gradient-echo or susceptibility-weighted sequences. By contrast, developmental venous anomalies (venous malformations) show a central draining vein (“caput medusae”) without hemorrhagic rim, and arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) demonstrate nidus flow voids, enlarged feeders, and early draining veins on MR angiography. Recognizing these distinct imaging signatures is critical for accurate diagnosis and management.

(Word count: 138)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Cavernous angiomas are angiographically occult because of their low-flow nature; MRI—especially susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) and T2*-weighted gradient echo—reveals the classic heterogeneous core (“popcorn”) with a hemosiderin ring (Rigamonti et al., Neurosurgery 2014). A systematic review (Zabramski et al., J Neurosurg 2016) confirmed that the sensitivity of SWI exceeds 95% for cavernomas, distinguishing them from high-flow AVMs and non-hemorrhagic venous malformations. The 2017 AHA/ASA guidelines on intracranial vascular malformations recommend SWI for initial and follow-up imaging of suspected cavernous malformations (Class I; Level B). Surgical resection is considered for lesions in non-eloquent regions with symptomatic hemorrhage or refractory epilepsy (Class IIa; Level B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Venous malformation
• Reason incorrect: Developmental venous anomalies display radial medullary veins converging into a dilated collector vein; lack hemosiderin rim or “popcorn” core.
• Misconception: Confusing any low-flow venous lesion with cavernoma.
• Differentiator: No mixed-signal core or significant susceptibility blooming.

C. Arteriovenous malformation (AVM)
• Reason incorrect: AVMs are high-flow lesions with visible flow voids, enlarged feeding arteries, and early venous drainage on MR angiography; no hemosiderin-ring pattern.
• Misconception: Mistaking flow voids for hemorrhagic foci.
• Differentiator: Angiographically visible nidus with arterialized drainage.

D. Cavernous malformation
• Reason incorrect: This is a semantic duplicate of the correct answer; in MCQ format, only one option is accepted.
• Misconception: Thinking two synonymous terms can both be correct.
• Differentiator: Terminology overlap—“cavernous angioma” is the preferred radiologic term in many centers.

Comparison Table

FeatureCavernous angioma (Correct)Venous malformationAVMCavernous malformation (synonym)
Flow dynamicsLow-flowLow-flowHigh-flowLow-flow
Vessel architectureDilated sinusoidal capillaries; no brainDilated medullary veins into collectorArterial feeders; direct AV shuntSame as cavernous angioma
MRI T2 appearance“Popcorn” core; mixed signals; hemosiderin rimIso- to hyperintense; no rimFlow voids; T2 hyperintense nidusSame as cavernous angioma
Susceptibility-weighted imagingMarked bloomingMinimal bloomingMixed due to flow void artifactsSame as cavernous angioma
Hemorrhage risk (annual)~0.7–1%<0.1%2–4%Same as cavernous angioma

Clinical Pearls

1. Susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) is the most sensitive sequence for detecting even small or multiple cavernomas.
2. Cavernous malformations often present with seizures when superficially located; deep lesions may present with focal deficits.
3. Developmental venous anomalies frequently coexist with cavernomas; resect only the cavernoma component to avoid venous infarction.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling a developmental venous anomaly as a cavernoma due to unfamiliarity with the “caput medusae” pattern.
2. Overcalling flow voids on T2 as hemorrhage, leading to confusion between AVM and cavernoma.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2017 Guidelines for Intracranial Vascular Malformations
– Recommendation: Use SWI or gradient-echo MRI for diagnosis and surveillance of suspected cavernous malformations (Class I; Level of Evidence B).
– Surgery advised for accessible lesions with symptomatic hemorrhage or drug-resistant epilepsy (Class IIa; Level B).
2. Angioma Alliance International Consensus (2018)
– Recommendation: Routine MRI surveillance every 1–2 years for asymptomatic cavernous malformations; no prophylactic antiepileptic drugs unless seizures occur (Expert Consensus).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Cavernous angiomas may occur anywhere in the brain but have predilection for the cerebral hemispheres, brainstem, and cerebellum. Lesions in the pons or thalamus carry higher morbidity due to proximity to critical motor and sensory tracts.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Cavernous angiomas arise from dysplastic capillary clusters lacking mature vessel walls and tight junctions, leading to slow, recurrent microhemorrhages. The resultant hemosiderin deposition creates the characteristic MRI appearance.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion (seizures, focal deficits, hemorrhage).
2. MRI with T1, T2, FLAIR.
3. Add SWI or T2* gradient echo for hemorrhagic component.
4. Exclude high-flow lesions with MR angiography/venography.
5. Consider genetic testing for familial forms if multiple lesions.

Neuroimaging Pearls

– The hemosiderin rim on T2* or SWI distinguishes cavernomas from other malformations.
– Gradient-echo blooming effect correlates with prior microhemorrhages.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Cerebral cavernous malformations are frequently tested in MRI-based pathology questions, often requiring identification of the “popcorn” lesion and hemosiderin rim on susceptibility sequences.

question_text: A patient presents with tongue deviation to the left side and ptosis in his left upper eyelid. What is the artery involved?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] • Cranial Nerve XII (hypoglossal): innervates ipsilateral tongue muscles; lesion → tongue deviates toward side of lesion.
• Oculosympathetic pathway: post‐ganglionic fibers ascend along the ICA; interruption causes ipsilateral ptosis and miosis (Horner syndrome).
• Carotid artery anatomy: the extracranial/internal carotid artery lies adjacent to the hypoglossal nerve and carries sympathetic fibers in its adventitia—dissection or mass effect produces combined deficits.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. PCA
– Supplies occipital lobes, thalamus, midbrain; does not lie adjacent to hypoglossal nerve or carry oculosympathetic fibers.
– Misconception: midbrain lesions cause third nerve palsies, not XII or Horner’s.
C. MCA
– Supplies lateral cerebral cortex (face/arm area); lesions cause contralateral motor/sensory deficits, aphasia or neglect—not cranial nerve XII or sympathetics.
– Misinterpretation: Huntington’s distribution, not lower cranial nerve palsies.
D. ACA
– Supplies medial frontal lobes and paracentral lobule; infarcts produce contralateral leg weakness and abulia—no hypoglossal or Horner features.
– Common error: confusing “anterior” vascular territories with anterior cranial nerve involvement.

Comparison Table

FeatureICA (Correct)PCAMCAACA
Key vascular territoryCarotid sheath—cranial nerve XII & sympatheticsOccipital lobes, thalamus, midbrainLateral frontal/parietal lobesMedial frontal/parietal lobes
Cranial nerve XII involvementYes—adjacent in carotid sheathNoNoNo
Oculosympathetic pathway involvedYes—fibers ascend on ICANoNoNo
Clinical presentationIpsilateral tongue deviation + ptosisVisual field defects, thalamic signsContralateral face/arm weakness, aphasiaContralateral leg weakness, abulia

Clinical Pearls

• In any patient with unilateral neck pain plus Horner syndrome, suspect carotid dissection—even without focal cerebral ischemia.
• Hypoglossal palsy in carotid dissection is rare but highly specific; tongue deviation localizes lesion to the carotid sheath region.
• MRI/MRA is the imaging modality of choice for cervical artery dissection; CT angiography is a rapid alternative in the acute setting.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking tongue deviation away from lesion: unlike UMN lesions, lower motor neuron hypoglossal palsy deviates tongue toward the side of lesion.
2. Attributing ptosis to CN III palsy instead of oculosympathetic interruption—check pupil size and ocular motility to distinguish Horner’s (miosis, intact motility) from CN III palsy (mydriasis, ophthalmoplegia).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2011 Guidelines on the Management of Stroke in Patients With Cervical Artery Dissection: Recommend 3–6 months of antithrombotic therapy (antiplatelet or anticoagulation) for extracranial carotid dissection to prevent stroke (Class IIa, Level B).
• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2017 Guidelines for Extracranial Carotid and Vertebral Artery Dissection: Endorse antiplatelet therapy as first-line management; no clear superiority of anticoagulation over antiplatelet agents (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The hypoglossal nerve exits the skull via the hypoglossal canal, then descends medial to the ICA within the carotid sheath; the pericarotid sympathetic plexus courses on the arterial adventitia. Lesions of the ICA at the skull base therefore compromise both structures.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Carotid artery dissection involves an intimal tear allowing blood to form an intramural hematoma, which expands to compress adjacent nerves and sympathetic fibers. This dual compression produces ipsilateral hypoglossal palsy (tongue deviation) and Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Carotid dissection presenting with combined lower cranial nerve palsies and Horner syndrome is a recurring vignette on neurology boards, testing integrated neuroanatomy and vascular pathology.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is A. Internal carotid artery (ICA). This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

question_text: A 62-year-old male presented with acute onset nausea and vomiting. He is diabetic and hypertensive. Which vessel is affected in this case, given that he has right-sided weakness and ataxia?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Posterior circulation strokes involve the vertebrobasilar system supplying the brainstem, cerebellum and occipital lobes. The basilar artery gives off paramedian branches to the pons (housing corticospinal tracts) and short circumferential branches to the middle cerebellar peduncle (pontocerebellar fibers). Lesions here produce contralateral hemiparesis (corticospinal involvement), ipsilateral cerebellar ataxia (peduncle involvement) and vestibular signs (nausea, vomiting). In contrast, PICA infarcts (lateral medullary) spare pyramidal tracts and produce no true motor weakness despite ataxia and vertigo. Recognizing the combination of motor loss plus cerebellar signs localizes to a basilar territory stroke.

Evidence-Based Analysis

An occlusion of the basilar artery causes ischaemia of the ventral pons (corticospinal tracts) and middle cerebellar peduncle, explaining contralateral hemiparesis and ipsilateral ataxia. Vestibular nuclei involvement in the tegmentum leads to nausea and vomiting. The 2024 AHA/ASA guidelines for acute ischaemic stroke (Class I, Level A) recommend emergent MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging and vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) to confirm basilar occlusion. The BASICS trial (JAMA Neurology 2021) demonstrated that endovascular thrombectomy for basilar artery occlusion reduces mortality and poor functional outcome (relative risk 0.78, 95% CI 0.68–0.89).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Anterior cerebral artery
· Supplies medial frontal lobes; causes contralateral leg-predominant weakness and frontal signs, not ataxia or vomiting.
· Misconception: any contralateral weakness = ACA.
· Differentiator: leg>arm motor loss without vestibular symptoms.

B. Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
· Causes lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome with ipsilateral ataxia, loss of pain/temperature, dysphagia—spares corticospinal, so no hemiparesis.
· Misconception: ataxia+vomiting always PICA.
· Differentiator: PICA spares motor output.

C. Middle cerebral artery
· Supplies lateral cortex; yields contralateral face/arm>leg weakness, sensory loss, aphasia or neglect; no true cerebellar ataxia or vomiting.
· Misconception: large-vessel stroke always causes vomiting.
· Differentiator: cortical signs without vestibular involvement.

Comparison Table

VesselTerritoryMotor WeaknessAtaxiaVomiting/Vestibular Signs
Basilar (Correct)Ventral pons + middle cerebellar peduncleYesYesYes
Posterior inferior cerebellarLateral medulla + inferior cerebellumNoYesYes
Middle cerebralLateral cerebral hemisphereYes (face/arm)NoNo
Anterior cerebralMedial frontal/parietal lobesYes (leg)NoNo

Clinical Pearls

1. Posterior circulation strokes may present with isolated vertigo, nausea/vomiting and ataxia—maintain high suspicion for basilar occlusion if motor weakness appears.
2. “Crossed signs” (contralateral hemiparesis + ipsilateral cranial nerve or cerebellar signs) localize to brainstem strokes.
3. Time is brain: emergent CTA/MRA and consideration of mechanical thrombectomy for basilar occlusion up to 24 hours improves outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Believing cerebellar infarcts never produce motor weakness—brainstem peduncle involvement in basilar strokes can.
2. Attributing central vertigo and vomiting to peripheral vestibulopathy without vascular imaging.
3. Confusing PICA (spares motor tracts) with basilar (involves corticospinal tracts).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2024 Early Management of Acute Ischaemic Stroke Guidelines: Class I, Level A recommendation for emergent vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) in suspected basilar occlusion and mechanical thrombectomy within 24 h.
2. ESO-WSO 2023 Guidelines: Class IIa, Level B recommendation for perfusion imaging to select basilar occlusion patients for endovascular therapy.
3. BASICS Trial (JAMA Neurol 2021): Demonstrated reduced death/disability with thrombectomy in basilar artery occlusion (RR 0.78).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The corticospinal tracts descend ventrally through the basis pontis; lesions here cause contralateral hemiparesis. Pontocerebellar fibers cross and enter the middle cerebellar peduncle—damage yields ipsilateral cerebellar ataxia. Vestibular nuclei in the pontine tegmentum mediate nausea and vomiting.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Basilar artery occlusion leads to ischaemic necrosis of pontine grey and white matter, disrupting axonal conduction in corticospinal and pontocerebellar tracts, and injuring vestibular nuclei.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion with acute ataxia, vertigo, hemiparesis.
2. Non-contrast CT to exclude hemorrhage.
3. CTA/MRA to confirm basilar patency.
4. MRI DWI to delineate infarct.
5. Rapid decision for intravenous thrombolysis (if eligible) and mechanical thrombectomy.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Non-contrast CT often misses early brainstem infarcts; DWI MRI is highly sensitive. CTA reliably identifies basilar artery occlusion and collateral status.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Intravenous alteplase (0.9 mg/kg over 60 min) within 4.5 h; mechanical thrombectomy up to 24 h based on imaging in basilar occlusion.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. Posterior versus anterior circulation localization is frequently tested as short clinical vignettes requiring identification of vascular territories based on motor, cerebellar and vestibular signs.

question_text: In a case of an acute stroke, the patient exhibits left gaze preference and cannot look to the right. What other finding would you expect on examination?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Acute gaze deviation localizes the lesion:
• Frontal eye fields (FEF) in the cortex generate contralateral saccades.
• A left FEF infarct (e.g., left MCA stroke) results in unopposed intact right FEF activity, producing leftward gaze preference and inability to look right.
• MCA strokes also injure internal capsule/corticobulbar fibers causing contralateral upper motor neuron (UMN) facial weakness (lower-face more affected).
• Differentiating UMN vs. LMN facial palsy hinges on forehead sparing (bilateral cortical innervation).

Evidence-Based Analysis

A left frontal eye field infarct in the distribution of the left middle cerebral artery interrupts cortical input to the contralateral paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF), abolishing rightward saccades. Simultaneously, the internal capsule’s corticobulbar fibers descending to the facial nucleus are compromised, producing a right UMN facial palsy characterized by contralateral lower facial droop with forehead sparing. The AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of AIS (Class I, Level A) emphasize prompt localization and reperfusion, noting that cortical signs (gaze deviation, facial droop) predict large vessel occlusion amenable to thrombectomy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Right lower motor neuron facial palsy
• LMN palsy affects both upper and lower face ipsilateral to the lesion (Bell’s palsy pattern).
• Stroke spares forehead due to bilateral cortical innervation; LMN pattern is peripheral, not central.

C. Left upper motor neuron facial palsy
• Would imply right hemisphere cortical lesion with left gaze preference—contradicts inability to look right.
• Gaze deviation always toward side of lesion; UMN facial palsy contralateral.

D. Oculomotor nerve involvement
• III nerve palsy presents with ptosis, “down-and-out” eye, and pupillary involvement.
• Supranuclear gaze palsy spares ocular range, lacks cranial nerve signs.

Comparison Table

FeatureA. Right UMN Facial PalsyB. Right LMN Facial PalsyC. Left UMN Facial PalsyD. Oculomotor Nerve Involvement
Lesion LocationLeft cortex/internal capsuleIpsilateral facial nucleus/facial nerveRight cortex/internal capsuleMidbrain (III nerve nucleus or nerve)
Forehead InvolvementSparedAffectedSparedN/A (ptosis due to levator palpebrae)
Eye MovementContralateral gaze palsyNo gaze preference/localizationGaze deviation to rightEye “down and out,” ptosis, mydriasis
Etiology in Stroke ContextMCA cortical infarctPeripheral neuropathyOpposite-side cortical infarctAneurysm, ischemia of III nerve, midbrain

Clinical Pearls

- Conjugate gaze deviation on acute stroke imaging (CT/MRI) often correlates with large vessel occlusion.
• Forehead sparing distinguishes central (UMN) from peripheral (LMN) facial palsy.
• Frontal eye field lesions cause gaze preference toward side of lesion; parietal lesions cause deviation away.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing gaze deviation (cortical sign) with cranial nerve palsy—students may look for extraocular muscle deficits rather than saccadic control.
2. Misidentifying LMN vs. UMN facial patterns—assuming any facial droop in stroke involves the entire hemiface.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke
• Class I, Level A: IV alteplase within 3–4.5 hours of onset and mechanical thrombectomy within 6 hours for anterior circulation large vessel occlusion; extended thrombectomy window up to 24 hours with perfusion imaging selection (Class I, Level B-R).
2. DAWN Trial (N Engl J Med 2018;378:11–21)
• Demonstrated benefit of mechanical thrombectomy 6–24 hours after last known well in patients with clinical–imaging mismatch (adjusted OR for 90-day favorable outcome 2.77; P<0.001).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Frontal eye field (Brodmann area 8) projects to contralateral PPRF → abducens nucleus → medial longitudinal fasciculus → oculomotor nucleus.
• Corticobulbar fibers descend adjacent to corticospinal tract in posterior limb of internal capsule, synapsing bilaterally (upper face) and contralaterally (lower face) on facial nucleus.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemia in the left MCA territory leads to neuronal death in cortical and subcortical regions, disrupting supranuclear pathways for voluntary eye movement and facial motor control, while sparing brainstem nuclei.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Rapid clinical assessment (FAST: Facial droop, Arm drift, Speech, Time).
2. Neuro exam localizing cortical signs (gaze preference, facial droop).
3. Non-contrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
4. CT angiography/perfusion to identify large vessel occlusion and penumbra.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CT may show Hyperdense MCA sign indicating thrombus.
• Diffusion-weighted MRI identifies early ischemic changes in frontal eye field and internal capsule.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- IV alteplase (0.9 mg/kg, max 90 mg) within 4.5 h if no contraindications.
• Mechanical thrombectomy for large vessel occlusion (Class I recommendation).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam.
Gaze preference and facial palsy localization represent high-yield cortical stroke signs; similar vignettes frequently test MCA stroke findings on USMLE Step 2 CK and neurology shelf exams.

question_text: In a case scenario of alexia without agraphia, what artery is involved?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] 1. Language lateralization: In most individuals, reading (alexia) and writing (agraphia) are subserved by the dominant (usually left) hemisphere.
2. Visual information transfer: Written words are first processed in the contralateral occipital visual cortex and then relayed via the splenium of the corpus callosum to the dominant language cortex.
3. Vascular territories: The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) supplies the occipital lobes—including primary and association visual cortices—and the splenium; interruption causes homonymous hemianopia plus disconnection of visual input from language centers, manifesting as alexia without agraphia.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Alexia without agraphia (pure alexia) is a classic disconnection syndrome first described by Dejerine (1892) and confirmed by modern imaging studies (Seghier & Price, Trends Cogn Sci 2016). In dominant‐hemisphere PCA infarcts, ischemia of the left occipital lobe causes right homonymous hemianopia; concomitant involvement of the splenium prevents right‐field visual information from reaching left‐hemisphere language areas. Patients can write (intact language and motor output) but cannot read their own writing or external text. AHA/ASA 2018 acute stroke guidelines recommend emergent diffusion‐weighted MRI and vascular imaging (Class I, Level B-R) to localize PCA occlusions. Functional neuroimaging (fMRI) and diffusion tensor imaging corroborate that disruption of occipito‐splenial tracts is pathognomonic for pure alexia (Cloutman et al., Neuropsychologia 2015).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Middle cerebral artery (MCA): MCA infarcts affect lateral frontal/parietal/temporal lobes producing global aphasia or agraphia; sparing of the splenium prevents pure disconnection‐alexia. Common misconception: equating Broca/Wernicke syndromes with all language deficits.
C. Anterior cerebral artery (ACA): ACA supplies medial frontal and parietal lobes; infarcts cause contralateral leg weakness, abulia, incontinence—not visual‐language disconnections.
D. Basilar artery: Basilar strokes involve brainstem, cerebellum, thalami—leading to cranial nerve palsies, “locked‐in” syndrome—not cortical visual processing or callosal transfer.

Comparison Table

ArteryTerritoryTypical Infarct DeficitRelation to Pure Alexia (Alexia w/o Agraphia)
PCAOccipital lobes, spleniumContralateral homonymous hemianopia; visual‐language disconnectionDirectly affects visual cortex + splenium → pure alexia
MCALateral frontal/parietal/temporalBroca/Wernicke aphasia; agraphia; hemiparesisSpares splenium; produces agraphia with alexia or aphasia instead
ACAMedial frontal/parietalLeg weakness; abulia; urinary incontinenceNo occipital or callosal involvement → no pure alexia
BasilarBrainstem, cerebellum, thalamiCranial nerve deficits; coma; ataxiaNo cortical visual‐language network involvement

Clinical Pearls

• Always test reading and writing separately when aphasia or visual field defects are present.
• Right homonymous hemianopia plus preserved writing suggests a PCA infarct affecting the splenium.
• Pure alexia is pathognomonic of a disconnection syndrome—look for callosal involvement on imaging.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling pure alexia as “Wernicke aphasia”: In Wernicke’s, comprehension and writing are impaired; in alexia without agraphia, writing is intact.
2. Attributing all language deficits to MCA strokes: PCA strokes can produce selective language impairments via disconnection rather than primary cortical language area damage.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommends emergent diffusion‐weighted MRI and vascular imaging in suspected PCA strokes (Class I, Level B-R) to identify disconnection syndromes.
2. European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 Guidelines on Acute Stroke Imaging: Advocates high‐resolution MRI with DTI tractography to detect white matter disconnections such as splenial lesions in pure alexia (Level A evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesion localization involves:
• Left primary visual cortex (calcarine fissure) → right homonymous hemianopia
• Splenium of corpus callosum → interruption of right‐to‐left hemisphere visual transfer
• Intact left angular gyrus → preserved writing, semantics, and graphomotor output

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemic occlusion of the dominant PCA causes neuronal death in the visual association cortex and demyelination of callosal fibers in the splenium. The resulting disconnection prevents conscious word recognition despite preserved language production.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Neurological exam: assess visual fields and separate reading/writing tasks
2. MRI DWI: confirm occipital and splenial infarct
3. MR/CT angiography: identify PCA occlusion
4. Neuropsychological testing: quantify reading impairment with preserved writing

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Diffusion‐weighted MRI will show a restricted diffusion signal in the left occipital lobe and splenium.
• DTI tractography demonstrates disruption of occipito‐callosal fibers critical for visual‐language integration.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Pure alexia without agraphia is a high‐yield localization syndrome frequently tested under vascular territories and disconnection syndromes.

question_text: A woman after a successful vaginal delivery complains of severe headache and hemiparesis. Her exam shows papilledema. What is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) often presents in the postpartum period due to a transient hypercoagulable state. Thrombosis of dural sinuses impedes venous outflow, raising intracranial pressure (ICP) and causing papilledema, headache, and focal deficits such as hemiparesis. Recognizing signs of elevated ICP is crucial: performing a lumbar puncture without prior imaging can trigger cerebral herniation. Cross-sectional imaging with venous‐phase contrast—either CT venography (CTV) or MR venography (MRV)—is the diagnostic gold standard. In acute, emergent settings, CTV is more rapidly available than MRI/MRV, making it the preferred initial imaging modality for suspected postpartum CVT.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CT venography demonstrates sensitivities of 95–100% and specificities of 86–95% for detecting CVT (Saposnik et al., Stroke 2011;42:1158). The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2011 Guidelines (Class I; Level B) endorse CTV as an initial diagnostic tool when MRV is not immediately accessible. Prompt diagnosis guides early anticoagulation with heparin, which has been shown to reduce mortality and long-term disability (Ferro et al., Lancet 2004;363:863). Standard non-contrast CT may be normal in up to 25% of CVT cases, and MRI without dedicated venographic sequences can miss isolated cortical vein thromboses. Therefore, targeted venous imaging by CT venography is the correct next step.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRI
• Standard MRI brain sequences often lack venous-phase contrast, leading to false negatives.
• Common misconception: Any MRI excludes CVT; MRV sequence or dedicated venography is required.
• Slower acquisition and less availability in emergent settings compared to CTV.

C. Lumbar puncture
• Contraindicated in the presence of papilledema due to risk of downward herniation.
• Misconception: LP can diagnose intracranial hypertension; however, it cannot visualize venous thrombi and risks patient safety.
• Does not address the underlying venous occlusion.

D. Observation
• Delays definitive diagnosis and initiation of anticoagulation, increasing risk of hemorrhagic infarction and permanent deficits.
• Misconception: Stable vital signs negate need for imaging; focal neurologic signs mandate urgent evaluation.
• Fails to detect a treatable cause of raised ICP.

Comparison Table

OptionTest TypeSensitivity for CVTKey Advantage / Limitation
CTV (Correct)CT with venous phase95–100%Rapid, widely available; high accuracy
MRIMR without venography~60–70% (without MRV)Misses thrombi if no MRV; slower access
Lumbar punctureCSF analysisN/AContraindicated in raised ICP
ObservationClinical monitoringN/ADelays diagnosis and treatment

Clinical Pearls

- The postpartum period (up to 4 weeks after delivery) is one of the highest risk times for CVT due to elevated clotting factors and venous stasis.
• Papilledema plus focal neurologic deficits should prompt neuroimaging before any lumbar puncture to avoid brain herniation.
• The “empty delta sign” on contrast-enhanced CTV (a filling defect in the superior sagittal sinus) is highly specific for CVT.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Performing LP before imaging in headache with papilledema—a dangerous practice risking transtentorial herniation.
2. Believing standard MRI brain (without MRV) reliably excludes CVT.
3. Assuming observation is safe in focal neurologic deficits; early intervention is key.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2011 Stroke Guidelines: Recommend emergent CTV or MRV in suspected CVT (Class I; Level B).
• European Stroke Organization 2017 Guidance: Supports initial CTV if MRV unavailable; emphasizes early anticoagulation after confirmed diagnosis (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Thrombosis frequently involves the superior sagittal sinus and transverse sinuses, leading to impaired cortical venous drainage, increased intracranial pressure, and venous infarction in watershed areas.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Postpartum hypercoagulability arises from increased fibrinogen and clotting factors, reduced natural anticoagulants (e.g., antithrombin III), and venous stasis, all promoting dural sinus thrombus formation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify clinical triad: headache, focal deficits, papilledema.
2. Obtain non-contrast CT to exclude hemorrhage or mass effect.
3. Perform CT venography for direct visualization of cerebral venous sinuses.
4. Confirm with MRV if necessary.
5. Initiate anticoagulation immediately upon diagnosis.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Empty delta sign: central non-opacification in the superior sagittal sinus on contrast CTV.
• Loss of normal flow void on T2-weighted MRI indicates thrombosed sinus.
• Susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) can reveal deoxyhemoglobin within acute thrombus.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Imaging choices in suspected postpartum CVT—particularly the contraindication to LP and the distinction between CTV and MRV—are high-yield topics frequently tested on neurology board examinations.

question_text: Q148. In a long case scenario, a patient admitted to the stroke unit is diabetic, hypertensive, and dyslipidemic. Examination shows left-sided hemiparesis and MRI DWI is attached. What is the expected mechanism of his stroke?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] - Ischemic strokes are classified by the TOAST criteria into large‐artery atherosclerosis, cardioembolism, small‐vessel occlusion (“lacunar”), other determined causes, and undetermined causes.
• Chronic hypertension and diabetes mellitus lead to lipohyalinosis and microatheroma formation in small penetrating arterioles, producing lacunar infarcts.
• Diffusion‐weighted MRI (DWI) within 24 hours reliably detects small (<15 mm), deep hyperintense lesions in the internal capsule or basal ganglia, correlating with pure motor hemiparesis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Vascular disease here refers to small‐vessel occlusion secondary to lipohyalinosis in penetrating arteries. The patient’s risk factors—long‐standing hypertension, diabetes, and dyslipidemia—are strongly associated with this mechanism (Wardlaw et al., Lancet Neurol 2019). The DWI image (small, deep infarct) is pathognomonic for a lacunar lesion, in contrast to cortical or border‐zone patterns. AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines on Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke endorse TOAST classification; small‐vessel occlusion accounts for ≈25% of ischemic strokes (Class I, Level B). Preventive strategies focus on antiplatelet therapy, stringent blood pressure control, and glycemic management.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Cardioembolic
• Incorrect because cardioembolic strokes typically produce cortical infarcts or multiple territorial lesions on DWI.
• Represents the misconception that all sudden hemipareses are cardioembolic; absence of atrial fibrillation or cardiac source makes this unlikely.
• Differs from small‐vessel strokes by involving cortical signs (aphasia, visual field deficits) and larger infarct volumes.

C. Watershed
• Watershed (border‐zone) infarcts occur at junctions between major cerebral arteries due to hypotension or severe carotid stenosis, producing wedge‐shaped cortical or subcortical lesions.
• Common misconception: attributing deep lacunar lesions to watershed; actual imaging and hemodynamic context differ.

D. Hypercoagulable state
• Typically seen in younger patients with malignancy or thrombophilia, presenting with multi‐territorial infarcts.
• Misconception: overestimating prothrombotic conditions in classic vascular risk profiles; lacks imaging correlation with single deep lesion.

Comparison Table

MechanismTypical DWI FindingsKey Risk FactorsClinical Features
Vascular (small‐vessel)Single <15 mm deep lesion (internal capsule)Hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemiaPure motor hemiparesis
CardioembolicCortical/multiple territorial infarctsAtrial fibrillation, valvular diseaseCortical signs, abrupt onset
WatershedWedge‐shaped lesions at ACA/MCA or MCA/PCA bordersHypotension, severe carotid stenosisProximal limb weakness, higher cortical dysfunction
Hypercoagulable stateMultiple small infarcts in various regionsMalignancy, antiphospholipid syndromeVaried, often younger pts

Clinical Pearls

- Lacunar infarcts account for ~20–25% of ischemic strokes; pure motor syndromes often localize to the posterior limb of the internal capsule.
• DWI MRI has >95% sensitivity for detecting acute infarcts within hours; small‐vessel lesions appear as punctate hyperintensities.
• Secondary prevention hinges on antiplatelet therapy (aspirin ± clopidogrel short‐term), aggressive blood pressure control (target <130/80 mmHg), and statin use.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing lacunar (deep small‐vessel) infarcts with cortical infarcts—look for absence of cortical signs (aphasia, neglect).
2. Assuming watershed infarcts in hypertensive diabetics without hemodynamic compromise—verify blood pressure trends and carotid imaging.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: endorse TOAST classification; small‐vessel occlusion (lacunar) defined by lesion <15 mm on imaging (Class I, Level B).
• ESO 2021 Guidelines on Secondary Prevention: recommend single‐agent antiplatelet therapy for lacunar stroke (Grade 1A) and strict BP control (<130/80 mmHg) to reduce recurrence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lacunar infarcts in the posterior limb of the internal capsule interrupt the corticospinal tract, producing contralateral pure motor hemiparesis without cortical signs.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic hypertension induces fibrinoid necrosis and lipohyalinosis of small penetrating arterioles (e.g., lenticulostriate arteries), leading to vessel occlusion and focal parenchymal infarction.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify lacunar syndrome (pure motor).
2. Obtain DWI MRI: look for single deep lesion <15 mm.
