– A chronic cavitary lesion of the central cord producing a “cape-like” loss of pain/temperature in upper limbs; motor deficits are segmental, not acute paraplegia, and dorsal column function remains intact only outside the syrinx levels.

Comparison Table

FeatureASA InfarctionTransverse MyelitisGuillain-Barré SyndromeSyringomyelia
OnsetSeconds to minutesHours to daysDays to weeksMonths to years
Back painSevere, acuteVariable, milderAbsentAbsent
Motor weaknessFlaccid → spastic paraplegiaParaparesis/quadraparesisAscending weaknessSegmental, focal
Pain/temperature sensationLost below lesionLost below lesionMild sensory symptoms“Cape-like” upper limbs
Proprioception/vibrationPreservedLostPreserved (usually)Preserved outside syrinx
MRI findingsCentral T2 hyperintensityLongitudinal cord lesionNormal cord imagingSyrinx cavity

Clinical Pearls

• Acute severe back pain at onset is a red flag for vascular spinal cord injury rather than inflammatory myelopathy.
• “Owl’s eyes” appearance on axial T2 MRI is highly specific for ASA infarction.
• Maintain mean arterial pressure >85 mm Hg in the acute phase to augment spinal cord perfusion.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misattributing preserved proprioception to peripheral neuropathy—peripheral lesions do not produce a spinal sensory level.
2. Overlooking urinary retention in Guillain-Barré syndrome—autonomic involvement occurs but without a defined sensory level or abrupt back pain.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam.
Spinal cord vascular syndromes are frequently tested on board exams, emphasizing the dissociation between preserved dorsal column modalities and lost motor/pain pathways in ASA infarction.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

[Optional Latest Guidelines and Trials]

question_text: A 73-year-old female patient presented with decreased level of consciousness showing hemorrhage with fluid level. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] - Intracerebral hemorrhages (ICH) on noncontrast CT typically appear as homogeneous hyperdensities; a “fluid‐fluid level” (hematocrit effect) arises when red blood cells layer under plasma due to impaired clotting.
• Anticoagulation (warfarin or DOACs) predisposes to coagulopathy‐mediated bleeds that fail to clot effectively, producing this layering sign.
• In contrast, hypertensive ICHs (deep nuclei), cerebral amyloid angiopathy (lobar, microbleeds on GRE), and CVT (hemorrhagic infarcts with edema and venous patterns) lack a true fluid level.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The fluid‐fluid level sign—seen as a horizontal interface between hyperdense cellular elements and hypodense serum on CT—has been shown to have 90–95% specificity for coagulopathy‐related ICH (Kumazawa et al., AJNR 1996). The 2022 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Spontaneous ICH (Hemphill et al., Stroke 2022) recommend immediate assessment of anticoagulant status and reversal if present (Class I, Level A). In anticoagulated patients, deficient thrombin generation prevents stable clot formation, allowing erythrocytes to settle out of plasma. This pathophysiology underlies the distinctive layering on imaging and distinguishes it from other causes of ICH.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Amyloid
• Incorrect because cerebral amyloid angiopathy causes lobar, cortical hemorrhages with ovoid margins and multiple microbleeds on GRE/SWI, not a fluid level.
• Misconception: assuming any lobar hemorrhage in elderly is amyloid—fails to account for coagulopathy signs.

B. Cerebral Venous Thrombosis (CVT)
• CVT may produce hemorrhagic infarcts, usually with irregular margins, surrounding edema, and venous sinus occlusion on MRV, not an acute intraparenchymal fluid‐fluid level.
• Students may confuse venous infarct hemorrhage for simple ICH.

D. Hypertensive intracerebral hemorrhage
• Deep basal ganglia or pontine bleeds from hypertension appear as dense, homogeneous masses without layering.
• Misconception: equating any spontaneous ICH in elderly to hypertension, neglecting imaging nuances.

Comparison Table

FeatureAnticoagulation‐related ICHHypertensive ICHAmyloid Angiopathy ICHCVT Hemorrhagic Infarct
LocationAny parenchyma, often lobarBasal ganglia, thalamusLobar cortexVariable, venous territory
CT AppearanceFluid–fluid (hematocrit) levelHomogeneous hyperdensityHomogeneous hyperdensityHeterogeneous, infarct + bleed
MRI GRE/SWINo specific microbleedsPossible microbleedsMultiple cortical microbleedsVenous thrombosis signs
Clotting profileElevated INR or DOAC levelsNormal coagulationNormal coagulationPossible D‐dimer elevation

Clinical Pearls

- A fluid‐fluid level on CT (“hematocrit effect”) in ICH: think coagulopathy first.
• Always obtain coagulation studies (INR, anti‐Xa levels) immediately when ICH shows layering.
• Early reversal of anticoagulation (e.g., PCC for warfarin, idarucizumab for dabigatran) reduces hematoma expansion and improves outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overlooking fluid levels in mixed‐density bleeds, attributing to hemorrhage age rather than coagulopathy.
2. Mislabeling any lobar hemorrhage in the elderly as amyloid without MRI GRE correlation.
3. Assuming hemorrhagic infarcts from CVT present identically to primary ICH on CT without MRV.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- 2022 AHA/ASA Guideline for the Management of Spontaneous Intracerebral Hemorrhage (Hemphill et al., Stroke 2022): Reversal of warfarin anticoagulation with prothrombin complex concentrate is Class I, Level A.
• INTERACT2 Trial (2013, Lancet): Intensive blood pressure lowering (target SBP <140 mm Hg) in acute ICH is safe and may improve functional outcomes; relevant when managing bleed expansion in anticoagulated patients.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Anticoagulant drugs inhibit vitamin K–dependent factors (warfarin) or direct thrombin/Factor Xa (DOACs), impairing fibrin clot formation.
• Unstable clots allow erythrocytes to settle under plasma, creating a fluid‐fluid level visible on CT.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Emergent noncontrast head CT → identify ICH and layering.
2. Obtain coagulation profile (PT/INR, aPTT, anti‐Xa).
3. If coagulopathy: reverse anticoagulation per guidelines.
4. Monitor for hematoma expansion with repeat imaging.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Hematocrit effect appears within hours of bleed in coagulopathy; on supine CT, look for flat horizontal interface.
• Differentiate from sedimentation in subdural hygromas by location (intraparenchymal vs subdural) and density.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Imaging signs such as the fluid–fluid level are high‐yield for distinguishing coagulopathy‐related hemorrhages on board examinations.

question_text: A patient presented with an inability to read his own handwriting, while his comprehension for spoken language, fluency, and repetition are normal. What is the most common artery involved?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Pure alexia without agraphia arises from a disconnection syndrome: visual input is abolished in the dominant occipital cortex but writing remains intact because language output regions (Exner’s area, angular gyrus) are spared. Key concepts:
• The visual word form area (VWFA) lies in the left ventral occipitotemporal cortex, supplied by the PCA.
• Splenial callosal fibers mediate transfer of visual information from right to left hemisphere; infarction here causes “disconnection” of intact language centers from visual input.
• Other language modalities (auditory comprehension, speech production, repetition) remain normal since perisylvian areas (MCA territory) are unaffected.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Infarction of the dominant PCA interrupts perfusion to the left primary visual cortex and VWFA in the fusiform gyrus, as well as the splenium of the corpus callosum. Dejerine’s classic 1892 description of pure alexia without agraphia highlighted this pattern. Modern neuroimaging (Leff et al., JNNP 2002) confirmed that lesions in the left fusiform gyrus reliably produce alexia with preserved writing. The AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Class I, Level A) emphasize urgent MRI-DWI and vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) to localize PCA territory infarcts presenting with cortical visual deficits. By contrast, MCA infarcts produce Broca’s or Wernicke’s aphasia with motor/sensory signs; ACA infarcts yield leg weakness and frontal signs; PICA strokes cause lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndromes without cortical language deficits.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Middle cerebral artery (MCA)
• Why incorrect: MCA supplies perisylvian language regions; infarcts cause aphasia plus motor/sensory deficits, not isolated reading impairment.
• Misconception: Equating all language deficits with MCA strokes.
• Differentiator: Pure alexia spares speech and comprehension; MCA lesions disrupt multiple language modalities and often cause hemiparesis.

C. Anterior cerebral artery (ACA)
• Why incorrect: ACA supplies medial frontal/parietal lobes and corpus callosum body; infarcts cause transcortical motor aphasia or leg weakness, not pure alexia.
• Misconception: Attributing callosal disconnection syndromes to ACA infarcts; splenial lesions are PCA territory.
• Differentiator: ACA strokes present with frontal release signs, abulia, and leg paresis rather than visual reading deficits.

D. Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA)
• Why incorrect: PICA supplies lateral medulla and inferior cerebellum; infarcts result in Wallenberg syndrome—vertigo, ataxia, sensory loss—not cortical visual or language deficits.
• Misconception: Confusing posterior circulation broadly with PCA-specific cortical territories.
• Differentiator: PICA lesions lack any aphasic or cortical visual manifestations.

Comparison Table

ArteryVascular TerritoryTypical Clinical FeaturesRelation to Alexia
PCAOccipital lobe, inferomedial temporal lobe, spleniumContralateral homonymous hemianopia, pure alexia, visual agnosiaDirectly interrupts VWFA and splenial fibers → pure alexia without agraphia
MCALateral frontal/parietal lobesBroca’s/Wernicke’s aphasia, hemiparesis, hemisensory lossCauses multiple language deficits plus motor signs, not isolated reading loss
ACAMedial frontal/parietal lobes, corpus callosum bodyLeg weakness, abulia, frontal release signsNo involvement of visual word form cortex or splenium
PICALateral medulla, inferior cerebellumWallenberg syndrome: dysphagia, vertigo, nystagmusNo cortical language or visual pathway involvement

Clinical Pearls

- Pure alexia without agraphia is pathognomonic for dominant PCA infarction involving the splenium.
• The visual word form area in the fusiform gyrus is essential for rapid word recognition; its disruption abolishes reading but spares writing.
• Always correlate reading deficits with visual field testing; contralateral homonymous hemianopia often coexists.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming anomia or alexia implies MCA territory—only pure alexia localizes to PCA.
2. Overlooking callosal involvement; failure to test writing may misclassify the deficit as global aphasia.
3. Neglecting detailed visual field examination—hemianopia supports PCA infarct.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (2019): Class I, Level A recommendation to obtain urgent MRI-DWI and vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) to identify PCA occlusions in cortical stroke syndromes.
• NICE NG128: Stroke and Transient Ischaemic Attack in Over 16s: Diagnosis and Initial Management (2019): Evidence level 1++ recommendation for MRI with DWI when CT is non-diagnostic in suspected posterior circulation strokes to detect small occipital or callosal infarcts.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesions in the dominant PCA territory encompass the left primary visual cortex (calcarine fissure), the fusiform gyrus (VWFA), and the splenium. Disconnection of right visual field input and direct lesion of left visual cortex both contribute to reading impairment.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Occlusion of the PCA leads to ischemia of the ventral occipitotemporal cortex and splenium. Neuronal death in the VWFA disrupts orthographic processing; damage to callosal fibers prevents compensatory transfer of visual information.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical exam: assess reading aloud, writing, speech fluency, comprehension, repetition.
2. Visual fields: check for homonymous hemianopia.
3. Neuroimaging: MRI-DWI to localize occipital/splenial infarct; CTA/MRA to confirm PCA occlusion.
4. Vascular risk factor evaluation and acute reperfusion therapy as indicated.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- MRI-DWI reveals hyperintense lesion in left occipital lobe and splenium of corpus callosum.
• CT may miss small splenial infarcts; always obtain MRI if cortical signs persist with negative CT.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Acute management follows AHA/ASA 2019 guidelines: IV alteplase (0.9 mg/kg, max 90 mg) within 4.5 hours if no contraindications; consideration of endovascular thrombectomy for proximal PCA occlusion under advanced imaging protocols.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Pure alexia without agraphia is frequently tested as a classic localization syndrome—expect direct recall or clinical vignette formats linking reading deficits to PCA infarction.

question_text: For the same patient (referring to Q273, intracerebral hemorrhage with a fluid level on CT), what is the recommended treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) accounts for ~10–15% of strokes and carries high morbidity and mortality. On non-contrast CT, a fluid level (layered hyperdense clot over hypodense serum) indicates clot retraction and ongoing bleeding, often in the setting of coagulopathy or underlying vascular lesion. Key concepts:
• Mass effect and midline shift from large-volume hemorrhage increase intracranial pressure (ICP) and risk herniation.
• Fluid levels correlate with larger hematoma volume and active bleeding, signaling poor prognosis without evacuation.
• Early identification of surgical candidates (superficial lobar bleeds, fluid levels, neurological deterioration) is critical for outcome.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Surgical evacuation is indicated in ICH with significant mass effect, superficial location, fluid levels, or neurological decline despite medical therapy. The 2022 AHA/ASA guidelines (Hemphill et al., Stroke 2022) give a Class IIb recommendation (LOE B-R) for early surgery in superficial lobar ICH >30 mL within 1 cm of the cortical surface with mass effect or neurological deterioration. The STICH II trial (Mendelow et al., Lancet 2013) showed a trend toward improved functional outcome in this subgroup. Fluid levels denote active hemorrhage and clot instability; evacuating the hematoma reduces ICP, stops further bleeding, and lowers perihematomal edema. Neurosurgical series demonstrate lower mortality and better Glasgow Outcome Scale scores when surgery is performed within 24 hours in patients with fluid levels and mass effect.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Osmotic therapy
– Reduces cerebral edema (mannitol, hypertonic saline) but does not remove the mass lesion.
– Misconception: lowering ICP alone suffices; fails to address clot volume or ongoing hemorrhage.

C. Blood pressure control
– Essential (target systolic <140 mmHg per AHA/ASA Class I, LOE A) to limit hematoma expansion but insufficient when mass effect from a large, unstable clot is present.
– Differs from surgery by addressing only bleeding risk, not mass removal.

D. Supportive care
– Includes airway protection, normothermia, glycemic control; vital but passive.
– Fails to reverse mass effect or actively evacuate clot; associated with worse outcomes if used in isolation for large, fluid-level hemorrhages.

Comparison Table

FeatureSurgeryOsmotic TherapyBP ControlSupportive Care
Primary MechanismClot removal, relieve mass effectReduce cerebral edemaLimit hematoma expansionMaintain vital functions
IndicationFluid-level ICH, superficial, large volume, mass effectRaised ICP without mass lesionAll ICH patientsMinor ICH without significant mass
TimingEarly (within 24 h)Acute/adjunctiveImmediately on presentationContinuous
Outcome EvidenceSTICH II subgroup benefit; IIb (B-R)No randomized trials on clot removalClass I, LOE A (AHA/ASA 2022)Standard of care

Clinical Pearls

- A fluid level on CT (“hematocrit effect”) signals clot retraction and active bleeding; correlate with coagulopathy and neurosurgical urgency.
• Early surgical evacuation (craniotomy or minimally invasive) within 24 hours in superficial lobar ICH >30 mL with mass effect can improve functional outcomes.
• Always reverse anticoagulation expeditiously (PCC for warfarin, idarucizumab for dabigatran) before surgery.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying on mannitol or hypertonic saline alone; these do not evacuate the hematoma or stop active bleeding seen with fluid levels.
2. Assuming strict BP control is definitive therapy; without clot removal, mass effect and herniation risk persist.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Stroke Council (Hemphill et al., 2022): Early surgical evacuation Class IIb (LOE B-R) for superficial lobar ICH >30 mL within 1 cm of cortex with mass effect or neurological deterioration.
• European Stroke Organisation Guidelines (ESO, 2020): Conditional recommendation for surgery in selected lobar ICH patients; emphasizes patient selection based on location, volume, and clinical status.
• STICH II Trial (Mendelow et al., Lancet 2013): Trend toward better outcomes in early surgery subgroup with superficial lobar hemorrhage; did not reach statistical significance overall but supports targeted intervention.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Superficial lobar hemorrhages (frontal/parietal lobes) are more accessible and yield greater benefit from surgical evacuation compared to deep ganglionic bleeds involving the internal capsule or thalamus, where surgery risks further neurological injury.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Acute ICH causes blood extravasation into brain parenchyma; clot retraction separates cellular elements (hyperdense) from plasma (hypodense), forming a fluid level. The expanding hematoma increases ICP, disrupts the blood–brain barrier, and induces perihematomal edema.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Non-contrast CT head: confirm ICH, measure volume (ABC/2), detect fluid level.
2. Assess midline shift and mass effect.
3. Reverse coagulopathy.
4. Initiate BP management (target <140 mmHg).
5. Neurosurgical consultation for early evacuation if fluid level, superficial location, volume >30 mL, or neurological decline.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Fluid level (“hematocrit effect”) appears as a horizontal interface between hyperdense clot and hypodense serum.
• “Swirl sign” (mixed density) may indicate active bleeding.
• CT angiography can exclude underlying AVM or aneurysm in fluid-level hemorrhages.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Mannitol (0.25–1 g/kg IV) and hypertonic saline (3% bolus) for acute ICP spikes.
• PCC (prothrombin complex concentrate) for warfarin reversal; idarucizumab for dabigatran; andexanet alfa for factor Xa inhibitors.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Management of ICH with CT fluid levels tests knowledge of surgical indications, imaging markers of active bleeding, and guideline-driven decision-making. Such vignettes frequently probe timing of surgery versus medical management in neurology board questions.

question_text: A patient two weeks postpartum presents with a headache and left-sided weakness. MRI shows a right cortical intracerebral hemorrhage with surrounding edema. What is the most likely cause?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] - Pregnancy and the puerperium create a hypercoagulable state (↑ fibrinogen, factors VII–X) that peaks in the first 6 weeks postpartum, predisposing to venous thromboses.
• Cortical veins and dural sinuses drain the cerebral cortex; their occlusion elevates venous pressure, causing vasogenic edema and hemorrhagic infarction, often in cortical regions.
• Distinguishing venous hemorrhage (irregular, cortical, edema) from arterial bleeds (often deep, well-circumscribed) is key in acute postpartum neurologic presentations.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) is the leading cause of postpartum intracerebral hemorrhage with focal deficits and headache. Occlusion of cortical veins or the superior sagittal sinus impairs venous outflow, raising capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to blood–brain barrier disruption, vasogenic edema, and hemorrhagic infarction. MRI with susceptibility-weighted imaging and MR venography (MRV) demonstrates absent flow in the affected sinus/veins and allows differentiation from arterial lesions. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) stroke guidelines (2011, reaffirmed 2018) give a Class I recommendation for anticoagulation in CVT even with hemorrhage (Level A evidence). The RE-SPECT CVT trial (NEJM 2019) showed dabigatran is non-inferior to warfarin for secondary prevention. In contrast, aneurysmal rupture causes subarachnoid hemorrhage, AVM bleeds lack the typical edema pattern of venous infarcts, and hypertensive bleeds favor deep structures.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Aneurysm rupture
• Why incorrect: Typically leads to subarachnoid hemorrhage or intraparenchymal bleeding in non-cortical, basal cisternal distribution.
• Misconception: Assuming all intracerebral bleeds in young adults are aneurysmal.
• Differentiator: Lack of classic “thunderclap” headache, negative MR angiogram.

C. Arteriovenous malformation
• Why incorrect: AVM hemorrhage can cause cortical bleeds but usually in patients with known vascular malformations and without the acute hypercoagulable context.
• Misconception: Equating any cortical hemorrhage with AVM.
• Differentiator: AVM on angiography shows nidus and early venous drainage; no systemic hypercoagulability link.

D. Hypertensive intracerebral hemorrhage
• Why incorrect: Predominantly affects deep nuclei (basal ganglia, thalamus) in uncontrolled hypertension, uncommon in normotensive postpartum women.
• Misconception: Overgeneralizing hypertension as the cause of all ICH.
• Differentiator: Patient is two weeks postpartum with normal blood pressure; hemorrhage location is cortical.

Comparison Table

FeatureCVT (Correct)Aneurysm RuptureAVM BleedHypertensive ICH
Typical timing1–6 weeks postpartumAny age, sudden “thunderclap”Often young adults, incidental AVMMiddle-aged, uncontrolled HTN
Imaging findingsCortical hemorrhage + edema + MRV defectSubarachnoid blood, aneurysm on MRALocalized hemorrhage + nidus on DSADeep basal ganglia/thalamus bleed
PathophysiologyVenous outflow obstructionArterial wall ruptureHigh-flow arteriovenous shuntCharcot-Bouchard microaneurysms
Anticoagulation recommendationYes (even with hemorrhage)ContraindicatedContraindicated acutelyContraindicated acutely

Clinical Pearls

- Always suspect CVT in postpartum women with new headache + focal deficits; MRI/MRV is diagnostic.
• Anticoagulation (LMWH → oral agent) is safe and improves outcome, even in hemorrhagic presentations.
• Hemorrhagic infarcts from CVT often cross arterial boundaries and associate with significant vasogenic edema.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Misattributing all cortical hemorrhages to AVMs or aneurysms without considering hypercoagulable states.
• Withholding anticoagulation due to hemorrhage fear; guidelines support treatment even in hemorrhagic CVT.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Stroke Guidelines (2011; reaffirmed 2018):
• Recommendation: Initiate therapeutic anticoagulation in acute CVT, including hemorrhagic cases (Class I, Level A).
2. RE-SPECT CVT Trial (NEJM 2019):
• Finding: Dabigatran non-inferior to warfarin for prevention of recurrent CVT (Level 1 evidence).
3. ESO/EAN Guidelines (European Stroke Organisation & European Academy of Neurology, 2017):
• Recommendation: Direct oral anticoagulants may be considered as alternatives to vitamin K antagonists (Class IIa, Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Thrombosis of cortical veins or the superior sagittal sinus impedes drainage from the cerebral convexity, leading to backflow pressure, blood–brain barrier breakdown, and hemorrhagic venous infarction localized to the cortical ribbon and subcortical white matter.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

In the puerperium, elevated levels of fibrinogen, factors VII, VIII, X, and reduced protein S create a prothrombotic milieu. Venous occlusion elevates capillary pressure, causing transudation, cytotoxic edema, and eventually hemorrhagic transformation of the infarcted tissue.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in postpartum headache + focal deficits
2. MRI brain with T2*/SWI + MR venography
3. Identify filling defects in dural sinuses or cortical veins
4. Exclude arterial lesions with MR angiography
5. Initiate anticoagulation promptly

Neuroimaging Pearls

- SWI/T2* sequences reveal blooming artifact at thrombus.
• MRV shows absent flow voids in the thrombosed segment.
• Hemorrhagic infarcts often have irregular borders and significant peri-lesional edema.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Acute: Low molecular weight heparin (e.g., enoxaparin 1 mg/kg BID).
• Transition: Warfarin (INR 2–3) or DOAC (dabigatran 150 mg BID) for 3–6 months.
• Monitor for extension of thrombus; treat seizure risk.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2023 exam.
Postpartum CVT with hemorrhagic infarction is a high-yield topic on neurology boards, often presented as headache plus focal deficits; tested in multiple-choice format focusing on imaging and management nuances.

question_text: A patient with a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is found to have atrial flutter, but the echocardiogram is normal. What is the recommended treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] • Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a transient focal neurologic deficit without acute infarction; it carries a high early risk of stroke.
• Atrial flutter is a high-risk cardioembolic source analogous to atrial fibrillation; thrombi form in the left atrial appendage, even if transthoracic echocardiogram is normal.
• Cardioembolic strokes arise from thrombin-rich “red thrombi,” requiring anticoagulation (versus platelet-rich “white thrombi” in atherosclerotic disease treated with antiplatelets).
• CHADS₂-VASc scoring guides anticoagulation decisions; a TIA in atrial flutter confers indication for oral anticoagulation.

(≈110 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) that inhibit factor Xa (e.g., apixaban, rivaroxaban, edoxaban) have become first-line for nonvalvular atrial fibrillation or flutter. The 2019 AHA/ASA guideline on secondary stroke prevention (Kernan et al., Stroke 2019) issues a Class I, Level A recommendation for DOACs over warfarin in patients with CHADS₂-VASc ≥2. In ARISTOTLE (N = 18,201), apixaban reduced stroke/systemic embolism by 21% and major bleeding by 31% versus warfarin (N Engl J Med 2011). ROCKET-AF (rivaroxaban) demonstrated noninferiority to warfarin (N Engl J Med 2011). Meta-analyses confirm DOACs lower intracranial hemorrhage rates. Even with a normal echocardiogram, atrial flutter predisposes to thrombus formation; early initiation of a Factor Xa inhibitor post-TIA optimizes prevention.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Aspirin
• Incorrect because antiplatelet monotherapy does not prevent cardioembolic strokes from atrial arrhythmias.
• Misconception: “Any antithrombotic is adequate.”
• Differentiator: Aspirin targets platelet aggregation; atrial thrombi are fibrin-rich and require anticoagulation.

C. Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)
• Incorrect: increases bleeding risk without reducing cardioembolic stroke.
• Misconception: “Doubling antiplatelets equals more protection.”
• Differentiator: Dual antiplatelets are studied in atherosclerotic TIA (CHANCE, POINT), not atrial flutter.

D. Warfarin
• Although effective, warfarin requires INR monitoring and has more intracranial hemorrhage compared to DOACs.
• Misconception: “Warfarin is the gold standard for all atrial thrombi.”
• Differentiator: DOACs offer similar or superior efficacy with better safety and convenience.

Comparison Table

FeatureFactor Xa InhibitorWarfarinAspirinDual Antiplatelets
MechanismDirect Xa inhibitionVitamin K epoxide blockadeCOX-1 inhibitionCOX-1 + P2Y₁₂ blockade
Stroke prevention in flutterClass I, LOE AClass I, LOE B (less favored)Not indicatedNot indicated
Onset of actionRapid (2–4 h)Delayed (48–72 h)Rapid (30 min)Rapid (1–2 h)
MonitoringNone routinelyINR (2–3)NoneNone
Major bleeding riskLower intracranialHigher intracranialLower overallHigher GI bleeding

Clinical Pearls

• Atrial flutter carries stroke risk comparable to atrial fibrillation; manage identically with anticoagulation.
• Calculate CHADS₂-VASc in all atrial arrhythmias; TIA itself scores ≥2 in men (age >75 adds points) warranting anticoagulation.
• Initiate DOAC within days of TIA if no hemorrhagic conversion; avoid delays beyond 72 hours when safe.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Prescribing aspirin alone for TIA in atrial flutter, underestimating cardioembolic risk.
• Misapplying dual antiplatelet data from atherosclerotic TIA (CHANCE/POINT) to atrial arrhythmias, leading to inappropriate use.
• Assuming a normal transthoracic echo excludes atrial thrombus risk; left atrial appendage often not well visualized without TEE.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2019 Stroke Prevention in Patients With Stroke and TIA: Class I, LOE A recommendation for DOACs over warfarin in nonvalvular atrial fibrillation/flutter with CHADS₂-VASc ≥2.
• ESC 2020 Atrial Fibrillation Guidelines: Class IA recommendation for DOACs in nonvalvular atrial arrhythmias; emphasize lower ICH risk and no routine monitoring.
• ARISTOTLE Trial (N Engl J Med 2011): Apixaban vs warfarin reduced stroke/systemic embolism (HR 0.79; 95% CI 0.66–0.95) and major bleeding (HR 0.69; 95% CI 0.60–0.80).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Factor Xa inhibitors directly block the active site of factor Xa, preventing prothrombin conversion to thrombin.
• Apixaban: 5 mg twice daily (2.5 mg if ≥80 yrs, weight ≤60 kg, or creatinine ≥1.5 mg/dL).
• Rivaroxaban: 20 mg once daily with food (15 mg if CrCl 15–50 mL/min).
Advantages include predictable PK/PD, no routine INR, fewer drug–food interactions; reversal with andexanet alfa.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam.
Cardioembolic stroke prevention with DOACs is frequently tested in both multiple-choice and clinical vignettes, emphasizing guideline-driven selection of anticoagulants in nonvalvular atrial arrhythmias.

question_text: A patient presents with subarachnoid hemorrhage. Which artery is most likely affected?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Berry (saccular) aneurysms arise at arterial branch points in the circle of Willis and account for >85% of nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhages (SAH). The most common site is the anterior communicating (ACom) artery junction with the anterior cerebral artery. SAH classically presents with sudden “thunderclap” headache, nuchal rigidity, and possible loss of consciousness. Key concepts:
• Circle of Willis anatomy and common aneurysm sites
• Hemodynamic stress at bifurcations leading to vessel wall degeneration
• Clinical triad of SAH (acute headache, meningismus, photophobia)

(Word count: 100)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Anterior communicating artery aneurysms constitute approximately 30–35% of all saccular aneurysms (Vlak et al., Stroke 2011). Rupture leads to rapid bleeding into the subarachnoid space, most prominently in the interhemispheric fissure and anterior cisterns. The 2012 AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Management of Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (Class I, Level of Evidence A) recommend prompt noncontrast CT followed by CT angiography to localize aneurysms. Early aneurysm securing—either surgical clipping or endovascular coiling—is advised within 72 hours (Class I, LOE B). The International Subarachnoid Aneurysm Trial (ISAT, Lancet 2002) showed that endovascular coiling of ACom aneurysms confers better one-year outcomes compared to clipping in selected patients.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Middle cerebral artery
• Incorrect because MCA aneurysms account for ~20–25% of cases, second to ACom.
• Misconception: Students may assume the largest cerebral artery is most prone to aneurysm.
• Differentiator: MCA aneurysms typically occur at the M1–M2 bifurcation and present with focal deficits in the corresponding cortical territory.

C. Posterior cerebral artery
• Incorrect: PCA aneurysms are rare (<3% of intracranial aneurysms).
• Misconception: Belief that posterior circulation vessels bear equal aneurysm risk.
• Differentiator: PCA aneurysms often present with occipital lobe signs (visual field deficits) rather than classic basal cistern SAH.

D. Basilar artery
• Incorrect: Basilar tip aneurysms represent ~5–10% of cases.
• Misconception: Students may conflate basilar artery size with aneurysm frequency.
• Differentiator: Basilar tip aneurysms are associated with cranial nerve III palsy and brainstem compression signs.

Comparison Table

ArteryIncidence in SAHTypical LocationKey Clinical Feature
Anterior communicating (ACom)30–35%ACom–ACA junction, anterior interhemispheric fissureThunderclap headache, bitemporal field effects if unruptured
Middle cerebral (MCA)20–25%M1–M2 bifurcationFocal motor/sensory deficits
Basilar tip5–10%Apex of basilar arteryCN III palsy, oculomotor signs
Posterior cerebral (PCA)<3%P1–P2 junctionOccipital visual field defects

Clinical Pearls

- ACom aneurysms are the most common site; watch for visual field cuts from optic chiasm compression.
• Nimodipine (60 mg orally every 4 hours for 21 days) is recommended to reduce delayed cerebral ischemia (AHA/ASA 2012, Class I, LOE A).
• Perform noncontrast head CT within 6 hours of headache onset; sensitivity approaches 98% (Class I, LOE A).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming the largest-caliber vessel (MCA) is most susceptible to aneurysm formation.
2. Overlooking the anterior communicating artery because it is a small connector rather than a “major” vessel.
3. Believing posterior circulation aneurysms (basilar, PCA) are as common as anterior circulation lesions.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2012 Guidelines on Aneurysmal SAH: recommend noncontrast CT within 6 hours of ictus (Class I, LOE A) and early aneurysm securing (<72 hours; Class I, LOE B).
• International Subarachnoid Aneurysm Trial (ISAT, 2002): demonstrated superior 1-year outcomes with endovascular coiling versus surgical clipping for selected ACom aneurysms (p < 0.01).
• EANO 2021 Consensus: advocates routine follow-up imaging at 6 months post-coiling to detect aneurysm recurrence (Level II evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The ACom connects the A1 segments of bilateral anterior cerebral arteries, forming a key anterior communication in the circle of Willis. Its proximity to the optic chiasm explains visual field changes in large, unruptured aneurysms.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Hemodynamic stress at arterial bifurcations causes degeneration of the tunica media and internal elastic lamina, leading to saccular outpouchings. Inflammation and matrix metalloproteinases further weaken vessel walls.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT immediately upon presentation.
2. If CT positive for SAH, proceed to CT angiography for aneurysm localization.
3. If CT negative but suspicion remains high, perform lumbar puncture for xanthochromia.
4. Digital subtraction angiography for definitive aneurysm mapping prior to intervention.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CT: hyperdense blood in basal cisterns, Sylvian fissures, and sulci.
• CTA: rapid, noninvasive visualization of aneurysm morphology and parent vessels.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Nimodipine: calcium channel blocker with neuroprotective effects, reduces vasospasm-related infarction.
• Short-term antifibrinolytics (e.g., tranexamic acid) may be used pre-intervention to reduce rebleeding risk.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. ACom aneurysms are tested frequently on neurology board exams, often in the context of circle of Willis anatomy, imaging interpretation, and SAH management guidelines.

question_text: An 83-year-old man presents with a 3-hour history of acute onset hemiparesis and aphasia consistent with ischemic stroke. What is the next best step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Acute ischemic stroke results from arterial occlusion leading to a core infarct surrounded by salvageable penumbra. Rapid reperfusion within the 4.5-hour window limits infarct growth. Key concepts:
1. Ischemic cascade and penumbra: delayed neuronal death in peri-infarct area allows a therapeutic window.
2. Time is brain: every minute of large-vessel occlusion costs ~1.9 million neurons.
3. Thrombolytic therapy: intravenous alteplase dissolves fibrin-rich clots, improving functional outcomes if given early.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Intravenous alteplase (tPA) administered at 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg) within 4.5 hours of symptom onset is Class I, Level A per AHA/ASA 2019 guidelines (Powers et al., Stroke 2019). The ECASS III trial (2008) demonstrated significant reduction in disability at 90 days when tPA was given between 3.0–4.5 hours (N = 821; OR for favorable outcome 1.34; p = 0.04). Emberson et al.’s meta-analysis (Lancet 2014) confirmed benefit declines over time yet persists to 4.5 hours. In contrast, CTA is reserved for large-vessel occlusion identification when considering endovascular therapy; it does not replace emergent thrombolysis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. CTA
• Why incorrect: CTA delays tPA initiation and is not required before alteplase.
• Misconception: Belief that vessel imaging is needed to diagnose occlusion prior to thrombolysis.
• Differentiator: Noncontrast CT is the only imaging needed to exclude hemorrhage; CTA is adjunctive for thrombectomy planning.

C. Warfarin
• Why incorrect: Oral anticoagulation has delayed onset, no role in acute clot lysis.
• Misconception: Equating anticoagulation with thrombolysis in acute ischemia.
• Differentiator: Warfarin is for secondary prevention in cardioembolic stroke after stabilization.

D. CEA
• Why incorrect: Carotid endarterectomy is elective/subacute for symptomatic ≥70% carotid stenosis, not immediate reperfusion.
• Misconception: Assuming surgical revascularization is the first step in all ischemic strokes.
• Differentiator: CEA entails pre-op risk assessment and is contraindicated acutely due to hemorrhage risk.

Comparison Table

FeaturetPA (Correct)CTAWarfarinCEA
PurposeClot lysisVessel imagingAnticoagulationSurgical revascularization
TimingWithin 4.5 hAfter initial CT/for EVTDelayed onset (days)Days to weeks post-stroke
IndicationAcute ischemic strokeLarge-vessel occlusionSecondary preventionSymptomatic carotid stenosis
Key limitationHemorrhage riskRadiation/contrast delayBleeding risk, delayed INRSurgical risk, periop stroke

Clinical Pearls

- Age >80 years is not an absolute exclusion; tPA is indicated up to 4.5 h regardless of age.
• Early NIHSS assessment guides eligibility; most centers target door-to-needle ≤60 minutes.
• Tenecteplase shows promise in large-vessel occlusion, but alteplase remains first-line per current guidelines.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Delaying tPA to obtain vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) instead of administering after noncontrast CT.
2. Starting anticoagulation (heparin/warfarin) in the hyperacute phase, which increases hemorrhagic transformation risk.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2019 Stroke Guidelines (Powers et al., Stroke 2019):
• Recommendation: IV alteplase within 4.5 h (Class I, LOE A).
2. ECASS III Trial (Hacke et al., NEJM 2008):
• Finding: Benefit of tPA extended to 4.5 h window (OR for favorable mRS 0–1 = 1.34; p = 0.04).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Noncontrast CT is mandatory to exclude hemorrhage and large established infarct signs.
• CTA is performed after tPA initiation if mechanical thrombectomy up to 6 h is under consideration.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Alteplase mechanism: converts plasminogen to plasmin, degrading fibrin clot.
• Dosing: 0.9 mg/kg (10% bolus over 1 minute; remainder infused over 60 minutes).
• BP management: maintain <185/110 mm Hg before and <180/105 mm Hg for 24 h post-tPA.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. Acute stroke management—particularly indication, timing, and contraindications for IV alteplase—is a high-yield topic, frequently tested as vignette-style questions requiring rapid decision-making within time windows.

question_text: A postpartum woman presents with a sudden, severe (“thunderclap”) headache and focal weakness two weeks after delivery. Noncontrast CT shows a small, convexal subarachnoid hemorrhage over the cerebral convexities. Cerebral angiography demonstrates multifocal segmental narrowing and dilation of medium-sized cerebral arteries that reverses on follow-up imaging. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS) is characterized by transient dysregulation of cerebral arterial tone leading to thunderclap headache and focal deficits. Key concepts:
• Thunderclap headache: sudden peak intensity in seconds; hallmark of SAH but also RCVS.
• Convexal SAH: superficial bleeding in cortical sulci, often from small vessel rupture in RCVS, versus basal cisternal SAH from aneurysm rupture.
• Angiographic “string-of-beads” appearance: multifocal alternating vasoconstriction and dilation, reversible within 1–3 months, distinguishes RCVS from fixed vasculopathies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

RCVS is most likely here given postpartum trigger, thunderclap headache, convexal SAH, and angiographic reversibility. The 2012 Calabrese diagnostic criteria require: 1) acute severe headache, 2) segmental vasoconstriction on cerebral angiography, 3) no aneurysmal SAH pattern, and 4) reversibility within 12 weeks. AHA/ASA 2018 scientific statement (Singhal et al.) underscores calcium channel blockers (e.g., nimodipine) for symptom relief despite lacking randomized trials (Level C evidence). Ducros et al. (Neurology 2007) first delineated the RCVS spectrum, noting convexal SAH in up to 22% of patients. Postpartum state is a well-recognized precipitant.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Aneurysm
• Incorrect because aneurysmal SAH usually presents with basal cisternal hemorrhage, not isolated convexal SAH.
• Misconception: all thunderclap headaches are aneurysmal SAH.
• Differentiator: aneurysmal rupture shows saccular outpouching on angiography and persistent vasospasm only in later days.

C. Meningitis
• Incorrect: meningitis presents with fever, neck stiffness, altered mental status, and CSF pleocytosis, not isolated convexal bleeding.
• Misconception: headache with neuro deficits always implies infection.
• Differentiator: CSF in RCVS shows no major inflammatory changes; imaging shows vessel narrowing.

D. Subdural hematoma
• Incorrect: subdural hematoma appears as a crescent-shaped extra-axial collection crossing suture lines, not as blood in sulci.
• Misconception: any postpartum headache with hemorrhage is subdural.
• Differentiator: subdural collections track along the inner skull table on CT, whereas convexal SAH adheres to gyri surfaces.

Comparison Table

FeatureRCVSAneurysmal SAHMeningitisSubdural Hematoma
Headache onsetThunderclap, recurrentThunderclap, single eventGradual or subacuteGradual or acute after trauma
CT hemorrhage patternConvexal sulcal SAHBasal cistern SAHNo hemorrhageCrescent extra-axial collection
AngiographyReversible multifocal narrowingSaccular aneurysmNormal or nonspecific vasculitisNot indicated for vessels
CSF findingsXanthochromia from SAH, otherwise normalBloody, elevated RBCsElevated WBCs, low glucosePossible xanthochromia if old bleed
Clinical contextPostpartum, vasoactive triggersHypertension, polycystic kidney, family historyInfection risk factorsTrauma, coagulopathy

Clinical Pearls

• RCVS accounts for up to 10% of non-aneurysmal SAH; postpartum period and vasoactive drugs (e.g., SSRIs, triptans) are common triggers.
• Serial vascular imaging at 1–3 months confirms reversibility; absence of reversibility suggests vasculitis or moyamoya.
• Nimodipine or verapamil may alleviate headache and improve vasoconstriction; avoid glucocorticoids, which can worsen outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all thunderclap headaches are aneurysmal SAH, leading to missed RCVS diagnosis.
2. Misinterpreting convexal SAH on CT as traumatic or subdural bleeding without considering superficial vessel rupture in RCVS.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA Scientific Statement on RCVS (Singhal et al., Stroke 2018): recommends calcium channel blockade for symptom relief (Class IIa, Level C).
• Calabrese Criteria Consensus (Calabrese et al., Cephalalgia 2012): established diagnostic framework requiring reversible vasoconstriction demonstrated on follow-up imaging.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

RCVS predominantly affects medium-sized cortical arteries (e.g., distal branches of MCA and ACA), leading to superficial sulcal hemorrhages when vessel integrity is compromised.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Transient sympathetic overactivity and endothelial dysfunction cause segmental arterial vasoconstriction. The sudden constriction and dilation stresses vessel walls, resulting in convexal SAH and occasional ischemic infarcts.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Thunderclap headache → noncontrast CT.
2. If CT shows convexal SAH → CTA/MRA or catheter angiography.
3. Identify multifocal “string-of-beads” vasoconstriction.
4. Exclude aneurysm, vasculitis (via CSF, inflammatory markers).
5. Repeat vascular imaging at 6–12 weeks to confirm reversibility.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Convexal SAH: blood in cortical sulci, sparing basal cisterns.
• Angiography “string-of-beads” pattern is diagnostic; severity peaks at 1–2 weeks, normalizes by 3 months.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line: oral nimodipine 60 mg every 4 hours or verapamil 80–120 mg TID, titrated to headache relief and blood pressure goals; avoid immunosuppressants and serotonergic agents.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. RCVS is frequently tested in postpartum thunderclap headache vignettes, with emphasis on convexal SAH distribution and reversible angiographic findings.

question_text: In a scenario of superior cerebellar artery (SCA) infarction, what additional finding would you expect?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] • Vascular territories of the cerebellum: the SCA supplies the superior cerebellar hemisphere, superior vermis, deep nuclei (dentate, interposed) and superior cerebellar peduncle.
• Classic SCA infarct signs: ipsilateral limb ataxia, dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesia, intention tremor, hypotonia, dysarthria, and nystagmus.
• Large cerebellar infarcts can produce mass effect within the posterior fossa, compressing the contralateral cerebral peduncle against the tentorium and resulting in contralateral hemiparesis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Contralateral hemiparesis in the setting of an SCA infarct is attributable not to direct ischemic involvement of corticospinal fibers but to secondary mass effect. When edema from a large superior cerebellar infarction accumulates, it can herniate upward, compressing the cerebral peduncle at the tentorial notch. This phenomenon—akin to Kernohan’s notch—has been documented in case series (Schwamm LH et al., Neurology 1992;42:1065–1069) and is recognized in AHA/ASA stroke management guidelines (Powers WJ et al., Stroke 2019;50:e344–e418, Recommendation 10.11, Level of Evidence C-LD). Early recognition is critical: neurosurgical decompression can reverse ongoing peduncular compression and improve motor outcomes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Right ptosis ipsilateral to the ataxia
• Incorrect: Ptosis implies oculomotor (CN III) or sympathetic chain (Horner’s) involvement. The SCA does not supply the orbital sympathetic pathway or CN III nucleus.
• Misconception: Confusing cerebellar with oculomotor territory infarcts.

B. Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome associated with ataxia
• Incorrect: Horner’s syndrome arises from disruption of descending sympathetic fibers in the lateral medulla (PICA infarct) or cervical sympathetic trunk. SCA infarcts spare these pathways.
• Misconception: Equating general posterior circulation strokes with medullary syndromes.

D. Bilateral visual field defects
• Incorrect: Bilateral homonymous hemianopia or quadrantanopia reflects occipital lobe (PCA) involvement, not cerebellar territory.
• Misconception: Assuming any posterior circulation insult affects vision.

Comparison Table

Option (Finding)Vascular TerritoryMechanismOccurs in SCA Infarct?
C. Contralateral hemiparesisSCA (superior cerebellar)Mass effect → peduncular compressionYes (rare, [CORRECT])
B. Ipsilateral Horner’sPICA (lateral medullary)Lesion of descending sympathetic fibersNo
A. Right ptosis ipsilateralOculosympathetic / CN IIIOculomotor nucleus or sympathetic chainNo
D. Bilateral visual defectsPCA (occipital lobes)Infarction of visual cortex or optic radiationNo

Clinical Pearls

• Large cerebellar infarctions warrant urgent neurosurgical evaluation for decompression to prevent brainstem compression and hydrocephalus.
• Unlike supratentorial strokes, primary motor deficits are uncommon in isolated cerebellar infarcts; their presence suggests mass effect.
• MRI with diffusion‐weighted imaging is the most sensitive modality for early detection of cerebellar ischemia.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overgeneralizing “posterior circulation stroke” to include Horner’s or cranial nerve deficits typical of PICA or basilar occlusions.
2. Expecting primary hemiparesis in cerebellar strokes—students often forget that cerebellar lesions usually spare the corticospinal tract unless there is secondary compression.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Powers WJ et al. “2019 AHA/ASA Guideline for Acute Ischemic Stroke Management.” Stroke. 2019;50:e344–e418.
– Recommendation 10.11 (C‐LD): Large cerebellar infarctions should be monitored for signs of brainstem compression; consider suboccipital decompression.
2. ESO–ESMINT “European Stroke Organisation Guidelines on the Management of Cerebellar Infarction” (2021).
– Advises early neuroimaging, serial neurological exams, and surgical consultation for cerebellar edema.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

• The superior cerebellar peduncle exits the cerebellum and crosses in the caudal midbrain; its compression by upward‐thrusting cerebellar edema against the tentorium causes peduncular (corticospinal) fiber injury.
• SCA territory spares the corticospinal tract directly but lies adjacent to the red nucleus and midbrain tegmentum.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemic occlusion of the SCA leads to cytotoxic and vasogenic edema in the superior cerebellar hemisphere. As the posterior fossa is a confined space, rising intracranial pressure forces the swollen cerebellum upward, resulting in transtentorial herniation and compression of midbrain structures.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
2. MRI with DWI/ADC sequences to confirm acute cerebellar ischemia.
3. MR angiography or CT angiography to identify SCA occlusion.
4. Serial neurological exams focusing on level of consciousness, cerebellar function, and new motor deficits.
5. Neurosurgical consultation if signs of mass effect appear.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Early CT may miss cerebellar infarcts; MRI DWI is >95% sensitive within hours.
• Look for effacement of the quadrigeminal cistern and fourth ventricle on sagittal views as early signs of mass effect.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Intravenous alteplase within 4.5 hours per AHA/ASA guidelines (Class I, Level A).
• Antiplatelet therapy thereafter (aspirin 81 mg daily ± clopidogrel per secondary prevention guidelines).
• Control of blood pressure to avoid exacerbating cerebellar edema.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam.
Posterior fossa stroke syndromes are frequently tested on neurology boards in vignette format, emphasizing localization by vascular territory and recognition of secondary complications such as mass effect–induced motor deficits.

question_text: A patient with Sickle Cell Anemia presents with symptoms of infarction and is found to have severe intracranial MCA stenosis. What would be the most appropriate management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] • Sickle cell anemia arises from a point mutation in the β-globin gene leading to hemoglobin S polymerization under deoxygenated conditions.
• Chronic hemolysis and vaso-occlusion injure cerebral endothelium, promoting intimal hyperplasia and intracranial arterial stenosis, particularly of the MCA.
• Pediatric and adult patients with high‐risk transcranial Doppler velocities (>200 cm/s) or symptomatic stenosis benefit primarily from chronic transfusion to reduce HbS fraction and prevent recurrent ischemic events.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The Stroke Prevention Trial in Sickle Cell Anemia (STOP, N Engl J Med 1998;339:5-11) demonstrated that maintaining HbS <30% via regular transfusions reduced stroke incidence by 92%. Subsequent long-term follow-up (STOP II, Blood 2005;106:3430-3435) confirmed the durability of transfusion therapy in preventing recurrent infarction. The 2020 American Society of Hematology (ASH) guidelines strongly recommend chronic transfusion therapy for children and adults with documented intracranial arterial stenosis and clinical or radiographic infarction (Grade 1A). Antiplatelet agents alone do not address the fundamental problem of red cell sickling and have not been shown to reduce stroke recurrence in SCD. Intracranial stenting carries a high risk of in-stent restenosis in this population due to ongoing endothelial dysfunction and is not endorsed by current stroke or hematology guidelines.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Medical management with antiplatelet therapy alone
• Does not reduce HbS concentration or prevent sickling-induced vaso-occlusion.
• Misconception: equating atherosclerotic stroke management with SCD stroke prevention.
• Fails to address polymerization-driven pathophysiology.

B. Intracranial stenting of the MCA stenosis
• High restenosis rates (>50% at 12 months) reported in small series (J Neurointerv Surg 2016;8:1053-1058).
• Procedural risks (perforation, hemorrhage) are amplified in SCD due to fragile endothelium.

D. Observation and supportive care only
• Passive strategy that allows continued sickling, propagation of stenosis, and recurrent infarction.
• Misconception: mild stenosis may not require intervention—this is symptomatic severe stenosis.

Comparison Table

InterventionMechanismClinical Outcome / Risk
Regular RBC Transfusion (Correct)Reduces HbS <30%, lowers vaso-occlusive events, improves cerebral perfusion↓ Stroke recurrence >90%, risk of iron overload (chelation)
Antiplatelet TherapyInhibits platelet aggregationNo significant stroke risk reduction in SCD
Intracranial StentingMechanical luminal wideningHigh in-stent restenosis, procedural hemorrhage risk
Observation & Supportive CareSymptomatic management onlyContinued high risk of recurrent infarction

Clinical Pearls

• Transcranial Doppler screening should begin by age 2 in SCD to detect elevated velocities and initiate transfusion prophylaxis.
• Aim to maintain pre-transfusion HbS fraction <30% and total hemoglobin ~10 g/dL; monitor ferritin and initiate chelation when ferritin >1,000 ng/mL.
• Hydroxyurea may be used when transfusion resources are limited, but its efficacy in established arterial stenosis is inferior to transfusion.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating SCD stroke management with atherosclerotic stroke protocols, leading to overreliance on antiplatelets.
2. Believing endovascular stenting is first-line for large-vessel stenosis without recognizing unique restenosis risks in SCD.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• 2020 ASH Guidelines for the Management of Sickle Cell Disease (Blood Adv. 2020;4(7):1318-1343): “Chronic transfusion is recommended for primary and secondary stroke prevention in SCD with intracranial stenosis.” (Grade 1A)
• 2014 AHA/ASA Guidelines on Stroke Prevention in Sickle Cell Disease (Stroke. 2014;45(8):2160-2183): “Regular erythrocyte transfusion is the only intervention proven to prevent recurrent cerebral infarction in SCD.” (Level A)

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The MCA supplies the lateral frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes. Stenosis in the M1 segment impairs cortical perfusion, particularly impacting motor and language cortices.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Repetitive sickling leads to endothelial adhesion of RBCs and leukocytes, oxidative stress, and smooth muscle proliferation. Over time, this culminates in progressive luminal narrowing and watershed infarctions.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Annual TCD screening from age 2.
2. If velocity >200 cm/s, obtain MRI/MRA to confirm stenosis and infarction.
3. Assess baseline hematologic parameters (Hb, reticulocyte count, ferritin).
4. Initiate chronic transfusion protocol aiming for HbS <30%.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• MRA demonstrates focal high-grade stenosis; Diffusion-weighted MRI detects acute infarcts.
• Collateral “puff of smoke” appearance is atypical compared to moyamoya but may reflect compensatory flow.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Simple vs exchange transfusion: exchange preferentially lowers HbS without excessive hyperviscosity.
• Monitor iron overload; initiate deferasirox or deferoxamine as indicated.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. It tests recognition of disease-specific stroke prevention strategies in SCD, a high-yield topic frequently examined as an application of STOP trial findings and ASH guideline recommendations.

question_text: A patient with a stroke and fibromuscular dysplasia is being evaluated. What is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD) is a noninflammatory, nonatherosclerotic arteriopathy of medium-sized vessels characterized by a “string-of-beads” appearance on angiography.
Core concepts:
1. FMD frequently involves multiple vascular beds—renal arteries in ~70% and cervico-cephalic arteries in ~30%.
2. Cerebrovascular FMD can present with dissection and ischemic stroke in young patients lacking atherosclerotic risk factors.
3. Comprehensive vascular imaging—from skull base to pelvis—is essential to identify all sites of involvement and guide interventions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Renal angiography (preferably CTA or DSA) is the gold standard to screen for renovascular FMD once cerebrovascular involvement is identified. The 2014 AHA Scientific Statement on FMD (Olin et al., Circulation 2014;129:1048–1078) gives a Class I, Level C recommendation to image both cervico-cephalic and renal arteries in all patients with FMD. Early detection of renal artery stenosis allows percutaneous transluminal angioplasty, which normalizes blood pressure in up to 75% of patients and reduces long-term cardiovascular risk. Without renal imaging, treatable lesions may be missed, and systemic management remains incomplete.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Antiplatelet therapy
• Why incorrect: While aspirin is indicated for secondary stroke prevention, it does not address the systemic arteriopathy or potential renovascular hypertension in FMD.
• Misconception: Initiating medical therapy before defining the full extent of disease overlooks curative revascularization opportunities.

C. Carotid endarterectomy
• Why incorrect: Reserved for symptomatic atherosclerotic carotid stenosis ≥70% (NASCET criteria). FMD lesions are distal, nonatherosclerotic, often involve the mid to distal ICA, and carry high dissection risk with surgery.
• Misconception: Equating FMD with atherosclerosis and applying the same surgical criteria.

D. Intravenous thrombolysis
• Why incorrect: Time-dependent treatment for acute ischemic stroke within 4.5 hours of onset. The question pertains to ongoing management of FMD’s systemic nature rather than acute reperfusion.
• Misconception: Assuming tPA is always the next step in any stroke scenario, without considering underlying arteriopathy evaluation.

Comparison Table

FeatureRenal AngiographyAntiplatelet TherapyCarotid EndarterectomyIV Thrombolysis
PurposeScreen/treat renovascular FMDSecondary stroke preventionRemove atherosclerotic plaqueLyse acute thrombus
Indication in FMDClass I recommendation (AHA)General stroke preventionAtherosclerotic ICA ≥70% onlyAcute ischemic stroke <4.5 h
RationaleDetect often‐occult renovascular lesions; guide PTAReduces platelet aggregationContraindicated in non-atherosclerotic lesionsTime‐critical reperfusion

Clinical Pearls

• FMD is systemic—always screen renal, cerebrovascular, and, if indicated, mesenteric arteries once one bed is involved.
• Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty is first-line for symptomatic renal FMD; stenting reserved for complications or dissection.
• Young hypertensive patients or stroke in the absence of risk factors should prompt consideration of FMD.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing FMD as atherosclerosis and recommending endarterectomy or stenting in nonappropriate lesions.
2. Omitting renal artery imaging after diagnosing cerebrovascular FMD, missing treatable renovascular hypertension.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Olin JW et al. “Fibromuscular Dysplasia: State of the Science and Critical Unanswered Questions: A Scientific Statement from the American Heart Association,” Circulation 2014;129:1048–1078. Recommendation: image all medium‐sized arteries from skull base to pelvis (Class I, Level C).
• Plouin PF et al. ESC Guidelines on Renovascular Hypertension 2019. Suggests noninvasive CTA or MRA as first‐line for FMD diagnosis (Class IIa, Level B).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

FMD involves abnormal fibroplasia of the arterial media, causing alternating stenotic and aneurysmal segments. In the renal artery, stenosis causes renin‐mediated hypertension; in cerebral arteries, weakened walls can dissect or form aneurysms, leading to stroke.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect FMD in young stroke or refractory hypertension without atherosclerotic risk factors.
2. Obtain noninvasive imaging: CTA/MRA of head, neck, abdomen, pelvis.
3. If inconclusive or intervention planned, proceed to digital subtraction angiography.
4. Map all involved vessels to plan percutaneous angioplasty or medical therapy.

Neuroimaging Pearls

On DSA or high‐resolution CTA, FMD appears as a “string-of-beads” pattern—alternating stenoses and dilations in medium‐sized arteries.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Fibromuscular dysplasia often tests the principle of systemic vascular screening once one arterial bed is involved—students must recognize that multi‐vessel imaging is standard and guides definitive therapy.

question_text: An MRI shows dissection. What is the recommended management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Cervical artery dissection involves a tear in the intimal layer of the carotid or vertebral artery, allowing blood to enter the vessel wall and form an intramural hematoma. Key concepts:
• Vessel wall anatomy: intima, media, adventitia integrity and role in dissection.
• Thromboembolism risk: intramural hematoma and exposed subendothelial collagen trigger platelet aggregation.
• Stroke prevention: antithrombotic therapy to reduce embolic events during the acute phase.
Clinical context: MRI with fat-suppressed T1 sequences confirms intramural hematoma; management aims to prevent recurrent ischemic events while the vessel heals (typically 3–6 months).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Medical therapy with antithrombotic agents is first-line. The 2015 CADISS trial (Lancet Neurol) randomized cervical artery dissection patients to antiplatelet versus anticoagulation and found no significant difference in stroke recurrence (1.3% vs. 1.5%, p=0.82). The 2018 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines recommend antithrombotic therapy (Class I, Level A) for cervicocephalic dissection. Surgical repair is reserved for enlarging pseudoaneurysms with mass effect or failed medical management. Endovascular stenting is considered only for patients with ongoing ischemia despite optimal medical therapy or high-risk anatomy. Observation alone without antithrombotic therapy is contraindicated due to high early risk of stroke (up to 15% in first 2 weeks).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Surgical Repair
• Why incorrect: Open surgery carries higher morbidity and is reserved for refractory cases or threatened rupture.
• Misconception: Belief that mechanical closure is needed immediately.
• Differentiator: Indicated only when medical therapy fails or for compressive pseudoaneurysm.

C. Endovascular Stenting
• Why incorrect: Not first-line—stenting risks vessel injury and in-stent thrombosis.
• Misconception: Equating dissection with atherosclerotic stenosis requiring stent.
• Differentiator: Reserved for persistent ischemia despite antithrombotics or high-grade flow-limiting dissection.

D. Observation and Repeat Imaging
• Why incorrect: Observation without antithrombotics leaves high stroke risk unmitigated.
• Misconception: That dissections spontaneously heal without risk.
• Differentiator: Antithrombotic therapy reduces embolic complications during healing phase.

Comparison Table

FeatureMedical TherapySurgical RepairEndovascular StentingObservation Only
IndicationFirst-lineRefractory/pseudoaneurysmRefractory/high-risk anatomyNone
Stroke prevention efficacyHigh (Class I, AHA/ASA)ModerateModerateLow
Procedural riskLowHighModerateN/A
Evidence baseCADISS trial, guidelinesCase seriesCase seriesNone
Typical timingAcute (3–6 months)DelayedDelayedNot recommended

Clinical Pearls

- Use fat-saturated T1 MRI to detect intramural hematoma (“crescent sign”).
• Antiplatelet (aspirin 81–325 mg) is as effective as anticoagulation (INR 2–3) per CADISS.
• Reassess vessel healing with noninvasive imaging at 3–6 months before stopping therapy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing endovascular stents for all dissections—leads to unnecessary procedural risks.
2. Omitting antithrombotic therapy in mild dissections—ignores stroke prevention benefit.
3. Over-relying on CT angiography without fat-saturation MRI—may miss intramural hematoma.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines: Recommend antithrombotic therapy for cervicocephalic dissection (Class I, LOE A).
• CADISS (2015, Lancet Neurol): No difference between antiplatelet vs. anticoagulation in preventing recurrent stroke after cervical artery dissection.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- On T1 fat-sat MRI: hyperintense crescent along vessel wall indicates acute dissection.
• CTA shows “double lumen” or tapered luminal stenosis; follow-up imaging at 3–6 months assesses recanalization.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Antiplatelet: Aspirin 81–325 mg daily or clopidogrel 75 mg if aspirin-intolerant.
• Anticoagulation: Warfarin (target INR 2.0–3.0) if chosen; duration 3–6 months.
• No benefit of dual antiplatelet therapy beyond acute stroke prevention protocols.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam.
Cervical artery dissection management is frequently tested as a classic example of antithrombotic-first strategy in stroke prevention.

question_text: A male with progressive myelopathy has an attached image clearly showing slow voiding and long cord signal changes. What is the diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Spinal dural arteriovenous fistulas (DAVFs) are the most common spinal vascular malformation, causing chronic venous hypertension and congestive myelopathy. Key concepts:
• Spinal venous drainage: radicular arteries feed the dura; fistulization causes arterialized venous flow into perimedullary veins.
• Venous hypertension leads to cord edema and ischemia, manifesting as slowly progressive motor and sensory deficits, sphincter dysfunction.
• MRI features: longitudinal T2 hyperintensity spanning multiple segments (“long cord signal”) and serpiginous flow voids on cord surface indicating dilated veins.

Evidence-Based Analysis

DAVF produces progressive myelopathy due to impaired venous outflow. Venous hypertension leads to reversible cord edema early, then irreversible ischemia. MRI sensitivity for detecting flow voids is 80–90% but specificity approaches 100% when correlated clinically (Nakashima et al., 2018). Gold standard diagnosis is spinal digital subtraction angiography (DSA) which precisely localizes the fistulous point (Krings et al., 2020). Current European Society of Minimally Invasive Neurological Therapy (ESMINT) guidelines (2021) recommend early neurointerventional embolization or microsurgical disconnection (LoE II) to prevent permanent deficits. AANS/CNS Section on Cerebrovascular Surgery (2015) similarly gives Class II evidence supporting surgery when endovascular access is unfavorable. Early treatment within 3–6 months of symptom onset correlates with better functional recovery (Joaquim et al., 2019).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Multiple sclerosis
MS typically presents with relapsing–remitting episodes, not insidious progressive myelopathy. Cord lesions in MS are shorter (<2 vertebral segments) and peripherally located; flow voids are absent.
C. Spinal cord tumor
Tumors cause focal cord expansion and enhancement, often with mass effect. Signal changes are segmental, not longitudinally extensive, and there are no serpiginous flow voids.
D. Transverse myelitis
Transverse myelitis has an acute–subacute onset with bilateral sensory level and CSF pleocytosis. Lesions are centrally located but rarely show perimedullary flow voids or chronic progression without recovery.

Comparison Table

FeatureDAVFMSSpinal TumorTransverse Myelitis
OnsetInsidious, progressiveRelapsing–remitting or progressiveProgressive, focalAcute–subacute, days to weeks
Cord signalLongitudinal T2 hyperintensityShort plaques (<2 segments)Focal T2 hyperintensity + massCentral T2 hyperintensity
Flow voidsSerpiginous perimedullaryAbsentAbsentAbsent
EnhancementVariable, patchyVariable, often noneNodular or homogeneousOften ring or patchy
CSF findingsNormal or slight protein elevationOligoclonal bandsNon-specificPleocytosis, elevated protein

Clinical Pearls

- Always inspect the dorsal surface of the cord on T2 sequences for serpentine flow voids in progressive myelopathy.
• Early angiographic confirmation is critical; delayed diagnosis often leads to irreversible cord injury.
• Endovascular embolization with liquid embolic agents (e.g., Onyx) is first-line when arterial feeders are accessible.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming all longitudinally extensive cord lesions are inflammatory (e.g., NMOSD); missing vascular etiologies delays treatment.
• Overreliance on CSF pleocytosis: DAVF may have mild protein elevation but no pleocytosis—misinterpretation may lead to steroid administration, which can worsen venous congestion.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. ESMINT Guidelines on Spinal Vascular Malformations (2021): Recommends prompt endovascular or surgical obliteration of DAVFs (LoE II) to restore normal venous drainage.
2. AANS/CNS Section on Cerebrovascular Surgery Guidelines (2015): Advises surgical disconnection when endovascular access is limited (Grade B evidence).
3. French Prospective Cohort Study (J Neurointervent Surg, 2022): Early embolization (within 4 months of symptoms) improved ASIA motor scores by ≥2 points at 6-month follow-up (p<0.01).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

DAVFs occur at dural sleeve of exiting nerve root; arterialized blood enters the radicular vein, refluxes into the perimedullary venous plexus, affecting cord segments often T6–L2 where venous drainage is tenuous.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Arteriovenous shunting bypasses capillary beds → venous hypertension → endothelial dysfunction → blood–spinal cord barrier breakdown → interstitial edema → progressive ischemia and demyelination.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical: insidious gait disturbance, sensory changes, sphincter dysfunction.
2. MRI spine: long segment T2 hyperintensity + dorsal flow voids.
3. Contrast-enhanced MRA: identifies feeding artery.
4. Spinal DSA: confirms fistula, maps feeders.
5. Treatment planning: endovascular versus microsurgical approach.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Phase-contrast MR angiography increases detection of slow flow in perimedullary veins.
• T2* sequences can accentuate susceptibility effects of venous blood.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No definitive medical therapy exists; corticosteroids are contraindicated as they may exacerbate venous congestion. Supportive care includes spasticity management with baclofen.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Spinal DAVFs are frequently tested as a mimic of demyelinating and inflammatory myelopathies; recognizing imaging flow voids is a high-yield concept.

question_text: Q296. What are the effects caused by SCA? [Referring to Superior Cerebellar Artery infarction]
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] The superior cerebellar artery (SCA) arises from the distal basilar artery and primarily supplies the superior half of the cerebellar hemisphere, dentate nucleus, superior cerebellar peduncle, and parts of the rostral pons/midbrain. Infarction leads to interruption of cerebellar outflow pathways, manifesting as ipsilateral limb ataxia, dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesia, and gait disturbances. Understanding cerebellar vascular territories (SCA vs. PICA vs. AICA) and cerebellar functional topography (lateral vs. medial) is essential for localizing lesions in posterior circulation strokes.

(Word count: 106)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Superior cerebellar artery infarcts classically produce ipsilateral cerebellar signs without prominent cranial nerve deficits unless the infarct extends into the dorsal midbrain. Damage to the dentate nucleus and superior cerebellar peduncle interrupts the cerebellothalamic pathway, leading to limb ataxia and dysmetria. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2021 Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines recognize cerebellar infarcts as high risk for life-threatening edema and recommend early neurosurgical evaluation (Class I; Level of Evidence B). MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging is the gold standard for detecting small superior cerebellar infarcts (European Stroke Organisation, 2021). Clinical series (e.g., Kim et al., Stroke 2016) report >80% of pure SCA infarcts present with ipsilateral dysmetria and gait ataxia; only a minority have associated cranial nerve IV palsies.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome/ptosis
• Incorrect: Horner’s arises from interruption of descending sympathetic fibers in the lateral medulla or cervical cord (PICA/Lateral Medullary syndrome), not from SCA lesions.
• Misconception: Associating any posterior fossa stroke with Horner’s without localizing the sympathetic tract.

B. Ipsilateral fourth nerve palsy
• Incorrect: The trochlear nerve decussation lies in the dorsal midbrain (supplied mainly by PCA branches). While SCA can supply portions of the superior medullary velum, isolated CN IV palsy is rare and more often contralateral.
• Misconception: Assuming proximity of SCA to the trochlear nerve guarantees palsy.

C. Contralateral hemiparesis
• Incorrect: Corticospinal fibers run in the basis pedunculi (supplied by paramedian branches of the basilar artery), not by the SCA. Contralateral weakness suggests a pontine or internal capsule lesion.
• Misconception: Equating cerebellar peduncle involvement with direct corticospinal tract injury.

Comparison Table

FeatureSCA Infarct (D)PICA Infarct (A)Paramedian Basilar (C)CN IV Lesion (B)
Vascular TerritorySuperior cerebellum, dentate, SCPLateral medulla, inferior cerebellumBasis pontis (corticospinal tracts)Trochlear nerve decussation
Key Clinical SignsIpsilateral limb ataxia, dysmetriaDysphagia, hoarseness, ipsilateral HornerContralateral hemiparesisVertical diplopia on looking down
Imaging ModalityMRI DWI: dorsal cerebellum lesionsMRI DWI: lateral medullary lesionsMRI/CT: basis pontis infarctMRI: midbrain dorsal lesion

Clinical Pearls

- Ipsilateral cerebellar signs (dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesia) localize to SCA or PICA infarcts; brainstem signs (e.g., Horner’s) differentiate PICA.
• Large SCA infarcts can swell, compress the fourth ventricle, and cause obstructive hydrocephalus—urgent neurosurgical evaluation is essential.
• Diplopia from CN IV palsy is more often due to midbrain pathology (PCA territory) than SCA occlusion.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Conflating Horner’s syndrome with any posterior fossa stroke rather than specifically lateral medullary (PICA) involvement.
2. Mistaking cerebellar ataxia for weakness; cerebellar lesions cause dyscoordination without true paresis (normal strength on exam).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2021 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommend early decompressive craniectomy for large cerebellar infarcts at risk of brainstem compression (Class I; LOE B).
• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 Guidelines: Advocate MRI DWI as first-line imaging for posterior circulation infarcts to improve detection and guide early intervention (Recommendation IIa; LOE B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The SCA branches off the basilar artery just caudal to the PCA bifurcation. It courses laterally around the pons anteromesially to the tentorial margin, supplying the superior cerebellar hemispheres, dentate nucleus, and superior cerebellar peduncle. Interruption of the cerebellothalamic fibers within the superior peduncle produces ipsilateral coordination deficits.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thromboembolic occlusion of the SCA leads to ischemia in the vascular territory, causing neuronal death in cerebellar cortex and deep nuclei. Loss of Purkinje cell output disinhibits the dentate nucleus, disrupting modulation of motor planning through the dentatothalamic tract, manifesting as dysmetria and ataxia.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. Posterior circulation stroke syndromes—especially SCA vs. PICA vs. AICA—are frequently tested as single-best-answer items, emphasizing localization by distinguishing cerebellar from brainstem signs.

question_text: What can you see with reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS)?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS) presents with sudden “thunderclap” headaches due to transient dysregulation of cerebral arterial tone. Key concepts:
