Antiplatelet or anticoagulant therapies lack efficacy in this vasculopathic, non-embolic context.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Aspirin
• Reason incorrect: Antiplatelet alone does not address the underlying sickling-driven vasculopathy or reduce HbS.
• Misconception: Assuming pediatric arterial strokes mirror adult atherosclerotic mechanisms.
• Differentiator: Aspirin reduces platelet aggregation but fails to prevent sickle-cell occlusive events.

C. Anticoagulation
• Reason incorrect: SCD strokes are due to non-embolic large-vessel stenosis, not cardioembolism or hypercoagulability amenable to heparin/warfarin.
• Misconception: All pediatric strokes benefit from anticoagulation.
• Differentiator: No evidence for anticoagulants in primary or secondary prevention of SCD-related infarcts.

D. Hydroxyurea
• Reason incorrect: Effective for primary prevention (TWiTCH trial) but inferior for secondary prevention (SWiTCH showed higher recurrence when replacing transfusion).
• Misconception: Belief that hydroxyurea’s fetal-hemoglobin induction suffices post-stroke.
• Differentiator: Hydroxyurea does not reduce HbS fraction as rapidly or predictably as transfusion.

Comparison Table

FeatureChronic TransfusionAspirinAnticoagulationHydroxyurea
MechanismLowers HbS, reduces viscosityInhibits platelet COX-1Inhibits thrombin/coagulation cascadeIncreases HbF, reduces sickling
Evidence for secondary strokeSTOP/SWITCH: ↓recurrence >90%No proven benefit in SCDNo role in non-embolic strokeSWiTCH: ↑recurrence
Guideline recommendationAHA/ASA Class I, ASH 1ANot recommendedNot recommendedOnly primary prevention
Main adverse effectsIron overload, alloimmunizationBleeding riskBleeding riskMyelosuppression

Clinical Pearls

- Maintain HbS <30% and total hemoglobin ~10 g/dL during transfusion therapy; initiate chelation (deferoxamine or deferasirox) early.
• Annual TCD screening remains vital even after transfusion; velocities >200 cm/s warrant review of adherence.
• Transfusion breaks must be avoided: missed sessions rapidly increase stroke risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Equating adult platelet-mediated stroke prevention (aspirin) with pediatric SCD vasculopathy.
• Believing hydroxyurea can fully replace transfusion after a documented stroke.
• Overlooking iron chelation in chronic transfusion protocols, leading to secondary hemochromatosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association/American Stroke Association, Pediatric Stroke Guidelines (2019): Recommends indefinite regular transfusions for secondary prevention in SCD (Class I, Level A).
• American Society of Hematology, Sickle Cell Disease Management Guidelines (2020): Endorses chronic transfusion targeting HbS <30% post-stroke (Grade 1A).
• SWiTCH Trial (Stroke With Transfusions Changing to Hydroxyurea; 2016): Demonstrated higher stroke recurrence when substituting hydroxyurea for chronic transfusions in secondary prevention.
• TWiTCH Trial (2016): Established hydroxyurea’s non-inferiority to transfusion for primary prevention but not tested post-stroke.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

SCD-related strokes arise from chronic endothelial activation, intimal hyperplasia, and smooth muscle proliferation in intracranial arteries (particularly MCA/ICA). Sickled erythrocytes adhere to endothelium, occlude microvasculature, and trigger collateral shear stress. Repeated vaso-occlusive events foster vessel stenosis and luminal thrombosis. Chronic transfusion dilutes HbS, improves rheology, and interrupts this cycle, thereby stabilizing vessel walls and preventing new infarcts.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam.
Secondary stroke prevention in SCD is a high-yield topic on pediatric neurology; exam vignettes often describe recurrent strokes or rising TCD velocities to test knowledge of chronic transfusion protocols.

question_text: A case of right ICA dissection presented with left-sided weakness. What is the treatment in the acute setting?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Internal carotid artery (ICA) dissection arises from an intimal tear allowing blood to track into the vessel wall, forming an intramural hematoma that narrows the lumen and predisposes to thromboembolism. The ICA supplies anterior circulation structures (MCA/ACA territories), so dissection often presents with contralateral motor deficits. Acute goals are to prevent clot propagation and distal embolism. First-line therapy is medical (antithrombotic) rather than mechanical intervention. Key terms: intramural hematoma, thromboembolism, anterior circulation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Medical therapy—specifically antithrombotic treatment—is the cornerstone of acute management. The 2018 AHA/ASA stroke guidelines give a Class I recommendation for antithrombotic therapy in cervical artery dissection, without specifying superiority of anticoagulation over antiplatelets. The CADISS trial (Lancet Neurol 2015) randomized 250 patients to antiplatelet vs anticoagulation arms, finding no difference in stroke recurrence at 3 months. More recently, the TREAT-CAD trial (Lancet Neurol 2022) demonstrated aspirin non-inferiority to vitamin K antagonists for preventing stroke/TIA in dissection. Endovascular approaches (stenting/angioplasty) carry risks of vessel injury and are reserved for cases with recurrent ischemia despite optimal medical therapy or expanding pseudoaneurysms.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Stenting – Endovascular stenting is an invasive option with risk of vessel rupture and in-stent thrombosis; reserved for patients with progressive ischemia or large pseudoaneurysms refractory to medical therapy. Misconception: that mechanical reconstruction always beats antithrombotic therapy.
B. Angioplasty – Balloon angioplasty alone risks vessel rupture and intimal re-tear. It does not address thrombus in the false lumen and is not first-line.
D. Anticoagulation – Although anticoagulants inhibit thrombus propagation, trials (CADISS, TREAT-CAD) show no clear benefit over antiplatelets and carry higher hemorrhagic risk; guidelines now favor antiplatelet therapy in most cases.

Comparison Table

Management OptionMechanismIndicationEvidence Strength
Medical therapy (antiplatelet)Inhibits platelet aggregationFirst-line acute managementAHA/ASA Class I; CADISS; TREAT-CAD
AnticoagulationInhibits clotting cascade (e.g., warfarin)Alternative if antiplatelet contraindicatedNo superiority; ↑ bleeding (CADISS, TREAT-CAD)
StentingEndoluminal stent deploymentRecurrent ischemia or large pseudoaneurysmClass IIb; observational data only
AngioplastyBalloon dilation of stenotic segmentSame as stentingClass IIb; limited evidence

Clinical Pearls

- Cervical artery dissection accounts for up to 25% of ischemic strokes in patients <45 years old.
• Antiplatelet therapy (e.g., aspirin 75–325 mg daily) is generally preferred over anticoagulation due to similar efficacy and lower bleeding risk.
• Reserve endovascular treatment for failed medical therapy or symptomatic pseudoaneurysm with mass effect.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Automatically starting heparin/warfarin in all dissections despite evidence showing no superior benefit over antiplatelets.
• Proceeding to stenting or angioplasty without a trial of medical therapy, exposing patients to unnecessary procedural risks.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (2018): Class I recommendation for antithrombotic therapy in cervical artery dissection; choice between antiplatelet and anticoagulation left to clinician judgment.
• CADISS Trial (Lancet Neurol 2015): Randomized 250 patients; no significant difference in stroke/TIA recurrence between antiplatelet and anticoagulation arms at 3 months.
• TREAT-CAD Trial (Lancet Neurol 2022): Aspirin non-inferior to vitamin K antagonists for prevention of stroke/TIA in cervical artery dissection (HR 1.02; 95% CI 0.59–1.77).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The ICA ascends through the carotid canal, supplies the anterior circulation including the anterior and middle cerebral arteries. Dissection-related stenosis or occlusion causes hypoperfusion and embolism to downstream cortical and subcortical structures, such as the internal capsule, producing contralateral weakness.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

An intimal tear leads to blood dissecting between media and adventitia, creating a false lumen. The intramural hematoma compresses the true lumen (stenosis) and fosters thrombus formation, which can embolize distally or compromise perfusion.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect dissection in young stroke patients with neck pain or headache.
2. Order CTA or MRA of head and neck to identify the “flame-shaped” occlusion, double-lumen sign, or mural hematoma.
3. Confirm with fat-saturated T1 MRI if needed.
4. Initiate antithrombotic therapy immediately.
5. Monitor clinically and with periodic imaging; consider endovascular intervention if deterioration occurs.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CTA: flame-shaped tapering of lumen, pseudoaneurysm formation.
• MRA: high-signal T1 fat-saturated sequences show intramural hematoma.
• Duplex ultrasound: may show double lumen or intramural hematoma in cervical segment.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: Aspirin 75–325 mg daily for 3–6 months.
• Anticoagulation (heparin → warfarin, INR 2.0–3.0) reserved if antiplatelet contraindicated or recurrent events.
• Duration of therapy: typically 3–6 months, then reassess with imaging.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam.
Carotid artery dissection is frequently tested as a cause of stroke in young patients; examinees should recognize that antithrombotic therapy is first-line and that endovascular options are reserved for refractory cases.

question_text: Q171. What is an expected finding in a patient with a superior cerebellar artery (SCA) infarction?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] - The superior cerebellar artery (SCA) arises from the distal basilar artery and supplies the superior cerebellar hemisphere (including the dentate nucleus and superior cerebellar peduncle), plus parts of the rostral pons and inferior midbrain.
• Infarction in this territory disrupts cerebellar efferent fibers and vestibulocerebellar circuits, producing ipsilateral limb ataxia, dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesia and gaze‐evoked nystagmus, without involvement of long sensory or auditory tracts.
• In contrast, AICA infarcts produce ipsilateral facial paralysis and hearing loss, and PICA infarcts produce ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome with facial pain/temperature loss and contralateral body pain/temperature loss.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Superior cerebellar artery strokes account for approximately 7–10% of all cerebellar infarctions (Savitz et al., Mayo Clin Proc 2017). The SCA supplies the superior vermis, hemispheric folia, dentate nucleus, and superior cerebellar peduncle. Lesioning of Purkinje cell output via the superior peduncle leads to loss of inhibitory control over vestibular nuclei, resulting in ipsilesional gaze‐evoked nystagmus in >70% of pure SCA infarcts (Steinlin et al., Neurology 2018). Spinothalamic and dorsal column tracts run ventromedially and are supplied by paramedian and anterior spinal arteries, not the SCA, so sensory disturbances (pain/temperature or vibration) are not expected. Cohort studies (Nabavi et al., Stroke 2019) corroborate that isolated SCA infarcts present with cerebellar signs without auditory or sensory deficits. The 2018 AHA/ASA Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines endorse MRI with diffusion‐weighted imaging for posterior fossa infarcts to confirm small SCA territory lesions (Class I; Level of Evidence A).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome
• Reason incorrect: Horner’s arises from disruption of descending sympathetic fibers in the lateral medulla (PICA infarct), not in SCA territory.
• Misconception: Confusing PICA (Wallenberg) with SCA territory strokes.
• Differentiator: PICA lesions spare cerebellar hemispheres but affect lateral medullary structures including sympathetic pathways.

B. Ipsilateral hearing loss
• Reason incorrect: Hearing loss results from labyrinthine artery occlusion within the internal auditory branch of AICA, not SCA.
• Misconception: Attributing all cerebellar arterial strokes to auditory involvement.
• Differentiator: AICA infarcts often present with facial paralysis and ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

C. Contralateral sensory disturbance
• Reason incorrect: Spinothalamic fibers mediating pain/temperature run ventrolaterally in the brainstem and are supplied by PICA/AICA, not the superior cerebellar artery.
• Misconception: Assuming cerebellar infarcts always involve long sensory tracts.
• Differentiator: Pure SCA strokes spare sensory pathways; sensory deficits suggest PICA or lateral pontine involvement.

Comparison Table

OptionArtery TerritoryKey Clinical FeaturePresence in SCA Infarct?
APICAIpsilateral Horner’s syndromeNo
BAICAIpsilateral hearing lossNo
CPICA/AICAContralateral pain/temp sensory lossNo
DSCAIpsilateral gaze‐evoked nystagmus & ataxiaYes

Clinical Pearls

- Distinguish cerebellar vascular territories by key signs: AICA → hearing loss; PICA → Horner’s + sensory loss; SCA → pure cerebellar signs & nystagmus.
• Gaze‐evoked nystagmus in cerebellar lesions beats toward the side of the lesion due to loss of cerebellar inhibition on vestibular nuclei.
• MRI with DWI is far more sensitive than CT for early detection of posterior fossa infarcts.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking ipsilateral hearing loss as a feature of SCA strokes rather than AICA involvement.
• Believing all cerebellar infarcts produce sensory deficits by generalizing from lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome.
• Overlooking the importance of gaze‐evoked nystagmus when cerebellar signs are subtle.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines: Recommend MRI with diffusion‐weighted imaging for suspected posterior circulation infarcts (Class I; Level A) to detect small SCA territory strokes.
• AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines: In cerebellar infarcts with neurological deterioration or radiographic evidence of brainstem compression/hydrocephalus, urgent neurosurgical decompression is recommended (Class I; Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The SCA emerges just below the posterior cerebral arteries, encircles the midbrain, and supplies the superior cerebellar cortex, dentate nucleus, and superior cerebellar peduncle. Infarction disrupts Purkinje cell output and cerebellar modulation of vestibular nuclei, causing ipsilesional ataxia and nystagmus without affecting medial lemniscus or spinothalamic tracts.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thromboembolism or in situ thrombosis in the distal basilar artery occludes the SCA. Ischemia of Purkinje cells and deep nuclei impairs cerebellar processing of motor coordination and vestibular integration, manifesting as ataxia, dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesia, and nystagmus.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Perform noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage (often normal in cerebellar strokes).
2. Obtain MRI with DWI for definitive localization in the posterior fossa.
3. Use CT/MR angiography to identify arterial occlusion in the SCA or basilar artery.
4. Monitor for cerebellar edema; consult neurosurgery if brainstem compression or hydrocephalus develops.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Noncontrast CT has low sensitivity (<50%) for acute posterior fossa infarcts.
• DWI MRI detects infarction within minutes and delineates SCA territory involvement.
• CT angiography may reveal an SCA cut‐off sign distal to the basilar artery bifurcation.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Administer IV alteplase within 4.5 hours if no contraindications (AHA/ASA Class I; Level A).
• Initiate antiplatelet therapy (aspirin) after hemorrhage exclusion.
• Start high‐intensity statin therapy for secondary prevention.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam.
Posterior circulation cerebrovascular syndromes (PICA vs AICA vs SCA) are frequently tested on neurology boards, often asking for key distinguishing clinical features of each arterial territory.

question_text: A patient presents with acute right-sided weakness. Noncontrast CT head demonstrates a left basal ganglia intracerebral hemorrhage with a 3 mm midline shift and no intraventricular extension. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] - Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) types: deep (basal ganglia, thalamus) vs lobar vs cerebellar vs brainstem.
• Deep ICH often arises from hypertensive arteriolar rupture (Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysms).
• Surgical indications depend on location, volume (>30 mL), GCS, hydrocephalus, and degree of mass effect.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Supportive care is preferred for small-to-moderate deep ICH without severe mass effect or depressed consciousness. The 2022 AHA/ASA guidelines recommend conservative management for deep basal ganglia hemorrhages <30 mL, midline shift <5 mm, and GCS ≥9 (Class I, Level A). The STICH I (Mendelow et al., 2005) and STICH II (Mendelow et al., 2013) trials showed no functional benefit of early surgical evacuation for deep hemorrhages. Aggressive blood pressure reduction (target systolic <140 mm Hg; INTERACT2 trial) and supportive measures (maintain euvolemia, ICP control) reduce hematoma expansion and improve outcomes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Craniotomy
• Why incorrect: Deep basal ganglia ICH generally not evacuated unless life-threatening mass effect or GCS ≤8.
• Misconception: Any intracerebral bleed requires surgery.
• Differentiator: Superficial lobar hemorrhages near cortex are surgical candidates; deep bleeds are not.

B. Give LMWH
• Why incorrect: Anticoagulation exacerbates hemorrhage.
• Misconception: Early DVT prophylaxis with LMWH is safe immediately.
• Differentiator: Only mechanical prophylaxis or delayed low-dose unfractionated heparin after 24 – 48 h if stable.

D. Administer intravenous thrombolytics
• Why incorrect: Thrombolytics are contraindicated in hemorrhagic stroke.
• Misconception: All acute strokes benefit from tPA.
• Differentiator: tPA is for ischemic stroke within therapeutic window after CT excludes bleed.

Comparison Table

FeatureSupportive Care (C)Craniotomy (A)LMWH (B)Thrombolytics (D)
IndicationDeep ICH <30 mL, shift <5 mmSuperficial lobar ICH, mass effect or GCS ≤8DVT prophylaxis after stabilizationAcute ischemic stroke
Effect on hematomaNeutral; prevents expansionEvacuation but high riskPromotes expansionPromotes expansion
EvidenceAHA/ASA 2022 I, A; INTERACT2STICH I/II no benefit (Ib)Contraindicated initiallyContraindicated
ContraindicationsUnstable GCS, large volumeDeep hemorrhage, small shiftActive bleedHemorrhagic stroke

Clinical Pearls

1. Deep basal ganglia hemorrhages rarely benefit from craniotomy unless GCS ≤8 or large volume with herniation.
2. Early intensive BP control (systolic <140 mm Hg) reduces hematoma expansion (INTERACT2).
3. Delay pharmacologic DVT prophylaxis until hemorrhage stability is confirmed on repeat CT.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming any midline shift mandates surgical evacuation—threshold is generally >5 mm or clinical deterioration.
2. Initiating anticoagulants or thrombolytics before excluding hemorrhage on imaging in acute stroke.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines for ICH Management, 2022: Recommend conservative management for deep ICH <30 mL, midline shift <5 mm (Class I, Level A).
• STICH II Trial (Mendelow et al., NEJM 2013): Early surgery versus conservative treatment in superficial lobar ICH—no overall functional benefit (Level Ib).
• INTERACT2 Trial (Anderson et al., Lancet Neurol 2013): Intensive BP lowering (<140 mm Hg) improves functional outcome in ICH (Level IIa).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

A basal ganglia bleed compresses the posterior limb of the internal capsule, disrupting corticospinal fibers and causing contralateral hemiparesis.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic hypertension induces lipohyalinosis of small penetrating arterioles → Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysm formation → vessel rupture → hematoma expansion, perihematomal edema, increased intracranial pressure, and mass effect.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Immediate noncontrast CT to distinguish hemorrhage from ischemia.
2. Calculate ICH score (age, GCS, volume, intraventricular extension, infratentorial origin).
3. Blood pressure management and reversal of coagulopathy.
4. Repeat CT at 6 hours to assess stability.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Hyperdense acute hematoma on CT.
• Midline shift measured at septum pellucidum.
• “Spot sign” on CT angiography predicts expansion.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line BP agents: IV nicardipine or labetalol.
• Avoid heparin/LMWH until hemorrhage stability confirmed.
• Manage ICP with head elevation; consider hyperosmolar therapy if needed.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Management of ICH based on location, volume, and clinical status is frequently tested, often with CT images and ICH score calculations.

question_text: A case of malignant MCA stroke with mass effect and decreased level of consciousness is found unresponsive. What intervention will change outcomes?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Malignant middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarction refers to large hemispheric strokes producing cytotoxic edema, raised intracranial pressure (ICP), and risk of transtentorial herniation. Key concepts:
1. MCA anatomy: supplies lateral frontal, temporal, parietal lobes; proximal occlusion → large territory infarct and severe edema.
2. Ischemic cascade: energy failure → ion pump dysfunction → intracellular water shift → malignant edema peaks 2–5 days post‐stroke.
3. ICP and herniation physiology: uncontrolled swelling leads to midline shift, Cushing’s triad, brainstem compression.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Decompressive hemicraniectomy within 48 hours in malignant MCA infarction reduces mortality from ~80% to ~30–40% and increases survival with moderate disability (mRS ≤4). Three European RCTs (DECIMAL, DESTINY, HAMLET) and a pooled analysis (Vahedi et al., 2007) demonstrated significant mortality benefit (Level A evidence, Class I recommendation in AHA/ASA 2018 guidelines). Early surgery prevents ICP rise, halts herniation, and improves functional outcome.
Intravenous tPA is contraindicated after the hyperacute window or in massive established infarcts due to hemorrhagic risk. Hyperventilation transiently lowers ICP but may reduce cerebral perfusion. Stroke unit care alone cannot reverse advanced edema.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Stroke admission
• Incorrect because supportive care does not halt rapidly progressing edema or herniation.
• Misconception: routine stroke unit monitoring suffices in malignant edema.
• Differs from hemicraniectomy, which physically relieves mass effect.

C. Hyperventilation
• Temporizing measure only: lowers PaCO₂, induces cerebral vasoconstriction, but risks ischemia and rebound ICP rise.
• Common error: overestimating its duration of effect.
• Does not address underlying cytotoxic swelling.

D. Intravenous thrombolysis
• Time‐limited (≤4.5 h) and increases hemorrhage risk in large established infarcts.
• Misconception: tPA reduces mass effect in late-presenting MCA strokes.
• Does not reverse cytotoxic edema once infarct matured.

Comparison Table

FeatureHemicraniectomyStroke AdmissionHyperventilationIV Thrombolysis
MechanismSurgical decompressionSupportive monitoringCerebral vasoconstrictionFibrinolysis within 4.5 h
Effect on ICPSustained reductionNoneTemporary ↓, then reboundNo significant effect
Evidence in malignant MCA↓ mortality, ↑ functional outcomeNo RCTs for life‐savingNo outcome trialsContraindicated in large infarcts
Primary riskSurgical complicationsNone specificCerebral ischemiaHemorrhagic transformation

Clinical Pearls

• Perform decompressive hemicraniectomy within 48 h of symptom onset for maximal benefit.
• Ideal candidates: age ≤60, NIHSS ≥15, >50% MCA territory involvement.
• Post‐op: aggressive ICP control, early rehabilitation improves outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Believing hyperventilation alone prevents herniation; its benefit is short-lived and can worsen ischemia.
2. Administering tPA in large established infarcts due to misunderstanding of time window and hemorrhage risk.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA Stroke Guidelines 2018: Class I, Level A—decompressive hemicraniectomy recommended for malignant MCA infarction patients 18–60 yrs within 48 h.
• DESTINY II Trial (2015): extended benefit demonstrated in patients >60 yrs for mortality reduction, though survivors often have moderate–severe disability.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The MCA supplies lateral neocortex and deep structures (internal capsule). Large proximal occlusions cause extensive cortical and subcortical infarction, leading to hemispheric edema that compresses basal cisterns and shifts midline structures.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemia prompts glutamate‐mediated excitotoxicity, sodium–potassium pump failure, intracellular water influx, and cytotoxic edema. Swollen hemisphere exerts mass effect, raising ICP and risking uncal herniation with brainstem compression.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Noncontrast CT: hypodensity in >50% MCA territory, effacement of sulci, midline shift >5 mm. MRI DWI confirms infarct extent. Crescendoc edema peaks days 2–5.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Malignant MCA infarction and hemicraniectomy are frequently tested as classic life‐saving interventions in stroke management, often via scenario-based questions emphasizing timing and patient selection.

question_text: Q98. An image of diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) shows a watershed infarction on one side. What should be done next?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Watershed (border-zone) infarctions occur at the junctions between major cerebral artery territories (e.g., ACA–MCA or MCA–PCA) and are most often due to systemic hypoperfusion or severe proximal arterial stenosis. Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) rapidly detects cytotoxic edema in acute ischemia. Once a watershed pattern is identified, the next step is to assess vascular anatomy for stenosis or occlusion that predisposes to hypoperfusion. CT angiography (CTA) provides noninvasive, high-resolution evaluation of extracranial and intracranial vessels, guiding management of hemodynamic stroke risk.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke recommend prompt vascular imaging (CTA or MRA) in patients with infarcts at risk for recurrent events (Class I, Level B-R). CTA identifies symptomatic carotid or intracranial stenosis amenable to endarterectomy or stenting. A watershed pattern implies hemodynamic compromise rather than embolic occlusion alone; thus establishing large-vessel status is essential before instituting blood pressure targets or considering revascularization. Randomized trials (e.g., WASID) underscore that severe intracranial stenosis (>70%) confers high recurrence risk, warranting targeted intervention.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Initiate intravenous thrombolysis
• Incorrect because thrombolysis is indicated within a time window (<4.5 h) for occlusive stroke, not for subacute watershed infarcts already visualized on DWI.
• Misconception: any DWI-confirmed stroke mandates tPA—time window and hemorrhage risk must be assessed first.

C. Perform lumbar puncture
• Incorrect: LP is unrelated; no suspicion of infection, hemorrhage ruled out by imaging, and LP may risk herniation in infarcted tissue.
• Misconception: LP is a routine next step in any neurologic deficit.

D. Start high-dose corticosteroids
• Incorrect: steroids have no role in ischemic stroke management and may worsen glycemic control and immunosuppression.
• Misconception: steroids benefit all acute neurologic lesions (confuses with demyelinating or vasculitic processes).

Comparison Table

FeatureCTA (Correct)IV ThrombolysisLumbar PunctureHigh-Dose Steroids
PurposeVisualize vessel stenosis/occlusionRecanalize arterial clotSample CSF for pathologyAnti-inflammatory
Indication in watershed infarctEvaluate hypoperfusion etiologyTime‐limited, acute <4.5 hNot indicatedNot indicated
RiskContrast nephropathy, allergyHemorrhageHerniation, infectionImmunosuppression, hyperglycemia
Impact on managementGuides revascularization decisionsOnly if within window and no contraindicationsNo impactNo benefit in ischemia

Clinical Pearls

- Border-zone infarcts are hallmark of hemodynamic stroke; always evaluate carotid and intracranial circulation.
• DWI is positive within minutes of ischemia; follow-up with CTA/MRA clarifies etiology and guides revascularization.
• Symptomatic ≥70% carotid stenosis in watershed infarction patients may benefit from endarterectomy (NASCET criteria).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all acute MRI-confirmed infarcts with automatic tPA eligibility, without regard to time window or hemorrhage risk.
2. Assuming lumbar puncture is necessary for first-line evaluation of any new focal neurologic deficit.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines: “Noninvasive vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) is recommended in all acute ischemic stroke patients to detect large-vessel occlusion or stenosis” (Class I, Level B-R).
• ESO 2021 Guidelines: “CTA-based identification of large-vessel stenosis in watershed infarcts guides selection for carotid interventions; severe symptomatic stenosis (>70%) should be referred for endarterectomy” (Level A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Watershed zones lie between the distal territories of the ACA and MCA (anterior watershed) or MCA and PCA (posterior watershed). These zones receive the lowest perfusion pressure and are first affected in systemic hypotension or proximal stenosis.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Border-zone infarcts result from sustained cerebral hypoperfusion when autoregulatory capacity is overwhelmed, often in the presence of high-grade carotid or intracranial arterial stenosis, leading to cytotoxic edema detectable on DWI.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast CT to exclude hemorrhage.
2. MRI with DWI to confirm acute ischemia.
3. CTA of head and neck to identify stenosis/occlusion.
4. Tailor blood pressure targets and consider revascularization if significant large-vessel disease identified.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- DWI hyperintensity with corresponding ADC hypointensity confirms acute cytotoxic edema.
• CTA reveals vessel caliber, collateral status, and high-grade stenoses critical to management planning.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Border-zone infarcts and the required work-up with CTA are frequently tested as classic examples of hemodynamic stroke evaluation.

question_text: In the context of acute ischemic stroke, which visual field defect is commonly observed?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Visual signals travel: retina → optic nerves → chiasm → optic tracts → lateral geniculate nuclei → optic radiations → primary visual cortex.
• Lesions posterior to the optic chiasm cause contralateral visual field loss in both eyes (homonymous defects).
• Acute ischemic strokes frequently involve middle cerebral artery (MCA) or posterior cerebral artery (PCA) territories, affecting optic radiations or occipital cortex.
• Recognizing homonymous hemianopia localizes the lesion to retrochiasmal pathways, guiding emergent neuroimaging and reperfusion therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Homonymous hemianopia occurs in up to 15–20% of acute ischemic strokes, most often with PCA infarcts affecting the occipital cortex (Kalra et al., Stroke 2018). AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines on Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke recommend bedside confrontation visual field testing as part of the National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) (Class I, Level of Evidence B). MRI diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) confirms infarction in contralateral visual pathways. Restoration of perfusion via intravenous thrombolysis or endovascular thrombectomy can salvage peri-infarct tissue and improve visual outcomes when performed early (Albers et al., NEJM 2018).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Bitemporal hemianopia
• Due to chiasmal compression (e.g., pituitary macroadenoma); spares homonymous fields.
B. Homonymous hemianopia (correct)
• Retrochiasmal lesion yields same‐side defect; common in stroke.
C. Central scotoma
• Loss of central vision; arises from macular or optic nerve pathology (optic neuritis, maculopathy), not cortical ischemia.
D. Quadrantanopia
• One‐quarter field defect from partial optic radiation lesions (Meyer’s loop or parietal branch). Less frequent than complete hemianopia in acute stroke.

Comparison Table

OptionVisual Field DefectAnatomic LesionTypical Cause
Homonymous hemianopiaSame‐side loss in both eyesRetrochiasmal (optic tract, radiations, cortex)PCA/MCA territory stroke
Bitemporal hemianopiaLateral halves lostOptic chiasmPituitary tumor, craniopharyngioma
Central scotomaCentral vision field lossMacula or optic nerveOptic neuritis, macular degeneration
QuadrantanopiaOne quadrant lostMeyer's loop (temporal) or dorsal radiationsSmall PCA branch infarct (less common)

Clinical Pearls

• Bedside confrontation testing quickly detects homonymous defects; confirm with automated perimetry.
• PCA infarcts may spare macular vision ("macular sparing") due to dual blood supply.
• Early reperfusion (≤4.5 h for tPA, ≤24 h for thrombectomy in select patients) can improve both motor and visual outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking bitemporal hemianopia for stroke—chiasmal lesions, not vascular events.
2. Overattributing any visual loss in stroke to cortical causes; central scotoma suggests optic nerve or retinal disease.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines: NIHSS visual field assessment required; Class I, LOE B.
• ESO 2021 (European Stroke Organisation): Endovascular thrombectomy improves visual field preservation when PCA involvement extends into occipital lobe; Level II evidence.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Visual field defects in stroke are frequently tested in combination with vascular territory localization and NIHSS scoring.

question_text: A patient with cardioembolic stroke, ECG showed atrial fibrillation, and echocardiogram indicated nonvalvular cardiac disease. What should be given?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Atrial fibrillation (AF) causes stasis in the left atrium and left atrial appendage, promoting thrombus formation that can embolize to the cerebral circulation. Nonvalvular AF excludes mechanical valves or moderate-severe mitral stenosis. Secondary prevention of cardioembolic stroke relies on systemic anticoagulation to inhibit the coagulation cascade.
Key concepts:
• Thrombogenesis in AF involves activation of the intrinsic and common pathways culminating in factor Xa–mediated conversion of prothrombin to thrombin.
• Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) targeting factor Xa or thrombin provide predictable anticoagulation without routine monitoring.
• Antiplatelet agents (aspirin, clopidogrel) inadequately prevent cardioembolic stroke compared with anticoagulants.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Factor Xa inhibitors (e.g., apixaban, rivaroxaban, edoxaban) directly inhibit factor Xa, preventing thrombin generation. The 2019 AHA/ASA secondary stroke prevention guidelines and the 2021 European Stroke Organisation guidelines both recommend DOACs over warfarin for nonvalvular AF (Class I, Level A). Large randomized trials—ROCKET-AF (rivaroxaban), ARISTOTLE (apixaban), and ENGAGE AF-TIMI 48 (edoxaban)—demonstrated noninferiority or superiority to warfarin in preventing stroke/systemic embolism, with significantly lower intracranial hemorrhage rates (ARISTOTLE: 0.33% vs. 0.80% ICH rate, p<0.001). In acute ischemic stroke from AF, anticoagulation is typically initiated 4–14 days after stroke onset based on infarct size and hemorrhagic risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Aspirin
• Why incorrect: Antiplatelets do not inhibit thrombin-mediated clot formation central to cardioembolism.
• Misconception: Confusing atherosclerotic versus cardioembolic stroke prevention.
• Differentiator: Aspirin reduces platelet aggregation, not coagulation factor activity.

B. Warfarin
• Why incorrect: Although effective, warfarin requires INR monitoring, has variable pharmacokinetics, and higher intracranial hemorrhage risk compared to DOACs.
• Misconception: Belief that warfarin remains first-line for all AF.
• Differentiator: DOACs have fewer dietary/drug interactions and reduced ICH.

D. Clopidogrel
• Why incorrect: Similar to aspirin, clopidogrel targets P2Y12 receptors on platelets, ineffective for preventing clot formation in high-flow stasis conditions of AF.
• Misconception: Using dual antiplatelet therapy for stroke prevention in AF.
• Differentiator: No direct effect on factor Xa or thrombin.

Comparison Table

FeatureFactor Xa InhibitorWarfarinAspirinClopidogrel
MechanismDirect Xa inhibitionVitamin K antagonistCOX-1 inhibitionP2Y12 receptor block
Indication in NVAFFirst-lineAlternative (valvular)Not recommendedNot recommended
MonitoringNone routineINR checksNoneNone
ICH riskLowerHigherLowerLower
Efficacy vs warfarinNoninferior/superiorN/AInferiorInferior

Clinical Pearls

• In nonvalvular AF, DOACs reduce intracranial hemorrhage by ~50% versus warfarin.
• Initiate anticoagulation 4–14 days post-stroke; delay longer for large infarcts.
• Check renal function before choosing a DOAC; dose adjust in CKD.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Starting aspirin instead of anticoagulation in AF-related stroke.
2. Presuming warfarin is superior in all stroke patients with AF, ignoring DOAC benefits.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention (2019): Recommends DOACs over warfarin for nonvalvular AF (Class I, Level A).
2. European Stroke Organisation Guideline (2021): Endorses factor Xa inhibitors as first-line in nonvalvular AF to reduce stroke and ICH risk.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam.
Nonvalvular AF management is frequently tested as single-best-answer questions on stroke prevention.

question_text: A patient presents with a small right thalamic hemorrhage and normal blood pressure. What is the next appropriate step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) management balances preventing secondary complications (hematoma expansion, edema) and avoiding treatment-related risks.
• VTE risk rises soon after ICH due to immobility and inflammation; early pharmacologic prophylaxis reduces DVT/PE without increasing hematoma growth once the bleed is stable.
• Surgical interventions (EVD, evacuation) are reserved for large hemorrhages, significant mass effect, hydrocephalus, or cerebellar locations.
• Blood pressure control is crucial if hypertensive; with normotension, aggressive lowering may compromise cerebral perfusion.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Prophylactic low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) initiated 24–48 hours after ICH onset is supported by the 2022 AHA/ASA Guidelines (Class I, Level B-R). The landmark PREVENT trial and subsequent meta-analyses show no increase in hematoma expansion when heparin is started after CT stability is confirmed. In contrast, EVD is indicated only for intraventricular hemorrhage with hydrocephalus; surgical evacuation benefits superficial lobar bleeds >30 mL but not small deep hemorrhages; strict BP control applies only when systolic >180 mm Hg (ICH ATACH-II criteria).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. External ventricular drain (EVD) placement
– Incorrect: No intraventricular extension or hydrocephalus reported.
– Misconception: Belief that all thalamic bleeds cause hydrocephalus.
– Differentiator: EVD only for obstructive hydrocephalus.

C. Immediate surgical evacuation
– Incorrect: Small deep hemorrhages (<10 mL) in thalamus lack surgical benefit.
– Misconception: All ICH require evacuation.
– Differentiator: Evacuation reserved for superficial lobar bleeds >30 mL or deteriorating neurologic status.

D. Strict blood pressure control
– Incorrect: Patient is normotensive; aggressive lowering risks ischemia.
– Misconception: “Lower is always better” in ICH.
– Differentiator: Target SBP <140 mm Hg only if admission SBP >180 mm Hg per AHA/ASA.

Comparison Table

FeatureLMWH ProphylaxisEVD PlacementSurgical EvacuationBP Control
Primary indicationVTE preventionHydrocephalus reliefLarge/superficial ICHAcute SBP >180 mm Hg
Timing24–48 h post-ICH after CTImmediately if hydrocephalusTypically within 24 hImmediately upon SBP >180
Hematoma expansion riskNo increase if stableNeutralMay worsen deep bleedsPotential cerebral hypoperfusion
Supporting guideline levelClass I, Level B-R (AHA)Class I, Level C-LDClass IIb, Level B-RClass I, Level A (if >180)

Clinical Pearls

• Initiate mechanical VTE prophylaxis immediately and add LMWH at 24–48 h if repeat CT shows no hematoma growth.
• Small deep ICH (<10 mL) are managed medically; avoid neurosurgical interventions unless clinical deterioration.
• BP goal in ICH: systolic 140–160 mm Hg if initial SBP 150–220 mm Hg; avoid aggressive lowering in normotensive patients.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Delaying all pharmacologic prophylaxis for >7 days due to fear of expansion—increases VTE risk.
2. Assuming any thalamic bleed causes hydrocephalus and warrants EVD—requires radiographic/intracranial pressure evidence.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2022 ICH Guideline: Recommend starting prophylactic LMWH 24–48 h after ICH onset once hematoma stability confirmed (Class I, Level B-R).
• European Stroke Organisation 2021: Supports combined mechanical and low-dose pharmacologic VTE prophylaxis in ICH patients at low bleeding risk (Level A).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Management of small deep ICH and VTE prophylaxis timing is frequently tested, often contrasting medical versus surgical interventions and blood pressure targets.

question_text: A stroke patient has livedo reticularis. What is the diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Sneddon disease (syndrome) is a noninflammatory thrombotic vasculopathy affecting small‐ and medium‐sized arteries in skin and brain, classically presenting with livedo reticularis and recurrent ischemic strokes.
• Livedo reticularis: a lace‐like, violaceous skin mottling due to dermal arteriolar occlusion and capillary dilation.
• Cerebrovascular involvement: multiple cortical infarcts, often in watershed areas, with normal conventional angiography early on.
• Differential diagnosis hinges on distinguishing thrombotic noninflammatory arteriopathy (Sneddon) from systemic vasculitis (e.g., polyarteritis nodosa), autoimmune coagulopathies (APS, SLE), and embolic sources.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Sneddon disease is defined by the coexistence of persistent livedo reticularis and ischemic strokes without evidence of systemic inflammatory vasculitis or cardioembolism. Histopathology reveals intimal hyperplasia, luminal thrombosis, and minimal inflammatory infiltrate in small/medium dermal and leptomeningeal vessels (Bourgeois et al., J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2020).
A systematic review (Caetano et al., Stroke 2022) showed that 80% of patients with livedo and stroke fulfilling Sneddon criteria had negative inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP) and normal ANCA/ANA panels, distinguishing it from PAN or SLE. Advanced vessel wall MRI may demonstrate concentric wall thickening and enhancement without vessel wall edema (class IIa, LOE C; ESO 2021 guidelines on cryptogenic stroke).
Screening for antiphospholipid antibodies is recommended (Gianni et al., J Neurol 2022), but aPL positivity alone without the livedo–stroke syndrome fits primary APS, not Sneddon.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Polyarteritis nodosa
• Why incorrect: PAN is a necrotizing medium‐vessel vasculitis with systemic features (renal microaneurysms, mononeuritis multiplex), not isolated livedo reticularis with recurrent cortical strokes.
• Misconception: conflating livedo reticularis with vasculitis rather than thrombotic arteriopathy.
• Differentiator: PAN shows elevated ESR/CRP, tissue biopsy reveals fibrinoid necrosis and inflammatory infiltrate.

C. Antiphospholipid syndrome
• Why incorrect: APS causes hypercoagulability with stroke and can produce livedo, but livedo in APS is transient and serology (lupus anticoagulant, aCL, β2‐GP1) is persistently positive.
• Misconception: equating any livedo‐stroke association with APS rather than Sneddon’s distinctive noninflammatory arteriopathy.
• Differentiator: APS often has obstetric morbidity and venous thromboses; Sneddon lacks systemic coagulopathy criteria.

D. Systemic lupus erythematosus
• Why incorrect: SLE may have livedo and stroke, but it manifests with multi‐organ autoimmunity, hypocomplementemia, positive ANA/dsDNA, and immune complex vasculitis.
• Misconception: attributing livedo reticularis in any autoimmune disease to SLE.
• Differentiator: SLE shows broad serologic profile and inflammatory markers, unlike the noninflammatory histology of Sneddon.

Comparison Table

FeatureSneddon DiseasePolyarteritis NodosaAntiphospholipid SyndromeSystemic Lupus Erythematosus
Vessel involvementSmall/medium, noninflammatoryMedium, necrotizing vasculitisSmall/medium, thrombosisSmall, immune complex vasculitis
Livedo PatternPersistent, bilateral, widespreadRare, transientTransient, patchyOccasional, variable
SerologyNegative ANA/ANCA/ESRElevated ESR/CRP, negative ANCAPositive lupus anticoagulant, aCL, β2‐GP1Positive ANA, dsDNA, low C3/C4
Stroke characteristicsRecurrent cortical infarctsRare cerebral involvementArterial/venous thrombosesMultifactorial (vasculitis, thrombosis)
HistopathologyIntimal proliferation, thrombosisFibrinoid necrosis, inflammationThrombosis, no necrosisImmune complex deposition

Clinical Pearls

- Sneddon disease should be suspected in young/middle‐aged adults with livedo reticularis and “cryptogenic” strokes refractory to standard cardioembolic work‐up.
• Skin biopsy of livedo reticularis lesions with deep dermal sampling increases diagnostic yield (>80% sensitivity).
• Vessel wall MRI shows concentric concentric enhancement without edema in Sneddon vs. vasculitis‐associated edema in PAN/SLE.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking livedo reticularis in APS for Sneddon: always confirm aPL serology and obstetric/venous thrombosis history.
2. Assuming all livedo‐stroke syndromes are inflammatory: check ESR/CRP and biopsy for inflammatory infiltrates vs. thrombotic arteriopathy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 Guidelines on Cryptogenic Stroke: Recommend (Class IIa, LOE C) screening for nonatherosclerotic vasculopathies (e.g., Sneddon) with skin examination and high‐resolution vessel wall imaging when livedo reticularis is present.
• EULAR 2019 Recommendations for Antiphospholipid Syndrome: In stroke patients with persistent aPL positivity, lifelong anticoagulation with warfarin (INR 2.0–3.0) is advised (Grade C), underscoring the need to differentiate APS from Sneddon’s non‐inflammatory arteriopathy.
• Gianni et al., J Neurol 2022 (n=48): Found 35% of Sneddon patients had transient aPL positivity but lacked obstetric/venous thrombotic events, reinforcing that isolated livedo–stroke without full APS criteria indicates Sneddon.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Sneddon disease arises from a primary arteriopathy of dermal and cerebral vessels characterized by endothelial dysfunction, intimal hyperplasia, and in situ thrombosis without significant inflammatory cell infiltration. The precise trigger is unknown; hypotheses include genetic predisposition (e.g., PTHR1 mutations) and endothelial prothrombotic activation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical: Identify persistent livedo reticularis + unexplained ischemic strokes.
2. Labs: ESR/CRP, ANA/ANCA, aPL panel, complement levels.
3. Imaging: Brain MRI for multifocal infarcts; vessel wall MRI to distinguish thrombotic arteriopathy vs. vasculitis.
4. Biopsy: Deep skin biopsy of livedo lesions—look for intimal thickening and thrombosis without vasculitis.
5. Exclude: Cardioembolic sources, atherosclerosis, systemic vasculitis, APS/SLE.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- MRI: Multiple small cortical/subcortical infarcts, often in watershed zones.
• Vessel wall MRI: Concentric wall thickening with homogeneous enhancement; lack of mural edema distinguishes from inflammatory vasculitis.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Livedo reticularis with recurrent strokes is a high‐yield topic on neurology boards, frequently tested in single‐best‐answer format requiring differentiation between thrombotic arteriopathies and vasculitides.

question_text: A patient came with left side weakness; CT showed right semiovale hypodensity; what is the next step?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Acute ischemic stroke workup hinges on rapid imaging to differentiate hemorrhage from infarction and to identify large‐vessel occlusion (LVO).
• Neuroanatomy: The centrum semiovale is supplied by penetrating branches of the anterior cerebral and middle cerebral arteries; hypodensity there on noncontrast CT suggests early ischemia.
• Pathophysiology: Vessel occlusion creates a core infarct and surrounding penumbra; timely recanalization preserves at‐risk tissue.
• Imaging Strategy: Noncontrast CT excludes hemorrhage; CT angiography (CTA) of head/neck is the next step to detect LVO and guide thrombolysis or thrombectomy.
(105 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

CTA is the optimal emergent vascular study after noncontrast CT in suspected acute ischemic stroke. The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Class I, Level of Evidence B-R) recommend CTA or MRA of head/neck immediately after hemorrhage exclusion to identify LVO and select patients for endovascular therapy. Goyal et al.’s meta-analysis (Lancet 2016) demonstrated that CTA‐guided selection for mechanical thrombectomy yields a number needed to treat of 2.6 for functional independence. In late windows (6–24 h), the DAWN (N Engl J Med 2018) and DEFUSE 3 (N Engl J Med 2018) trials further underscore CTA plus perfusion imaging to expand thrombectomy candidacy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRI brain
• Incorrect because DWI/MRA, while sensitive, delays time to reperfusion. MRI is used when CT findings are equivocal or for subacute stroke characterization.
• Misconception: Belief that MRI must confirm infarct before vessel imaging; in hyperacute stroke, speed supersedes marginal sensitivity gains.

C. Start antiplatelet therapy
• Premature: Antiplatelet agents (e.g., aspirin) are initiated after vascular imaging and consideration of IV thrombolysis; starting without LVO assessment risks mismanagement if thrombectomy or tPA is indicated.
• Misconception: “Aspirin immediately” overlooks the priority of reperfusion strategies in LVO.

D. Carotid Doppler ultrasound
• Limited to extracranial carotid bifurcation; cannot visualize intracranial arteries or circle of Willis.
• Slower and operator‐dependent; CTA offers comprehensive, rapid head‐to‐neck evaluation.

Comparison Table

FeatureCTA of Head/NeckMRI BrainAntiplatelet TherapyCarotid Doppler US
Vessel visualizationIntracranial + extracranialIntracranial (MRA needed)NoneExtracranial only
Time to perform~2–5 minutes post-CT15–30 minutesImmediate15–20 minutes
Role in LVO detectionGold standardAdjunct if CT contraind.NonePoor for intracranial LVO
Guides thrombectomy decisionYesNo (requires additional)NoNo

Clinical Pearls

- In acute stroke (<24 h), always obtain emergent CTA following noncontrast CT to assess for endovascular therapy candidacy.
• Perfusion imaging (CTP or MR perfusion) refines patient selection in extended windows (6–24 h) per DAWN/DEFUSE 3.
• Carotid ultrasound is indicated later in subacute stroke to evaluate extracranial stenosis but is not a substitute for CTA in the hyperacute setting.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating MRI with first‐line acute stroke imaging, causing critical delays.
2. Initiating antiplatelet therapy before vascular imaging, potentially missing a thrombectomy window.
3. Overreliance on carotid Doppler in lieu of comprehensive CTA, risking undetected intracranial occlusions.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Class I recommendation for CTA or MRA immediately after noncontrast CT to detect LVO (Level B-R).
• DAWN Trial (N Engl J Med 2018): Demonstrated benefit of EVT up to 24 h in patients with mismatch profiles on CTA/perfusion (NIHSS 6–25, infarct core <70 mL).
• DEFUSE 3 (N Engl J Med 2018): Confirmed endovascular benefit in 6–16 h window using perfusion imaging selection (Class I, Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam.
Vascular imaging strategy in acute ischemic stroke is a high‐yield topic on neurology boards and STEP exams, frequently tested as a sequence: noncontrast CT → CTA (or MRA) → thrombolysis/thrombectomy decision.

question_text: A patient on warfarin developed acute focal weakness. A noncontrast CT brain scan shows an intracerebral hemorrhage with a distinct horizontal fluid–fluid level. What is the most likely underlying cause?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] • Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) morphology on CT: homogeneous hyperdensity vs. heterogeneous with layering.
• Fluid–fluid levels (“hematocrit effect”): layering of red cells below plasma due to impaired clot formation.
• Warfarin anticoagulation effects: vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibition → reduced factors II, VII, IX, X → coagulopathy predisposes to noncohesive bleed with sedimentation.

(Word count: 69)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Fluid–fluid levels on noncontrast CT are highly specific (>90%) for anticoagulation‐related hemorrhage (Delgado Almandoz et al., AJNR 2010). In coagulopathic bleeding, inadequate thrombin generation prevents solid clot formation; red cells settle under gravity, creating a hyperdense layer over a hypodense plasma layer. The 2022 AHA/ASA ICH guidelines recommend rapid reversal of VKA-associated ICH with four-factor prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) and intravenous vitamin K (Class I, Level A). Early reversal (<1 hour) reduces hematoma expansion and improves functional outcome (Wilson et al., Stroke 2019).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Hypertensive hemorrhage
– Incorrect: Typically deep basal ganglia/thalamic bleed without fluid levels; clot forms rapidly due to normal coagulation.
– Misconception: All spontaneous ICH in elderly hypertensives show layering.
– Differentiator: Homogeneous hyperdense appearance, no sedimentation.

C. Arteriovenous malformation rupture
– Incorrect: Presents with heterogeneous hyperdensity only if long-standing bleed; angiography shows nidus.
– Misconception: AVM bleeds always show mixed densities.
– Differentiator: Contrast angiography evidence, no classic fluid–fluid levels.

D. Cerebral amyloid angiopathy
– Incorrect: Lobar hemorrhages in elderly with microbleeds on MRI; coagulation normal, clot solidifies.
– Misconception: CAA bleeds layer on CT like coagulopathy.
– Differentiator: Superficial cortical bleed distribution, positive Congo red pathology.

Comparison Table

FeatureCoagulopathy (Correct)Hypertensive HemorrhageAVM RuptureCAA Hemorrhage
Anticoagulation statusPositive (e.g., warfarin)Usually negativeVariableNegative
CT appearanceFluid–fluid level (hematocrit)Homogeneous hyperdensityHeterogeneous without layeringHomogeneous or lobar bleed
Clotting factor levelsReduced II, VII, IX, XNormalNormalNormal
AnatomyAnywhere (often lobar)Deep grey nuclei (basal ganglia, thalamus)Any AVM location, cortical/deepLobar (cortical/subcortical)
Diagnostic confirmationCoagulation panel, reversal testClinical & imagingAngiography, MRIMRI microbleeds, pathology

Clinical Pearls

1. Fluid–fluid levels on CT should prompt urgent INR measurement and reversal in VKA-associated ICH.
2. Four-factor PCC reverses warfarin in <15 minutes vs. FFP in ≥30 minutes, reducing hematoma growth.
3. Not all heterogeneous-appearing bleeds are neoplastic or vascular malformations; consider coagulopathy first.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Students often attribute any mixed-density hemorrhage to an AVM rather than checking anticoagulation status.
• Belief that CAA bleeds always have layering; in reality, CAA bleeds clot normally, appearing uniformly hyperdense.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2022 ICH Guideline: Class I recommendation for rapid VKA reversal with PCC + IV vitamin K (Level A).
2. Wilson et al., Stroke 2019: Early (<1 h) PCC administration in VKA-ICH reduced hematoma expansion by 50% (Level B evidence).

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Fluid–fluid levels (“hematocrit effect”) are best seen on noncontrast CT within hours of bleed onset.
• Susceptibility-weighted MRI shows blooming but cannot distinguish layering as CT does.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Warfarin reversal: four-factor PCC (25–50 IU/kg) + 10 mg IV vitamin K.
• Avoid FFP in urgent reversal unless PCC unavailable; risk of volume overload and delayed effect.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. Anticoagulation-related hemorrhages with CT fluid–fluid levels are frequently tested as a specific imaging sign of coagulopathy.

question_text: A stroke patient with an NIHSS score of 3. What is the treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Ischemic strokes are classified by etiology (cardioembolic vs. atherothrombotic) and severity (NIHSS). An NIHSS score ≤3 designates a non-disabling (minor) stroke. In atherothrombotic strokes, platelet aggregation on a ruptured plaque drives early recurrence risk. Early initiation of antiplatelet therapy (within 24–48 hours) significantly lowers recurrence. Recognizing stroke severity via NIHSS informs whether to choose monotherapy versus short-term dual therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Aspirin irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase-1, reducing thromboxane A2–mediated platelet aggregation. The AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines (Class I, Level A) recommend starting 160–325 mg aspirin within 24–48 hours of non-cardioembolic ischemic stroke onset, followed by 75–100 mg daily. The International Stroke Trial (IST) and CAST demonstrated ~15–20% reduction in recurrent events with early aspirin. While CHANCE (2013) and POINT (2018) support 21-day dual antiplatelet therapy for minor stroke/TIA (NIHSS ≤3), aspirin monotherapy remains foundational, particularly if bleeding risk is elevated or dual therapy contraindicated. Clopidogrel monotherapy is reserved for true aspirin allergy (CAPRIE trial). Anticoagulants (warfarin, factor Xa inhibitors) are indicated only when a clear cardioembolic source (e.g., atrial fibrillation) is identified.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Warfarin
• Incorrect: A vitamin K antagonist indicated for cardioembolic stroke prevention (e.g., AF), not non-cardioembolic minor stroke.
• Misconception: “All strokes require anticoagulation.”
• Differentiator: Benefits require cardioembolic etiology and INR monitoring; no benefit in atherothrombotic stroke.

C. Factor X inhibitor
• Incorrect: Direct oral anticoagulants (e.g., rivaroxaban) are approved for non-valvular AF and venous thromboembolism, not for acute non-cardioembolic stroke.
• Misconception: “Newer anticoagulants supersede antiplatelets in all ischemic stroke subtypes.”
• Differentiator: Lack of indication without cardioembolic source; increased hemorrhage risk.

D. Clopidogrel
• Incorrect: A P2Y12-inhibitor used as monotherapy only when aspirin is contraindicated; evidence for acute monotherapy is less robust than aspirin.
• Misconception: “Any single antiplatelet is equivalent for initial therapy.”
• Differentiator: Clopidogrel loading (300 mg) and maintenance (75 mg) are less validated than aspirin in the acute phase.

Comparison Table

FeatureAspirin (Correct)WarfarinFactor X InhibitorClopidogrel
MechanismCOX-1 inhibition → ↓TxA2VKORC1 inhibition → ↓Vit KDirect FXa inhibitionP2Y12 receptor blockade
IndicationAcute non-cardioembolic strokeCardioembolic prevention (AF)AF, VTE preventionASA allergy; long-term use
Initiation timingWithin 24–48 hAfter EF/echo confirms AFAfter etiology confirmedWithin 24 h if ASA unsuitable
Guideline recommendationAHA/ASA I, AAHA/ASA I (AF)AHA/ASA I (AF)AHA/ASA IIb (monotherapy)
Key trialsIST, CASTBAATA, EAFTROCKET-AF, ARISTOTLECAPRIE

Clinical Pearls

• NIHSS ≤3 defines non-disabling stroke—this group benefits most from prompt antiplatelet therapy.
• Administer aspirin 160–325 mg within 24 h, then transition to 75–100 mg daily for secondary prevention.
• Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) for 21 days can further reduce recurrence but increases bleeding risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Prescribing anticoagulation (warfarin/DOAC) without confirming cardioembolic source.
• Equating clopidogrel monotherapy with aspirin’s evidence base in the acute setting.
• Delaying aspirin beyond 48 hours, missing the window for maximum benefit.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2018 Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: First-line—aspirin 160–325 mg within 24–48 h (Class I, Level A).
• CHANCE Trial (NEJM 2013): Aspirin + clopidogrel reduced 90-day stroke risk in minor stroke/TIA (OR 0.68; 95% CI 0.57–0.81).
• POINT Trial (NEJM 2018): Similar benefit in Western cohorts but higher major hemorrhage; recommends ≤21 days of dual therapy (Grade 2B).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Aspirin: IR COX-1 inhibitor; loading 160–325 mg, then 75–100 mg daily.
• Clopidogrel: Prodrug; loading 300 mg, then 75 mg daily.
• Warfarin: Dose-adjusted to INR 2.0–3.0; not indicated absent cardioembolic source.
• FXa inhibitors: Rivaroxaban 20 mg qd; apixaban 5 mg bid; for AF only.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam.
Management of non-disabling stroke is frequently tested via vignettes emphasizing NIHSS thresholds and choice of antithrombotic therapy.

question_text: Q70. A patient diagnosed with acute ischemic stroke underwent workup, and her vessel imaging showed atherosclerotic disease; however, there was no critical stenosis. An echocardiogram is normal except for an ejection fraction of 55%. An 8-hour Holter monitor did not show any arrhythmia. What is the most likely mechanism of her stroke?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Ischemic strokes are categorized by TOAST criteria into large-artery atherosclerosis, cardioembolism, small-vessel occlusion, other determined, and undetermined (cryptogenic). Large-artery atherosclerosis typically requires ≥50% intracranial or ≥70% extracranial stenosis to produce ischemia by hemodynamic compromise or in situ thrombosis. However, non‐stenotic but unstable plaques can rupture and send distal emboli. Cardioembolic sources (e.g., atrial fibrillation, low ejection fraction <35%) are excluded here. Hypoperfusion requires critical stenosis or systemic hypotension. Recognizing artery‐to‐artery embolism from non‐stenotic atherosclerotic plaque is essential in cryptogenic stroke evaluation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Artery‐to‐artery embolism (“embolic” mechanism) is the most likely cause when imaging shows atherosclerotic plaques without critical stenosis. Contemporary studies (Amarenco et al., Lancet Neurol 2020) demonstrate that plaques with ulceration or intraplaque hemorrhage on MRI can shed microemboli despite <50% luminal narrowing. The 2018 AHA/ASA “Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke” guidelines (Class I, Level B‐R) endorse transcranial Doppler microembolic signal monitoring in suspected plaque embolism. In situ thrombosis is generally superimposed on high‐grade stenosis (>70%). Hypoperfusion requires collateral failure in severe stenosis or systemic hypotension, neither of which is present. Thus, embolism from non‐stenotic plaque best explains her infarct.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Hypoperfusion
• Incorrect: Requires critical stenosis or systemic hypotension (e.g., ≥70% carotid stenosis).
• Misconception: Equating any atherosclerosis with low‐flow stroke.
• Differentiation: No significant luminal narrowing or hemodynamic compromise on vessel imaging.

C. Vessel stenosis
• Incorrect: Would imply direct ischemia from luminal narrowing.
• Misconception: All atherosclerotic disease produces flow‐limiting stenosis.
• Differentiation: Imaging showed plaque without critical stenosis.

D. Thrombosis
• Incorrect: In situ thrombosis forms on ulcerated plaque in severe stenosis, not on stable non‐stenotic plaques.
• Misconception: Any clot in an artery equals local thrombosis.
• Differentiation: Thrombosis is associated with high‐grade stenosis and local flow patterns, which are absent here.

Comparison Table

FeatureEmbolism (Correct)HypoperfusionVessel StenosisThrombosis
MechanismArtery-to-artery plaque rupture → distal emboliReduced cerebral perfusion below thresholdDirect luminal narrowing causing ischemiaIn situ clot formation over plaque
ImagingPlaque ulceration or intraplaque hemorrhage on vessel MRICollateral failure + watershed infarcts≥50% intracranial or ≥70% extracranialHigh‐grade stenosis with intraluminal filling defect
Hemodynamic requirementNone (embolic shower)Critical stenosis or hypotensionHigh‐grade stenosisSevere luminal narrowing
Diagnostic testTranscranial Doppler microembolic signals, plaque MRIPerfusion MRI/CT, BP monitoringCTA/MRA with degree of narrowingDuplex US/CTA showing occlusive thrombus
ManagementAntiplatelet + statin; consider plaque stabilization therapiesImprove BP & flow, revascularizationEndarterectomy/stenting if symptomaticAnticoagulation if high‐risk, antiplatelet

Clinical Pearls

- Symptomatic non‐stenotic carotid plaques (SyNC) can cause up to 15% of cryptogenic strokes; high‐resolution MRI identifies vulnerable features.
• Transcranial Doppler microembolic signal monitoring has Class IIa support (AHA/ASA 2018) for detecting ongoing plaque embolization.
• Holter monitoring for ≥24–72 hours is more sensitive for intermittent atrial fibrillation than an 8-hour study.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming any carotid atherosclerosis automatically implies hemodynamic hypoperfusion.
2. Equating stroke due to plaque with local thrombosis rather than embolization, leading to misdirected treatment (e.g., anticoagulation vs antiplatelet).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines: Recommend antiplatelet therapy and high‐intensity statin for stroke due to non‐stenotic plaque (Class I, Level B‐R).
• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 Guidelines: Endorse high‐resolution vessel wall MRI to characterize plaque vulnerability in cryptogenic stroke (Level B evidence).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
2. CTA/MRA of head and neck to assess stenosis and plaque morphology.
3. Carotid duplex ultrasound if CTA equivocal.
4. High‐resolution vessel wall MRI for plaque characterization.
5. Echocardiography + extended Holter (24–72 h) to rule out cardioembolism.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Intraplaque hemorrhage on T1‐weighted MRI appears hyperintense and indicates high risk for embolization.
• Transcranial Doppler may detect embolic signals (“chirps”) in the middle cerebral artery ipsilateral to the plaque.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Initiate dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) for 21 days post‐embolic stroke per CHANCE and POINT trials.
• High‐intensity statin therapy (e.g., atorvastatin 80 mg) lowers risk of recurrent plaque‐mediated events.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. This topic—stroke mechanism classification and management of non‐stenotic plaque—frequently appears in multiple‐choice sections, often testing interpretation of vascular imaging and TOAST criteria.

question_text: A patient presents with a picture showing a fluid level hemorrhage. What is the mechanism of this hemorrhage?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] - Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) etiologies include hypertensive vasculopathy (deep nuclei), cerebral amyloid angiopathy (lobar cortex), vascular malformations (nidus rupture), and coagulopathies (variable sites).
• On noncontrast CT, acute blood is hyperdense; a “fluid level” or hematocrit effect—visible as a horizontal interface between plasma and packed red cells—occurs when clot stabilization is delayed.
• Normal coagulation rapidly forms a fibrin mesh, preventing layering; impaired coagulation (e.g., warfarin, DIC, severe thrombocytopenia) allows red blood cells to settle under gravity before firm clot formation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The hallmark hematocrit effect in ICH is highly specific (>95%) for bleeding diatheses impairing clot formation. A study by Rosand et al. (Stroke, 2019) demonstrated that CT fluid levels correlate with supratherapeutic anticoagulation and severe thrombocytopenia. Pathophysiologically, deficient thrombin generation and fibrin cross-linking delay clot retraction, permitting red cell sedimentation. The 2022 AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Management of Spontaneous ICH (Class I, LOE B) recommend immediate coagulation assessment and reversal in patients with fluid-level hemorrhages, given their association with active bleeding and hematoma expansion. By contrast, hypertensive and amyloid-related bleeds clot rapidly, yielding uniform hyperdensities without layering, and AVM ruptures similarly lack sedimentation signs.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Hypertensive vasculopathy
• Mechanism: Rupture of Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysms in small penetrating arteries with rapid fibrin clot formation.
• Misconception: Deep location bleeds are always coagulopathic; however, they typically produce homogeneous density.
• Differentiator: No sedimentation; CT shows solid hyperdensity without a fluid interface.

C. Cerebral amyloid angiopathy
• Mechanism: β-amyloid deposition weakens cortical/leptomeningeal vessels, causing lobar hemorrhages.
• Misconception: All lobar bleeds with mixed density imply CAA; in fact, CAA bleeds clot normally, without layering.
• Differentiator: Superficial cortical distribution and chronic superficial siderosis, not fluid levels.

D. Arteriovenous malformation
• Mechanism: High-flow shunting and vessel wall stress rupture, leading to parenchymal hemorrhage.
• Misconception: Vascular malformations always produce heterogeneous bleeds with layering; they form solid clots.
• Differentiator: CT/MR shows nidus, flow voids or calcifications; hemorrhage is uniformly hyperdense.

Comparison Table

EtiologyTypical LocationCT AppearanceUnderlying Mechanism
CoagulopathyVariable (lobar, deep)Fluid level (hematocrit effect)Impaired fibrin formation → delayed clot stabilization
Hypertensive VasculopathyBasal ganglia, thalamus, ponsHomogeneous hyperdensityCharcot–Bouchard rupture with rapid clotting
Cerebral Amyloid AngiopathyLobar cortexIrregular lobar hyperdensityAmyloid deposition weakens vessels; normal clotting
Arteriovenous MalformationJuxtacortical junctionSolid hyperdensity; possible nidusHigh-flow shunting → vessel rupture, rapid clotting

Clinical Pearls

1. Fluid levels on noncontrast CT (“hematocrit effect”) strongly indicate an underlying coagulopathy—promptly check INR, platelet count, and thromboelastography.
2. In warfarin‐related ICH with fluid levels, administer four‐factor prothrombin complex concentrate and intravenous vitamin K to reduce hematoma expansion.
3. On MRI, susceptibility‐weighted imaging can also demonstrate blood–fluid levels, aiding diagnosis in subacute presentations.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overattributing deep basal ganglia hemorrhages to hypertension without considering anticoagulation status when a fluid level is present.
2. Misidentifying small cortical bleeds with mixed density as CAA without evaluating coagulation parameters.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines for Management of Spontaneous ICH, 2022: Class I, LOE B recommendation for urgent reversal of coagulopathy (INR >1.4) in ICH cases with fluid levels.
• European Stroke Organisation Guidelines, 2023: Expert consensus endorses CT hematocrit effect as an imaging biomarker for active bleeding and risk stratification in anticoagulated patients.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Impaired thrombin generation (e.g., due to vitamin K antagonists) or fibrinogen depletion (e.g., DIC) delays fibrin polymerization and clot retraction. This allows denser red blood cells to settle under gravity, separating from plasma and forming a horizontal fluid level.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Recognition of CT fluid levels as a marker of coagulopathy in ICH is a high‐yield concept on neurology boards, often tested via imaging interpretation and mechanism questions.

question_text: Q71. A man who developed acute vertigo and dysphagia along with left side ataxia on examination had the following finding (picture of uvula deviated to left). What is the most common finding?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] - Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome arises from infarction of the PICA or vertebral artery affecting the dorsolateral medulla.
• Key structures: nucleus ambiguus (dysphagia, uvula deviation), inferior cerebellar peduncle (ipsilateral ataxia), spinal trigeminal nucleus (ipsilateral facial pain/temperature), spinothalamic tract (contralateral body pain/temperature), and descending sympathetic fibers (ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome).
• Recognition of associated signs (e.g., Horner’s syndrome) is critical for lesion localization and management decisions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Right ptosis (Horner’s syndrome) is the most common additional finding in lateral medullary infarction. A prospective series by Kim et al. (Stroke 2003;34:1952–1960) reported ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome in 43% of PICA strokes, second only to gait ataxia (75%). The 2019 AHA/ASA guidelines (Class I, Level B-R) emphasize assessment for sympathetic fiber involvement in dorsolateral medullary infarcts to aid clinical localization and prognostication. Horner’s arises from disruption of descending hypothalamic fibers before synapse in the ciliospinal center (C8–T2). The absence of corticospinal signs (e.g., upgoing plantar) differentiates PICA infarcts from vertebral artery occlusions involving the pyramid.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Left facial hemianesthesia
• Incorrect: Lateral medullary lesions cause ipsilateral loss of facial pain/temperature, not “hemianesthesia” (all modalities).
• Misconception: Confusing spinothalamic involvement (body) with trigeminal nucleus signs.
• Differentiator: Trigeminal nucleus damage yields ipsilateral facial pain/temperature loss, not anesthesia of all modalities.

C. Left dysmetria
• Incorrect: Dysmetria (cerebellar signs) is present in PICA strokes but the vignette already documents left‐sided ataxia.
• Misconception: Thinking cerebellar signs are the distinguishing “most common” additional finding.
• Differentiator: Ataxia is common (75%), but the question asks for the most characteristic associated sign beyond those given.

D. Right upgoing plantar
• Incorrect: An extensor plantar response reflects corticospinal tract involvement, which is spared in dorsolateral medullary infarcts.
• Misconception: Confusing lateral medullary with lateral inferior pontine or vertebrobasilar strokes that may involve corticospinal fibers.
• Differentiator: Absence of pyramidal signs is a hallmark of PICA infarct.

Comparison Table

FeatureRight Ptosis (Horner’s)Left Facial HemianesthesiaLeft DysmetriaRight Upgoing Plantar
Structure injuredDescending sympathetics in medullaSpinal trigeminal nucleusInferior cerebellar peduncleCorticospinal tract
Laterality in this caseRight side ipsilateral to lesionWould be right side if presentLeft side (given)Would be contralateral to lesion
Frequency in PICA infarct~43% (Kim et al. Stroke 2003)~35% (ipsilateral face pain/T)~75% (ataxia)<5%
Exam findingPtosis, miosis, anhidrosisLoss of facial pain/temperatureDysdiadochokinesia, dysmetriaBabinski sign

Clinical Pearls

- In lateral medullary syndrome, dysphagia and hoarseness are more specific than facial weakness because nucleus ambiguus is involved, not facial nucleus.
• Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome in a patient with vertigo and dysphagia strongly localizes to the dorsolateral medulla (PICA territory).
• Absence of limb weakness (no UMN signs) helps distinguish PICA from vertebral artery or AICA infarcts.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming facial weakness rather than dysphagia/hoarseness localizes lateral medullary strokes.
• Overattributing cerebellar signs (ataxia) without recognizing pre‐existing vestibular or proprioceptive dysfunction.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2019 Update on Acute Ischemic Stroke Management (Stroke 2019;50:e344–e418)
• Recommendation: Evaluate for lateral medullary infarct with MRI DWI in patients with vertigo, dysphagia, and Horner’s signs (Class I, LOE B-R).
2. ESO-ESMINT 2018 Guidelines for the Management of Cerebrovascular Diseases
• Recommendation: Early recognition of PICA infarct features (nucleus ambiguus involvement, ipsilateral Horner’s) guides targeted swallowing assessment to reduce aspiration risk (Level A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Nucleus ambiguus (cranial nerves IX, X) → dysphagia, uvula deviation.
• Inferior cerebellar peduncle → ipsilateral limb ataxia.
• Descending sympathetic tract → ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis).
• Spinal trigeminal nucleus → ipsilateral facial pain/temperature deficits.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Occlusion of the PICA or vertebral artery impairs blood flow to the dorsolateral medulla, causing infarction of its nuclei and tracts. Ischemia of descending sympathetic fibers produces Horner’s syndrome, while interruption of cerebellar peduncular fibers leads to ataxia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: vertigo + dysphagia + ataxia.
2. Neurological exam: evaluate cranial nerves, sympathetic signs, sensory levels.
3. MRI with DWI/FLAIR to confirm dorsolateral medullary infarct.
4. Vascular imaging (MRA/CTA) to identify PICA/vertebral occlusion.
5. Cardiac and vascular risk assessment for secondary prevention.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- DWI MRI: hyperintensity in lateral medulla within hours of symptom onset.
• CTA/MRA: shows PICA or vertebral artery occlusion without leptomeningeal collaterals typical of cortical strokes.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- IV thrombolysis within 4.5 hours if no contraindications (AHA/ASA Class I).
• Antiplatelet therapy (aspirin ± clopidogrel) for secondary prevention.
• Statin therapy irrespective of LDL for plaque stabilization.
• Consider dysphagia management with early ENT/swallowing therapy referral.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam.
