Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome is frequently tested in clinical vignette format, emphasizing nucleus ambiguus findings (dysphagia, uvula deviation) and Horner’s syndrome to distinguish PICA infarcts from other posterior circulation strokes.

question_text: The same patient is now asking what treatment you will give. What will you prescribe?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Sneddon syndrome is a rare, noninflammatory occlusive arteriopathy of small‐to‐medium cerebral and cutaneous vessels. Characteristic livedo reticularis reflects dermal vessel involvement, while recurrent cortical infarcts arise from progressive intimal hyperplasia and thrombosis. Understanding the interplay between endothelial dysfunction and platelet activation underpins stroke risk. Definitive management focuses on antithrombotic therapy to prevent further ischemic events rather than immunosuppression or prophylactic seizure control.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Antithrombotic agents (low‐dose aspirin or full anticoagulation with warfarin, INR 2–3) target the primary mechanism in Sneddon—thrombus formation on a noninflamed, fibrotic endothelium. Though no randomized trials exist specifically for Sneddon syndrome, multiple case series (Frances et al., 1991; Takeuchi et al., 2000) report a marked reduction in recurrent strokes with antiplatelet or anticoagulant regimens. The 2019 AHA/ASA guideline on secondary prevention of noncardioembolic stroke endorses antiplatelet therapy (Class I, Level A). By interrupting platelet aggregation on damaged vessels, antithrombotics directly address the disease’s pathophysiology and minimize further cerebral infarcts.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Antiepileptic
– Seizure prophylaxis does not reduce thrombotic stroke risk. Seizures occur in ~10% of Sneddon patients and warrant treatment only if clinically manifest.

C. Immunosuppressive therapy
– Sneddon syndrome lacks inflammatory vasculitis; immunosuppressants provide no benefit unless there is coexistent systemic lupus erythematosus. Mistaking Sneddon for lupus vasculitis leads to unnecessary steroid exposure.

D. Antihypertensive medication
– While optimal blood pressure control is part of general stroke prevention, hypertension is not the primary driver of Sneddon’s arteriopathy. Antihypertensives do not prevent the platelet‐mediated occlusions central to this syndrome.

Comparison Table

FeatureAntithrombotic (Correct)AntiepilepticImmunosuppressiveAntihypertensive
MechanismInhibits platelet aggregation/coagulationModulates neuronal excitabilitySuppresses immune responseReduces systemic blood pressure
Role in Sneddon syndromePrevents recurrent ischemic strokesTreats seizures onlyNo role in noninflammatory arteriopathyAdjunctive, not disease‐specific
Level of EvidenceCase series; stroke guidelines (Class I, B)Standard seizure managementNo RCTs in SneddonGeneral stroke risk factor control

Clinical Pearls

• Livedo reticularis in a young stroke patient should prompt consideration of Sneddon syndrome and skin biopsy confirmation.
• Absence of inflammatory markers and vessel wall infiltration differentiates Sneddon from true vasculitis.
• First‐line secondary prevention is antiplatelet or anticoagulant therapy; escalated to warfarin if events recur on aspirin.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing Sneddon with systemic vasculitis and prescribing immunosuppressants.
2. Prioritizing seizure prophylaxis over antithrombotic therapy in asymptomatic patients.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2019 “Guideline on Secondary Prevention of Stroke in Patients with Stroke and TIA”: Recommends antiplatelet therapy for noncardioembolic ischemic stroke (Class I, Level A).
• EULAR 2016 “Recommendations for Management of Antiphospholipid Syndrome”: Advises low‐dose aspirin or warfarin (INR 2–3) for arterial thrombosis in prothrombotic disorders (Grade B, Level III).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesions predominate in cortical watershed areas supplied by distal branches of the middle and anterior cerebral arteries, where thrombotic occlusions most commonly occur.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Intimal smooth muscle proliferation and subendothelial fibrosis narrow vessel lumens; superimposed platelet adhesion leads to recurrent cortical infarctions.

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI demonstrates multifocal cortical infarcts of different ages without vessel wall enhancement, and angiography shows narrowing of small‐to‐medium arteries without vasculitic beading.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Aspirin 75–100 mg daily is first‐line; switch to warfarin (target INR 2.0–3.0) if recurrent events occur. Monitor INR biweekly initially, then monthly once stable.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Sneddon syndrome is frequently tested as a cause of stroke in young patients with livedo reticularis, emphasizing antithrombotic management over immunosuppression or seizure prophylaxis.

question_text: Q97. What are the CSF findings in RCVS?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS) is characterized by segmental narrowing of cerebral arteries leading to thunderclap headache and sometimes focal deficits.
• CSF analysis in RCVS is usually normal, helping distinguish it from inflammatory (e.g., vasculitis) or infectious causes.
• Key CSF parameters: cell count, protein, glucose ratio. In RCVS, cell count and glucose are normal; protein remains within reference.
• Understanding CSF profiles is crucial in subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) work-up: xanthochromia, elevated red cells vs. RCVS (no xanthochromia, normal CSF).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Normal CSF in RCVS is supported by multiple case series (Calabrese et al., Lancet Neurol 2007; Ducros, Cephalalgia 2012). The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3, 2018) diagnostic criteria state: “CSF normal or near-normal (<10 leukocytes/mm3; protein ≤0.5 g/L).” A multicenter cohort (Rocha et al., Stroke 2019) of 216 patients showed 96% had normal cell count and protein. In contrast, primary angiitis of the CNS often presents with pleocytosis and elevated protein (>0.5 g/L; Salvarani et al., Ann Neurol 2007). Thus, option B is correct.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Slightly high protein
• RCVS protein typically ≤0.5 g/L; mild elevations suggest inflammatory vasculitis or infection.
• Misconception: confusing RCVS with PACNS, which often has protein 0.6–1.5 g/L.

C. Elevated white blood cells
• Pleocytosis (>5 WBC/mm3) indicates inflammation (e.g., vasculitis, viral meningitis).
• RCVS lacks true inflammatory CSF profile.

D. Low glucose levels
• Hypoglycorrhachia (<2.2 mmol/L) points to bacterial/fungal infection or malignancy.
• Glucose is normal in RCVS.

Comparison Table

FeatureRCVS (B: Normal protein)Vasculitis (PACNS)SAHViral Meningitis
ProteinNormal (≤0.5 g/L)Elevated (>0.5–1.5)Normal–↑Mildly ↑
WBC countNormal (<5/mm3)Pleocytosis (>10)RBCs↑10–500/mm3
GlucoseNormalNormalNormalNormal
Clinical contextThunderclap headacheSubacute deficitsAcute worst headacheFever, neck stiffness

Clinical Pearls

1. Always obtain CSF when imaging is non-diagnostic in thunderclap headache to exclude SAH and vasculitis.
2. A truly normal CSF in the context of angiographic vasospasm strongly supports RCVS.
3. RCVS often resolves without immunosuppression; distinguishing it from PACNS prevents unnecessary steroids.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming any CSF protein elevation excludes RCVS—small increases (<0.6 g/L) can occur but are atypical.
2. Overreliance on angiography alone; without CSF, PACNS may be misdiagnosed as RCVS.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Headache Society. ICHD-3 (2018): Defines RCVS criteria—headache + segmental vasoconstriction + normal/near-normal CSF (≤10 WBC/mm3; protein ≤0.5 g/L). (Level V, expert consensus)
2. Rocha M. et al. Stroke (2019): Validation of RCVS2 score in 216 patients; normal CSF was present in 96% and carried 2 points in the score (Level II evidence).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. RCVS frequently tests on boards via contrasting CSF profiles with PACNS, SAH, and meningitis. When asked about laboratory findings, “normal CSF” is the hallmark for RCVS.

question_text: Q91. A common question scenario about progressive symptoms of a spinal fistula with attached MRI for the spine includes which of the following?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Spinal dural arteriovenous fistulas (DAVFs) are acquired shunts between a dural artery and medullary vein causing venous hypertension and progressive myelopathy. Key principles:
• Venous congestion impairs spinal cord perfusion, leading to T2 hyperintensity and edema.
• MRI shows central cord T2 signal and dilated perimedullary flow voids.
• Presentation is insidious in men >50 with gait clumsiness, sensory loss, and sphincter dysfunction.
Understanding these vascular pathologies and their imaging patterns is essential for timely diagnosis and treatment.

Evidence-Based Analysis

DAVFs are the most common spinal vascular malformation presenting with progressive myelopathy rather than acute hemorrhage. Venous hypertension from arterialized dural veins leads to cord edema and ischemia (Thron, 2009). On MRI, serpiginous flow voids on the dorsal surface and central T2 hyperintensity are characteristic (Rodesch et al., 2007). Diagnostic spinal angiography remains gold standard (J Neurosurg Spine, 2018). Early surgical or endovascular disconnection of the fistula halts progression; surgical ligation has lower recurrence rates than embolization for DAVFs (Furie et al., 2016).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Cavernoma
• Incorrect because cavernomas are low‐flow, hemosiderin‐laden capillary malformations that present with acute or subacute hemorrhage, not progressive venous hypertension.
• Misconception: equating any vascular lesion with gradual myelopathy.
• Differentiator: “popcorn” MRI appearance with hemosiderin ring, no perimedullary flow voids.

C. AVM
• Incorrect as spinal arteriovenous malformations (intramedullary AVMs) are high‐flow lesions causing acute hemorrhage or dramatic neurological decline.
• Misconception: all AV shunts behave like DAVFs.
• Differentiator: nidus within cord parenchyma and early venous drainage on angiography.

D. Spinal cord tumor
• Incorrect because tumors (e.g., ependymoma, astrocytoma) show focal enhancing mass lesions, cysts, or syrinx, not serpiginous vessels.
• Misconception: attributing T2 hyperintensity to neoplasm rather than venous edema.
• Differentiator: contrast enhancement pattern and mass effect on MRI.

Comparison Table

FeatureDAVF (Correct)CavernomaIntramedullary AVMSpinal Cord Tumor
Flow characteristicsLow‐flow, dural arterial feederLow‐flow, capillary malformationHigh‐flow, intramedullaryN/A
MRI T2 signalCentral hyperintensity + dorsal flow voids“Popcorn” core + hemosiderin rimFlow voids + intraparenchymal edemaFocal mass with edema
Clinical presentationProgressive myelopathy, gait & sphincter issuesAcute/subacute hemorrhagic eventsSudden hemorrhage or stepwise declineSlowly progressive sensory/motor loss
TreatmentSurgical/endovascular disconnectionObservation or microsurgical removal (hemorrhage)Embolization +/- surgeryResection, radiosurgery

Clinical Pearls

- Always inspect for perimedullary flow voids on T2‐weighted MRI when myelopathy is progressive.
• In older males with insidious gait disturbance and sphincter dysfunction, suspect DAVF.
• Surgical ligation has lower recurrence rates than embolization for spinal DAVFs (Level B evidence).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misreading central cord T2 hyperintensity as transverse myelitis and initiating steroids, which delays definitive treatment.
2. Failing to obtain spinal angiography after non‐contrast MRI, missing the dural feeder.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AANS/CNS Evidence‐Based Guidelines for the Management of Cervical and Thoracic Spinal Vascular Malformations, J Neurosurg Spine. 2018.
• Recommendation: Surgical disconnection of DAVF is first‐line therapy (Level B).
2. Krings et al., Consensus on the Classification and Endovascular Therapy of Spinal Vascular Malformations, European Radiology. 2021.
• Recommendation: Dural fistulas should be treated surgically when feeders are small or tortuous (Level C).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam.
Spinal DAVFs are frequently tested in Step 2/3 and neurology boards by presenting insidious myelopathy with MRI flow voids; expect questions on imaging recognition and management choice.

question_text: A 50-year-old patient presents with transient right-sided weakness. The diagnosis is TIA, with right ICA stenosis of 60% and left ICA stenosis of 65%. What is the recommended treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Transient ischaemic attacks (TIAs) are brief episodes of focal neurological dysfunction due to temporary cerebral hypoperfusion or microembolism, commonly from an atherosclerotic plaque at the internal carotid artery (ICA) bifurcation. Plaque ulceration can shed thromboemboli into anterior circulation (MCA territory), causing motor or sensory deficits. Degree of stenosis, quantified by NASCET criteria, stratifies stroke risk: symptomatic stenosis ≥70% confers the greatest benefit from revascularization; those with 50–69% derive moderate benefit. Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) historically remains the gold standard, but carotid artery stenting (CAS) with angioplasty offers a minimally invasive alternative, particularly in high surgical‐risk patients. Prompt intervention—ideally within two weeks—halves the risk of ipsilateral stroke. Medical therapy (antiplatelets, statins, BP control) underpins periprocedural care but does not replace revascularization in high‐grade symptomatic lesions. (147 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Angioplasty plus stenting (CAS) directly reestablishes luminal diameter and secures plaque with a scaffold, reducing embolic risk. The North American Symptomatic Carotid Endarterectomy Trial (NASCET, 1991) demonstrated an absolute stroke risk reduction of 17% at 2 years for CEA versus medical therapy in symptomatic ≥70% stenosis. The CREST trial (N Engl J Med 2010) randomized 2,502 symptomatic and asymptomatic patients to CAS versus CEA and found noninferiority for the composite endpoint of periprocedural stroke, MI, or death and ipsilateral stroke up to 4 years (7.2% CAS vs 6.8% CEA; HR 1.11; 95% CI 0.81–1.51; p=0.51). The 2018 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines (Class I, Level A) recommend revascularization for symptomatic stenosis ≥70% and (Class IIa, Level B-R) for 50–69%. CAS is preferred in patients at high surgical risk for CEA (Class I, Level A), and dual antiplatelet therapy (ASA plus clopidogrel) around the time of CAS reduces periprocedural thromboembolic events. Early intervention within 14 days of TIA is critical to maximize benefit.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. ASA
• Monotherapy reduces platelet aggregation but does not address high-grade (>50%) symptomatic stenosis; stroke recurrence remains high without revascularization.
• Misconception: “Any antiplatelet prevents plaque embolism sufficiently.”
• Differentiator: lacks mechanical plaque removal or scaffolding.

B. Angioplasty
• Balloon angioplasty alone leads to vessel recoil and high restenosis rates (up to 50% at 6 months).
• Misconception: “Dilating the vessel is enough without stenting.”
• Differentiator: no structural support to prevent plaque displacement.

C. ASA & Plavix
• Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) reduces early recurrence in minor stroke/TIA (POINT trial, NEJM 2018), but does not eliminate the embolic source in high-grade stenosis.
• Misconception: “DAPT can replace revascularization in symptomatic carotid disease.”
• Differentiator: medical therapy alone fails to achieve the large absolute risk reduction seen with revascularization.

Comparison Table

OptionMechanismPrimary BenefitLimitations
A. ASACOX-1 inhibitionReduces platelet aggregationNo plaque removal; high recurrent risk
B. AngioplastyBalloon dilationImmediate lumen expansionVessel recoil; high restenosis
C. ASA & PlavixCOX-1 + P2Y12 inhibitionReduces early recurrent eventsDoes not treat mechanical stenosis
D. Angio & stentingBalloon dilation + stent placementRestores flow; scaffolds plaque; embolic protectionRequires dual antiplatelet therapy; procedural risk

Clinical Pearls

- The greatest reduction in recurrent stroke occurs when revascularization is performed within 2 weeks of the index TIA.
• Symptomatic carotid stenosis 50–69%: revascularization yields moderate benefit (NASCET absolute risk reduction ~6%); ≥70% yields substantial benefit (NASCET ~16%).
• CAS is indicated in patients with anatomical or medical high surgical risk (e.g., prior neck surgery, irradiation, severe cardiopulmonary disease).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Failing to offer revascularization for symptomatic 50–69% stenosis, believing medical therapy alone suffices.
2. Confusing plain balloon angioplasty with stenting—only stenting provides durable plaque scaffolding and reduces recoil.
3. Extending dual antiplatelet therapy beyond 21–30 days for TIA without considering bleeding risk.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines 2018:
• Revascularization for symptomatic stenosis ≥70% (Class I, Level A); consider for 50–69% (Class IIa, Level B-R).
• CAS recommended for high surgical risk patients (Class I, Level A).
• CREST (Carotid Revascularization Endarterectomy vs Stenting Trial), NEJM 2010:
• CAS noninferior to CEA for composite endpoint at 4 years (HR 1.11; 95% CI 0.81–1.51).
• POINT Trial, NEJM 2018:
• DAPT (ASA + clopidogrel) reduced major ischemic events by 25% at 90 days in minor stroke/TIA (HR 0.75; 95% CI 0.59–0.95).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. Carotid stenosis management is a high-yield vascular neurology topic, often tested in the format of symptomatic degree thresholds, timing of intervention, and choice between CEA and CAS.

question_text: A female who develops transverse sinus thrombosis: what is the most accurate statement to describe this patient?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) arises from clot formation in dural sinuses or cortical veins, leading to impaired venous drainage, raised intracranial pressure, and possible hemorrhagic infarction. Key points:
• Anatomical: The superior sagittal and transverse sinuses are major dural channels draining cortical veins.
• Pathophysiology: Thrombosis → venous congestion → vasogenic edema, cytotoxic injury, hemorrhage.
• Epidemiology: CVT disproportionately affects young to middle-aged women due to hormonal and prothrombotic states (oral contraceptives, pregnancy, puerperium).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Female sex is a well-established independent risk factor for CVT. In the International Study on Cerebral Vein and Dural Sinus Thrombosis (ISCVT, Ferro et al. 2004), 75% of 624 patients were women (female:male ≈3:1), largely attributable to exogenous and endogenous hormonal influences. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) guidelines (2011, Class I, Level A) recommend prompt anticoagulation with low-molecular-weight heparin regardless of hemorrhagic transformation; this underscores that option D is false. Headache occurs in >85% of cases, whereas seizures present in ~40% (Ferro et al. 2004), refuting option B. Superior sagittal sinus involvement is most frequent (~70–80%), with transverse sinus involvement in ~40–50% (Coutinho et al. 2012), so option C is incorrect.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Seizure is the most common presenting symptom
– Incorrect: Headache (~85–95%) is most common; seizures occur in ~30–40%.
– Misconception: Overestimating seizure frequency in CVT.
– Differentiator: Always consider headache first in CVT diagnosis.

C. The transverse sinus is the most commonly affected sinus in CVT
– Incorrect: Superior sagittal sinus involvement (~75%) exceeds transverse sinus (~50%).
– Misconception: Confusion between common cortical vein vs dural sinus sites.
– Differentiator: Knowledge of relative sinus involvement rates.

D. Anticoagulation is contraindicated in cerebral venous thrombosis
– Incorrect: Anticoagulation (LMWH or UFH) is first-line even with intracerebral hemorrhage (AHA/ASA 2011, ESO 2017).
– Misconception: Fear of hemorrhagic conversion.
– Differentiator: Hemorrhagic stroke due to venous infarct is treated with anticoagulation.

Comparison Table

FeatureA. Female Risk FactorB. Seizure CommonC. Transverse Sinus Most CommonD. Anticoagulation Contraindicated
Prevalence in Women~75% of cases (ISCVT, Ferro 2004)Not relevantNot relevantNot relevant
Most Common SymptomHeadache (>85%)Seizures (~40%)HeadacheHeadache
Most Affected SinusSuperior sagittal (75%)Superior sagittal (75%)Superior sagittal (75%)Superior sagittal (75%)
TreatmentLMWH/UFH regardless of hemorrhageLMWH/UFHLMWH/UFHLMWH/UFH (not contraindicated)

Clinical Pearls

- CVT should be suspected in any young woman with new, severe headache plus prothrombotic risk factors.
• Anticoagulation with LMWH is safe and reduces mortality, even in the presence of intracerebral hemorrhage.
• MR venography is highly sensitive; look for absence of flow in the sinus and the “empty delta” sign on contrast CT.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overvaluing seizure presentation: seizures occur less often than headache.
2. Misidentifying the most common sinus: superior sagittal > transverse.
3. Withholding anticoagulation for hemorrhagic venous infarcts, contrary to guidelines.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2011 Guidelines for CVT (Class I, Level A): LMWH recommended in acute CVT, even with hemorrhage.
2. European Stroke Organization (ESO) 2017 Guidelines: Confirm noninferiority of DOACs (RE-SPECT CVT, 2019) to warfarin for CVT prevention (Class IIa, Level B).
3. RE-SPECT CVT Trial (Dabigatran vs. warfarin, 2019): Similar rates of recurrent thrombosis and major bleeding.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The transverse sinus courses laterally from the confluence of sinuses, draining the superior sagittal and straight sinuses into the sigmoid sinus. Thrombosis impedes cortical vein drainage, leading to venous congestion.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thrombus formation in a dural sinus elevates venous pressure → blood–brain barrier disruption → vasogenic edema and petechial hemorrhages → potential hemorrhagic infarction.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: headache + risk factors (OCP, pregnancy, infection).
2. Noncontrast CT: may show hyperdense sinus.
3. CT/MR venography: confirm filling defect.
4. Initiate anticoagulation immediately.
5. Evaluate for prothrombotic disorders.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Contrast CT: “empty delta” in superior sagittal sinus.
• MR T1/T2: acute clot is isointense to hyperintense; MRV shows absence of flow.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- LMWH (e.g., enoxaparin 1 mg/kg SC q12h) preferred over UFH unless renal failure or high bleed risk.
• Transition to warfarin (INR 2.0–3.0) for 3–12 months; DOACs emerging as alternatives.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam.
CVT topics are tested via epidemiology (female risk), clinical features (headache > seizures), imaging (empty delta), and management (anticoagulation despite hemorrhage).

question_text: A patient came with left side weakness; CT showed right semiovale hypodensity; what is the next step?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Acute focal neurologic deficits often signify ischemic stroke due to arterial occlusion.
1. Neuroanatomy: The centrum semiovale contains descending corticospinal fibers; infarction here produces contralateral motor weakness.
2. Imaging triage: Noncontrast CT excludes hemorrhage and may show early ischemic changes (hypodensity).
3. Vascular assessment: CT angiography (CTA) rapidly identifies large‐vessel occlusion (LVO) amenable to thrombectomy. Time‐sensitive decisions hinge on vessel patency rather than tissue characterization alone.

(Word count: 95)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke recommend emergent vascular imaging (CTA) immediately after noncontrast CT when endovascular therapy is considered (Class I, Level A). CTA has sensitivity > 95% and specificity > 90% for detecting intracranial LVO (Puetz et al., Stroke 2011). Early identification of LVO enables expedited transfer to angiography suite for mechanical thrombectomy, which in trials like MR CLEAN and EXTEND-IA improved functional outcomes (NNT ≈ 7). MRI, while more sensitive for early infarction, delays reperfusion. Anticoagulation in acute ischemic stroke increases hemorrhagic transformation risk without proven early benefit (TOAST trial). Lumbar puncture is unrelated when CT excludes hemorrhage.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRI brain
• Incorrect: Though diffusion‐weighted MRI detects acute infarct with high sensitivity, it delays reperfusion decisions.
• Misconception: Equating superior tissue contrast with optimal emergent strategy.
• Differentiator: CTA provides rapid vascular roadmap critical for thrombectomy.

C. Start anticoagulation
• Incorrect: Early anticoagulation (e.g., heparin) in noncardioembolic stroke raises hemorrhagic conversion risk without reducing disability (Lancet 1997).
• Misconception: “Clot equals anticoagulation” oversimplifies stroke etiology.
• Differentiator: Vessel imaging first to define mechanism and hemorrhage risk.

D. Lumbar puncture
• Incorrect: LP is used for suspected meningitis/subarachnoid hemorrhage when CT is non‐diagnostic, not for ischemic stroke workup.
• Misconception: Overuse of LP in neurologic deficits.
• Differentiator: No role once CT defines ischemia.

Comparison Table

FeatureCTA (Correct)MRI BrainAnticoagulationLumbar Puncture
PurposeVessel patency, LVO detectionParenchymal detail, infarct agePrevent embolism progressionCSF analysis
Time to perform<5 minutes after CT≥20-30 minutesImmediate but requires risk assessment≥30 minutes plus preparation
Impact on reperfusionDirects thrombectomy candidacyDelays reperfusion decisionsNo direct impact on LVO managementIrrelevant
Hemorrhage riskLow (contrast allergy risk)Low (no ionizing radiation)↑ hemorrhagic conversion↑ intracranial pressure risk
Guideline recommendationClass I, Level A (AHA/ASA 2019)Class IIb, Level CClass III, Level B (acute phase)Not recommended

Clinical Pearls

• Always obtain emergent CTA following noncontrast CT in suspected large‐vessel stroke to assess for thrombectomy (<6-24 hr window).
• “Time is brain”: for every 30-min delay in reperfusion, 120 million neurons are lost.
• Early anticoagulation without mechanism confirmation increases hemorrhage risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating MRI’s superior tissue contrast with the fastest route to reperfusion.
2. Initiating anticoagulation before vascular imaging, risking hemorrhagic conversion in large infarcts.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2019: Recommends immediate CTA after noncontrast CT for patients within 24 hr of last known well if candidate for endovascular therapy (Class I, Level A).
• EXTEND-IA (2017): Demonstrated that CTA-guided selection for thrombectomy plus alteplase improved 90-day modified Rankin Scale scores vs alteplase alone (MR 71% vs 40%, p<0.001).

Neuroimaging Pearls

CTA visualizes extracranial and intracranial arteries in seconds, delineating occlusion site, collateral status, and guiding endovascular strategy.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Acute stroke imaging protocols—especially the role of CTA following noncontrast CT—are frequently tested, often in single-best-answer format assessing guideline‐based management.

question_text: A patient presents with 6 hours of right-sided weakness affecting the arm, leg, and face, along with mild dysarthria. A brain CT shows an acute left internal capsule infarction. What is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] • Lacunar (small‐vessel) infarcts result from lipohyalinosis of lenticulostriate arteries supplying the internal capsule, producing a pure motor syndrome.
• Intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is indicated within 4.5 hours of ischemic stroke onset; beyond this window, risks of intracranial hemorrhage outweigh benefit.
• For minor ischemic strokes (NIHSS ≤3–5), early dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin plus clopidogrel reduces 21-day recurrence compared to aspirin alone.

Evidence-Based Analysis

DAPT is correct because this patient is outside the 4.5-hour thrombolysis window and has a minor non‐cardioembolic stroke (NIHSS ≈4: facial weakness 1, arm 1, leg 1, dysarthria 1).
– CHANCE trial (NEJM 2013): aspirin + clopidogrel within 24 h of minor stroke (NIHSS ≤3) reduced 90-day stroke recurrence by 32% (HR 0.68; p=0.001).
– POINT trial (NEJM 2018): similar benefit in a global population (NIHSS ≤3).
– THALES trial (NEJM 2020): aspirin + ticagrelor in mild-to-moderate stroke (NIHSS ≤5) lowered composite of stroke or death at 30 days (HR 0.79; p=0.02) with acceptable bleeding risk.
– AHA/ASA 2021 guideline (Class I, LOE A): recommend DAPT for 21 days in minor non-cardioembolic stroke.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. IV tPA
• Incorrect: Beyond 4.5 h window. CT evidence of established infarction increases hemorrhage risk.
• Misconception: tPA can be administered anytime before 24 h.

C. Aspirin
• Incorrect: Single antiplatelet less effective than DAPT for early secondary prevention in minor stroke.
• Misconception: Monotherapy is sufficient immediately post-stroke.

D. Supportive care and monitoring
• Incorrect: Fails to address high early recurrence risk; antithrombotic therapy is standard unless contraindicated.
• Misconception: Mild deficits do not require active therapy.

Comparison Table

FeatureDAPT (aspirin + clopidogrel)Aspirin MonotherapyIV tPASupportive Care
Time window≤24 h for minor strokeAny time post-stroke≤4.5 h from onsetN/A
Primary benefit↓ early recurrence (~30%)Moderate preventionAchieve reperfusionNo antithrombotic effect
Major hemorrhage riskModerate (short-term)LowHigh (ICH risk ~6%)Minimal
Stroke subtype applicabilityMinor non-cardioembolicAll non-cardioembolicAll eligible ischemic strokesNone
Guideline recommendationClass I, LOE AClass I, LOE A (long-term)Class I for ≤4.5 hSupportive adjunct only

Clinical Pearls

• Initiate DAPT within 24 h of minor stroke onset and continue for 21 days, then transition to monotherapy.
• NIHSS thresholds vary: CHANCE/POINT used ≤3, THALES used ≤5—tailor DAPT to patient severity.
• Lacunar strokes often show no acute changes on CT; MRI-DWI is more sensitive.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Administering tPA outside the 4.5 h window increases hemorrhagic transformation risk.
2. Overextending DAPT beyond 21 days markedly raises bleeding without added stroke prevention.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2021 Guideline on Early Management of Stroke: Recommends aspirin + clopidogrel for 21 days in minor non-cardioembolic stroke (Class I, LOE A).
• THALES Trial (NEJM 2020): Aspirin + ticagrelor reduced 30-day stroke/death in NIHSS ≤5 strokes (HR 0.79; p=0.02), supporting DAPT in mild-to-moderate deficits.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

• Posterior limb of the internal capsule carries corticospinal fibers; infarction causes contralateral pure motor deficits affecting face, arm, and leg.
• Lenticulostriate branches of the MCA are end arteries—no collateral circulation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

• Chronic hypertension → lipohyalinosis and microatheroma formation in small penetrating arteries → lacunar infarcts.
• Infarction disrupts descending motor tracts, manifesting as acute contralateral weakness.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast CT head to exclude hemorrhage.
2. Assess onset-to-door time and calculate NIHSS.
3. Determine reperfusion eligibility (tPA ≤4.5 h, thrombectomy if large vessel).
4. For minor stroke outside reperfusion window, initiate DAPT for 21 days.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Acute lacunar infarcts may not be visible on CT for up to 24 h; a CT showing a small hypodensity suggests established infarct and contraindicates tPA.
• MRI-DWI is the gold standard for detecting small vessel infarcts.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Aspirin loading 160 mg, then 75–100 mg daily; clopidogrel loading 300 mg (or 600 mg), then 75 mg daily.
• Monitor for GI bleeding; consider PPI prophylaxis in high-risk patients.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. Acute stroke management by time window, NIHSS severity, and infarct subtype is a high-yield topic, often tested in vignette format to assess appropriate use of tPA, thrombectomy, and antiplatelet strategies.

question_text: In a scenario for giant cell arteritis (GCA), what is the most likely mechanism or artery involved?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Giant cell arteritis (GCA) is a granulomatous vasculitis of medium- and large-sized arteries in patients over 50, with predilection for branches of the carotid and vertebral systems. The most feared complication is vision loss from arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION), caused by occlusion of the posterior ciliary arteries supplying the optic nerve head. Key clinical features include new-onset temporal headache, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, and elevated ESR/CRP. Differentiating AION (optic disc swelling) from central retinal artery occlusion (retinal whitening, cherry-red spot) hinges on understanding ophthalmic arterial branch anatomy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Posterior ciliary artery involvement explains the pathogenesis of vision loss in GCA. Granulomatous inflammation of these arteries causes luminal narrowing and optic nerve head ischemia, as demonstrated by Hayreh et al. (1998) in histopathologic studies of arteritic AION. CRAO, while capable of causing abrupt monocular blindness, is infrequently seen in GCA (<5%) and is more often due to cholesterol emboli or atherosclerosis. The superficial temporal artery is classically biopsied for diagnosis but does not supply the optic nerve. Intracranial vessels such as the vertebral artery, lacking a vasa vasorum network, are relatively spared, explaining the rarity of posterior circulation strokes in GCA (Evans et al., 1988). Immediate high-dose corticosteroids (40–60 mg/day prednisone) upon clinical suspicion reduce the incidence of bilateral vision loss (BSR/BHPR Guidelines 2010).

Incorrect Options Analysis

Option B: Retinal central artery occlusion
– CRAO leads to inner retinal infarction with a pale retina and cherry-red fovea; it is typically embolic/atherosclerotic in origin and rarely due to GCA.
Option C: Superficial temporal artery
– Inflammation here produces headache, scalp tenderness, and jaw claudication and is the standard biopsy target but does not perfuse the optic nerve.
Option D: Vertebral artery
– Intracranial arteries like the vertebrals have few vasa vasorum and are generally not affected by GCA; vertebrobasilar strokes in GCA are uncommon.

Comparison Table

FeaturePosterior ciliary arteriesCentral retinal artery occlusionSuperficial temporal arteryVertebral artery
OriginBranches of ophthalmic arteryBranch of ophthalmic arteryBranch of external carotid arteryBranch of subclavian artery
FunctionSupplies optic nerve head and choroidSupplies inner retinal layersSupplies scalp and temporal regionSupplies posterior circulation (brainstem, cerebellum)
GCA involvementGranulomatous inflammation → AIONRare involvement in GCACommon involvement → headache, jaw claudication (biopsy site)Rare involvement; intracranial vessels spared
Clinical manifestationSudden vision loss, pale/swollen optic discSudden vision loss, cherry-red spotScalp tenderness, temporal headacheBrainstem/cerebellar stroke symptoms

Clinical Pearls

1. Initiate high-dose glucocorticoids immediately when GCA is suspected to prevent bilateral blindness.
2. Jaw claudication has a specificity >90% for GCA and should heighten diagnostic urgency.
3. Temporal artery ultrasound “halo sign” correlates with vessel wall edema and can guide biopsy decisions.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing arteritic AION with CRAO: AION presents with optic disc swelling, whereas CRAO shows retinal whitening and a cherry-red spot.
2. Believing only the superficial temporal artery is involved: GCA often affects multiple extracranial branches of the carotid, including ophthalmic and occipital arteries.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. British Society for Rheumatology and British Health Professionals in Rheumatology (BSR/BHPR) Guidelines, 2010: recommend immediate initiation of 40–60 mg/day prednisone and temporal artery imaging (Level III evidence).
2. American College of Rheumatology and Vasculitis Foundation (ACR/VF) Guidelines, 2022: recommend adjunctive tocilizumab for induction and maintenance in high-relapse–risk patients (Level 1A evidence for reduced relapse rates).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The ophthalmic artery, a branch of the internal carotid artery, gives off short and long posterior ciliary arteries that penetrate the sclera around the optic nerve, supplying the optic nerve head and choroid. Occlusion of these vessels results in anterior ischemic damage to the optic nerve.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

GCA features T-cell–mediated granulomatous inflammation of the vessel media and adventitia, with multinucleated giant cells and fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina. Intimal hyperplasia and luminal stenosis lead to ischemia; involvement of posterior ciliary arteries causes optic nerve head infarction and sudden vision loss.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Vision loss in GCA due to posterior ciliary artery occlusion is a high-yield topic on neurology and rheumatology boards, often tested in case-based vignettes requiring knowledge of ophthalmic arterial anatomy and systemic vasculitis manifestations.

question_text: Q88. A scenario of lateral medullary syndrome shows PICA involvement. What is the significance of the absence of vertebral artery in the options?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome results from infarction of the dorsolateral medulla, most commonly due to PICA occlusion but occasionally from vertebral artery involvement. Key neuroanatomical concepts:
• PICA supplies the lateral medulla (nucleus ambiguus, vestibular nuclei, spinothalamic tract).
• Vertebral artery lesions can produce overlapping findings but often include additional medial structures (hypoglossal nucleus involvement).
• Clinical hallmarks: contralateral loss of pain/temperature body, ipsilateral facial numbness, dysphagia, hoarseness, ataxia, and Horner syndrome.
Understanding vascular territory overlap is essential for diagnosis and management.
(Word count: 112)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The absence of “vertebral artery” as an answer choice does not alter clinical or diagnostic reasoning once PICA infarction is established by history, examination, and imaging. According to the 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Early Management of Patients with Acute Ischemic Stroke, differentiation of posterior circulation strokes relies on clinical syndrome and MRI/MRA confirmation, not exhaustive listing of every possible vessel. In lateral medullary syndrome, PICA occlusion is the prototypical mechanism; lack of vertebral artery in options neither adds nor subtracts diagnostic certainty. Therefore, option B (“It is irrelevant”) is correct.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. It indicates a different diagnosis.
‐ Incorrect: Lateral medullary syndrome may arise from PICA or vertebral artery. Absence of the vertebral artery in the options does not imply an alternative syndrome.

C. It confirms the diagnosis of PICA syndrome.
‐ Incorrect: Confirmation requires clinicoradiologic correlation; absence of one vascular option does not itself confirm another.

D. It suggests a need for further imaging.
‐ Incorrect: Further imaging (e.g., MR angiography) is guided by clinical uncertainty, not by omissions in a multiple-choice list.

Comparison Table

FeaturePICA InfarctVertebral Artery Infarct
Typical clinical syndromeLateral medullary (Wallenberg) signsMay include PICA signs + medial deficits (hypoglossal)
Common imaging findingDorsolateral medullary hyperintensity on DWILarger or more heterogeneous infarct including medial structures
Nucleus ambiguus involvementPresent → dysphagia, hoarsenessOften present
Hypoglossal nucleus involvementAbsentMay be present (tongue deviation)
Vascular anatomy overlapSole PICA territoryPICA + vertebral contributions

Clinical Pearls

• Dysphagia and hoarseness are more severe in PICA than in pure vertebral medullary infarcts due to nucleus ambiguus ischemia.
• MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) is >95% sensitive for posterior fossa strokes within 24 hours.
• A negative vertebral artery option in a question stem does not negate vertebral involvement in real‐world practice; always rely on imaging.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming option omissions equate to clinical exclusion: testwise guessing can mislead students into overinterpreting answer lists.
2. Confusing PICA and vertebral artery syndromes: both can produce lateral medullary signs but differ in ancillary features (e.g., hypoglossal signs in vertebral infarct).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2019 Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommends posterior circulation stroke diagnosis by clinical syndrome + emergent MRI/MRA (Class I, Level A).
• ESO-ECASS 2018 Posterior Circulation Consensus: Emphasizes tailored imaging (DWI/PWI) for vertebrobasilar strokes, no requirement to list every vessel in decision tools (Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Posterior circulation anatomy and stroke syndromes (lateral medullary) are tested frequently in both vignette and image-based formats, often emphasizing differentiation between PICA and vertebral artery infarctions.

question_text: Q101. Which factors increase the risk for aneurysm formation?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Intracranial saccular (berry) aneurysms arise at arterial branch points in the circle of Willis due to hemodynamic stress and focal defects in the internal elastic lamina. Endothelial injury from chronically elevated transmural pressure (hypertension) and toxic effects of cigarette smoke accelerate matrix metalloproteinase–mediated degradation of the arterial wall. Female sex hormones, particularly in postmenopausal women, influence collagen turnover and may predispose to wall weakness. Recognizing these pathophysiological drivers is essential when evaluating patients for aneurysm screening and risk reduction.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option D (“All of the above”) is correct because multiple large cohort and case-control studies—and current guidelines—identify uncontrolled hypertension, active cigarette smoking, and female gender as independent risk factors for the formation of intracranial aneurysms. The International Study of Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms (ISUIA, 1998; Wiebers et al., 2003) demonstrated that hypertension doubles aneurysm prevalence, while smoking confers a threefold increased risk (Odds Ratio [OR] ≈ 3.1). Female predominance (female:male ≈ 3:1) is observed across populations, likely related to hormonal influences on vessel wall integrity. The 2022 AHA/ASA guideline on the Management of Patients with Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms (Class I, Level B evidence) recommends strict blood pressure control (<140/90 mm Hg) and smoking cessation to reduce aneurysm formation and growth.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Uncontrolled blood pressure
• Incorrect because it lists only hypertension; it omits two additional validated risk factors (smoking and female sex).
• Misconception: Overemphasis on blood pressure while under-recognizing behavioral and demographic contributors.

B. Hypertension and smoking
• Incorrect because although these are significant, the option fails to include female gender, which has been consistently associated with higher aneurysm prevalence (female:male ≈ 3:1).
• Misconception: Treats aneurysm risk as solely modifiable without considering nonmodifiable demographic factors.

C. Female gender
• Incorrect because gender alone does not capture the multifactorial nature of aneurysm pathogenesis; modifiable risks (hypertension, smoking) dramatically amplify risk.
• Misconception: Assumes demographic factor is sufficient for aneurysm formation.

Comparison Table

FeatureA: BP OnlyB: HTN + SmokingC: Female GenderD: All of the Above
HypertensionYesYesNoYes
SmokingNoYesNoYes
Female SexNoNoYesYes
Cumulative Risk CoverageIncompleteIncompleteIncompleteComplete
Reflects Evidence-Based RiskPartialPartialPartialFull

Clinical Pearls

1. Systematically screen first-degree relatives of patients with aneurysmal SAH if there is a family history—female relatives with hypertension and smoking history are highest risk.
2. Smoking cessation yields measurable risk reduction; risk for aneurysm growth drops by ~40% within five years of quitting.
3. Postmenopausal hormone replacement therapy remains investigational; current data do not support its use solely for aneurysm prevention.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Focusing exclusively on modifiable factors (e.g., hypertension) and neglecting demographic risks (female sex) leads to underappreciation of total risk burden.
2. Believing that aneurysm formation is independent of lifestyle factors; neglecting smoking cessation greatly undercuts preventive strategy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA Management of Patients with Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms (2022): Class I, Level B recommendation for BP control (<140/90 mm Hg) and smoking cessation to prevent aneurysm formation and growth.
• European Stroke Organisation Guidelines (ESO, 2021): Grade A recommendation for combined risk-factor modification (including antihypertensive therapy and smoking cessation) in individuals at high risk for intracranial aneurysms.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Risk factors for cerebral aneurysm formation are frequently tested as combinations of modifiable (hypertension, smoking) and nonmodifiable (female sex, family history) variables.

question_text: Q160. (Source: Part II 2019mcqs.txt) Acute paraparesis after major repair of the aorta can be devastating. The sensory level is often found at which of the following?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] In anterior spinal artery (ASA) syndrome—often seen after thoracoabdominal aortic surgery—ischemia occurs in the ventral two-thirds of the cord. Key concepts:
• Vascular supply: the ASA is reinforced by radicular arteries; the largest is the artery of Adamkiewicz, typically arising between T9–T12.
• Watershed zones: the mid-to-lower thoracic cord (T4–T8) has fewer segmental feeders and is most vulnerable to hypoperfusion.
• Clinical signs: loss of motor function and pain/temperature below the lesion with preserved proprioception. Sensory “level” localizes the infarct.

(Word count: 91)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The lower thoracic cord around T8 is the epicenter of watershed perfusion in ASA syndrome after aortic cross-clamping. Large series (Safargy et al., J Vasc Surg 2020) document that sensory levels cluster at T6–T10, with a peak at T8 in over 60% of cases. Experimental models confirm that interruption of intercostal and lumbar radicular arteries at T8 leads to anterior horn cell and spinothalamic tract infarction. European Society for Vascular Surgery (ESVS 2022) guidelines recommend intraoperative neuromonitoring focused on T8–T12 segments and maintaining mean arterial pressure above 80 mmHg to protect this watershed region (Level C evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. C2
• Incorrect: High cervical segments retain robust collateral ASA supply via vertebral and deep cervical arteries.
• Misconception: Confusing traumatic cervical spinal cord injury (sensory level C4–C5) with vascular infarction patterns.
• Differentiator: Aortic cross-clamping does not compromise cervical feeders.

B. T4
• Incorrect: Although the mid-thoracic zone spans T4–T8, true perfusion nadir is lower (T6–T10).
• Misconception: Equating the nipple dermatome (T4) with the vascular watershed peak.
• Differentiator: Radicular artery density falls most sharply below T6, not at T4.

D. L4
• Incorrect: The lumbar enlargement (L1–L4 segments) is supplied by the artery of Adamkiewicz and has richer collateralization.
• Misconception: Expecting lower-limb sensory levels to correspond to lumbar segments.
• Differentiator: Infarcts from thoracic aortic surgery rarely localize in true lumbar segments.

Comparison Table

FeatureT8 (Correct)T4C2L4
Dermatome landmarkEpigastric/umbilical lineNipple lineOcciput/neck regionMedial knee region
Watershed vulnerabilityMaximal (T6–T10 peak)Moderate (T4–T6 edge)MinimalLow
Common post-aortic surgeryYes (>60% cases)UncommonNeverRare
Radicular feeder densityLowestModerateHighestHigh

Clinical Pearls

• Intraoperative somatosensory and motor evoked potential monitoring targeted at T8–T12 reduces paraplegia risk by 30–50%.
• Prophylactic cerebrospinal fluid drainage (CSF pressure <10 mmHg) during thoracoabdominal repair lowers cord ischemia (Class IIa, ACC/AHA 2017).
• Postoperative hypotension is the single most modifiable risk factor; maintain MAP ≥85 mmHg for 48 hours.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming the sensory level equals dermatomal landmarks taught in trauma (e.g., T4 = nipple line) rather than the vascular watershed.
2. Mistaking central cord syndrome (cape-like loss of pain/temperature in upper limbs) for ASA infarction in aortic surgery patients.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• ESVS Guidelines 2022: Recommend intraoperative neuromonitoring of motor evoked potentials with alarms set for a 50% amplitude drop at T8–T12 (Grade C).
• ACC/AHA Aortic Disease Focused Update 2017: Class IIa recommendation for prophylactic CSF drainage in thoracoabdominal aneurysm repair to reduce paraplegia (Level of Evidence: B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The ASA runs in the ventral median fissure, supplying anterior horn cells and spinothalamic tracts. The artery of Adamkiewicz—most often at T9–T12—provides critical reinforcement; its interruption causes infarction one to two segments above, typically around T8. Collateral anastomoses are sparse at T6–T10, creating a “watershed” susceptible to hypotension and cross-clamp ischemia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Cross-clamping disrupts intercostal and lumbar radicular feeders, provoking anterior spinal cord hypoperfusion. Ischemia damages motor neurons and decussating pain/temperature fibers, while dorsal columns (supplied by the posterior spinal arteries) remain intact. Reperfusion exacerbates injury via free radical generation and blood–spinal cord barrier breakdown.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Immediate neurological exam localizing sensory level.
2. Urgent MRI spine with diffusion-weighted imaging to confirm ASA territory infarction (owl’s-eye sign).
3. Exclude compressive causes (CT angiography to rule out hematoma).
4. Monitor MAP and institute CSF drainage if not already in place.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• T2-weighted MRI: bilateral anterior horn hyperintensity (“owl’s eyes”).
• Diffusion-weighted imaging: restricted diffusion in ventral cord within 3 hours of onset.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• No proven neuroprotective drug; focus is on hemodynamic augmentation (vasopressors to maintain MAP ≥85 mmHg).
• High-dose steroids are not routinely recommended in vascular spinal cord infarction (Class III, AHA/ASA 2018).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam.
Spinal cord infarction and its characteristic sensory levels are tested annually in vascular neurology and neuroanatomy sections, often as single-best-answer questions requiring recall of watershed zones and dermatome mapping.

question_text: In a case of acute ischemic stroke presenting within the intravenous thrombolysis window with an NIHSS score of 3, what is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] - Acute ischemic stroke results from arterial occlusion causing neuronal ischemia; rapid reperfusion salvages penumbral tissue.
• The NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) quantifies stroke severity (0–42); scores <5 designate “mild” strokes but do not preclude disabling deficits.
• Intravenous alteplase (tPA) must be administered within 4.5 hours of symptom onset to maximize benefit (NINDS, ECASS III).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Intravenous tPA is the standard of care for eligible acute ischemic stroke patients within 4.5 hours, regardless of NIHSS if deficits are potentially disabling. The NINDS trial (1995) demonstrated a 30% relative improvement in functional outcome at 90 days (Class I, Level A). ECASS III extended the window to 4.5 hours with maintained efficacy (Aug 2008). AHA/ASA 2018 guidelines state: “IV alteplase is recommended for patients with mild but disabling symptoms” (Class I, LOE A). Although “minor, non-disabling” strokes may be excluded, this NIHSS 3 patient is presumed to have clinically relevant deficits warranting reperfusion.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. DAPT
• Reason incorrect: Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) benefits minor stroke/TIA not treated with thrombolysis (POINT, CHANCE trials), but it is not first‐line when tPA is indicated and within the window.
• Misconception: Equating antiplatelets with reperfusion therapy.

C. Thrombectomy
• Reason incorrect: Mechanical thrombectomy is reserved for large vessel occlusions (ICA/M1) and typically NIHSS ≥6; low NIHSS makes LVO unlikely. CT angiography must document a proximal occlusion before thrombectomy consideration.
• Misconception: All strokes are endovascular candidates.

D. Supportive care and monitoring
• Reason incorrect: Withholding reperfusion in a patient within the tPA window risks infarct expansion and poorer long‐term outcome.
• Misconception: Mild score implies benign course without intervention.

Comparison Table

InterventionIndicationTime WindowEvidence Level
IV tPAAcute ischemic stroke, disabling deficits≤4.5 hoursClass I, LOE A (AHA/ASA ’18)
DAPTMinor non‐disabling stroke/TIA without tPA≤24 hours post-eventClass I, LOE A (POINT/CHANCE)
Mechanical ThrombectomyLVO with NIHSS ≥6; salvageable penumbra≤6 hours (up to 24 h with perfusion imaging)Class I, LOE A (ESCAPE, EXTEND-IA, DAWN)
Supportive carePatients outside reperfusion criteriaN/AN/A

Clinical Pearls

- Mild NIHSS (<5) does not equal non‐disabling; assess for disabling deficits (e.g., aphasia, hemianopia, ataxia).
• Initiate tPA within door-to-needle time ≤60 minutes for optimal outcomes.
• If tPA contraindicated or beyond window, consider DAPT for minor non-disabling strokes to reduce recurrence.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying solely on NIHSS threshold to decide tPA eligibility without assessing functional impairment.
2. Assuming thrombectomy is first-line for all ischemic strokes rather than reserving it for documented large vessel occlusions.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines 2018: Recommend IV alteplase ≤4.5 h for mild but disabling deficits (Class I; Level A).
• POINT Trial (NEJM 2018): Showed DAPT reduces recurrent stroke in minor stroke/TIA but excluded tPA‐treated patients (Class I; Level A).
• ECASS III (Lancet 2008): Demonstrated benefit of tPA between 3–4.5 h, informing extended window recommendations.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. Acute stroke management, including tPA eligibility for mild deficits, is frequently tested, often presenting clinical vignettes with NIHSS scores and time windows to assess guideline‐based decision making.

question_text: A patient was not able to read his handwriting. Which artery is most likely involved in this condition?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Pure alexia (alexia without agraphia) is characterized by the inability to read, despite preserved writing ability. Core principles:
• Visual word form processing occurs in the left occipital lobe (visual cortex) and the splenium of the corpus callosum transfers visual input to language areas.
• A lesion in the dominant posterior cerebral artery (PCA) territory (left occipital cortex + splenium) disrupts this pathway, leading to pure alexia.
• Differentiation from alexia with agraphia (angular gyrus in the MCA territory) is critical: the former spares writing, the latter impairs both reading and writing.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Pure alexia was first characterized by Geschwind’s disconnection model (1965) and later refined by Damasio et al. (1982), demonstrating that PCA infarcts affecting the left occipital lobe plus the splenium produce a selective reading deficit. MRI diffusion‐weighted imaging (DWI) consistently localizes these lesions in PCA territory. The AHA/ASA 2019 guidelines for early management of acute ischemic stroke (Class I, Level B-R) recommend prompt neuroimaging—including MRI with DWI—to identify PCA infarcts, especially when visual or language complaints predominate. Pure alexia is thus best explained by interruption of the ventral visual stream (“what” pathway) in PCA territory, disconnecting intact visual cortices from Wernicke’s area.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. ACA
• ACA strokes affect medial frontal and parietal lobes, leading to lower limb weakness and abulia.
• Does not involve visual cortex or language pathways related to reading.
• Common misconception: equating any frontal infarct with language deficits.

B. MCA
• Dominant MCA infarcts produce Broca’s or Wernicke’s aphasia and may cause alexia with agraphia (angular gyrus), not pure alexia.
• Patients cannot write or read, whereas pure alexics can write but cannot read what they wrote.
• Key distinction: MCA angular infarcts impair both modalities.

C. ICA
• ICA occlusion produces large territory infarcts (ACA + MCA), causing global deficits, hemispatial neglect, and severe contralateral weakness.
• Too extensive to yield isolated reading impairment without motor or broader language signs.

Comparison Table

FeaturePCA (Pure Alexia)MCA (Angular Gyrus)ACAICA
Vascular TerritoryLeft occipital + spleniumInferior parietal lobuleMedial frontal/parietalGlobal anterior circulation
Key Lesion LocationVisual cortex + callosalAngular gyrusParacentral lobuleACA + MCA areas
Reading AbilitySeverely impairedImpairedPreservedVariable, with broader deficits
Writing AbilityPreservedImpairedPreservedOften impaired by hemiparesis
Clinical SyndromePure alexiaAlexia + agraphiaLeg paresis, abuliaGlobal aphasia, motor deficits

Clinical Pearls

- Pure alexia patients may “spell out” words letter by letter because intact tactile/visual scanning supports minimal reading.
• Clock‐drawing and confrontation naming are typically normal except for reading tasks.
• Preservation of writing with reading failure is pathognomonic for PCA splenial involvement.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking alexia with agraphia (MCA angular gyrus) for pure alexia; always test writing separately.
• Assuming all language deficits localize to MCA; always consider vascular territory and cortical vs. disconnection syndromes.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Visual input travels from bilateral occipital cortices; the right visual field projects to the left visual cortex, the left field to the right. The splenium transfers information from right occipital cortex to the dominant left hemisphere. A PCA infarct disrupting this callosal pathway blocks visual word form access to language centers.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemic occlusion of the left PCA branch leads to infarction of the primary visual cortex and adjacent splenial fibers. The disconnection prevents processed visual word forms from reaching Wernicke’s area, while Exner’s writing center and motor pathways remain intact, preserving writing.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- MRI DWI: acute hyperintensity in left occipital lobe and splenium confirms pure alexia.
• CT may miss small splenial infarcts; high‐resolution MRI is preferred.
• Perfusion imaging can demonstrate penumbral tissue in PCA territory when performed early.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. On board exams, pure alexia is frequently tested under cortical disconnection syndromes; remember the “cannot read but can write” hallmark for PCA lesions.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

[Optional Latest Guidelines and Trials]

question_text: Q93. In the management of a transient ischemic attack (TIA), what is the recommended treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is defined as transient focal neurological dysfunction without evidence of acute infarction, most often due to brief thromboembolic or atherothrombotic cerebral ischemia. Early risk of stroke recurrence is highest within 48 hours (≈10–20%). Secondary prevention targets platelet-mediated thrombosis in non-cardioembolic TIA. Key concepts include:
• Platelet activation and aggregation at sites of vascular injury (Cox-1 and P2Y₁₂ pathways)
• ABCD2 score for risk stratification (Age, Blood pressure, Clinical features, Duration, Diabetes)
• Time-sensitive initiation of antithrombotic therapy

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin plus clopidogrel, initiated within 24 hours of a high-risk TIA or minor non-cardioembolic stroke (NIHSS ≤3), for a short course (21 days) reduces 90-day stroke recurrence by ~30–35% compared to aspirin alone. The CHANCE trial (Lancet Neurol 2013) showed a hazard ratio (HR) of 0.68 (95% CI 0.57–0.81) for recurrent stroke with 21-day DAPT, without significant bleeding increase. The POINT trial (NEJM 2018) confirmed efficacy (HR 0.75; 95% CI 0.59–0.95) but noted higher major hemorrhage risk with prolonged DAPT at 90 days (HR 2.32; 95% CI 1.10–4.87). The 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines (Class I, Level A) recommend DAPT for 21–90 days in high-risk patients, then transition to monotherapy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Single antiplatelet therapy
• Aspirin monotherapy yields only ~20% relative reduction in recurrent stroke.
• Misconception: Early monotherapy suffices; fails to capitalize on synergistic inhibition of two platelet pathways.

C. Anticoagulation
• Effective in cardioembolic TIA (e.g., atrial fibrillation) but not in non-cardioembolic cases.
• Misconception: “TIA always requires anticoagulation”; inappropriate in atherosclerotic or lacunar mechanisms, with higher hemorrhage risk.

D. No treatment
• Untreated TIA carries 10%–20% stroke recurrence at 90 days.
• Misconception: TIAs are benign; ignores critical period for secondary prevention.

Comparison Table

FeatureSingle AntiplateletDual AntiplateletAnticoagulationNo Treatment
MechanismCox-1 inhibitionCox-1 + P2Y₁₂ receptor blockadeThrombin or factor Xa inhibitionNone
InitiationWithin 24 hWithin 24 h; limited to 21 daysIf cardioembolic source identifiedN/A
90-Day Stroke Reduction~20% vs placebo~30–35% vs aspirinNot shown in non-cardioembolic0%
Major Bleeding RiskLowModerate (short-term)HighNone

Clinical Pearls

- Initiate DAPT within 24 hours for high-risk TIA (ABCD2 ≥4); discontinue at 21 days to minimize bleeding.
• Use ABCD2 score to guide urgency and intensity of therapy.
• After DAPT course, continue long-term monotherapy (aspirin or clopidogrel).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Extending DAPT beyond 30 days increases hemorrhagic complications without further ischemic benefit.
2. Prescribing anticoagulation for all TIAs overlooks etiological classification, leading to unnecessary bleeding risk.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guideline for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Stroke 2018): Class I, Level A recommendation for DAPT (aspirin + clopidogrel) for 21–90 days in high-risk TIA/minor stroke.
• POINT trial (NEJM 2018): Demonstrated DAPT reduced composite ischemic events at 90 days (5.0% vs 6.5%; HR 0.75) but increased major hemorrhage (0.9% vs 0.4%; HR 2.32).
• CHANCE trial (Lancet Neurol 2013): In Chinese population, 21-day DAPT decreased 90-day stroke recurrence (8.2% vs 11.7%; HR 0.68) without significant bleeding rise.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Early dual antiplatelet therapy for high-risk TIA is a high-yield topic on stroke prevention questions, often tested in multiple-choice format focusing on timing, duration, and patient selection.

question_text: Q76. (Source: Part 2 2020 copymcqs.txt) What is the site of the lesion in Weber syndrome?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Weber syndrome is a classic crossed brainstem syndrome resulting from a focal infarct of the paramedian perforators of the posterior cerebral artery at the ventral (base) aspect of the midbrain. Core concepts:
• Ventral midbrain (“basis pedunculi”) contains corticospinal fibers (crus cerebri) and oculomotor nerve fascicles.
• Lesion here produces ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy (ptosis, “down and out” eye, mydriasis) plus contralateral hemiparesis.
• Differentiation from other midbrain syndromes (Claude, Benedikt) depends on involvement of tegmentum versus basis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The defining pathology in Weber syndrome is an infarct of the ventral midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus. Anatomical studies (Ropper & Samuels, Adams and Victor’s Principles of Neurology) confirm that corticospinal and corticobulbar fibers traverse the basis pedunculi immediately adjacent to oculomotor nerve fascicles. MRI diffusion‐weighted imaging in Kim et al. (J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry. 2005;76(3):e6) demonstrates acute lesions precisely in this location. Clinical series (Kim JS, 2006) show >90% of patients present with ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral spastic weakness, correlating with ventral midbrain injury. No other brainstem site produces this unique combination.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Tegmentum
– Incorrect because the tegmentum is the dorsal midbrain region; lesions here (Claude syndrome) produce ataxia (red nucleus) and oculomotor palsy without prominent corticospinal weakness.
– Misconception: confusing any midbrain infarct with Weber. Tegmental lesions spare the crus cerebri.

C. Tectum
– The tectum (roof of midbrain) contains superior/inferior colliculi; lesions cause vertical gaze palsies (Parinaud syndrome), not ipsilateral third‐nerve palsy plus hemiparesis.
– Misconception: equating “midbrain” with any roof structure.

D. Pons
– A pontine lesion (e.g., Millard–Gubler) involves facial nerve or abducens nuclei and corticospinal fibers but spares oculomotor nerve; contralateral hemiparesis would be with ipsilateral facial paralysis or abduction deficit.
– Misconception: any brainstem basis infarct gives oculomotor signs—pontine basis is anatomically separate.

Comparison Table

FeatureBase of Midbrain (Weber)Tegmentum (Claude)Tectum (Parinaud)Pons (Millard–Gubler)
Lesion locationVentral midbrain (basis)Dorsal midbrain (tegmentum)Dorsal roof (colliculi)Ventral pons (basis)
Cranial nerve involvementIII nerve fasciclesIII nerve fasciclesVertical gaze (III nucleus)VI or VII nucleus
Motor pathway involvementCorticospinal fibers → hemiparesisSparing of corticospinal → no major weaknessNo corticospinal involvementCorticospinal fibers → hemiparesis
Key clinical signIpsilateral oculomotor palsy + contralateral spastic weaknessOculomotor palsy + ataxiaSupranuclear vertical gaze palsyFacial/abduction palsy + hemiparesis

Clinical Pearls

- Always correlate oculomotor deficits with ipsilateral motor weakness to localize to the ventral midbrain.
• Differentiate Weber (basis) from Benedikt (tegmental red nucleus involvement → tremor, ataxia) and Claude (tegmental → ataxia without significant hemiparesis).
• MRI with DWI is the gold standard to visualize small paramedian midbrain infarcts.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing ventral versus dorsal midbrain: thinking any midbrain stroke is Weber.
2. Mislabeling Benedikt (tremor, involuntary movements) as Weber due to similar oculomotor findings.
3. Attributing an oculomotor palsy plus hemiparesis to a pontine lesion rather than midbrain.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Basis pedunculi: houses descending corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts; compressed in Weber infarcts.
• Oculomotor nerve fascicles exit ventrally between posterior cerebral and superior cerebellar arteries; infarct here causes third‐nerve palsy.
• Vascular supply: paramedian branches of the PCA and basilar tip perfuse this region.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam.
Brainstem stroke syndromes are frequently tested as single‐best‐answer questions. Expect variations on Weber vs. Benedikt vs. Claude in vascular neuroanatomy blocks.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

[Optional Latest Guidelines and Trials]

question_text: A patient with an Acom aneurysm, what is the most important risk factor for rupture?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] - Saccular intracranial aneurysms form at arterial bifurcations in the Circle of Willis, particularly the anterior communicating artery (Acom), where high-flow hemodynamic stress weakens the vessel wall.
• Rupture risk is multifactorial: patient demographics (age, hypertension), environmental factors (smoking), genetic predisposition, and aneurysm-specific features (size, location, morphology).
• Management decisions hinge on accurately stratifying rupture risk; small aneurysms (<7 mm) in anterior circulation have low annual rupture rates, whereas larger ones pose substantially higher risk.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Aneurysm size is the single most powerful predictor of rupture. The International Study of Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms (ISUIA, 2003) demonstrated annual rupture rates of 0.05% for anterior circulation aneurysms <7 mm versus 1.3% for those ≥7 mm. The PHASES score (Greving et al., Lancet Neurol 2014) identified aneurysm diameter as the dominant predictor, with hazard ratios escalating from 1 for ≤5 mm to 6.3 for >10 mm. The 2015 AHA/ASA guidelines (updated 2021) recommend considering treatment for anterior circulation aneurysms ≥7 mm (Class I, Level of Evidence B). Larger aneurysms endure greater wall tension per the Law of Laplace, directly accelerating medial layer degeneration and rupture.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Smoking
• While smoking increases rupture risk (~1.6-fold; PHASES), its impact is modest compared to size.
• Misconception: inflammation from smoking overrides mechanical factors.
• Differentiation: size amplifies wall tension exponentially, whereas smoking’s effect is incremental.

C. Hypertension
• Hypertension confers a moderate risk increase (HR ~1.7) by elevating transmural pressure, but size exerts a greater effect.
• Misconception: systemic pressure alone dictates rupture, neglecting aneurysm geometry.
• Differentiation: diameter directly magnifies wall stress beyond hemodynamic load.

D. Family history of aneurysms
• Family history slightly increases formation risk; its association with rupture is weak (HR ~1.2).
• Misconception: genetic predisposition equals high immediate rupture potential.
• Differentiation: genetics influence aneurysm development, but rupture hinges on mechanical wall forces.

Comparison Table

Risk FactorRelative Risk (HR)Mechanism of Rupture
Size (>7 mm)6.3 (vs ≤5 mm baseline)Increased wall tension (Law of Laplace), shear stress
Smoking1.6Vessel wall inflammation, oxidative damage
Hypertension1.7Elevated transmural pressure, medial degeneration
Family history1.2Genetic vessel wall susceptibility

Clinical Pearls

- Anterior communicating artery aneurysms are inherently higher-risk due to complex flow patterns at the Acom–ACA junction.
• Use the PHASES score to quantify 5-year rupture risk; aneurysm size contributes the most points.
• Monitor small aneurysms (<7 mm) with serial imaging, as growth often precedes rupture.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Overprioritizing blood pressure control while underestimating aneurysm growth; both are important but size changes mandate intervention.
• Assuming all small (<5 mm) aneurysms are benign; rare but clinically significant ruptures can occur, especially with adverse morphology.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guidelines on Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms (2015; updated 2021): Treatment is recommended for anterior circulation aneurysms ≥7 mm in patients with reasonable life expectancy (Class I, LOE B).
2. PHASES Score Study (Greving et al., Lancet Neurol 2014; validation 2018): Established a 5-year rupture risk model highlighting aneurysm diameter as the predominant factor (Level II evidence).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Rupture risk stratification—especially the primacy of aneurysm size—is frequently tested in neurology and neurosurgery board examinations, often via clinical vignettes requiring application of ISUIA or PHASES data.

question_text: In a case of livedo reticularis and strokes in the MCA territory, what is the diagnosis to rule out a cardioembolic cause?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] - Livedo reticularis reflects a mottled, net‐like skin discoloration due to dermal microvascular impairment.
• Sneddon syndrome is a noninflammatory thrombotic arteriopathy of medium‐sized vessels, classically combining livedo racemosa (a more irregular form of livedo reticularis) with recurrent ischemic strokes, often in the MCA distribution.
• Distinguish from hypercoagulable states (e.g., antiphospholipid antibody syndrome) by absence of pathogenic antibodies and from large‐vessel vasculitides (Takayasu) or progressive intracranial arteriopathies (Moyamoya) by differing vessel involvement and imaging.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Sneddon syndrome is confirmed by the clinical triad of livedo racemosa, recurrent ischemic strokes, and exclusion of aPL antibodies. Pathologically, it features noninflammatory intimal proliferation and luminal thrombosis in dermal and cerebral arterioles. A French multicenter series (Francès et al., 2004) reported a mean age of presentation of 35 years, female predominance (M:F ≈1:4), and livedo preceding cerebral events by ~2 years. The 2018 EULAR guidelines on management of antiphospholipid syndrome emphasize that patients with livedo and ischemic stroke should be tested for aPL; a negative panel prompts consideration of Sneddon syndrome (level of evidence 2B). Antiplatelet therapy is recommended empirically, though no randomized trials exist; retrospective data suggest reduced stroke recurrence with low‐dose aspirin or warfarin.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
• Why incorrect: Requires persistently positive lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, or anti-β2‐glycoprotein I. In Sneddon syndrome, these are absent.
• Misconception: Any stroke with livedo must be APS – whereas livedo can be non‐immune in Sneddon.
• Differentiator: APS shows hypercoagulability on laboratory testing; Sneddon does not.

C. Moyamoya disease
• Why incorrect: Characterized by progressive stenosis/occlusion of distal internal carotid arteries with basal collateral “puff of smoke” on angiography; no cutaneous findings.
• Misconception: All young‐onset strokes imply Moyamoya – cutaneous signs are absent.
• Differentiator: Moyamoya shows characteristic angiographic collateral network; Sneddon shows medium‐vessel arteriopathy without collaterals.

D. Takayasu arteritis
• Why incorrect: A granulomatous large‐vessel vasculitis affecting the aorta and main branches, presenting with pulse deficits, bruits, and systemic inflammation; no livedo reticularis.
• Misconception: Any vascular skin change implies vasculitis – Takayasu does not affect dermal vessels.
• Differentiator: Elevated ESR/CRP, imaging of the aorta, not medium dermal vessels.

Comparison Table

FeatureSneddon syndromeAntiphospholipid syndromeMoyamoya diseaseTakayasu arteritis
Vessel sizeMedium (dermal, cerebral arterioles)Small/medium (venules, arterioles)Distal ICA and proximal MCALarge (aorta and major branches)
Skin findingsLivedo racemosa (irregular livedo reticularis)Livedo reticularisNoneNone
LaboratoryNegative aPL antibodiesPositive lupus anticoagulant, aCL, anti-β2GPINegative for aPLElevated ESR/CRP
NeuroimagingOcclusive arteriopathy without collateralsNormal vessels or infarcts“Puff of smoke” basal collateralsAortic/branch stenoses, wall thickening
HistopathologyIntimal proliferation, thrombosisFibrin thrombi, no vasculitisFibrocellular intimal thickeningGranulomatous inflammation

Clinical Pearls

1. Livedo racemosa (broken, irregular pattern) is more specific for Sneddon than the regular net-like livedo reticularis seen in APS.
2. In young stroke patients with skin findings but negative hypercoagulable workup, Sneddon syndrome should be considered; skin biopsy can confirm noninflammatory arteriopathy.
3. Empiric antiplatelet therapy (aspirin 75–100 mg/day) is standard; anecdotal benefit with warfarin exists, but no RCTs have been conducted.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming any livedo plus stroke equals APS without ordering aPL antibody panel.
• Overlooking skin examination in stroke workup; failure to recognize livedo racemosa delays Sneddon diagnosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- EULAR Recommendations for APS Management (2018): advise testing for aPL in unexplained strokes; negative results prompt alternative diagnoses such as Sneddon syndrome (Level 2B).
• European Federation of Neurological Societies (EFNS) Guidelines on Non‐Atherosclerotic Vasculopathies (2020): recommend skin biopsy in suspected Sneddon for histopathologic confirmation (Level C evidence).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. On neurology boards, Sneddon syndrome is tested under noninflammatory arteriopathies; key clues include livedo racemosa and recurrent MCA‐territory strokes in young adults.

question_text: In a scenario regarding cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT), what will confirm the diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) involves occlusion of dural venous sinuses or cortical veins, leading to impaired venous outflow, raised intracranial pressure, venous infarction, and hemorrhage. Key concepts:
• Venous anatomy: superior sagittal, transverse, sigmoid sinuses; cortical veins.
• Presentation: headache (often subacute), focal deficits, seizures, papilledema.
• Diagnostic goal: visualize thrombus within venous channels to guide anticoagulation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CTV (CT venography) directly opacifies the dural sinuses, allowing high-resolution visualization of filling defects.
• Sensitivity 95%, specificity 91% for CVT (Saposnik et al., Stroke 2011).
• AHA/ASA 2011 guidelines recommend CTV or MRV as first-line (Class I, Level B).
