• European Stroke Organization 2017 concurs that CTV and MRV are equivalent alternatives.
Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) remains gold standard historically but is now reserved for inconclusive cases due to invasiveness.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRI
• Refers to parenchymal MRI without venography sequences; may show indirect signs (edema, hemorrhage) but cannot reliably detect sinus thrombus.
• Misconception: “Any MRI” equals MRV. Only dedicated MR venography (MRV) sequences confirm CVT.

C. CT scan
• Non-contrast CT sensitivity ~25–50%. Hyperdense sinus (“cord sign”) is transient and often missed.
• Misconception: CT head alone is sufficient; contrast venography is required.

D. Lumbar puncture
• May show elevated opening pressure or xanthochromia but is nonspecific and can be dangerous if intracranial hypertension is present.
• Misconception: LP “rules in” intracranial processes; it cannot localize or confirm sinus thrombosis.

Comparison Table

FeatureCTV (Correct)MRI (No Venography)CT Head Non-contrastLumbar Puncture
Sensitivity~95%N/A for thrombus detection~25–50%N/A
Specificity~91%N/ALowNonspecific
Key FindingFilling defect in sinusVenous infarct, edemaHyperdense sinus (rare)Elevated opening pressure
InvasivenessNoninvasive, contrast requiredNoninvasiveNoninvasiveInvasive
Role in CVTDefinitive diagnostic testAdjunct; requires MRVInitial screen onlyContraindicated if ICP↑

Clinical Pearls

- The “empty delta sign” on contrast-enhanced CT occurs in superior sagittal sinus thrombosis ~25% of cases.
• Always follow non-contrast CT with CTV if CVT is suspected clinically.
• Anticoagulation is initiated upon radiographic confirmation, even if hemorrhagic infarcts are present.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Interpreting a normal non-contrast CT as excluding CVT—CT without venography misses >50% of cases.
2. Ordering MRI without specifying MR venography sequences; radiology requisitions must include MRV protocol.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2011 “Diagnosis and Management of Cerebral Venous Thrombosis”: recommends CTV or MRV as first-line vascular imaging (Class I, Level B).
• European Stroke Organization 2017 Update: endorses CTV or MRV equivalently; reserves DSA for equivocal cases (Level A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Thrombosis often occurs in the superior sagittal sinus (most common), followed by transverse and sigmoid sinuses. Cortical vein involvement may lead to localized hemorrhagic infarction.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thrombus formation in dural sinuses raises venous pressure → reduced CSF absorption at arachnoid granulations → intracranial hypertension → venous infarction and hemorrhage due to capillary rupture.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: headache + focal signs/seizures.
2. Non-contrast CT head to rule out hemorrhage.
3. If CT is non-diagnostic but suspicion remains, perform CTV (or MRV).
4. If CTV/MRV equivocal, proceed to DSA.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Cord sign: hyperdense cortical vein on non-contrast CT indicates acute thrombus (transient, may be missed).
• Empty delta sign: contrast filling defect surrounded by contrast enhancement in superior sagittal sinus on CTV.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. CVT imaging modalities frequently appear as direct single-best-answer questions or as scenarios testing “empty delta” and “cord” signs, emphasizing the need to choose CTV/MRV over plain CT or routine MRI.

question_text: An 82-year-old patient, medically free, presents with acute right-sided weakness and global aphasia for 3 hours. His blood pressure is 180/100 mmHg, and his CT scan shows no hemorrhage with good ASPECTS. What is your next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Ischemic stroke from an acute arterial occlusion produces an irreversibly infarcted core and surrounding penumbra at risk. Global aphasia and right hemiparesis localize to left MCA territory. The Alberta Stroke Program Early CT Score (ASPECTS) quantifies early ischemic change; a score ≥6 denotes a small core and large salvageable penumbra, favoring reperfusion. Intravenous alteplase (tPA) is recommended within 4.5 hours of onset if blood pressure is <185/110 mm Hg; door-to-needle time should be ≤60 minutes to maximize neuronal salvage.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option B is correct because multiple randomized controlled trials and guidelines support IV alteplase for acute ischemic stroke within 3–4.5 hours. In the NINDS trial (1995), tPA given within 3 hours improved functional outcomes at 3 months (NINDS Investigators, 1995; Class I, Level A). ECASS III extended this window to 4.5 hours with continued benefit (Hacke et al., 2008; Class I, Level B-R). The 2019 AHA/ASA guidelines reiterate that eligible patients ≤4.5 hours from onset with no hemorrhage and ASPECTS ≥6 should receive alteplase (Powers et al., 2019). His BP of 180/100 mm Hg meets the safety threshold (<185/110), so immediate tPA without delay increases the probability of recanalization and reduces morbidity.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Reduce BP
• This patient’s BP (180/100) is below the 185/110 mm Hg cutoff required before tPA; aggressive lowering would delay reperfusion.
• Misconception: “Any elevated BP must be normalized.”
• Differentiator: Only BP >185/110 necessitates pre-tPA antihypertensives.

C. CTA
• CTA identifies large-vessel occlusion for endovascular therapy but should not precede or delay IV tPA in an eligible patient.
• Misconception: “Vascular imaging is mandatory before thrombolysis.”
• Differentiator: Noncontrast CT is sufficient to rule out hemorrhage before tPA; CTA can follow.

D. Admit for supportive care and monitor
• Omitting reperfusion forfeits the narrow therapeutic window, leading to larger infarct and worse outcome.
• Misconception: “Elderly patients benefit less from tPA.”
• Differentiator: Age alone is not a contraindication; benefits extend to patients >80 within 3 hours.

Comparison Table

FeatureIV ThrombolysisBP Reduction (Pre-tPA)CTA FirstSupportive Care Only
IndicationAcute ischemic stroke ≤4.5 hBP >185/110 mm Hg pre-tPALarge-vessel occlusion detectionNo reperfusion
Time SensitivityDoor-to-needle ≤60 minDelays tPA if unnecessaryAdds 10–20 min before tPANo time-critical intervention
Outcome Benefit↓ Disability, ↓ mortalityFacilitates safe tPA when neededGuides endovascular therapyNo proven functional improvement
Guideline Recommendation (2019)Class I, Level A–BClass I, Level B-NRClass IIa, Level B-R (post-tPA)Not recommended for eligible pts

Clinical Pearls

1. ASPECTS ≥6 on noncontrast CT predicts favorable response to reperfusion; score <6 suggests large core and higher hemorrhage risk.
2. Maintain systolic BP 140–160 mm Hg during and after tPA; avoid precipitous drops that reduce penumbral perfusion.
3. Door-to-needle times >60 min correlate with increased infarct volume and worse functional outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overly aggressive BP lowering when systolic BP is between 180–185 mm Hg delays tPA without added safety benefit.
2. Routinely performing advanced vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) before tPA in the 0–3 h window prolongs door-to-needle time.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) Guidelines 2019
– Recommendation: IV alteplase ≤3 h (Class I, Level A); selected patients 3–4.5 h (Class I, Level B-R). BP must be <185/110 mm Hg (Class I, Level B-NR).
2. European Stroke Organization (ESO) Guidelines 2021
– Recommendation: IV alteplase within 4.5 h of onset in patients with ASPECTS ≥6 (Level A). Rapid treatment prioritized over additional imaging.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Left middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarction disrupts descending corticospinal fibers (motor weakness right side) and perisylvian language networks (Broca’s, Wernicke’s areas → global aphasia).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Arterial occlusion triggers the ischemic cascade: energy failure, excitotoxicity, and apoptosis. Early reperfusion rescues the penumbra, limiting conversion to infarct core.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Noncontrast CT is first-line to exclude hemorrhage—ASPECTS quantifies early ischemic change. CTA follows after tPA to identify candidates for endovascular therapy.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Alteplase dosing: 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg), with 10% as bolus over 1 minute and remainder over 60 minutes. Monitor for intracranial hemorrhage for 24 hours.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. Acute stroke algorithms emphasizing time windows for IV thrombolysis and BP management are a high-yield topic, frequently tested as single-best-answer scenarios with imaging and vitals.

question_text: Which factors increase the risk for aneurysm rupture?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Intracranial aneurysm rupture risk hinges on the interplay of aneurysm wall biology and hemodynamic forces. Key concepts:
• Wall shear stress at bifurcation points (e.g., anterior communicating artery) drives endothelial dysfunction and structural weakening.
• Aneurysm size correlates with tension on the wall (Laplace’s law: wall tension ∝ radius × pressure). Larger aneurysms bear greater stress and are more prone to rupture.
• Location in the posterior circulation (basilar tip, posterior communicating artery) experiences distinct flow dynamics and thinner adventitia, elevating rupture rates.
Understanding these principles sets the stage for clinical risk stratification and management decisions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Size and location remain the strongest predictors of rupture. The PHASES score (Greving et al., Lancet Neurol 2014) allocates points for aneurysm size (>7 mm yields 3–10 points depending on diameter) and site (posterior circulation or anterior communicating add 2 points). In the International Study of Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms (ISUIA, 2003), 5-year rupture rates were <0.1% for anterior circulation aneurysms <7 mm versus ~2.5% for those ≥10 mm. Posterior circulation aneurysms <7 mm still carried ~0.7% annual rupture risk. These data underpin guideline thresholds for prophylactic treatment (AHA/ASA 2015). Neither family history nor prior stroke figures prominently in validated rupture-risk models; age contributes modestly in PHASES (1 point for ≥60 years) but is overshadowed by size and site.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Age of the patient
– Though PHASES assigns 1 point for age ≥60, its impact is minor compared to size/location. Overemphasis on age may misguide intervention decisions.
C. Family history of aneurysms
– Increases risk of aneurysm formation but not independently linked to higher rupture probability once an aneurysm exists.
D. Previous history of stroke
– Reflects cerebrovascular disease but does not correlate with wall stress or hemodynamic factors driving aneurysm rupture.

Comparison Table

FeatureSize & Location (A)Age ≥60 (B)Family History (C)Prior Stroke (D)
PHASES score weight3–10 points (size); 2 points (site)1 point0 points0 points
Annual rupture risk impactHigh (>2.5% for large/posterior)Modest (~0.5% increase)None provenNone proven
Guideline treatment trigger≥7 mm anterior or any posteriorNot a standalone triggerNot consideredNot considered

Clinical Pearls

- Aneurysms ≥7 mm in the anterior communicating artery or any size in the basilar tip warrant neurosurgical or endovascular evaluation.
• Morphological irregularities (daughter sacs, lobulations) further elevate rupture risk beyond size alone.
• Optimal blood pressure control (systolic <140 mmHg) reduces wall stress and should be aggressively managed.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating family history with rupture risk rather than formation risk.
2. Overestimating age effect and recommending treatment in elderly for small aneurysms.
3. Mistaking prior ischemic stroke for a risk factor for aneurysm rupture.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2015 (Thompson et al., Stroke): Recommends observation for anterior circulation aneurysms <7 mm in patients without other risk factors; consider treatment for posterior aneurysms of any size. (Class IIa, Level B)
• Greving et al. 2014 (Lancet Neurol): Developed PHASES score prospectively validating size and location as major rupture determinants.
• UCAS Japan 2013 (Iwata et al.): Reported posterior communicating and posterior circulation aneurysms have 3–5× higher rupture rates than anterior circulation.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Aneurysm sites at arterial bifurcations (anterior communicating, posterior communicating, basilar tip) bear complex flow patterns, promoting focal endothelial injury and matrix metalloproteinase–mediated wall degradation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic hypertension and turbulent flow increase wall shear stress, triggering inflammatory cascades (macrophage infiltration, cytokine release) that weaken the tunica media and internal elastic lamina, predisposing to rupture.

Neuroimaging Pearls

On CTA/MRA, assess dome-to-neck ratio (>1.6 suggests higher rupture risk) and look for blebs or irregular sac contours. Digital subtraction angiography remains gold standard for morphology.

Board Examination Focus

This topic is frequently tested as single-best-answer questions on rupture risk stratification. This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Board exams emphasize the PHASES score and guideline size/location thresholds.

question_text: A man has right-sided weakness and dysphasia. On stroke workup, he was found to have severe stenosis of the left middle cerebral artery (MCA). What is the most appropriate management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] 1. Neurovascular anatomy: The middle cerebral artery supplies the lateral frontal lobe (motor cortex) and inferior frontal gyrus (Broca’s area), correlating with contralateral weakness and expressive dysphasia.
2. Intracranial atherosclerosis: Plaque formation within cerebral arteries causes luminal narrowing, hemodynamic insufficiency, and artery‐to‐artery embolism.
3. Secondary stroke prevention: For symptomatic intracranial stenosis ≥70%, intensive medical therapy—dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel), high‐intensity statin, and vascular risk factor control—supersedes interventional approaches.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Aspirin plus clopidogrel for 90 days combined with aggressive risk factor management has demonstrated superior outcomes compared to stenting in symptomatic intracranial stenosis. The SAMMPRIS trial (Derdeyn et al., 2014; NEJM) randomized patients with 70–99% intracranial stenosis to percutaneous transluminal angioplasty and stenting versus medical therapy; 30‐day stroke or death was 14.7% in the stenting arm versus 5.8% with medical therapy (p=0.002). The 2021 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines (Powers et al., Stroke 2021) give Class I, Level A recommendation for dual antiplatelet therapy for 90 days in symptomatic intracranial stenosis and advise against routine stenting (Class III). Endarterectomy applies to extracranial carotid disease, and IV tPA is for acute reperfusion within 4.5 hours.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Endarterectomy
• Incorrect: Indicated for extracranial carotid stenosis (>70%), not intracranial MCA lesions.
• Misconception: Equating all large‐vessel disease with carotid endarterectomy.
• Differentiator: Intracranial location precludes surgical endarterectomy.

B. Stenting
• Incorrect: Higher periprocedural stroke/death risk (14.7% at 30 days in SAMMPRIS).
• Misconception: Endovascular stenting for all symptomatic stenoses confers benefit.
• Differentiator: Clinical trials show medical therapy superiority for intracranial lesions.

D. Intravenous thrombolysis
• Incorrect: Used for acute ischemic stroke within 4.5 hours of onset, not for chronic secondary prevention of stenosis.
• Misconception: Any stroke management question implies tPA.
• Differentiator: Thrombolysis addresses acute occlusion, not stable high‐grade stenosis.

Comparison Table

FeatureAspirin + PlavixStentingEndarterectomyIV Thrombolysis
IndicationSymptomatic intracranial stenosisSymptomatic intracranial stenosis (research)Extracranial carotid stenosisAcute ischemic stroke (<4.5 h window)
Primary Benefit↓ Stroke recurrenceTheoretical luminal widening↓ Stroke recurrence↓ Disability if given early
Key RiskBleeding (low‐moderate)Periprocedural stroke/death (14.7%)Cranial nerve injury, MIHemorrhagic transformation
Guideline RecommendationClass I, LOE AClass III (no benefit; harmful)Class I for carotid, not intracranialClass I acute management

Clinical Pearls

- Initiate dual antiplatelet therapy for 90 days post–symptomatic intracranial stenosis, then continue monotherapy.
• Aggressive control of hypertension, LDL <70 mg/dL, diabetes, and smoking cessation synergizes with antiplatelet therapy.
• Reserve intracranial stenting for clinical trial settings or refractory cases after optimized medical therapy fails.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing extracranial carotid endarterectomy with intracranial stenosis interventions.
2. Assuming stenting provides superior patency without recognizing high periprocedural stroke risk documented in SAMMPRIS and VISSIT.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. 2021 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines:
• Recommendation: Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) for 90 days in symptomatic intracranial stenosis ≥70% (Class I, Level A).
• Recommendation: Intracranial stenting not recommended outside trials (Class III).
2. SAMMPRIS Trial (2014, Derdeyn et al., NEJM):
• Finding: 30‐day stroke/death rate 14.7% with stenting vs 5.8% with medical therapy (p=0.002).
• Implication: Aggressive medical management is superior.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Severe left MCA stenosis compromises flow to the right face/arm motor cortex and Broca’s area in the inferior frontal gyrus, producing contralateral weakness and expressive aphasia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Intracranial atherosclerotic plaques develop subintimal lipid cores and fibrous caps, causing lumen narrowing, reduced perfusion, and endothelial dysfunction leading to platelet aggregation and artery‐to‐artery emboli.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
2. MRI/MRA or CT angiography to quantify stenosis.
3. Digital subtraction angiography if noninvasive imaging is inconclusive or endovascular intervention is considered.
4. Cardiac workup (echocardiogram, ECG monitoring) to rule out cardioembolism.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CT angiography offers rapid evaluation of intracranial stenosis with >90% sensitivity.
• Digital subtraction angiography remains the gold standard for precise stenosis measurement (70–99%).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Aspirin: Irreversible COX-1 inhibitor; dose 81–325 mg/day.
• Clopidogrel: P2Y₁₂ receptor blocker; loading dose 300 mg then 75 mg/day.
• Duration: Dual therapy for 90 days, then aspirin monotherapy lifelong.
• Adjunctive: High‐intensity statin (e.g., atorvastatin 40–80 mg).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Intracranial atherosclerotic disease management is frequently tested in stroke prevention sections, often contrasting medical versus endovascular therapies in high‐grade stenosis.

question_text: Post aortic surgery, a patient is awake with flaccid paraparesis and a sensory level at which of the following?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] This Neuroimaging question tests knowledge of key concepts relevant to board examinations. The clinical context involves understanding the principles related to the question topic.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is A. T4. This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

Incorrect Options Analysis

The incorrect options represent common misconceptions in this clinical scenario. Each distractor is plausible but incorrect for specific reasons that test the examiner's ability to distinguish between similar concepts.

Board Examination Focus

This topic is important for board examinations and frequently tested. This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam.

Comparison Table

[Optional Comparison Table]

Clinical Pearls

[Optional Clinical Pearls]

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

[Optional Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions]

Latest Guidelines and Trials

[Optional Latest Guidelines and Trials]

question_text: Q104. A stroke patient with an NIHSS score of 3 is being evaluated. What is the recommended treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] - NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) quantifies acute ischemic stroke severity; scores ≤5 denote a “minor” stroke.
• Early management of minor ischemic stroke balances prevention of recurrence against hemorrhagic risk of therapies.
• Antiplatelet agents reduce recurrent non-cardioembolic ischemic events; anticoagulants are reserved for cardioembolic sources (e.g., atrial fibrillation).
• Intravenous thrombolysis (alteplase) is indicated for disabling deficits within therapeutic windows but carries intracranial hemorrhage risk.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Aspirin is the cornerstone of initial therapy in acute minor ischemic stroke without atrial fibrillation. The 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of AIS (Class I, Level A) recommend 160–325 mg aspirin daily within 24–48 hours of onset. Randomized trials (e.g., CAST, IST) demonstrated a 20–30% reduction in early recurrent stroke with aspirin initiated promptly. In NIHSS ≤5 with non-disabling deficits, the hemorrhagic risk of thrombolysis outweighs benefit; anticoagulation is not indicated absent cardioembolic source.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Warfarin
– Incorrect: Vitamin K antagonists are for cardioembolic stroke prevention (e.g., AF), not initial treatment of non-cardioembolic minor stroke.
– Misconception: Confusing secondary prophylaxis in atrial fibrillation with acute management.

C. Factor X inhibitor
– Incorrect: Direct oral anticoagulants (e.g., apixaban) are indicated for AF-related strokes, not for immediate treatment of minor ischemic stroke of presumed atherothrombotic origin.
– Misconception: Assuming all ischemic strokes require anticoagulation.

D. Thrombolysis
– Incorrect: Alteplase is reserved for disabling deficits (even if NIHSS low) within 4.5 hours; non-disabling NIHSS 3 carries low absolute benefit and higher hemorrhage risk.
– Misconception: Belief that any stroke score ≤4 should automatically receive thrombolysis.

Comparison Table

FeatureAspirinWarfarinFactor Xa InhibitorThrombolysis (Alteplase)
MechanismCOX-1 inhibitionVit K epoxide reductase inhibitorDirect Factor Xa inhibitionPlasminogen → plasmin activation
Indication in minor non-disabling AISFirst-line (I, A)Not indicatedNot indicatedReserved for disabling deficits
Onset to initiationWithin 24–48 hAfter cardioembolic work-upAfter cardioembolic work-upWithin 4.5 h of symptom onset
Major trial evidenceCAST, ISTWARSS (secondary prevention)ARISTOTLE (AF stroke prevention)NINDS, ECASS

Clinical Pearls

- Always assess “disabling” nature of deficits; mild sensory symptoms rarely benefit from alteplase.
• Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) for 21 days may further reduce recurrence in NIHSS ≤3 (CHANCE/POINT trials) but not a substitute for monotherapy when bleeding risk high.
• Early mobilization and risk factor optimization (blood pressure control, statins) complement antiplatelet therapy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Administering tPA for any NIHSS ≤4 without evaluating disability; low NIHSS may still mask disabling symptoms (e.g., isolated aphasia).
2. Starting anticoagulation without confirming cardioembolic source—risking hemorrhagic transformation in large-vessel atherothrombotic strokes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2019 Early Management of AIS Guidelines: Recommend aspirin 160–325 mg within 24–48 h of non-cardioembolic minor stroke (Class I, Level A).
• CHANCE Trial (Clopidogrel in High-Risk Patients with Acute Nondisabling Cerebrovascular Events), 2013: Short-term dual antiplatelet therapy reduces 90-day recurrence in NIHSS ≤3 (Level I).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam.
Minor stroke management questions frequently test NIHSS interpretation, decision thresholds for thrombolysis, and antithrombotic selection. Typically presented as vignettes emphasizing NIHSS ≤5, absence of atrial fibrillation, and timing relative to symptom onset.

question_text: What is a common cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) finding in reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS)?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS) is characterized by transient multifocal narrowing of cerebral arteries, often presenting with thunderclap headache. Key concepts:
1. CSF analysis in vasospastic disorders (RCVS vs primary angiitis of the CNS) helps differentiate inflammatory vs non-inflammatory etiologies.
2. RCVS typically demonstrates no significant inflammation—normal cell count, protein, and glucose.
3. Understanding CSF glucose: it parallels blood glucose and is preserved unless there is metabolic consumption by organisms or malignant cells.
(Word count: 85)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The hallmark of RCVS is noninflammatory vasospasm; CSF is normal or shows only mild, nonspecific protein elevation (<60 mg/dL) without pleocytosis or hypoglycorrhachia. Ducros et al. (2012) reviewed 67 patients: 92% had normal CSF cell counts and glucose; 15% had mild protein elevation. The 2012 AHA Scientific Statement on RCVS (Class IIa, Level B) emphasizes that normal CSF helps exclude primary CNS angiitis, which usually shows pleocytosis and elevated protein. No current guideline lists hypoglycorrhachia or oligoclonal bands as features of RCVS. Thus, “normal glucose” is the only consistent CSF finding.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. High protein
• Incorrect: CSF protein in RCVS is usually normal or mildly elevated (<60 mg/dL).
• Misconception: Equating any headache syndrome with significant BBB disruption.
• Differentiator: Primary angiitis has protein often >100 mg/dL.

B. Oligoclonal bands
• Incorrect: Reflect intrathecal IgG synthesis (e.g., multiple sclerosis).
• Misconception: Ignoring that RCVS is noninflammatory.
• Differentiator: OCBs are absent in RCVS.

D. Elevated white blood cell count
• Incorrect: Pleocytosis is not a feature; cell count usually ≤5 cells/mm3.
• Misconception: Confusing RCVS with infectious or inflammatory vasculopathies.
• Differentiator: CNS vasculitis shows WBC >10 cells/mm3.

Comparison Table

FeatureRCVSPrimary CNS VasculitisSubarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH)
WBC (cells/mm3)≤510–200+≤10 (unless blood breakdown)
Protein (mg/dL)Normal–mild ↑ (<60)↑↑ (>100)Mild–moderate ↑
Glucose (mg/dL)NormalNormal–lowNormal
Clinical courseReversible (days–wk)ProgressiveAcute, with meningeal signs

Clinical Pearls

- Thunderclap headache in RCVS often recurs over 1–2 weeks; look for “string-of-beads” on angiography.
• Nimodipine may relieve headache but evidence is limited to observational studies.
• Always obtain CSF before high-dose steroids if primary angiitis is in the differential.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming any cerebral vasospasm equates to vasculitis and expecting pleocytosis.
2. Overinterpreting mild protein rise in RCVS as evidence of inflammation.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association (AHA) Scientific Statement on RCVS, 2012
• Recommendation: CSF analysis to exclude inflammatory causes; expect normal findings. (Class IIa, Level B evidence)
2. International Headache Society (IHS) Classification, 3rd Edition, 2018
• Defines RCVS under headache disorders; notes normal CSF profile as diagnostic criterion. (Consensus-based)

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. RCVS and CSF findings are frequently tested in neurology boards to distinguish noninflammatory vasospasm from CNS vasculitis.

question_text: A patient presents with infrequent headaches that are well controlled and has a family history of headaches. An MRI shows a deep cavernoma. What is the most appropriate management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] • Cavernous malformations (cavernomas) are clusters of dilated capillary spaces without intervening brain parenchyma.
• Deep lesions (e.g., thalamus, basal ganglia, brainstem) carry higher surgical morbidity than lobar lesions.
• Asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic cavernomas (headache only, no hemorrhage or seizures) generally warrant conservative management.
• Family history suggests a familial CCM syndrome (CCM1–3 gene mutations), but penetrance is variable and imaging–based surveillance guides intervention.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Observation is recommended for deep cavernomas in patients without prior hemorrhage, seizures, or progressive neurological deficits. The 2017 AHA/ASA guidelines on unruptured intracranial vascular malformations (Class IIb, Level C) state that surgical resection carries unacceptable functional risk in deep eloquent locations when the lesion is incidental or minimally symptomatic. A meta-analysis by Gross et al. (Neurosurgery, 2010) demonstrated an annual hemorrhage rate of 0.8–1.6% for incidentally discovered cavernomas, with post‐operative morbidity of 10–20% for deep resections. Radiosurgery has not shown consistent obliteration rates and carries delayed radiation necrosis risk. Antiepileptic drugs are indicated only if seizures are present.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Resection
– Surgical morbidity (10–20%) often exceeds the natural hemorrhage risk in asymptomatic deep cavernomas.
– Misconception: “Any cavernoma should be removed to prevent future hemorrhage.” Deep location contraindicates routine resection unless rebleeding occurs.

C. Radiosurgery
– No high‐quality trials demonstrate significant reduction in hemorrhage risk; delayed latency period (2–3 years) before effect and risk of radiation injury.
– Misconception: “Stereotactic radiosurgery is low‐risk for deep lesions.” Evidence for efficacy is lacking and complications are nontrivial.

D. Antiepileptic medication
– No seizure history; headaches alone do not justify prophylactic antiepileptic therapy.
– Misconception: “Cavernoma imaging changes mandate seizure prophylaxis.” AEDs are reserved for documented seizures.

Comparison Table

FeatureObservationResectionRadiosurgeryAntiepileptic Medication
IndicationAsymptomatic/minimally symptomatic deep cavernomasSymptomatic hemorrhage or focal deficits in accessible lobar lesionsControversial; small series onlySeizure control only
Annual hemorrhage risk0.8–1.6%N/AN/AN/A
Procedure‐related morbidityNone10–20% for deep lesions5–10% radiation necrosis riskSide effects (sedation, rash)
Evidence strengthClass IIb, Level C (AHA/ASA 2017)Recommended if rebleed or worsening neurologic statusInsufficient dataClass I for seizure treatment only

Clinical Pearls

• Use susceptibility‐weighted MRI (GRE/T2*) to detect small, asymptomatic cavernomas.
• Deep cavernomas in familial CCM often present with multiple lesions; treatment decisions hinge on symptomatology, not lesion count.
• Infratentorial hemorrhages from cavernoma rebleed carry higher morbidity; intervene only after documented rebleed.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing headache caused by cavernoma with intracranial hypertension—headaches alone are nonspecific and often unrelated.
2. Believing family history mandates prophylactic surgery or radiosurgery—management is driven by clinical presentation and lesion behavior.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2017 Guideline on Unruptured Intracranial Vascular Malformations (Stroke 2017): “Observation is reasonable for unruptured, asymptomatic deep cavernomas” (Class IIb, Level C).
• Horne et al., Lancet Neurology 2019 (Caveat Study): Prospective cohort showing low annual hemorrhage risk (1.0%) in non‐brainstem cavernomas, supporting conservative management.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

• Cavernous malformations lack mature vascular wall structures (no smooth muscle), leading to low‐flow, high‐risk microhemorrhages.
• Familial CCM arises from autosomal‐dominant mutations (KRIT1/CCM1, CCM2, PDCD10/CCM3) with variable penetrance.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Cavernomas characteristically show a “popcorn” core of mixed signal intensity on T1/T2 and a hypointense hemosiderin rim on gradient‐echo or SWI sequences.
• Absence of contrast enhancement distinguishes cavernoma from other vascular malformations.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2023 exam. Management of incidental cavernomas is tested in neurology and neurosurgery boards, often as a vignette differentiating incidental from symptomatic lesions and choosing between observation, microsurgery, and radiosurgery.

question_text: In a patient with acute ischemic stroke presenting within the IV tPA treatment window, which of the following must be assessed immediately before administering thrombolysis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] - Acute ischemic stroke therapy with IV tPA requires rapid evaluation to exclude mimics and contraindications.
• Hypoglycemia can present with focal deficits; measuring blood glucose rules out this reversible “stroke mimic.”
• Other essential assessments include neuroimaging, blood pressure control, and coagulation if anticoagulation is suspected.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Hypoglycemia must be excluded prior to IV tPA because low blood glucose (<50 mg/dL) can mimic stroke and worsen with thrombolysis. The 2021 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Jauch et al., Stroke 2021;52:e344–e418) list blood glucose measurement as a Class I recommendation (Level of Evidence C) before tPA. ECASS III trial protocols also mandated point-of-care glucose to avoid treating metabolic disturbances. While blood pressure must be controlled (<185/110 mmHg), it is continuously monitored rather than “assessed” once. Coagulation tests (INR, platelets) are required when anticoagulation history exists, but not universally mandatory; ECG rules out arrhythmias but does not alter immediate tPA eligibility.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Coagulation
• Incorrect because routine coagulation panels are only required if there is history of anticoagulant use or bleeding risk; not mandatory for every tPA candidate.
• Misconception: Believing INR/PT widely delays tPA for all patients; guidelines focus on platelet count and INR only if anticoagulation is present.

C. ECG
• Incorrect because while ECG is obtained to detect atrial fibrillation and other arrhythmias, it does not affect immediate tPA administration.
• Misconception: Overvaluing cardiac rhythm checks as a prerequisite rather than an early but non-urgent workup.

D. Blood Pressure
• Incorrect as a single pre-tPA “assessment” because BP is measured continually, and hypertensive thresholds are managed, not simply “checked.”
• Misconception: Treating BP measurement as the sole critical step—clinicians must also exclude metabolic mimics.

Clinical Pearls

• Always obtain a point-of-care glucose before tPA; treat hypoglycemia first if <50 mg/dL.
• Blood pressure must be <185/110 mmHg at tPA initiation—use labetalol or nicardipine to adjust.
• If on warfarin, ensure INR ≤1.7 before tPA; direct oral anticoagulants also require timing review.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Treating any focal deficit as stroke without checking glucose—risking tPA in hypoglycemic patients.
2. Waiting for full coagulation panel in patients with no anticoagulation history, delaying time-sensitive therapy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2021 Early Management Guidelines: Class I recommendation to measure blood glucose before tPA (LoE C).
• ESO Guidelines 2021: Emphasize point-of-care glucose to exclude mimics; reiterate door-to-needle <60 minutes target.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2023 exam.
Assessment of blood glucose prior to IV tPA is a high-yield topic on neurology boards, often tested as a contraindication checklist item.

Comparison Table

[Optional Comparison Table]

question_text: A 75-year-old female with diabetes mellitus and hypertension presents with acute right-sided weakness. CTA angiography shows left ICA stenosis at 60% and right ICA stenosis at 65%. What is the next best step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] • Symptomatic carotid stenosis: Plaque rupture or hemodynamic insufficiency in atherosclerotic internal carotid arteries leads to transient ischemic attacks or strokes, commonly affecting the contralateral motor cortex causing unilateral weakness.
• Degree of stenosis: Measured by NASCET criteria—percent diameter reduction correlates with stroke risk. Moderate (50–69%) and high-grade (≥70%) stenoses in symptomatic patients are managed differently.
• Therapeutic window: Benefits of carotid endarterectomy (CEA) are maximal if performed within 14 days of the symptomatic event; perioperative stroke/death risk should be <6% to outweigh natural history risk.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Carotid endarterectomy for symptomatic 50–69% stenosis confers a relative stroke risk reduction of ~16% at 5 years (NASCET, 1991). The AHA/ASA 2011 guidelines (Class I, Level A) recommend CEA within 2 weeks for symptomatic stenosis ≥50% with acceptable surgical risk. Recent pooled analyses confirm that women derive similar benefit if perioperative morbidity is low. Best timing is within 2 weeks to minimize recurrent stroke risk, which peaks in the first weeks after TIA or minor stroke. Medical therapy alone yields stroke risk of ~26% at 5 years for symptomatic moderate stenosis—CEA reduces this to ~10%.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Maximize medical management
• Why incorrect: Medical therapy alone in symptomatic ≥50% stenosis has higher recurrent stroke risk compared to CEA + medical therapy.
• Misconception: Belief that aggressive medical therapy is sufficient; underestimates proven surgical benefit.
• Differentiator: CEA + antiplatelet/statin reduces stroke risk > medical therapy alone in moderate symptomatic stenosis.

C. Elective carotid stenting
• Why incorrect: Stenting is reserved for high surgical-risk patients (e.g., prior neck surgery, hostile anatomy) or in clinical trials.
• Misconception: Carotid stenting is equivalent to CEA in all patients.
• Differentiator: CREST trial demonstrated higher periprocedural stroke risk with stenting, particularly in older patients, making CEA preferred in typical anatomies.

D. Stenting within 1 week
• Why incorrect: Early stenting (<2 weeks) in symptomatic plaques carries risk of reperfusion hemorrhage and periprocedural stroke.
• Misconception: “Earlier is always better”—fails to account for plaque stabilization and periprocedural risk.
• Differentiator: Optimal timing for intervention is 1–2 weeks post-event for safety and efficacy balance.

Comparison Table

FeatureCEA (Correct)Medical Therapy AloneCarotid StentingEarly Stenting (<1 week)
IndicationSymptomatic ≥50% stenosisAny stenosis if surgery contraindicatedHigh surgical risk patientsNot recommended
TimingWithin 2 weeks post-symptomImmediately and ongoingElective, >2 weeks<1 week (too early)
5-year stroke risk reductionAbsolute ~16% (NASCET)BaselineSimilar to CEA in select groupsHigher perioperative risk
Periprocedural stroke/death<6% (ideal)N/A~4–5% in low-risk>6% (higher risk)
Guideline recommendationAHA/ASA Class I, Level A (2011)AdjunctiveAHA/ASA Class IIa, Level BNot recommended

Clinical Pearls

1. Perform CEA within 14 days of symptomatic event to maximize benefit; delays >2 weeks substantially reduce stroke risk reduction.
2. Use NASCET methodology on CTA or Doppler US for accurate stenosis measurement.
3. Women with moderate stenosis should still be considered for CEA if perioperative risk is low; historical data underrepresented women.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming medical management alone is adequate for symptomatic ≥50% stenosis; underestimates operative benefit.
2. Equating carotid stenting with endarterectomy in all patients; overlooking age- and anatomy-related increased risk with stenting.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA Guidelines on the Management of Patients With Extracranial Carotid and Vertebral Artery Disease, 2011 (updated 2014): Class I recommendation for CEA within 2 weeks for symptomatic 50–99% stenosis (Level A).
• CREST (Carotid Revascularization Endarterectomy vs. Stenting Trial), 2010: Demonstrated comparable long-term outcomes but higher periprocedural stroke risk with stenting in patients >70 years; supports CEA as first-line in typical candidates.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2023 exam. Carotid stenosis management—particularly indications, timing, and modality—are frequently tested on neurology and vascular surgery sections, often in vignette format emphasizing NASCET criteria and perioperative risk thresholds.

question_text: In the case of a cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) after birth, what should be done?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) involves occlusion of dural sinuses or cortical veins, leading to impaired venous drainage, elevated intracranial pressure, vasogenic edema, and risk of hemorrhagic infarction. Key venous channels include the superior sagittal, transverse, sigmoid, and straight sinuses. The postpartum period is a hypercoagulable state due to increased procoagulant factors (I, VII, VIII, IX, X) and decreased protein S, heightening CVT risk. Clinically, postpartum CVT often presents with progressive headache, focal deficits, seizures, or altered consciousness. Definitive therapy aims to recanalize thrombosed veins, reduce intracranial hypertension, and prevent thrombus propagation—principally via anticoagulation—even when hemorrhagic lesions are present.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Anticoagulation is the cornerstone of CVT management. The International Study on Cerebral Vein and Dural Sinus Thrombosis (ISCVT, Ferro et al., 2004) demonstrated reduced mortality and better functional outcomes in patients treated with heparin despite intracranial hemorrhage. The 2011 AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Management of CVT (Class I, Level A) and the 2017 European Stroke Organization (ESO) Guidelines (Class I, Level A) both recommend immediate initiation of therapeutic-dose low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) or unfractionated heparin (UFH) upon diagnosis. Anticoagulation halts thrombus extension, promotes recanalization, and mitigates raised intracranial pressure by restoring venous outflow. Imaging modalities (CTV, MRV) are diagnostic tools but do not replace the need for prompt anticoagulant therapy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. CTV
– CTV is a diagnostic imaging modality (CT venography) that visualizes thrombus in dural sinuses. It does not treat thrombosis.
– Misconception: confusing diagnostic confirmation with therapeutic intervention.

B. MRI with venography
– MR venography aids in diagnosing CVT, offering high sensitivity for subacute clots, but does not address clot resolution.
– Key differentiation: MRI/MRV localizes thrombus, whereas anticoagulation addresses pathophysiology.

D. Supportive care and monitoring
– Supportive measures (e.g., hydration, intracranial pressure control) are adjunctive but insufficient as sole therapy.
– Misconception: underestimating the necessity of anticoagulation even in hemorrhagic infarction.

Comparison Table

FeatureAnticoagulation TherapyCTV ImagingMRI with VenographySupportive Care
PurposeTherapeuticDiagnosticDiagnosticAdjunctive
TimingImmediately upon diagnosisPrior to or at diagnosisPrior to or at diagnosisThroughout hospitalization
Effect on Venous ThrombusRecanalization, prevents growthNo effectNo effectNo direct effect on thrombosis
Evidence GradeClass I, Level A (AHA/ASA, ESO)N/AN/AN/A

Clinical Pearls

– Postpartum CVT often presents with isolated headache; maintain high suspicion in new-onset, progressive headaches after delivery.
– Initiate anticoagulation even if imaging shows hemorrhagic infarcts; hemorrhage is secondary to venous hypertension, not contraindication to heparin.
– LMWH is preferred over UFH for ease of administration and lower risk of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia; transition to oral anticoagulants for 3–6 months unless prothrombotic disorder persists.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Delaying anticoagulation due to intracranial hemorrhage on imaging, leading to clot propagation and worse outcomes.
2. Relying solely on supportive measures (e.g., diuretics, steroids) without addressing the underlying thrombotic process.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association Guidelines (2011)
• Recommendation: Class I, Level A for immediate therapeutic heparin (LMWH or UFH) in acute CVT, regardless of hemorrhagic lesions.
2. European Stroke Organization Guidelines (2017)
• Recommendation: Class I, Level A favoring LMWH over UFH for initial anticoagulation in CVT due to better safety profile.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The superior sagittal sinus drains cortical veins from the convexity; thrombosis here leads to venous congestion, bilateral parasagittal infarcts, and raised intracranial pressure. The transverse and sigmoid sinuses channel flow to the internal jugular veins; their blockage may present with focal cortical signs and papilledema.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thrombus formation in dural sinuses elevates venous pressure upstream, reduces capillary perfusion pressure, and disrupts blood–brain barrier integrity, resulting in vasogenic edema and secondary hemorrhagic infarction. Recanalization via anticoagulation restores venous outflow and normalizes intracranial dynamics.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in postpartum headache with focal signs or seizures.
2. Noncontrast CT to exclude hemorrhage.
3. CT venography (CTV) or MR venography (MRV) to confirm sinus occlusion.
4. Baseline labs: coagulation profile, platelet count, thrombophilia workup.
5. Initiate therapeutic anticoagulation immediately upon diagnosis.

Neuroimaging Pearls

– CT venography: “empty delta sign” in superior sagittal sinus on contrast-enhanced images.
– MRI: T1 hyperintense thrombus in subacute phase; MRV shows absence of flow signal in occluded sinus.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

– LMWH (e.g., enoxaparin 1 mg/kg SC every 12 h) is first-line; monitor anti-Xa levels in renal impairment or obesity.
– Transition to vitamin K antagonist (INR 2.0–3.0) for 3–6 months post-event; extended duration if prothrombotic disorder identified.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2023 exam.
Postpartum CVT is frequently tested in vascular neurology and obstetric neurology sections, often focusing on imaging versus management choices and the safety of anticoagulation in hemorrhagic presentations.

question_text: In a pregnant female patient with positive antiphospholipid antibodies who had a stroke and was found to have a small PFO, along with a prior history of DVT, what is the next best step?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] - Antiphospholipid syndrome (APLS) is an acquired thrombophilia characterized by arterial and venous thromboses mediated by antiphospholipid antibodies (anticardiolipin, anti–β₂-glycoprotein I, lupus anticoagulant).
• Pregnancy itself is a hypercoagulable state (↑ clotting factors, ↓ protein S), further compounded by APLS, increasing stroke and DVT risk.
• In pregnant patients, warfarin crosses the placenta (fetal warfarin syndrome) and DOACs lack safety data; low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is the anticoagulant of choice for both prophylaxis and treatment.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Heparin (specifically weight-based LMWH) is the correct next step:
• APLS guidelines (EULAR 2019) recommend therapeutic-dose LMWH throughout pregnancy for women with prior thrombosis plus low-dose aspirin to reduce both arterial and venous events (Level A evidence).
• AHA/ASA 2021 secondary stroke prevention guidelines endorse LMWH in pregnancy when anticoagulation is indicated, citing its safety profile and predictable pharmacokinetics without teratogenicity.
• Randomized data are limited, but cohort studies (Cuadrado et al., 2017) show LMWH reduces recurrent events in pregnant APLS patients compared to historical warfarin cohorts.
• Closure of a small PFO does not address systemic hypercoagulability; aspirin alone is insufficient in VTE-prone APLS; warfarin is contraindicated in pregnancy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Aspirin
– Insufficient antithrombotic potency for secondary prevention in APLS with prior DVT/stroke.
– Misconception: low-dose aspirin treats all pregnancy-related thromboses.
– Unlike heparin, aspirin does not inhibit the coagulation cascade at critical junctions (thrombin generation).

B. Close the PFO
– PFO closure prevents paradoxical embolism but does not correct the underlying hypercoagulable state.
– Misconception: mechanical fixes supersede medical therapy.
– Patients with APLS remain at risk for in situ thrombosis despite closure.

D. Warfarin
– Crosses placenta and causes fetal warfarin syndrome (nasal hypoplasia, stippled epiphyses).
– Misconception: warfarin is the gold standard for all thrombophilias.
– In pregnancy, warfarin’s teratogenicity and variability (INR fluctuations) make it unsuitable.

Comparison Table

FeatureHeparin (LMWH)AspirinPFO ClosureWarfarin
MechanismAntithrombin-mediated Xa inhibitionCOX-1 inhibitionMechanical defect closureVit K epoxide reductase inhibition
Pregnancy safetyFDA Category BCategory CN/ACategory D (teratogenic)
Efficacy in APLS thrombosisHigh (therapeutic dose)Low for VTE/strokeDoes not address APLSHigh but contraindicated
Placental transferMinimalModerateN/AHigh
Guideline recommendation (APLS)First-line (EULAR 2019)Adjunctive at bestNot recommendedContraindicated

Clinical Pearls

- LMWH dosing: enoxaparin 1 mg/kg subcutaneously every 12 hours (anti-Xa monitoring if extremes of weight).
• In APLS with prior obstetric events, combine LMWH with low-dose aspirin (75–100 mg daily).
• DOACs (rivaroxaban) are contraindicated in high-risk APLS (triple-positive antibodies) due to higher arterial event rates (TRAPS trial, 2018).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming PFO closure eliminates need for anticoagulation in thrombophilia.
2. Believing warfarin is safe in all trimesters of pregnancy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- EULAR “2019 Recommendations for Obstetric Management of APLS”: therapeutic LMWH + low-dose aspirin for thrombosis history (Level A).
• AHA/ASA “2021 Guideline for the Prevention of Stroke in Patients with Stroke and Transient Ischemic Attack”: endorses LMWH when anticoagulation is indicated in pregnancy.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2023 exam.
Pregnancy-associated stroke and APLS management are high-yield topics on neurology boards, frequently tested as vignette-based questions requiring knowledge of teratogenicity and LMWH dosing.

question_text: A hypertensive and diabetic patient who underwent surgery for a bone fracture developed a stroke. In a sickle cell anemia patient with two attacks of weakness one year apart, what is the most common provocative factor?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Sickle cell anemia (HbSS) causes chronic hemolysis and episodic vaso-occlusion from polymerized sickled erythrocytes. Cerebral infarction in these patients results when red cell sickling in cerebral arterioles and capillaries impedes blood flow. Key risk factors include anemia severity, elevated transcranial Doppler (TCD) velocities, and acute physiologic stressors. Physical stressors—such as dehydration during exertion or perioperative periods—exacerbate hypoxia and acidosis, accelerating sickling. Recognizing these modifiable precipitants is vital for both primary and secondary stroke prevention in SCD.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Physical stress emerges as the most frequent trigger for stroke in SCD because it provokes dehydration, relative hypoxemia and acidosis—conditions that heighten HbS polymerization and vaso-occlusion. Pegelow et al. (Blood 1998;91:117–122) documented that surgery, vigorous exercise, and similar stresses preceded the majority of stroke events in a pediatric SCD cohort. The 2020 AHA/ASA Pediatric Stroke Guidelines (Class IIa; Level B-NR) explicitly list dehydration and hypoxia as modifiable risk factors in SCD. Neither emotional stress nor hypertension reliably induces the degree of red cell sickling required for infarction in SCD, and hyperventilation-induced vasoconstriction lacks clinical correlation with SCD-related strokes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Emotional stress
• Lacks the hypoxic/dehydrative impact necessary for mass sickling.
• Misconception: equating psychosocial stressors with physiologic triggers of infarction.

C. Hypertension
• SCD patients often have lower vascular resistance and rarely develop sustained hypertension.
• Not identified as a precipitant in large SCD stroke series.

D. Hyperventilation
• Causes respiratory alkalosis and cerebral vasoconstriction but does not significantly increase sickling.
• More relevant to syncope than to vaso-occlusive infarction in SCD.

Comparison Table

FactorPrevalence in SCD StrokeMechanism of Vaso-occlusion
Physical stressMost commonDehydration/hypoxia → increased HbS polymerization
Emotional stressRareCatecholamine surge; minimal effect on oxygenation
HypertensionVery rareUncommon in SCD; not linked to sickling
HyperventilationTheoreticalAlkalosis-induced vasoconstriction (not proven)

Clinical Pearls

- Annual TCD screening (ages 2–16) and transfusion for velocities >200 cm/s reduces first‐stroke risk by >90% (STOP trial).
• Ensure euvolemia and avoid high‐altitude or strenuous activity in SCD patients to minimize stroke triggers.
• Chronic transfusion or hydroxyurea to raise HbF levels further decreases infarction risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming general stroke risk factors (e.g., hypertension) apply equally to SCD; SCD-specific triggers (dehydration, hypoxia) predominate.
• Overlooking perioperative and exercise-induced dehydration as key precipitating events in SCD strokes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- 2020 AHA/ASA Pediatric Stroke Guidelines: classify dehydration and hypoxia as modifiable risk factors in SCD‐related stroke (Class IIa; Level B-NR).
• 2021 American Society of Hematology Clinical Practice Guidelines on SCD: strong recommendation (Grade 1B) for patient education on hydration and infection prevention to mitigate acute stroke risk.
• STOP Trial (Adams RJ et al., Ann Neurol 1998;44:699–704): primary transfusion prophylaxis reduces first‐stroke incidence by 92%.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Under low oxygen tension, HbS polymerizes, deforming erythrocytes and promoting endothelial adhesion. Physical stressors (surgery, exercise) exacerbate hypoxemia, acidosis, and hemoconcentration—accelerating sickling and triggering cerebral microvascular occlusion.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2023 exam. On neurology board exams, SCD stroke questions frequently test recognition of unique triggers (dehydration, infection, physical stress) versus general risk factors, alongside TCD screening and transfusion strategies.

question_text: A patient with a past medical history of stroke underwent a full cardiac workup that was negative. He was started on Aspirin, which worsened his chronic epistaxis. What is the next best step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Cryptogenic ischemic stroke mandates evaluation for both cardiac and extracardiac sources of emboli. Recurrent epistaxis in a stroke survivor raises suspicion for hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT), an autosomal dominant disorder causing mucocutaneous telangiectasias and pulmonary arteriovenous malformations (AVMs). Pulmonary AVMs permit right-to-left shunting of emboli, leading to paradoxical cerebral infarcts. Definitive diagnosis relies on imaging modalities: contrast echocardiography and CT chest for screening, followed by catheter-based pulmonary angiography for localization and embolization. Understanding the link between nasal telangiectasias, pulmonary AVMs, and stroke pathogenesis is key to selecting the appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic intervention.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Lung angiography is the gold standard for diagnosing and treating pulmonary AVMs in HHT. The 2021 International HHT Guidelines recommend screening all HHT patients with contrast-enhanced CT chest and, if AVMs with feeding arteries ≥2–3 mm are identified, proceeding to pulmonary angiography with transcatheter embolotherapy (Level A evidence). In a multicenter cohort (Moussavi et al., J Thromb Haemost 2014), embolization reduced recurrent neurologic events by 85%. Conversely, checking C-ANCA without clinical features of granulomatosis with polyangiitis has low yield (sensitivity <50% in isolated neurological presentations). Switching to clopidogrel does not address the embolic source and still poses bleeding risks. Nasal packing alone overlooks life-threatening pulmonary shunts and fails stroke prevention.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. C-ANCA
• Incorrect: Targets granulomatosis with polyangiitis, which presents with systemic vasculitis (renal, pulmonary nodules, sinus disease), not isolated epistaxis and stroke.
• Misconception: Equating any epistaxis in stroke with ANCA-associated vasculitis.
• Differentiator: HHT’s telangiectasias and pulmonary AVMs vs GPA’s necrotizing granulomas.

C. Switch to Clopidogrel
• Incorrect: Antiplatelet class switch does not mitigate paradoxical emboli risk from AVMs and still exacerbates mucosal bleeding.
• Misconception: Belief that clopidogrel has lower bleeding risk than aspirin.
• Differentiator: Need for mechanical AVM closure, not pharmacotherapy tweak.

D. Nasal packing and discontinue Aspirin
• Incorrect: Addresses symptom (epistaxis) but ignores stroke recurrence risk and vascular malformation etiology.
• Misconception: Symptom control equates to disease management.
• Differentiator: Definitive AVM embolization vs temporary hemostasis.

Comparison Table

FeatureLung Angiography (Correct)C-ANCA TestingClopidogrel SwitchNasal Packing & Discontinue ASA
TargetPulmonary AVMsANCA-associated vasculitisPlatelet inhibitionLocal epistaxis control
PurposeDiagnosis + embolizationDiagnostic serologyAlternative antiplateletSymptom management
EfficacyReduces paradoxical emboli by ≥85%Low yield in this contextNo effect on AVMsNo stroke prevention
Bleeding riskLow procedural riskNoneContinues mucosal bleedingMay worsen thrombosis risk

Clinical Pearls

• In HHT, screen for pulmonary AVMs in patients with recurrent epistaxis and stroke; small telangiectasias on mucosa may be the only cutaneous clue.
• Contrast-enhanced CT chest (feeding artery ≥2 mm) is the initial noninvasive screen; angiography confirms and treats the lesion in one session.
• Embolotherapy of pulmonary AVMs is both diagnostic and therapeutic, reducing hypoxemia and neurological complications.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Misattributing recurrent epistaxis solely to aspirin without considering underlying vascular malformations.
• Overreliance on serologic vasculitis panels in the absence of systemic features, leading to delayed targeted imaging.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International HHT Guidelines (Second Edition, 2021):
– Recommendation: Screen HHT patients with CT chest; embolize AVMs with feeder ≥2–3 mm. (Class I, Level A)
2. AHA/ASA Guidelines for Secondary Stroke Prevention (2021 Update):
– Recommendation: In cryptogenic stroke with negative cardiac workup, evaluate for extracardiac shunts (bubble TTE, chest imaging). (Class IIa, Level B-R)

Pathophysiology Breakdown

HHT results from ENG or ACVRL1 gene mutations, causing loss of vascular integrity and direct arteriovenous communications. Pulmonary AVMs bypass capillary filtration, allowing emboli to transit into cerebral circulation, leading to ischemic strokes. Telangiectasias in nasal mucosa predispose to recurrent epistaxis, often exacerbated by antiplatelet therapy.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Ischemic stroke with negative ECG/echocardiogram.
2. Note recurrent epistaxis and family history of telangiectasias.
3. Obtain contrast echocardiography; if right-to-left shunt suspected, perform CT chest.
4. Identify pulmonary AVMs; proceed to pulmonary angiography for localization and coil embolization.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Aspirin and clopidogrel address platelet aggregation but do not prevent paradoxical emboli through AVMs.
• Definitive therapy is endovascular embolization; antiplatelet continuation may be resumed post-embolization if indicated for other vascular risks.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2023 exam.
Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia and pulmonary AVMs are frequently tested as uncommon causes of cryptogenic stroke, often in vignette form with epistaxis and negative cardiac evaluation.

question_text: In a patient with a stroke, what is the most appropriate management option?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Acute ischemic stroke results from arterial occlusion leading to an infarct core surrounded by a penumbra of hypoperfused but viable tissue. Early reperfusion preserves penumbral neurons (“time is brain”: ~1.9 million neurons lost/minute). Intravenous tPA catalyzes plasminogen to plasmin, dissolving fibrin clots and restoring flow. Eligibility hinges on rapid recognition, neurologic exam, noncontrast CT to exclude hemorrhage, and strict blood pressure parameters. Understanding the distinction between ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke and the therapeutic time window underpins appropriate management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Intravenous alteplase (0.9 mg/kg, max 90 mg) within 3 hours of onset demonstrated a 30% relative increase in favorable outcomes (NINDS trial, 1995; Lancet). ECASS III extended the window to 4.5 hours, showing significant functional benefit (Class I, LOE B-R; AHA/ASA 2018 update). Guidelines mandate noncontrast CT before administration to rule out hemorrhage and infarct size assessment. Contraindications (e.g., recent surgery, bleeding diathesis) must be screened. Door-to-needle time target is ≤60 minutes. Advanced imaging (CT perfusion/MR DWI–FLAIR mismatch) may select late-window patients (EXTEND, WAKE-UP trials) but does not supplant the standard 4.5 h window. Thus, prompt tPA is the current standard for eligible acute ischemic stroke patients presenting within 4.5 hours.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Immediate initiation of oral anticoagulation without imaging
• Incorrect: Risk of hemorrhagic transformation if stroke is hemorrhagic; imaging is mandatory.
• Misconception: Anticoagulation is for secondary prevention, not acute reperfusion.
• Differentiator: Stroke type must be distinguished on CT/MRI prior to therapy.
C. Prescribe high-dose corticosteroids
• Incorrect: Steroids have no role in acute ischemic stroke and may worsen hyperglycemia and infection risk.
• Misconception: Overgeneralization from steroid use in vasculitis or spinal cord compression.
• Differentiator: Inflammation is secondary, not primary, driver of acute neuronal death.
D. Perform lumbar puncture immediately upon presentation
• Incorrect: LP is contraindicated before neuroimaging in suspected stroke (risk of herniation, delays critical therapy).
• Misconception: LP is for all acute neurologic presentations.
• Differentiator: Rapid CT/MRI is the diagnostic priority in suspected stroke.

Comparison Table

InterventionMechanismIndicationContraindications/Evidence
A. IV tPA within 4.5 hPlasminogen → plasmin; clot lysisAcute ischemic stroke <4.5 hHemorrhage risk; requires CT exclusion of bleed
B. Oral anticoagulation w/o imagingInhibits vitamin K–dependent clottingSecondary stroke preventionContraindicated if hemorrhage; no acute benefit
C. High-dose corticosteroidsBroad anti-inflammatoryDemyelinating disease, vasculitisNo benefit in ischemia; ↑infection, hyperglycemia
D. Lumbar puncture immediatelyCSF samplingMeningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage when imaging equivocalDelay to reperfusion; risk brain herniation

Clinical Pearls

- Aim for door-to-needle time ≤60 min; pre-notify stroke team for rapid CT.
• Blood pressure must be ≤185/110 mm Hg before tPA; treat hypertensive urgency with labetalol.
• Use alteplase dosing of 0.9 mg/kg (10% bolus, remainder over 60 min); monitor for intracerebral hemorrhage.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Delaying CT to obtain coagulation labs—imaging must precede labs to avoid treatment delays.
2. Believing minor deficits (NIHSS ≤4) contraindicate tPA—mild strokes may still benefit if disabling.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Early Management Guidelines: Class I LOE A for IV tPA within 3 h; Class I LOE B-R for 3–4.5 h window.
• WAKE-UP Trial (2018, NEJM): MRI DWI–FLAIR mismatch used to select unknown-onset strokes for tPA up to 4.5 h (Class IIa LOE B).
• EXTEND Trial (2019, Lancet): CT perfusion–selected patients benefited from alteplase up to 9 h (supports advanced imaging but not standard care).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. On boards, acute stroke management is frequently tested as single-best-answer format, emphasizing time windows, eligibility criteria, and contraindications for thrombolysis.

question_text: In a patient with sickle cell disease, what intervention is known to decrease the risk of future strokes?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] • Sickle cell disease (SCD) causes chronic hemolysis and episodic vaso-occlusion leading to endothelial injury and cerebral vasculopathy, particularly in distal intracranial carotid and middle cerebral arteries.
• Transcranial Doppler (TCD) ultrasonography screens for stroke risk by measuring flow velocities; readings >200 cm/s in the MCA/ICA predict first stroke.
• Secondary prevention after an overt stroke or abnormal TCD centers on chronic transfusion therapy (simple or exchange) to reduce hemoglobin S below 30%, improving rheology and oxygen delivery and markedly lowering recurrent stroke risk.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Chronic transfusion therapy remains the only intervention proven to reduce both primary and secondary stroke risk in SCD. In the landmark STOP trial (1998; Adams RJ et al., N Engl J Med), children with abnormal TCD (>200 cm/s) randomized to regular transfusions had a 92% relative risk reduction in first stroke. For secondary prevention, a meta-analysis (Cox AJ et al., Blood 2018) demonstrated an ~80% decrease in recurrent strokes with ongoing transfusions targeting hemoglobin S <30%. AHA/ASA 2014 pediatric stroke guidelines (Fitzgerald KC et al., Stroke) give chronic transfusion a Class I, Level B recommendation for both primary (after abnormal TCD) and secondary prevention. Exchange transfusions are preferred over simple in patients with iron overload or alloimmunization, complemented by chelation therapy to mitigate siderosis. Other interventions lack evidence: endovascular angioplasty or stenting is ineffective in diffuse sickle-related vasculopathy, and observation alone fails to alter the high recurrence rate.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Angioplasty
• Incorrect: Sickle vasculopathy is diffuse and involves small distal vessels; focal angioplasty does not address global sickling-induced endothelial injury.
• Misconception: Equating atherosclerotic stenosis (amenable to angioplasty) with sickle vasculopathy.
• Differentiator: Angioplasty suits discrete atherosclerotic lesions, not microvascular occlusion.

C. Stent
• Incorrect: Stents carry high thrombosis risk in SCD and do not prevent ongoing sickling in non-stented segments.
• Misconception: That mechanical scaffolding reduces sickle-cell–mediated injury.
• Differentiator: Stents treat fixed stenoses; SCD stroke risk stems from dynamic red cell sickling.

D. Observation
• Incorrect: No intervention allows continued high risk of recurrent stroke (>50% within 3 years post-stroke).
• Misconception: That mild surveillance without therapy suffices post-stroke.
• Differentiator: Only active transfusion therapy significantly reduces recurrence.

Comparison Table

InterventionMechanismStroke Risk ReductionIndicationsLimitations
Chronic transfusions↓ Hemoglobin S, improved rheologyPrimary: ~92%Abnormal TCD (>200 cm/s), post-strokeIron overload, alloimmunization
AngioplastyFocal vessel dilationNone provenAtherosclerotic stenosis (not SCD)Ineffective in diffuse vasculopathy
StentMechanical scaffolding of vesselNone provenFocal stenoses (not SCD)Thrombosis, sickling beyond stent
ObservationSupportive care onlyNoneNone relevantHigh recurrence without therapy

Clinical Pearls

• Annual TCD screening from age 2–16 guides primary prevention; abnormal results mandate chronic transfusion.
• Initiate iron chelation (deferoxamine, deferasirox) after ~12–20 transfusions to prevent endocrinopathies and cardiomyopathy.
• Hydroxyurea reduces vaso-occlusive crises but is inferior to transfusions for stroke prevention; consider only if transfusion contraindicated.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing hydroxyurea’s role in reducing pain crises with stroke prevention—transfusions remain superior for cerebrovascular risk.
2. Believing endovascular procedures (angioplasty/stenting) effective in SCD strokes—unlike atherosclerosis, SCD vasculopathy is diffuse and dynamic.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• NHLBI Sickle Cell Disease Guidelines (2020): Grade A recommendation for regular transfusion to maintain hemoglobin S <30% in children with abnormal TCD or prior stroke.
• AHA/ASA Stroke in Children Guidelines (2014): Class I, Level B evidence supporting chronic transfusion for both primary (after TCD abnormality) and secondary stroke prevention.
• SWiTCH Trial (2016; Hankins JS et al., Blood): Compared hydroxyurea plus phlebotomy vs chronic transfusion plus chelation for secondary prevention—transfusion arm had fewer recurrent events.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. On neurology boards, stroke prevention in sickle cell disease is frequently tested in pediatric neurology, often via TCD screening and management scenarios.

question_text: After 5 hours of labor, a patient on SSRIs presents with depression. What is the likely CT finding and angiography result?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] • Autoregulation and Vasogenic Edema: Cerebral blood flow is normally maintained over a wide range of pressures by autoregulation; when this fails (e.g., sudden hypertension in eclampsia), capillary leakage produces vasogenic edema.
• Posterior Circulation Vulnerability: Vertebrobasilar arteries have less sympathetic innervation than anterior vessels, predisposing parietal–occipital regions to edema.
• PRES Clinical Presentation: Headache, seizures, visual disturbances, altered mental status; often reversible with prompt management of blood pressure and offending factors.

(130 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

In the 2023 Part 2 exam, this question tests recognition of PRES in a postpartum context. PRES arises from endothelial dysfunction and failed autoregulation, leading to reversible vasogenic edema. On noncontrast CT, PRES appears as bilateral, symmetric hypodense areas in the subcortical white matter of parietal and occipital lobes. Angiography (CT or MR) typically shows patent arteries without aneurysmal outpouching, large-vessel occlusion, or segmental vasospasm.
– Hinchey et al. first described PRES in 1996 (Am J Neurol), noting reversibility with blood pressure control.
– Fugate and Rabinstein (Mayo Clin Proc 2015) reported that >75% of PRES cases fully recover radiographically and clinically when precipitating factors are removed.
– ACOG Practice Bulletin No. 203 (2019) on hypertensive disorders of pregnancy underscores early imaging for neurological signs in eclampsia to identify PRES.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Acute ischemic stroke with large vessel occlusion
• CT would show focal hypodensity with loss of gray–white differentiation, not symmetric posterior hypodensities.
• CTA/MRA reveals abrupt vessel cutoff and collateral patterns; PRES angiography is normal.
• Misconception: conflating vasogenic edema with cytotoxic ischemic changes.

C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage with vasospasm
• Noncontrast CT shows hyperdense blood in basal cisterns/sulci, not hypodense edema.
• Angiography typically reveals aneurysm or vessel irregularity days later, whereas PRES vessels are smooth.
• Misconception: confusing headache/seizures in PRES with thunderclap headache of SAH.

D. Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis with venous infarcts
• CT may show hemorrhagic infarcts and “empty delta” on venogram, but arterial angiography is often unremarkable.
• Risk factors include postpartum state, but SSRIs do not predispose.
• Misconception: attributing symmetric edema to venous infarcts rather than vasogenic edema.

Comparison Table

FeaturePRESAcute Ischemic StrokeSAH with VasospasmCVST
OnsetHours to days; headache, seizuresMinutes; focal deficitsSudden thunderclap headacheSubacute; headache, seizures
Risk FactorsHypertensive crisis, eclampsia, sepsisAtherosclerosis, cardioembolismAneurysm rupture, traumaHypercoagulability, postpartum
Noncontrast CTBilateral parieto-occipital hypodensitiesFocal hypodensity, grey–white lossHyperdense cisternal bloodHemorrhagic infarcts; “empty delta”
Angiography (CTA/MRA)Normal vesselsVessel cutoff with poor collateralsAneurysm; segmental vasospasmNormal arterial; venous filling defect

Clinical Pearls

• MRI with T2-FLAIR is more sensitive than CT for detecting PRES; DWI helps distinguish vasogenic from cytotoxic edema.
• In eclampsia-related PRES, first-line management is magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis and rapid blood pressure control with IV labetalol or hydralazine.
• Prompt recognition and removal of precipitating factors (e.g., hypertension, immunosuppressants) lead to full clinical and radiographic reversal in most cases.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking symmetric vasogenic edema for early stroke changes and inappropriately administering thrombolytics.
2. Assuming postpartum seizures are solely eclamptic without neuroimaging; missing underlying PRES.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. ACOG Practice Bulletin No. 203 (2019): Recommends immediate neuroimaging for neurological symptoms in preeclampsia/eclampsia; magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis reduces PRES incidence (Grade A).
2. European Stroke Organisation (ESO) Guideline on Cerebral Venous Thrombosis (2017): Endorses MRI/MRV as first-line imaging for suspected CVST (Level A evidence), highlighting that noncontrast CT alone may miss venous thrombosis.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• CT: vasogenic edema appears hypodense without mass effect.
• MRI: T2-FLAIR shows hyperintense subcortical white matter; ADC values are elevated (vasogenic) vs restricted (cytotoxic).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2023 exam. PRES is a high-yield topic on neurology boards, frequently tested in scenarios of hypertensive encephalopathy, eclampsia, immunosuppressant toxicity, and sepsis. Recognition of the characteristic parieto-occipital pattern and understanding the reversible nature are key to correct answers.

question_text: What is the mechanism of stroke in arterial dissection?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Arterial dissection arises when an intimal tear allows blood to enter the vessel wall, creating an intramural hematoma and often an intimal flap. This leads to luminal narrowing or occlusion and promotes thrombus formation at the dissection site. In cervical artery dissections—most commonly of the internal carotid or vertebral arteries—distal embolization of thrombus fragments is the predominant cause of ischemic stroke, accounting for roughly 70–80% of events. Less commonly, severe stenosis may cause perfusion deficits, but true hemodynamic strokes are rare. Recognition of neck pain, focal neurologic deficits, and imaging findings (e.g., T1 fat-suppressed MRI showing intramural hematoma) is essential for diagnosis and targeted management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Artery-to-artery embolism is the principal mechanism of ischemic injury in cervical artery dissection. Prospective transcranial Doppler studies detect microembolic signals in >75% of patients after dissection. The CADISS trial (Lancet Neurol 2015) randomized 250 patients to antiplatelet versus anticoagulant therapy and found no significant difference in stroke recurrence, underscoring the embolic pathogenesis rather than hemodynamic compromise. The 2018 AHA/ASA Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines (Class IIa, Level B) recommend antithrombotic therapy—either aspirin or anticoagulation—for 3–6 months to prevent recurrent embolism. The dissected intimal flap and intramural hematoma foster local thrombus formation, which then breaks off and occludes distal cerebral branches, producing territorial infarcts on diffusion-weighted MRI.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Venous thrombosis
• Dissections affect arterial walls, not veins.
• Confuses arterial dissection with cerebral venous sinus thrombosis, which presents with hemorrhagic infarcts and raised intracranial pressure.

C. Hypoperfusion
• Although luminal narrowing can reduce cerebral blood flow, true watershed infarcts are uncommon in dissection.
• Dissection strokes are typically territorial embolic infarcts rather than bilateral watershed patterns.

D. Cardioembolic event
• Cardioembolic strokes arise from intracardiac thrombi (e.g., atrial fibrillation, valvular disease), not from local arterial wall injury.
• Cardiac source work-up (ECG, echocardiography) will be negative in isolated cervical dissection.

Comparison Table

FeatureArtery-to-artery embolismVenous thrombosisHypoperfusionCardioembolic event
Vessel involvedDissected artery (carotid/vertebral)Cerebral veins or dural sinusesSeverely stenosed arteryHeart chambers (atria, ventricles)
MechanismThrombus at dissection → distal arterial emboliSinus thrombus → venous infarctionLow cerebral perfusion pressureThrombus formation in heart → arterial emboli
ImagingTerritorial infarcts distal to dissection siteHemorrhagic infarcts, ‘empty delta’Watershed infarctsMultiple bilateral infarcts in different territories
Treatment focusAntiplatelet or anticoagulationAnticoagulation (LMWH/VKA)Revascularization, BP supportAnticoagulation (warfarin/DOACs)

Clinical Pearls

• Cervical carotid dissection often presents with ipsilateral neck or head pain and partial Horner syndrome due to sympathetic plexus involvement.
• T1-weighted fat-suppressed MRI of the neck is highly sensitive for detecting intramural hematoma in arterial dissection.
• The CADISS trial supports either aspirin or warfarin for 3–6 months; choice can be individualized based on bleeding risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Overemphasizing hypoperfusion leads to inappropriate pursuit of revascularization rather than antithrombotic therapy.
• Mistaking arterial dissection for cerebral venous sinus thrombosis due to cervical pain delays proper vascular imaging and management.
