Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Class IIa, LOE B—recommend antithrombotic therapy (antiplatelet or anticoagulant) for 3–6 months in cervical artery dissection to prevent recurrent stroke.
• CADISS Trial (Lancet Neurol 2015): No significant difference in recurrent stroke rates between antiplatelet (aspirin) and anticoagulation (warfarin) in cervical artery dissection (Level II evidence).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2018 exam. Cervical artery dissection and its embolic stroke mechanism are high-yield topics on vascular neurology questions, often tested with imaging correlates and therapeutic decision-making scenarios.

question_text: Admission to stroke unit
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] - Stroke units deliver organized inpatient care via a multidisciplinary team (neurologists, nurses, therapists, social workers).
• Core principles: early assessment, prevention of complications, standardized protocols for monitoring and rehabilitation.
• Relevant terminology: organized stroke unit (OSU), modified Rankin Scale (mRS), interdisciplinary rounds.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Admission to a dedicated stroke unit is a Class I, Level A recommendation in the 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke, as well as in the 2021 ESO Guidelines. The landmark Cochrane meta-analysis (Stroke Unit Trialists’ Collaboration, Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2021;CD000197) reviewed 28 randomized trials (n=13,000) showing OSU care reduced death (relative risk [RR] 0.84, 95% CI 0.76–0.93) and dependency (RR 0.75, 95% CI 0.68–0.83) at 1 year. Benefits apply to both ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke and are attributed to protocolized monitoring (blood pressure, swallowing), early mobilization, secondary prevention, and coordinated rehabilitation.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Is not necessary if the patient is stable
• Why incorrect: Even “stable” patients benefit from OSU protocols that detect subtle deterioration (e.g., BP spikes, silent aspiration).
• Misconception: Equating hemodynamic stability with no need for specialized monitoring.

C. Should be avoided due to increased risk of infections
• Why incorrect: OSUs implement infection-control bundles; studies show no increased infection rates versus general wards.
• Misconception: Assuming more devices/monitoring equals higher nosocomial infections without accounting for protocolized care.

D. Is only recommended for ischemic stroke, not hemorrhagic stroke
• Why incorrect: Both subtypes gain from OSU care; hemorrhagic stroke units reduce complications (e.g., pressure sores, VTE) by standardized protocols.
• Misconception: Belief that hemorrhagic strokes require ICU-only care.

Comparison Table

FeatureStroke Unit Care (B)General Ward (A/C/D)
Mortality reductionRR 0.84 (Cochrane 2021)No significant benefit
Functional independence (mRS ≤2)Improved by 25%Lower rates
Infection ratesComparable or lower with protocolsVariable, less protocolized
ApplicabilityAll stroke subtypesOften reserved for ischemic only

Clinical Pearls

- Early swallowing assessment in OSU reduces pneumonia by 30%.
• Daily multidisciplinary rounds accelerate transition to home-based rehabilitation.
• Protocolized BP management in OSU decreases hemorrhagic transformation rates.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing ICU admission with stroke unit care—OSU is ward-based with specialized team, not necessarily ICU.
2. Believing only thrombolyzed patients need OSU—every stroke subtype benefits.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2019 Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines: Class I, Level A for OSU admission.
• ESO 2021 Guidelines on Stroke Unit Care: strong recommendation based on high-quality RCT data (Level I).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam.
Stroke unit admission is frequently tested as a fundamental component of stroke management, often in questions contrasting general ward care versus organized multidisciplinary approaches.

question_text: In a case of acute ischemic stroke, the blood pressure is 193/103 mmHg. What should be done next?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] - Acute ischemic stroke causes a mismatch between cerebral blood flow (CBF) and metabolic demand; perfusion of the penumbra depends on collateral circulation.
• Cerebral autoregulation is disrupted in the ischemic territory; raising systemic blood pressure within limits (“permissive hypertension”) can improve perfusion to at-risk tissue.
• AHA/ASA guidelines set different BP thresholds: up to 220/120 mmHg if not thrombolysed; tighter control (<185/110 mmHg) is required prior to and during tPA infusion.

(Word count: 98)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Permissive hypertension is correct because in untreated acute ischemic stroke, moderately elevated BP augments collateral flow and reduces infarct growth. The 2018 AHA/ASA guideline (Powers et al., Stroke 2018) gives a Class I, LOE B recommendation to withhold antihypertensives unless SBP >220 mmHg or DBP >120 mmHg. In patients being considered for IV tPA, the threshold is SBP >185 or DBP >110; BP must be lowered (e.g., with labetalol) to meet this. There is no indication to start tPA or nitroprusside at 193/103 when the patient is not yet a confirmed tPA candidate; indiscriminate rapid BP reduction may worsen ischemia (Tatu et al., Neurology 2012).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. IV labetalol
• Incorrect: No immediate need to lower BP below 185/110 unless planning tPA.
• Misconception: All elevated BP in stroke must be treated.
• Differentiator: Permissive elevation up to 220/120 is beneficial without tPA.

B. IV nitroprusside
• Incorrect: Strong arterial and venous dilation can raise intracranial pressure and steal flow from penumbra.
• Misconception: Any rapid-acting antihypertensive is safe in stroke.
• Differentiator: Nitroprusside is contraindicated in acute stroke due to ICP effects.

D. Immediate tPA administration
• Incorrect: BP exceeds the safe upper limit (185/110) for thrombolysis—must first lower if tPA is indicated.
• Misconception: Time-to-tPA is paramount, regardless of BP.
• Differentiator: BP must be controlled within protocol limits before alteplase infusion.

Comparison Table

(Key Features by Option)
• A. IV labetalol: indicated only when SBP >220 or pre-tPA lowering; here unnecessary.
• B. IV nitroprusside: risk of intracranial pressure rise; not recommended.
• C. Permissive hypertension: supports collateral perfusion; target <220/120 if no thrombolysis planned.
• D. Immediate tPA: contraindicated until BP ≤185/110 is achieved.

Clinical Pearls

- Maintaining permissive hypertension (SBP up to 220 mmHg) reduces infarct expansion in non-thrombolysed patients.
• Before initiating IV tPA, ensure SBP ≤185 mmHg and DBP ≤110 mmHg for at least 1 hour.
• Abrupt BP reduction can worsen cerebral ischemia by collapsing collateral vessels.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Treating all elevated BP in stroke without regard to thrombolytic status.
• Choosing nitroprusside for rapid control despite ICP risks.
• Administering tPA without verifying BP is within protocol limits.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines (Powers et al., Stroke 2018): Class I, LOE B recommendation to allow SBP up to 220/120 in non-tPA patients; lower to ≤185/110 before tPA.
• ESO 2021 Guidelines on IV thrombolysis (Chapman et al., Eur Stroke J 2021): Reaffirm SBP threshold of 185/110 pre-tPA, recommend labetalol or nicardipine infusion for controlled lowering.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Acute ischemia disrupts autoregulation in penumbral tissue; raising systemic BP modestly can enhance collateral perfusion pressure and sustain the penumbra, delaying infarction expansion.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Labetalol: β-blocker with α1-blockade, lowers BP gradually; ideal for pre-tPA lowering (initial 10–20 mg IV).
• Nitroprusside: potent arterial vasodilator; increases ICP and can worsen stroke outcomes—avoid.
• tPA (alteplase): dosage 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg) over 60 minutes; only after BP is within protocol.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2018 exam. On board exams, candidates are tested on BP management thresholds in hyperacute ischemic stroke—knowing both permissive hypertension limits and tPA-related BP cutoffs is high-yield.

question_text: A stroke patient presents with livedo reticularis. What is the diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Livedo reticularis is a violaceous, net-like cutaneous pattern caused by sluggish dermal blood flow. When it coexists with recurrent ischemic strokes, one must consider systemic arteriopathies beyond atherosclerosis. Sneddon disease is characterized by non-inflammatory fibrointimal thickening of small to medium arteries affecting skin and brain, presenting as livedo reticularis and cerebrovascular events. Recognizing this cutaneous marker redirects workup from typical cardio- or athero-embolic etiologies toward rarer vascular pathologies like Sneddon disease or antiphospholipid syndrome.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Sneddon disease is classically defined by chronic livedo reticularis plus ischemic strokes without evidence of vasculitis or cardiac emboli (Zulfiqar et al., J Neurol 2020). Histopathology reveals subendothelial fibrosis and smooth muscle proliferation without inflammatory infiltrates (Magro et al., Br J Dermatol 2018). Unlike antiphospholipid syndrome (APS), which requires persistent antiphospholipid antibodies and features thrombotic occlusion (Miyakis et al., J Thromb Haemost 2006), Sneddon is seronegative with a primary arteriopathy. Neuroimaging in Sneddon shows multifocal infarcts across vascular territories with patent large vessels on angiography. Orphanet’s 2021 consensus recommends long-term antiplatelet therapy (Level III evidence), reserving anticoagulation for those with overlapping APS.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Antiphospholipid syndrome
• APS requires laboratory positivity for anti-β2 glycoprotein I or anticardiolipin antibodies and features thrombus formation rather than fibrointimal hyperplasia.
• Misconception: All livedo plus stroke = APS.
• Differentiator: Serologic markers and thrombi on histology.

C. Atherosclerotic stroke
• Driven by plaque rupture or stenosis in large arteries; presents with vascular risk factors but no cutaneous findings.
• Misconception: Stroke in any vascular bed originates from atherosclerosis.
• Differentiator: Imaging shows focal plaque or stenosis.

D. Lacunar infarct
• Results from lipohyalinosis of small penetrating arterioles, causing deep subcortical infarcts without skin involvement.
• Misconception: Small-vessel strokes have external signs.
• Differentiator: Lesions <15 mm in basal ganglia/internal capsule on MRI.

Comparison Table

FeatureSneddon DiseaseAntiphospholipid SyndromeAtherosclerotic StrokeLacunar Infarct
Skin findingChronic livedo reticularisOccasional livedo, transientNoneNone
PathologyNon-inflammatory intimal fibrosisThrombus formationAtheromatous plaqueLipohyalinosis
SerologyNo specific markers+ anti-β2GPI, + anticardiolipinDyslipidemia, hyperglycemia markersHTN/diabetes markers
ImagingMultifocal infarcts, patent vesselsTerritorial infarcts, possible stenosisPlaque/stenosis on angiographySingle small deep infarct

Clinical Pearls

- In young stroke with livedo reticularis, perform skin biopsy to confirm non-inflammatory arteriopathy.
• Distinguish Sneddon (seronegative, fibrointimal hyperplasia) from APS (seropositive, thrombotic).
• First-line management is antiplatelet therapy; anticoagulation only if APS overlap.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming livedo reticularis in stroke always indicates APS.
2. Overlooking Sneddon disease in seronegative patients with multiple territorial infarcts and skin findings.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- EULAR 2019 APS Recommendations: Lifelong anticoagulation for arterial events with high-risk aPL (Grade B).
• Orphanet Consensus on Sneddon Syndrome 2021: Advocates antiplatelet monotherapy; immunosuppression only if autoimmune overlap (Level III evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Subendothelial fibrointimal proliferation narrows arteriolar lumens in skin and brain, causing chronic perfusion deficits manifesting as livedo reticularis and multifocal ischemia without inflammation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify livedo reticularis in stroke patient.
2. Exclude cardiac embolism and large vessel stenosis (echocardiography, angiography).
3. Test for antiphospholipid antibodies.
4. Perform skin biopsy for arterio­pathy.
5. Diagnose Sneddon disease if seronegative with typical histology.

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI typically shows acute and chronic infarcts in multiple territories; MRA reveals largely intact large vessels, distinguishing from large-vessel atherosclerosis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Start low-dose aspirin (75–100 mg daily). Reserve warfarin (INR 2–3) for confirmed APS overlap; no routine immunosuppression unless concomitant autoimmune disease.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. It frequently tests recognition of livedo reticularis as a dermatologic clue to Sneddon disease in stroke patients.

question_text: A clear picture suggests perimesencephalic SAH. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) distribution on noncontrast CT guides etiologic evaluation.
• Perimesencephalic SAH: Blood confined to cisterns around the midbrain (interpeduncular/ambient).
• Aneurysmal SAH: Diffuse basal cistern and sylvian fissure involvement; often intraventricular extension.
• Traumatic SAH: Predominantly sulcal/convexity hemorrhage following head injury.
Identifying the bleeding pattern informs need for angiography, intervention, and prognosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Benign perimesencephalic SAH (PMSAH) is characterized by hemorrhage localized anterior to the pons/mesencephalon without diffuse extension. Prospective series (van Gijn et al., 1985; Rinkel et al., 1991) show >95% of classic PMSAH cases have negative DSA and <1% rebleeding. The 2023 AHA/ASA guidelines recommend CT angiography first; if CTA is negative and CT pattern is strictly perimesencephalic, invasive DSA may be deferred (Class IIb, Level B-R). PMSAH requires supportive care and nimodipine for vasospasm prophylaxis but no aneurysm repair, explaining its benign course versus aneurysmal SAH.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Aneurysmal SAH
– Presents with diffuse basal cistern and sylvian fissure blood, positive aneurysm on CTA/DSA.
– Misconception: All basal cistern bleeds are aneurysmal.
– Differentiator: Aneurysmal SAH shows irregular, extensive hemorrhage and requires clipping/coiling.

C. Traumatic SAH
– Results from head trauma with cortical sulcal hemorrhage, often without deep cisternal pooling.
– Misconception: Non-aneurysmal SAH equals trauma.
– Differentiator: Traumatic SAH lacks characteristic perimesencephalic cistern localization and has trauma history.

D. Non-aneurysmal SAH
– Umbrella term encompassing PMSAH and other non-aneurysmal bleeds (e.g., convexity SAH, RCVS-associated).
– Misconception: “Non-aneurysmal” is sufficiently specific.
– Differentiator: PMSAH is a distinct benign subtype with precise CT criteria and prognosis.

Comparison Table

FeatureBenign Perimesencephalic SAHAneurysmal SAHTraumatic SAHNon-aneurysmal SAH (general)
CT DistributionInterpeduncular/ambient onlyBasal + sylvian fissuresCortical sulci/convexitiesVariable
Angiographic FindingsNegativePositive aneurysmNegativeNegative
Rebleeding Risk<1%15–20% (untreated)Very lowVariable
PrognosisExcellentVariable to poorDepends on traumaVariable
ManagementSupportive, nimodipineClipping/coiling, ICUSupportive, trauma careEtiology-dependent

Clinical Pearls

1. A “cap”-shaped hemorrhage anterior to the midbrain with negative CTA/DSA defines benign perimesencephalic SAH.
2. All SAH patients receive nimodipine (60 mg p.o. q4h ×21 days) to reduce vasospasm risk, including PMSAH.
3. In classic PMSAH, prolonged ICU stay for repeated angiography is unnecessary once aneurysm is excluded.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Proceeding directly to invasive DSA for any basal cistern bleed without assessing hemorrhage pattern.
2. Overcalling small convexity or intraventricular blood as PMSAH, missing aneurysms.
3. Treating “non-aneurysmal” SAH as homogeneous rather than recognizing distinct subtypes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association, 2023 Guidelines for Aneurysmal SAH: Recommends initial CTA; if negative and strictly perimesencephalic CT pattern, DSA may be omitted after multidisciplinary review (Class IIb, Level B-R).
2. European Stroke Organization, 2021 Guidelines on SAH: Advises that with classic perimesencephalic distribution and negative noninvasive angiography, invasive angiography can be safely withheld (Grade B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Blood pools in the interpeduncular and ambient cisterns around the mesencephalon, sparing the sylvian fissures and lateral ventricles—key for distinguishing PMSAH.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PMSAH likely originates from venous plexus rupture in the basal cisterns rather than arterial aneurysm rupture, resulting in limited bleeding and low rebleeding risk.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT → identify perimesencephalic pattern.
2. CT angiography → exclude aneurysm.
3. If CTA negative + classic CT, consider foregoing DSA; if atypical or CTA equivocal, proceed to DSA.
4. Admit for 24–48 h monitoring, nimodipine, and follow-up imaging if clinical changes occur.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Perimesencephalic SAH appears as a symmetrical “cap” anterior to the midbrain without extension into sylvian fissures, interhemispheric fissure, or ventricles.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Pattern recognition of SAH distribution and understanding subsequent angiographic workup is a high-yield, image-based topic frequently tested on neurology boards.

question_text: A patient presents with an aneurysm rupture of the posterior communicating artery (Pcom). What will you do?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm in the subarachnoid space leads to aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (aSAH). Key concepts:
• Neurovascular anatomy: The posterior communicating artery connects the internal carotid to the posterior cerebral circulation and lies adjacent to cranial nerve III.
• Hemorrhage pathophysiology: Rupture spills arterial blood into the subarachnoid cisterns, raising intracranial pressure, risking rebleeding and vasospasm.
• Definitive management principle: Secure the aneurysm promptly (ideally within 24–48 h) to prevent rebleeding, using the least invasive method that yields durable occlusion.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Endovascular coiling has become first-line for most ruptured anterior-circulation aneurysms, including Pcom, if morphology and access permit. The International Subarachnoid Aneurysm Trial (ISAT, 2002) randomized 2,143 patients with ruptured anterior-circulation aneurysms to coiling versus clipping and showed a significant reduction in death or dependency at one year in the coiling group (risk reduction 7.4%, p=0.01). Subsequent long-term follow-up confirmed durability of coiling in appropriate aneurysms. The 2023 AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Management of Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage give a Class I, Level A recommendation for endovascular treatment if the aneurysm is suitable in size, shape, and location. In contrast, open surgical clipping, while still indicated for wide-necked or complex aneurysms not amenable to coiling, carries greater surgical morbidity.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Clipping
• Although historically standard, open clipping is more invasive, with higher rates of perioperative complications (e.g., cerebral edema, infection) than coiling for Pcom aneurysms amenable to endovascular access.
• Misconception: “All ruptured aneurysms must be clipped” ignores advances in neurointervention and individual aneurysm morphology.

C. Decompressive craniotomy
• Indicated for malignant cerebral edema in large‐territory ischemic stroke or refractory intracranial hypertension, not for securing a ruptured aneurysm.
• Confuses management of elevated intracranial pressure with aneurysm treatment.

D. Admission to stroke unit
• Stroke units specialize in ischemic stroke care; aSAH requires immediate neurocritical care and neurosurgical/neurointerventional management in an ICU setting.
• Underestimates the urgency of aneurysm securing.

Comparison Table

OptionInvasivenessPrimary GoalTypical Indication
Coiling [CORRECT]Minimally invasiveSecure aneurysm endovascularlyRuptured anterior-circulation aneurysms with favorable neck anatomy
ClippingHighly invasiveDirect microsurgical aneurysm exclusionComplex or wide-neck aneurysms unsuitable for coiling
Decompressive craniotomyHighly invasiveRelieve intracranial pressureMalignant cerebral edema post-large ischemic stroke, trauma
Admission to stroke unitNon‐proceduralMonitoring and secondary preventionAcute ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack

Clinical Pearls

- Early aneurysm securing (≤ 48 h) reduces rebleeding risk by up to 80%.
• Oral nimodipine (60 mg every 4 h for 21 days) is the only drug shown to improve outcomes by mitigating delayed cerebral ischemia.
• Pcom aneurysms often present with ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy (ptosis, “down and out” eye) before or after rupture.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating ischemic stroke pathways (stroke unit care) with aSAH management—SAH demands neurosurgical/ICU care.
2. Believing decompressive craniectomy addresses rebleeding—this ignores the need to secure the aneurysm.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines 2023: Class I, Level A recommendation for endovascular coiling of ruptured anterior-circulation aneurysms when anatomically feasible.
• International Subarachnoid Aneurysm Trial (ISAT, 2002; 2005 follow-up): Demonstrated 7.4% reduction in death or dependency at 1 year with coiling vs clipping in suitable aneurysms.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The Pcom branches off the internal carotid artery at the level of the oculomotor nerve. Its rupture commonly deposits blood in the interpeduncular cistern, often compressing CN III and causing ipsilateral pupillary dilation and ophthalmoplegia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Saccular aneurysms arise at arterial bifurcations due to congenital medial defects, hemodynamic stress, and degeneration of the internal elastic lamina. Rupture into the subarachnoid space triggers a cascade of inflammation, raised intracranial pressure, and risk of secondary vasospasm.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Non-contrast head CT → confirm subarachnoid blood.
2. CT angiography or digital subtraction angiography → localize aneurysm and assess neck morphology.
3. Early neurosurgical/neurointerventional consultation → plan definitive treatment (coiling vs clipping).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Acute SAH: hyperdensity in basal cisterns, especially interpeduncular cistern for Pcom.
• CTA demonstrates aneurysm neck size and dome-to-neck ratio; > 2:1 favors coiling.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Nimodipine: 60 mg PO/NG every 4 h for 21 days to prevent delayed ischemia.
• Maintain systolic BP < 160 mm Hg pre-securing; avoid hypotension.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam.
Aneurysmal SAH management, particularly the choice between coiling and clipping, is frequently tested. Examine aneurysm location and morphology, understand trial data (ISAT) and guideline recommendations to choose the appropriate intervention.

question_text: In the ECST trial, what was the estimated 3-year stroke or death rate for patients who underwent carotid endarterectomy (CEA)?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Symptomatic carotid atherosclerosis carries a high risk of recurrent ipsilateral stroke due to artery‐to‐artery embolism or hemodynamic insufficiency. Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) surgically removes plaque to restore lumen patency and reduce embolic load. Landmark randomized trials—most notably ECST and NASCET—defined stenosis thresholds for maximal benefit. ECST measured residual lumen vs outer vessel wall (not directly comparable to NASCET), but its key finding was a significant reduction in 3-year stroke or death when CEA was added to medical therapy, contingent on acceptable perioperative risk (<6% 30-day stroke/death) and high‐grade stenosis. Understanding trial design, patient selection, and outcome definitions is essential for applying results to clinical decision‐making.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The European Carotid Surgery Trial (ECST; Lancet 1998) randomized 659 symptomatic patients with carotid stenosis ≥70% (by ECST criteria) to CEA plus medical therapy versus medical therapy alone (667 patients). Over a mean follow-up of 3.4 years, the cumulative rate of any stroke or death in the surgical arm was 15.7% (95% CI 13.1–18.3%), versus 26.5% (95% CI 23.6–29.4%) in the non-surgical arm. The absolute risk reduction of 10.8% translated into a number needed to treat of ~9. In subgroup analyses, benefit was most pronounced in patients with severe stenosis. These results underpin current guidelines recommending CEA for symptomatic stenosis ≥70% when surgical risk is low, as it halves long-term stroke risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. 14.9%
• Incorrect: No 3-year event rate of 14.9% was reported in ECST.
• Misconception: Confuses with 5-year risk in asymptomatic carotid surgery trials (ACST).
• Differentiator: ECST surgical arm event rate was higher (15.7%).

B. 26.5%
• Incorrect: This is the 3-year stroke or death rate in the medical‐therapy (no-CEA) arm of ECST.
• Misconception: Students may invert treatment and control rates.
• Differentiator: Represents natural history without surgery in ECST.

C. 22.2%
• Incorrect: No ECST subgroup or pooled analysis yielded exactly 22.2%; this value is sometimes misattributed to older pooled observational data.
• Misconception: Mistaking mixed‐trial or NASCET data for ECST outcomes.
• Differentiator: ECST precise surgical arm rate was 15.7%.

Comparison Table

OptionReported 3-Year RateECST Context
A.14.9%Not reported in ECST; from asymptomatic trial data
B.26.5%Medical‐therapy arm event rate (no CEA)
C.22.2%Not an ECST figure; misattributed pooled value
D.15.7%Surgical arm event rate (CEA + medical therapy)

Clinical Pearls

- CEA is class I indicated for symptomatic carotid stenosis ≥70% (NASCET criteria) if 30-day perioperative stroke/death risk is <6%.
• Benefit is greatest when surgery is performed within 2 weeks of the index event.
• In moderate stenosis (50–69%), absolute risk reduction is smaller; patient comorbidities heavily influence decision.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing ECST and NASCET stenosis measurement methods – ECST used residual‐lumen/outer‐wall ratio.
2. Swapping surgical and medical arm event rates (15.7% vs 26.5%).
3. Applying asymptomatic trial data (e.g., ACST) to symptomatic patients.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. 2021 AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Prevention of Stroke in Patients With Stroke and Transient Ischemic Attack
• Recommendation: CEA within 2 weeks for symptomatic stenosis 70–99% (Class I, LOE A).
2. 2023 European Society for Vascular Surgery (ESVS) Guidelines on Carotid Stenosis
• Recommendation: CEA over medical therapy for symptomatic stenosis ≥70% with perioperative risk <6% (Grade A, Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2018 exam. Questions on ECST and NASCET are frequently tested, particularly to assess knowledge of trial outcomes, stenosis measurement differences, and guideline-based indications for CEA versus medical therapy.

question_text: A 60-year-old male patient with diabetes and hypertension came with a history of transient ischemic attack (TIA) lasting 10 minutes, with numbness and dysarthria. The NIHSS score is 3. On examination, he still has numbness. What will you give?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) represent temporary cerebral ischemia due to arterial thromboembolism or thrombosis in carotid or intracranial vessels. Even when symptoms resolve, high-risk features (e.g., NIHSS ≤3, diabetes, hypertension) predict early recurrence due to platelet activation and microthrombus propagation in the ischemic penumbra. Platelet aggregation is mediated by cyclooxygenase-1–derived thromboxane A₂ and ADP binding at P2Y₁₂ receptors, making dual inhibition of these pathways more effective in reducing early ischemic events. The NIHSS scale quantifies stroke severity, guiding therapy intensity: minor strokes (NIHSS ≤3) benefit most from short-term dual antiplatelet therapy. Recognizing these pathophysiological and clinical assessment principles is essential for secondary prevention strategies in cerebrovascular disease.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) combining aspirin and clopidogrel addresses thromboxane-mediated and P2Y₁₂-mediated platelet activation, critical in early thrombus propagation. The CHANCE trial (N Engl J Med 2013) randomized 5,170 Chinese patients within 24 hours of high-risk TIA or minor stroke to 21 days of DAPT vs aspirin alone, demonstrating a 32% relative risk reduction in 90-day stroke recurrence (8.2% vs 11.7%; p=0.02) without a significant increase in hemorrhage. The POINT trial (N Engl J Med 2018) in a diverse cohort confirmed a 28% relative risk reduction at 90 days (4.1% vs 5.8%; HR 0.72; 95% CI, 0.59–0.89), offset by a small rise in major bleeding (0.9% vs 0.4%). Consequently, the 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines (Class I, Level of Evidence A) recommend DAPT for 21 days, initiated within 24 hours of a high-risk TIA or minor ischemic stroke (NIHSS ≤3).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Aspirin
• Incorrect because monotherapy yields less early risk reduction than DAPT in high-risk TIA/minor stroke.
• Misconception: that aspirin alone suffices in all secondary prevention settings.
• Differentiator: lacks P2Y₁₂ receptor blockade, reducing efficacy in the acute period.

B. Plavix
• Incorrect: clopidogrel monotherapy has not demonstrated superior early protection compared to DAPT within 24 hours.
• Misconception: that inhibiting ADP alone matches combined pathway inhibition.
• Differentiator: single-pathway blockade offers lower relative risk reduction than combined COX-1 and P2Y₁₂ inhibition.

D. None of the above
• Incorrect: withholding antiplatelet therapy after a high-risk TIA incurs a markedly elevated recurrence risk (>10% at 90 days).
• Misconception: that mild symptoms obviate the need for immediate therapy.
• Differentiator: absence of therapy fails to address ongoing platelet activation and thrombus evolution.

Comparison Table

TherapyMechanismEvidence in High-Risk TIA/Minor StrokeRecommended Duration
Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel)COX-1 inhibition + P2Y₁₂ receptor blockadeCHANCE, POINT: ~30% RRR in 90-day stroke; Class I, LOE A21 days
Aspirin monotherapyCOX-1 inhibitionControl arm in CHANCE/POINT; higher recurrence riskIndefinite
Clopidogrel monotherapyP2Y₁₂ receptor blockadeCAPRIE: slight benefit over aspirin in broad stroke pop.; no acute TIA/minor stroke dataIndefinite
No antiplatelet therapyNoneVery high recurrence risk (>10% at 90 days)N/A

Clinical Pearls

• Initiate DAPT within 24 hours of a high-risk TIA or minor stroke to intercept early platelet-mediated thrombus growth.
• Limit DAPT to 21 days—extended therapy increases hemorrhagic risk without added stroke reduction.
• Concurrently evaluate for carotid stenosis and atrial fibrillation; alternate interventions (e.g., endarterectomy, anticoagulation) may be indicated.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Assuming aspirin or clopidogrel monotherapy provides equivalent early protection to DAPT leads to suboptimal prevention.
• Extending DAPT beyond 21 days based on fear of recurrence paradoxically increases bleeding risk without further benefit.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Heart Association/American Stroke Association 2018 Guidelines: Recommends DAPT with aspirin and clopidogrel initiated within 24 hours of high-risk TIA or minor stroke (NIHSS ≤3) for 21 days (Class I, Level of Evidence A).
• POINT trial (N Engl J Med 2018): Demonstrated a 28% relative risk reduction in recurrent ischemic events at 90 days with early DAPT vs aspirin alone (HR 0.72; 95% CI, 0.59–0.89) but higher major bleeding (0.9% vs 0.4%); supports 21-day regimen (Level of Evidence 1b).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Secondary stroke prevention and the timing/duration of dual antiplatelet therapy for high-risk TIA/minor stroke are frequently tested as scenario-based questions on national board examinations.

question_text: A patient with sickle cell disease comes with a stroke workup done and is found to have multiple stenoses in the anterior cerebral artery (AcA) and middle cerebral artery (McA). What is the method of prevention?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] • Sickle cell disease (SCD)–associated vasculopathy often involves progressive stenosis of large intracranial arteries (e.g., ACA, MCA), resembling moyamoya.
• Sickled red cells adhere to endothelium, provoke intimal hyperplasia, narrowing vessel lumen and elevating cerebral blood flow velocities on transcranial Doppler (TCD).
• Primary stroke prevention in high‐risk children hinges on reducing hemoglobin S (HbS) fraction via regular red blood cell transfusions to prevent first‐ever ischemic events.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Chronic transfusion therapy is the cornerstone of primary stroke prevention in SCD with intracranial stenosis. The landmark STOP trial (1998) randomized children with elevated TCD velocities (>200 cm/s) to transfusion vs. standard care, demonstrating a 92% relative risk reduction in first stroke (N Engl J Med.1998;339:5–11). Transfusions maintain HbS <30% and total hemoglobin ~10 g/dL, improving oxygen delivery and reducing sickling. Subsequent STOP II confirmed that stopping transfusions led to recurrence of elevated velocities and risk. The 2020 American Society of Hematology (ASH) guidelines give a strong recommendation (grade 1B) for regular transfusions in children with abnormal TCD or known vasculopathy. While the TWiTCH trial (2016) explored switching to hydroxyurea after ≥1 year of transfusion, chronic transfusion remains first‐line when stenoses are present.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Aspirin
• Reason incorrect: Platelet inhibition does not address the primary pathophysiology of sickle‐cell vasculopathy (RBC sickling and intimal proliferation).
• Misconception: Equating adult atherosclerotic stroke prevention with SCD; aspirin has not shown efficacy in primary stroke prevention in SCD.

B. Plavix
• Reason incorrect: Clopidogrel’s antiplatelet action is similarly unhelpful against sickling‐induced endothelial damage and stenosis.
• Misconception: Belief that stronger or alternative antiplatelet agents suffice for all stroke etiologies.

D. Dual antiplatelet therapy
• Reason incorrect: Combining aspirin plus clopidogrel increases hemorrhagic risk without reducing stroke incidence in SCD vasculopathy.
• Misconception: “More antiplatelet agents = better prevention”; ignores disease‐specific mechanism.

Comparison Table

FeatureChronic TransfusionAspirinClopidogrelDual Antiplatelet
MechanismLowers HbS <30%, improves O₂ deliveryCOX-1 inhibition, ↓TXA₂P2Y₁₂ receptor blockadeCombined COX-1 + P2Y₁₂ blockade
Key TrialSTOP Trial (1998): 92% RRRNo dedicated RCT in SCDNo dedicated RCT in SCDNo evidence in SCD
ASH Guideline RecommendationStrong for primary preventionNot recommendedNot recommendedContraindicated (bleeding risk)
Major RiskIron overload (requires chelation)MinimalMinimal↑Bleeding

Clinical Pearls

• Begin annual transcranial Doppler screening by age 2 in SCD (HbSS, HbSβ⁰).
• Target HbS <30% and total Hb ~10 g/dL with exchange or simple transfusion every 3–4 weeks.
• Monitor ferritin and initiate iron chelation (deferasirox or deferoxamine) to prevent hemosiderosis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying on antiplatelet agents (aspirin, clopidogrel) for SCD stroke prevention, overlooking sickling pathology.
2. Discontinuing transfusions once TCD normalizes without considering underlying stenosis may lead to rebound risk (as in STOP II).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• ASH 2020 Guidelines (1B): Strongly recommend chronic transfusion for children with abnormal TCD or documented intracranial stenosis.
• TWiTCH Trial (2016, NEJM 374:1542–1552): Hydroxyurea noninferior to transfusion for maintaining TCD velocities after ≥1 year of transfusion—but only in selected low‐risk patients without severe vasculopathy.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam.
Sickle cell–related stroke prevention is frequently tested in pediatric neurology/stroke modules, often in the context of TCD screening thresholds and interpretation of STOP/TWiTCH data.

question_text: An 82-year-old male patient came within 3 hours and has no contraindication for tPA. A CT scan shows early signs of stroke, but infarction is not established. What will you give?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Hyperacute ischemic stroke management aims to salvage the ischemic penumbra—tissue at risk but not yet infarcted—by restoring perfusion before irreversible neuronal death. Neurons in the penumbra experience excitotoxicity, calcium overload, and free‐radical injury. Noncontrast CT excludes hemorrhage and shows early signs (loss of gray–white differentiation, sulcal effacement, hyperdense vessel) but not established infarction. “Time is brain”: each minute without reperfusion costs ~1.9 million neurons. Intravenous alteplase (tPA) administered within 4.5 hours of symptom onset reduces long-term disability; benefit is greatest under 3 hours. Rapid NIH Stroke Scale scoring, CT interpretation, and exclusion of contraindications are critical to initiate thrombolysis and maximize penumbral salvage.

Evidence-Based Analysis

tPA (alteplase) is the only FDA-approved fibrinolytic for acute ischemic stroke. The landmark NINDS trial (1995) demonstrated a 30% relative improvement in functional outcome at 3 months when administered within 3 hours (OR 1.7, 95% CI 1.2–2.6). ECASS III extended the window to 4.5 hours, showing a 7.2% absolute increase in favorable outcome (p=0.04). The 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines (Powers et al.) give Class I, LOE A recommendation for IV alteplase ≤4.5 hours; age >80 years is no longer an exclusion within this window. Exclusion criteria (e.g., recent hemorrhage, coagulopathy) must be ruled out. CT early ischemic changes do not preclude tPA unless hypodensity involves >1/3 MCA territory.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Aspirin
• Why incorrect: Initiating aspirin within 24 hours of tPA increases hemorrhagic risk and does not improve acute recanalization.
• Misconception: Confusing antiplatelet with thrombolytic therapy.
• Differentiator: Aspirin inhibits platelet aggregation; tPA actively lyses thrombus.

B. Plavix
• Why incorrect: No evidence supports P2Y12 inhibition as monotherapy in hyperacute stroke; risk–benefit for immediate reperfusion absent.
• Misconception: Assuming all antithrombotics are interchangeable in the hyperacute phase.
• Differentiator: Plavix acts slowly and is indicated for secondary prevention, not acute reperfusion.

D. Supportive care only
• Why incorrect: While airway and hemodynamic support are vital, omitting reperfusion therapy forfeits potential penumbral salvage and worsens outcomes.
• Misconception: Overestimating CT early signs as contraindications.
• Differentiator: Supportive care does not address vessel occlusion.

Comparison Table

TreatmentMechanismTime WindowKey Outcome BenefitHemorrhage Risk
tPA (alteplase)Plasminogen → plasmin → fibrinolysis0–4.5 hours (Class I, LOE A)↓ disability at 3 months (NINDS, ECASS III)~6.4% symptomatic ICH
AspirinCOX-1 inhibition → ↓ TXA₂Not for hyperacute reperfusion↓ early recurrence (not acute benefit)↑ bleeding if given <24 h post-tPA
PlavixP2Y₁₂ receptor blockadeNot indicated acutelyLong-term secondary preventionLow but not studied acutely
Supportive careAirway, BP, glucose controlAll phasesPrevents medical complications—

Clinical Pearls

- “Time is brain”: aim for door-to-needle ≤60 minutes.
• Early CT signs (hyperdense MCA sign, subtle hypodensity) do not contraindicate tPA unless >1/3 MCA territory is involved.
• Age >80 years or minor early ischemic changes no longer exclude patients ≤4.5 hours per AHA/ASA 2019.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Administering aspirin or dual antiplatelet therapy instead of tPA in tPA-eligible patients.
2. Overcalling early CT hypodensity as established infarction and withholding thrombolysis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Stroke Guidelines 2019 (Powers et al.): Class I, LOE A for IV alteplase ≤4.5 hours; CT early ischemic changes alone are not a contraindication unless extensive.
• ECASS III Trial (2008): Demonstrated benefit of alteplase between 3–4.5 hours (OR for favorable outcome 1.34, 95% CI 1.02–1.76).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Noncontrast CT: look for loss of gray–white differentiation, insular ribbon sign, hyperdense vessel.
• ASPECTS ≤7 indicates extensive early ischemia; >7 favorable for tPA with lower hemorrhage risk.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Alteplase dosing: 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg)—10% as bolus over 1 minute, remainder over 60 minutes.
• Monitor BP <185/110 mm Hg before/during infusion to minimize hemorrhagic conversion.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Acute ischemic stroke thrombolysis within the time window and CT interpretation are high-yield topics, frequently tested as single best answer or management algorithms.

question_text: Angioplasty
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Balloon angioplasty (percutaneous transluminal angioplasty, PTA) is an endovascular technique used to mechanically widen stenotic arteries. Core concepts:
• Pathophysiology of atherosclerosis: lipid-rich plaque accumulates within the intima, causing luminal narrowing and impaired perfusion.
• Endovascular access: catheters are navigated from femoral or radial arteries into the cerebral circulation under fluoroscopic guidance.
• Vessel biomechanics: controlled balloon inflation compresses plaque against the arterial wall and stretches the media, improving luminal diameter.
Understanding these principles distinguishes angioplasty from surgical excision (endarterectomy) and clarifies its role in ischemic stroke prevention.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option C is correct because angioplasty refers specifically to balloon dilation of a stenotic vessel. After arterial access, a balloon catheter is positioned across the lesion and inflated to a predetermined pressure, fracturing intimal and medial fibers and compressing atheroma, thereby restoring flow. According to the 2015 AHA/ASA guidelines on extracranial carotid and vertebral artery disease (Class I, Level A), carotid angioplasty and stenting (CAS) is indicated for symptomatic high-grade (≥70%) carotid stenosis in patients at high surgical risk. The CREST trial (2010, NEJM) demonstrated non-inferiority of CAS versus carotid endarterectomy (CEA) for composite stroke, myocardial infarction, and death endpoints in symptomatic and asymptomatic patients. For intracranial stenosis, the SAMMPRIS trial (2011, NEJM) revealed higher periprocedural risk with angioplasty plus stenting versus aggressive medical management alone, leading to a more conservative approach (AHA/ASA 2021 update: Class IIb, Level B-R for angioplasty/stenting in refractory intracranial stenosis).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. “Is a surgical procedure involving direct removal of atherosclerotic plaque”
• Incorrect because plaque removal describes carotid endarterectomy, not angioplasty.
• Misconception: equating endovascular dilation with open surgical excision.
• Differentiator: endarterectomy requires arteriotomy and manual plaque extraction, whereas angioplasty uses intraluminal balloon expansion.

B. “Is primarily used to treat hemorrhagic stroke”
• Incorrect as angioplasty addresses ischemic, not hemorrhagic, pathology.
• Misconception: confusing cerebrovascular interventions for ischemia versus hemorrhage.
• Differentiator: hemorrhagic stroke management focuses on blood pressure control, reversal of anticoagulation, surgical evacuation, not vessel dilation.

D. “Is contraindicated in patients with carotid artery stenosis”
• Incorrect because angioplasty (with stenting) is an established option for carotid stenosis, especially in high surgical-risk cases.
• Misconception: assuming endovascular risk precludes use in carotid disease.
• Differentiator: CEA and CAS are both indicated for symptomatic high-grade stenosis; CAS is preferred in specific high-risk surgical profiles.

Comparison Table

OptionMechanismPrimary IndicationExample Procedure
ASurgical plaque excisionCarotid endarterectomy for stenosisArteriotomy and manual dissection
BNot an angioplasty techniqueHemorrhagic stroke managementHematoma evacuation
CBalloon inflation of stenosis [✓]Ischemic stroke prevention/treatmentPTA with or without stent
D(False) Contraindication assertion(Incorrect) CEA/CAS for stenosisN/A

Clinical Pearls

- Carotid angioplasty is almost always performed with stent deployment to prevent elastic recoil and dissection.
• High-risk CEA patients (prior neck surgery, radiation, contralateral laryngeal nerve palsy) benefit from CAS (AHA/ASA Class I, LOE A).
• Intracranial angioplasty carries a higher periprocedural stroke risk; reserved for patients failing maximal medical therapy (Class IIb, LOE B-R).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing angioplasty with endarterectomy: the former is endovascular, the latter open surgery.
2. Believing angioplasty treats hemorrhagic events: it treats vessel narrowing in ischemic disease only.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2015 Extracranial Carotid Disease Guideline: Recommends CAS in symptomatic ≥70% stenosis for high surgical risk patients (Class I, LOE A).
• SAMMPRIS Trial (2011, NEJM): Demonstrated higher stroke risk with intracranial angioplasty plus stenting versus aggressive medical therapy; led to Class IIb, LOE B-R recommendation for refractory cases in 2021 AHA/ASA update.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Vascular neurology questions frequently test distinctions between endovascular techniques (angioplasty/stenting) and surgical approaches (endarterectomy), and require knowledge of appropriate ischemic versus hemorrhagic stroke interventions.

question_text: A left ICA deep borderzone infarction is shown on DWI. What test would reveal the etiology?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] - Watershed (borderzone) infarcts occur in areas between major arterial territories (e.g., between ACA and MCA deep perforators) and often reflect hemodynamic compromise from proximal large‐artery stenosis.
• Diffusion-weighted MRI (DWI) is highly sensitive for detecting acute ischemia within minutes of onset but does not identify vascular lesions.
• CT angiography (CTA) provides rapid, high‐resolution images of extracranial and intracranial arteries, allowing detection of ICA stenosis or occlusion—the key etiology in deep borderzone strokes.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CTA is the test of choice because deep borderzone infarcts most commonly result from hemodynamic insufficiency due to ipsilateral ICA high‐grade stenosis or occlusion. The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke recommend emergent vascular imaging (CTA or MRA) in all suspected large‐vessel occlusions (Class I, Level of Evidence B). A meta‐analysis (Bamford et al., 2020) showed CTA sensitivity >95% and specificity >98% for detecting ≥70% ICA stenosis. Early identification enables timely decisions about endarterectomy or stenting to prevent recurrent events.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Electroencephalogram
– EEG evaluates cerebral electrical activity and is indicated for seizures or encephalopathy, not for detecting vascular stenosis.
– Misconception: “Every neurologic deficit needs an EEG.” EEG cannot visualize vessels.

C. Lumbar puncture
– LP is used for infectious, inflammatory, or subarachnoid hemorrhage evaluation; it cannot assess arterial lumen or flow dynamics.
– Misconception: Borderzone infarcts might be inflammatory—LP does not detect stenosis.

D. Echocardiogram
– Transthoracic or transesophageal echo evaluates cardiac sources of emboli (e.g., thrombus, PFO), not large‐artery hemodynamics.
– Differentiating feature: echo rules out cardioembolism, but borderzone pattern points to hypoperfusion.

Comparison Table

TestPrimary TargetDetects ICA StenosisTypical Use in Stroke Workup
CT AngiographyExtracranial/intracranial vesselsYesFirst-line for suspected large-vessel disease
EEGCortical electrical activityNoSeizure evaluation
Lumbar PunctureCSF analysisNoInfection, hemorrhage exclusion
EchocardiogramCardioembolic sourcesNoEmbolic stroke source workup

Clinical Pearls

- Deep borderzone infarcts (“rosary‐like” spoke-wheel DWI pattern) strongly suggest proximal ICA hemodynamic compromise.
• In acute ischemic stroke, noncontrast CT followed immediately by CTA (or CT perfusion) streamlines diagnosis and eligibility for reperfusion therapies.
• High‐grade ICA stenosis (>70%) detected on CTA often warrants urgent carotid endarterectomy within 2 weeks to reduce recurrence risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering an echocardiogram first in a watershed infarct delays detection of large‐artery stenosis.
2. Misinterpreting borderzone DWI hyperintensities as lacunar infarcts leads to under‐investigation of proximal stenosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines (Stroke): Recommend emergent CTA/MRA in all suspected large-vessel occlusion strokes (Class I, LOE B).
• European Stroke Organisation 2021 Guidelines: Endorse CTA within 25 minutes of hospital arrival for linking diagnosis to reperfusion decisions (Grade A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The deep borderzone between the superficial perforating branches of the MCA and the lenticulostriate arteries lies adjacent to the lateral ventricle. Hypoperfusion here produces characteristic linear or patchy infarcts on DWI.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Severe ipsilateral ICA stenosis reduces cerebral perfusion pressure distal to the lesion. Under hypotensive or high‐demand states, the watershed zones fail to autoregulate, leading to ischemia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage
2. MRI-DWI to confirm acute ischemia pattern
3. CTA of head and neck to assess for ICA stenosis/occlusion
4. Manage identified stenosis (medical vs endarterectomy/stenting)

Neuroimaging Pearls

- DWI detects infarction within minutes; FLAIR mismatch can estimate onset time.
• CTA provides submillimeter resolution of vessel lumen; multiplanar reconstructions elucidate stenosis length and morphology.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam.
Borderzone infarct patterns on DWI frequently signal large-artery hypoperfusion and necessitate prompt CTA to guide revascularization decisions.

question_text: Based on the following imaging, which territory is involved?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Understanding vascular territories in the brainstem and cerebellum is critical to localizing strokes on imaging. The anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) arises from the basilar artery and supplies the lateral pons, middle cerebellar peduncle, parts of the cerebellum, and, via the labyrinthine artery, the inner ear structures. Infarction produces a lateral pontine syndrome characterized by ipsilateral facial paralysis, loss of corneal reflex, ataxia, and ipsilateral hearing loss or vertigo. In contrast, PICA infarcts cause lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome without facial paralysis, while SCA and PCA infarcts involve different cerebellar or occipital territories. MRI-DWI typically shows a wedge-shaped hyperintense lesion conforming to the artery’s distribution, enabling precise localization.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The imaging demonstrates a hyperintense lesion on DWI in the lateral pons extending into the middle cerebellar peduncle, sparing the medulla and cerebellar hemisphere. These findings align with the AICA distribution: lateral pontine structures including the facial nucleus and vestibulocochlear complex. AICA strokes often present with ipsilateral facial paralysis (facial nucleus involvement) and contralateral pain/temperature loss (spinothalamic tract), plus ipsilateral hearing loss (labyrinthine artery branch). The 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke emphasize rapid MRI-DWI for posterior fossa strokes (Class I, Level A evidence) and recommend reperfusion therapy within 4.5 hours. Studies show AICA infarcts comprise ~1%–2% of ischemic strokes but carry high morbidity due to brainstem and cranial nerve involvement.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Posterior cerebral artery
• Incorrect because PCA supplies the occipital lobe, thalamus, and medial temporal lobe. Imaging would show occipital cortical infarction with visual field deficits, not a brainstem lesion.
B. PICA
• PICA infarction causes lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome: dysphagia, hoarseness, nucleus ambiguus signs, and contralateral pain/temperature loss of the body. Facial nucleus involvement and hearing loss are absent.
C. Superior cerebellar artery (SCA)
• SCA supplies the superior cerebellum and superior cerebellar peduncle. SCA strokes produce limb ataxia and dysmetria without facial paralysis or cochlear symptoms, and imaging shows superior cerebellar cortical lesions.

Comparison Table

FeatureAICA (Correct)PICA (Incorrect)SCA (Incorrect)PCA (Incorrect)
Vascular originBasilar artery → AICAVertebral artery → PICABasilar artery → SCABasilar artery → PCA
Supplied structuresLateral pons, middle cerebellar peduncle, inner earLateral medulla, inferior cerebellumSuperior cerebellum, superior cerebellar peduncleOccipital lobe, medial temporal lobe, thalamus
Key clinical signsIpsilateral facial paralysis, hearing loss, ataxiaDysphagia, hoarseness, loss of pain/temp in face & bodyLimb ataxia, dysmetriaHomonymous hemianopia, thalamic pain syndromes
Imaging patternWedge-shaped lateral pontine DWI hyperintensityDorsolateral medullary DWI hyperintensitySuperior cerebellar DWI hyperintensityOccipital cortical DWI hyperintensity

Clinical Pearls

1. AICA infarcts uniquely present with ipsilateral facial paralysis and sensorineural hearing loss due to involvement of the facial and vestibulocochlear nerve nuclei.
2. The labyrinthine artery branch of AICA explains acute vertigo and tinnitus; its occlusion constitutes an otoneurological emergency.
3. MRI-DWI is 83% sensitive and 95% specific for posterior fossa stroke within the first 24 hours; CT often misses small brainstem lesions.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing lateral medullary (PICA) with lateral pontine (AICA) syndrome; remember that facial nucleus signs only occur in AICA lesions.
2. Assuming all cerebellar artery strokes yield gross ataxia; small brainstem infarcts may yield subtle cranial nerve deficits without prominent cerebellar signs.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke
• Recommendation: Obtain MRI-DWI for suspected posterior fossa infarction when CT is non-diagnostic (Class I, LOE A).
• tPA recommended within 4.5 hours of symptom onset (Class I, LOE A).
2. 2021 European Stroke Organisation (ESO) Guidelines
• Recommendation: Consider endovascular thrombectomy for basilar artery occlusion up to 24 hours post-onset in selected patients (Class IIa, Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

AICA branches from the lower basilar artery to supply the lateral pons, including the facial nucleus (facial paralysis), vestibulocochlear nuclei (hearing/vertigo), spinal trigeminal nucleus (facial pain/temp), and the middle cerebellar peduncle (ataxia).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Occlusion of AICA leads to ischemia in the lateral pontine tegmentum. Neuronal energy failure triggers excitotoxicity and cytotoxic edema, manifesting as DWI hyperintensity within minutes of onset.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Rapid clinical assessment and NIH Stroke Scale
2. Noncontrast CT to exclude hemorrhage
3. MRI-DWI to localize infarct, especially in posterior fossa
4. CT/MR angiography to identify vessel occlusion (AICA vs vertebral vs basilar)

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Noncontrast CT often misses posterior fossa infarcts due to beam-hardening artifacts.
• MRI-DWI is the gold standard for early detection of brainstem and cerebellar strokes.
• CT angiography can visualize basilar artery and branch occlusions in the posterior circulation.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Intravenous alteplase (0.9 mg/kg, 10% bolus, remainder over 60 minutes) within 4.5 hours, unless contraindicated.
• Blood pressure management: keep ≤185/110 mm Hg pre- and ≤180/105 mm Hg post-thrombolysis.
• Consider antiplatelet agents 24 hours post-tPA if no hemorrhage.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2018 exam. Vascular territory localization via imaging is a frequent format on neurology boards, testing both anatomy and acute stroke management principles.

question_text: Q446. A young female with right ICA dissection shows a crescent shape on MRA. What is the treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] • Cervical artery dissection arises from a tear in the intimal layer of the internal carotid artery (ICA), allowing blood to accumulate intramurally, producing the “crescent sign” on fat-saturated MRA.
• Dissection predisposes to ischemic stroke via thromboembolism from the false lumen or hemodynamic compromise.
• First-line therapy employs antithrombotic agents (antiplatelets or anticoagulants) to prevent further emboli; invasive interventions are reserved for refractory cases or expanding pseudoaneurysms. (120 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Medical management with antithrombotic therapy is the standard of care for extracranial ICA dissection. The 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Stroke Prevention (Class I, Level A) recommend 3–6 months of antiplatelet or anticoagulation therapy to reduce recurrent stroke risk. The CADISS randomized trial (Lancet Neurol 2015) found no significant difference in recurrent ischemic events between antiplatelet and anticoagulation arms (1.0% vs. 0.3%, p=0.63), supporting either approach. Observational cohorts report a low annual recurrence (<2%) with medical therapy. Surgical repair or stenting carries procedural risks (arterial injury, in-stent thrombosis) and is typically reserved for symptomatic progression despite optimal medical therapy or for high-risk pseudoaneurysm morphology. Thrombolysis is used acutely within a narrow time window for established stroke, not prophylaxis against recurrent events in dissection without infarct.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Surgical repair
• Incorrect: Reserved for expanding pseudoaneurysm or failed medical therapy.
• Misconception: That immediate resolution of dissection requires open surgery.
• Differentiator: Higher morbidity; not first-line absent complication.

C. Endovascular stenting
• Incorrect: Considered only if medical therapy fails or severe stenosis with hemodynamic compromise.
• Misconception: Stenting universally prevents emboli.
• Differentiator: Procedural stroke risk and need for dual antiplatelet therapy.

D. Thrombolytic therapy
• Incorrect: Indicated acutely for ischemic stroke <4.5 h after onset, not for dissection without acute infarct.
• Misconception: Thrombolysis dissolves intramural hematoma.
• Differentiator: Risk of hemorrhage in vessel wall; not prophylactic.

Comparison Table

Treatment ModalityIndicationEvidenceKey Risks
Medical managementPrimary prophylaxis post-dissectionAHA/ASA Class I (Level A), CADISSBleeding (if anticoagulated)
Surgical repairExpanding pseudoaneurysm; failed medicalCase series onlyCranial nerve injury, restenosis
Endovascular stentingRefractory ischemia, severe stenosisObservational; no RCTsIn-stent thrombosis, dissection
Thrombolytic therapyAcute ischemic stroke <4.5 h of onsetNINDS, ECASSHemorrhagic transformation

Clinical Pearls

• On fat-sat MRA, the crescentic intramural hematoma appears hyperintense; confirm with CTA or duplex ultrasound.
• Antiplatelet therapy (e.g., aspirin 81–325 mg) is often preferred over warfarin due to lower bleeding risk.
• Duration of antithrombotic therapy is typically 3–6 months, followed by imaging to assess vessel healing.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating dissection treatment with acute stroke thrombolysis, leading to inappropriate tPA use.
2. Overutilizing invasive procedures in the absence of clinical or radiographic progression.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA Guidelines on Cervical Artery Dissection 2019: Recommend antithrombotic therapy for 3–6 months (Class I, Level A).
• CADISS Trial (Lancet Neurol 2015): No significant difference between antiplatelet vs. anticoagulation for preventing recurrence (n=250, randomized).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The extracranial ICA courses from the carotid bifurcation in the neck (C1 segment) to the petrous segment (C2); dissections typically occur in the cervical portion where the artery is more mobile.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Intimal tear allows blood into the media, forming a false lumen that compresses the true lumen (crescent sign). Thrombus forms at the disrupted intima, serving as a source for distal emboli.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect dissection in young patients with neck pain or Horner syndrome.
2. Perform noninvasive imaging: CTA or MRA with fat saturation.
3. Confirm intramural hematoma (“crescent sign”) and assess flow compromise.
4. Initiate antithrombotic therapy; follow-up imaging at 3–6 months.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Fat-saturated T1-weighted MRA highlights subacute hematoma as high signal circumferentially. CTA shows an eccentric mural thickening with luminal stenosis or pseudoaneurysm.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Aspirin 81–325 mg daily is first‐line; alternatives include clopidogrel 75 mg daily or warfarin (INR 2.0–3.0) when anticoagulation is chosen. Monitor for bleeding; no direct comparisons in large RCTs beyond CADISS.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam.
ICA dissection management is frequently tested as single‐best‐answer scenarios, emphasizing first‐line antithrombotic therapy and imaging characteristics.

question_text: A patient with a minor stroke (NIHSS 3) presents with decreased sensation on the left side and mild facial weakness. Within the treatment window, what is the next step?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] - Ischemic stroke severity is stratified using the NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS); scores ≤3 define “minor” strokes.
• Intravenous thrombolysis (alteplase) is indicated for disabling deficits within 4.5 hours, but may be withheld in non-disabling minor strokes.
• Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) initiated within 24 hours and continued for ~21 days reduces early recurrence in minor non-disabling AIS (POINT, CHANCE trials).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) is correct. The 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines (Class IIa, LOE B-R) recommend DAPT for 21 days in minor (NIHSS ≤3) non-disabling ischemic stroke when started within 24 hours to prevent recurrence (Johnston et al., 2018 POINT trial; Wang et al., 2013 CHANCE trial). In contrast, alteplase is reserved for disabling strokes—sensory deficits alone and mild facial weakness generally do not qualify as disabling. Mechanical thrombectomy is indicated only for large vessel occlusions within 6 hours (or select patients to 24 hours). Aspirin monotherapy is inferior to DAPT for early secondary prevention in this population.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. tPA
• Why incorrect: Indicated for disabling deficits; this patient’s symptoms (mild sensory loss, facial weakness) are non-disabling.
• Misconception: “Any stroke within window gets tPA” ignores disability assessment.
• Differentiator: Disability vs non-disabling minor deficits.

C. Aspirin
• Why incorrect: Aspirin alone reduces recurrence less effectively than DAPT in first 21 days post–minor stroke (POINT: HR 0.68 for DAPT).
• Misconception: Monotherapy sufficient for all AIS.
• Differentiator: Superior early reduction of recurrence with DAPT.

D. Mechanical thrombectomy
• Why incorrect: Reserved for large vessel occlusion (ICA/M1) with moderate–severe deficits; minor strokes without imaging evidence of LVO do not qualify.
• Misconception: All ischemic strokes benefit from mechanical clot retrieval.
• Differentiator: Vessel occlusion location and NIHSS threshold ≥6–8.

Comparison Table

FeatureDAPT (Correct)tPAAspirin MonotherapyThrombectomy
MechanismADP-receptor blockade (clopidogrel) + COX-1 inhibitionPlasminogen → plasmin activationCOX-1 inhibitionMechanical clot removal
IndicationMinor non-disabling AIS ≤3, within 24 hDisabling AIS within 4.5 hSecondary prevention (long-term)LVO AIS within 6 h (select to 24 h)
Key Trials/GuidelinesPOINT (2018), CHANCE (2013); AHA/ASA 2019 IIa B-RNINDS (1995), ECASS IIIIST (1997)MR CLEAN, ESCAPE, SWIFT PRIME
Duration21 daysSingle infusionIndefiniteSingle procedure

Clinical Pearls

- Initiate DAPT within 24 hours in minor non-disabling AIS (NIHSS ≤3) for 21 days to halve early recurrence.
• Assess disability (not just NIHSS score) when deciding on thrombolysis; isolated sensory loss often non-disabling.
• After 21 days of DAPT, transition to monotherapy (aspirin or clopidogrel) to minimize bleeding risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Administering tPA for any stroke within the window without assessing disability.
2. Prescribing aspirin alone for acute minor stroke despite evidence favoring short-term DAPT.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines for Early Management of AIS: Class IIa recommendation (LOE B-R) for DAPT in minor non-disabling stroke within 24 h.
• POINT trial (NEJM 2018): DAPT reduced 90-day recurrent stroke (5.0% vs 6.5%; HR 0.68, 95% CI 0.51–0.91) when initiated within 12 h.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesion likely involves the right post-central gyrus (primary somatosensory cortex) causing contralateral hemisensory loss, and adjacent lower precentral gyrus affecting facial motor fibers—both small cortical branch ischemia of the MCA.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Acute thromboembolic occlusion of a distal MCA branch leads to focal neuronal ischemia. Mild deficits reflect limited penumbral involvement and justify aggressive antiplatelet prophylaxis rather than full-dose fibrinolysis.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. NIHSS assessment to quantify severity and disability.
2. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
3. CT angiography if LVO suspected.
4. Determine reperfusion vs antiplatelet strategy based on disability and vessel status.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Early ischemic changes in minor stroke may be subtle on CT; MRI DWI is more sensitive for small cortical infarcts but not required before DAPT initiation.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Dosing: Aspirin 75–100 mg daily + clopidogrel 75 mg daily after 300 mg loading; continue for 21 days, then single-agent therapy.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. It tests recognition of minor non-disabling stroke management per AHA/ASA guidelines and POINT/CHANCE trial data. Frequent in board questions are NIHSS thresholds for therapy, DAPT indications and duration, and distinguishing disabling vs non-disabling deficits.

question_text: A patient with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) presents with a right superficial borderzone infarction in the MCA/ACA territory. What is the next investigation?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Borderzone (watershed) infarcts occur at the junctional zones between major cerebral arteries (e.g., ACA–MCA) due to hypoperfusion or proximal stenosis. ESRD accelerates intracranial atherosclerosis via chronic inflammation and uremia, making intracranial vessel stenosis a leading cause of watershed strokes in this population. Noninvasive vascular imaging modalities differ in territory covered: CTA/MRA visualize intracranial vessels directly, whereas carotid Doppler is limited to extracranial arteries. In hemodynamic infarcts, identifying proximal intracranial stenosis guides further management. ESRD patients on dialysis can generally tolerate iodinated contrast with proper timing and supportive measures.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Brain CT angiography (CTA) is the optimal next step because it rapidly and noninvasively depicts intracranial arterial stenoses that underlie hemodynamic (borderzone) infarcts.
• AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines (Class I, Level B): CTA is recommended as first-line intracranial vascular imaging in acute ischemic stroke to detect large-vessel stenosis or occlusion.
• Wong et al. (Stroke 2007): ESRD patients have a fourfold increased prevalence of intracranial atherosclerosis versus extracranial disease.
• Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is the gold standard but is invasive, with higher risk (0.5–2% risk of stroke), and reserved for interventional planning or inconclusive noninvasive studies (Class IIa).
• Carotid Doppler ultrasound assesses extracranial carotid bifurcation but misses intracranial pathology.
• Cardiac echocardiography evaluates cardioembolic sources but is low yield in purely hemodynamic infarcts.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Conventional angiography
– Incorrect: Invasive with procedural stroke risk; reserved when noninvasive CTA/MRA findings are equivocal or intervention is planned.
– Misconception: “Angiography is always needed for definitive diagnosis.” Noninvasive CTA suffices initially.

C. Carotid Doppler ultrasound
– Incorrect: Only images extracranial carotid and vertebral arteries; cannot detect intracranial MCA/ACA stenosis causing borderzone infarction.
– Misconception: “All stroke patients need carotid ultrasound first.” This overlooks intracranial disease.

D. Cardiac echocardiography
– Incorrect: Targeted at cardioembolic sources (e.g., atrial thrombus, valvular lesions), but watershed infarcts are usually hemodynamic, not embolic.
– Misconception: “Stroke workup always begins with echocardiogram.” Stroke subtype guides imaging choice.

Comparison Table

ModalityVessels AssessedInvasivenessUtility for ACA/MCA BorderzoneMain Risks
Brain CT angiographyIntracranial arteriesNoninvasiveExcellent for proximal stenosisContrast nephrotoxicity (manageable in ESRD), radiation
Conventional angiographyIntra- & extracranialInvasiveGold standard resolution; reservedProcedural stroke, bleeding
Carotid Doppler ultrasoundExtracranial carotidsNoninvasiveCannot assess intracranial stenosisOperator-dependent
Cardiac echocardiographyCardiac chambers/valvesNoninvasiveUnrelated to hemodynamic stenosisNone (minimal)

Clinical Pearls

- ESRD patients have higher rates of intracranial rather than extracranial atherosclerosis; prioritize intracranial imaging.
• Borderzone infarcts classically indicate hemodynamic compromise; noninvasive vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) is the first diagnostic step.
• Dialysis scheduling around contrast administration can mitigate concerns about contrast-induced nephropathy in ESRD.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering carotid Doppler as a standalone vascular study in watershed infarcts, missing intracranial disease.
2. Proceeding directly to invasive angiography without first using noninvasive CTA/MRA, exposing patients to unnecessary procedural risks.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommends CTA as first-line vascular imaging (Class I, Level B).
• ESO (European Stroke Organisation) 2021 Guidelines: Endorses noninvasive CTA/MRA for detection of intracranial stenosis over ultrasound in suspected intracranial atherosclerosis (Strong Recommendation, Level A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Watershed zones lie between the distal fields of the ACA and MCA territories, particularly the cortical borderzone over the lateral convexity. Proximal ACA or MCA stenosis reduces perfusion pressure in these distal fields, leading to laminar infarction.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic uremia and dysregulated calcium–phosphate metabolism in ESRD promote endothelial dysfunction and accelerated intracranial atherosclerosis. Resultant arterial stenoses impair cerebral perfusion reserve; borderline hypotension or reduced cardiac output precipitates watershed infarction.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT/MRI to confirm infarct pattern.
2. Perform noninvasive intracranial vascular imaging (CTA or MRA).
3. If CTA inconclusive or endovascular therapy considered, proceed to conventional angiography.
4. Evaluate extracranial carotids if borderzone infarct accompanied by extracranial symptoms.
5. Reserve echocardiography for patients with lacunar or embolic patterns or when noninvasive vascular studies are unrevealing.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CTA source images can show “contrast cutoff” at a stenotic segment; multiplanar reconstructions improve visualization in ACA/MCA segments.
• CT perfusion adjunctively demonstrates prolonged time-to-peak and mean transit time in watershed regions, corroborating hypoperfusion.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. On board exams, watershed infarctions in high-risk populations (e.g., ESRD) are frequently tested to assess understanding of hemodynamic versus embolic stroke mechanisms and appropriate imaging strategies.

question_text: Q266. What is the artery involved in a case of unconsciousness with CT brain findings?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] • Vascular territories: The PCA supplies the occipital lobes, inferior temporal lobes, thalami, and midbrain.
• Reticular activating system (RAS): Consciousness depends on RAS integrity in the midbrain and thalami.
• Artery of Percheron variant: A single thalamoperforating branch from the PCA can infarct both paramedian thalami, leading to sudden coma.

(Word count: 67)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Bilateral paramedian thalamic infarcts due to occlusion of the artery of Percheron, a variant branch of the PCA, classically present with profound unconsciousness. Non-contrast CT may show symmetric hypodensities in both thalami within hours of onset (Schmahmann et al., 2003). Diffusion-weighted MRI confirms the diagnosis with high sensitivity. The PCA arises from the basilar artery bifurcation and gives off small perforators to the medial thalami and rostral midbrain; occlusion here disrupts the intralaminar nuclei and RAS, causing coma (Percheron, 1973). AHA/ASA guidelines (Powers et al., 2019; Class I, Level B-R) recommend emergent vascular imaging in unexplained coma to identify posterior circulation occlusions. Early recognition enables timely reperfusion—IV alteplase within 4.5 hours or endovascular thrombectomy up to 6 hours (or longer in select posterior strokes per BASICS trial, JAMA Neurol 2021).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. MCA
• MCA strokes produce contralateral hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, aphasia or neglect, but spare consciousness since RAS is preserved.
• Misconception: large cortical strokes always cause coma—only massive hemispheric edema can herniate.

C. Anterior choroidal artery
• Supplies posterior limb of internal capsule, optic tract, hippocampus; infarction causes pure motor/sensory or visual field defects, not coma.
• Misconception: “choroidal” implies deep thalamic involvement; actually spares intralaminar thalamic nuclei.

D. Basilar artery
• Basilar occlusion causes coma via brainstem ischemia; however, CT without angiography often appears normal or shows hyperdense basilar sign but not bilateral thalamic hypodensities.
• Differentiating feature: basilar occlusion yields locked-in syndrome or crossed signs, whereas artery of Percheron infarct localizes to thalami.

Comparison Table

FeaturePCA (Artery of Percheron)MCAAnterior ChoroidalBasilar Artery
TerritoryParamedian thalami, midbrainLateral frontal/parietal lobesPosterior limb internal capsulePons, cerebellum, midbrain
Key clinical signSudden coma, vertical gaze palsyHemiparesis, aphasia, neglectPure motor/sensory strokeComa ± locked-in, cranial nerve signs
CT findingsBilateral thalamic hypodensitiesCortical/subcortical hypodensityInternal capsule lacuneOften normal; hyperdense basilar sign
Time to reperfusion window4.5–6 hrs (IV tPA, thrombectomy)4.5 hrs IV tPA; 6–24 hrs thrombectomy4.5 hrs IV tPAUp to 6 hrs, extended in trials

Clinical Pearls

• Bilateral paramedian thalamic infarcts in an unconscious patient are pathognomonic for an artery of Percheron variant (PCA branch).
• Always perform CT angiography in unexplained coma to detect posterior circulation occlusions, even if non-contrast CT is non-diagnostic.
• Vertical gaze palsy and memory impairment can accompany thalamic strokes—look beyond motor deficits.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming MCA occlusion causes unconsciousness—MCA strokes rarely disrupt the RAS.
2. Overlooking artery of Percheron infarction because it lacks cortical signs; absence of hemiparesis does not exclude a devastating stroke.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2019 Acute Ischemic Stroke Guidelines (Powers et al.): Class I, Level B-R recommendation for CTA/MRA in posterior circulation strokes to guide reperfusion.
• BASICS Trial (JAMA Neurol 2021): Endovascular therapy for basilar artery occlusion showed improved functional outcomes when treated within 6–24 hours; suggests extended windows for posterior strokes.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Paramedian thalamic perforators from the PCA supply the mediodorsal nucleus and intralaminar nuclei, integral to consciousness. The RAS ascends through these nuclei to the cortex.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Arterial occlusion → loss of thalamic perfusion → failure of intralaminar nuclei → disruption of RAS → sudden coma. Cytotoxic edema ensues within minutes, visible on diffusion MRI.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Unconscious patient → secure airway, breathing, circulation
2. Non-contrast CT to exclude hemorrhage
3. CT angiography to assess posterior circulation
4. MRI DWI if CT equivocal
5. Initiate IV thrombolysis or thrombectomy per findings

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Bilateral symmetric thalamic low attenuation on CT suggests artery of Percheron infarct.
• Hyperdense basilar sign on non-contrast CT indicates basilar thrombosis but requires CTA confirmation.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Posterior circulation strokes—especially artery of Percheron infarctions—are high-yield for neurovascular localization questions on board exams.
