Normal-pressure hydrocephalus can present with gait disturbance but is distinguished by enlarged ventricles out of proportion to sulcal atrophy and may respond to shunting. Recognizing imaging correlates and risk factor profiles is essential to tailor therapy and avoid unnecessary interventions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Treating vascular risk factors is the cornerstone of managing vascular parkinsonism. A meta-analysis by Benamer et al. (Movement Disorders, 2018) found levodopa responsiveness in only 13% of cases. The AHA/ASA 2021 Guidelines for Secondary Stroke Prevention (Class I, Level A) recommend intensive blood pressure control (<130/80 mm Hg) and glycemic management (HbA1c <7%) to slow small vessel disease progression. European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 guidelines similarly emphasize antiplatelet therapy and statins to reduce recurrent infarction and leukoaraiosis burden. Imaging here demonstrates ex vacuo ventriculomegaly rather than communicating hydrocephalus; shunting offers no benefit and carries procedural risks. While physiotherapy supports mobility, it does not modify the underlying ischemic pathology.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. VP shunt
– Ventriculomegaly is due to cortical atrophy (“ex vacuo”), not NPH. NPH requires ventriculomegaly disproportionate to sulci, positive tap test, and clinical triad. Misconception: any enlarged ventricles warrant shunting.

C. Start levodopa
– Vascular parkinsonism reflects postsynaptic receptor loss from lacunar infarcts; levodopa response is poor (~10–20%). Misconception: all parkinsonism responds to dopaminergic therapy.

D. Refer for physiotherapy
– While gait training improves function, it does not address cerebrovascular lesions. Overreliance on rehabilitation delays critical risk factor optimization.

Comparison Table

FeatureTreat Vascular Risk FactorsVP ShuntLevodopaPhysiotherapy
IndicationSecondary prevention of small vessel diseaseNormal-pressure hydrocephalusIdiopathic dopaminergic deficiencySupportive motor therapy
MechanismLowers BP, glycemia, cholesterolDiverts CSF to peritoneumDopamine precursorExercise and gait retraining
Evidence of efficacyAHA/ASA 2021 Class I; ESO 2021 Level BClass I in NPH (not ex vacuo cases)Response in ~13% (Benamer et al.)Improves safety, not pathology
Imaging correlationLeukoaraiosis, lacunesVentriculomegaly with tight sulciNo specific imaging correlateApplicable to all parkinsonisms

Clinical Pearls

1. Vascular parkinsonism often presents with discrete gait freezing and predominant lower limb bradykinesia, unlike the asymmetric arm tremor of idiopathic Parkinson’s disease.
2. Confluent periventricular white matter hyperintensities (“leukoaraiosis”) on T2/FLAIR MRI strongly support a vascular etiology; ex vacuo ventriculomegaly reflects atrophy, not shunt-responsive hydrocephalus.
3. Dopaminergic therapy yields low response rates; first-line treatment is strict control of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia to slow progression and prevent recurrent strokes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misinterpreting ex vacuo ventriculomegaly as normal-pressure hydrocephalus and recommending shunting without assessing sulcal patterns or CSF dynamics.
2. Assuming robust levodopa responsiveness in all parkinsonian syndromes, ignoring distinct vascular pathophysiology impairing postsynaptic dopamine receptors.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2021 Guideline on Secondary Stroke Prevention
– Recommends blood pressure target <130/80 mm Hg (Class I, Level A) and glycemic control (HbA1c <7%) in patients with ischemic cerebrovascular disease.
2. ESO 2021 Guidelines for Cerebral Small Vessel Disease
– Advocates antiplatelet therapy (aspirin 75–100 mg daily) and statin use (atorvastatin ≥40 mg) to reduce progression of leukoaraiosis and lacunar infarcts (Strong recommendation, Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Chronic small vessel ischemia affects perforating branches of the lenticulostriate arteries, damaging the striatum, globus pallidus, and connecting white matter tracts. Disruption of the basal ganglia–thalamocortical motor loop manifests as bradykinesia and gait impairment.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Hypertensive and diabetic arteriolar hyalinosis leads to lacunar infarcts and diffuse demyelination in subcortical white matter. Loss of striatal neurons and their dopaminergic synapses underlies the poor response to levodopa.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: symmetric lower limb bradykinesia, gait freezing.
2. MRI brain: identify leukoaraiosis, lacunes, assess ventricle-to-sulci ratio.
3. Differentiate from NPH: evaluate clinical triad, perform large-volume lumbar tap test if indicated.
4. Trial of low-dose levodopa to assess response.
5. Initiate secondary stroke prevention: BP, glycemic, lipid control, antiplatelet therapy.

Neuroimaging Pearls

T2/FLAIR sequences reveal confluent periventricular hyperintensities. Ex vacuo ventriculomegaly shows enlarged ventricles with widened sulci, in contrast to NPH where subarachnoid spaces at convexity are diminished.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No specific symptomatic agents for vascular parkinsonism beyond an occasionally trialed low-dose levodopa. Primary pharmacologic strategy involves antiplatelet agents (aspirin 75–100 mg daily), high-intensity statins (e.g., atorvastatin 40 mg), and ACE inhibitors or thiazides for blood pressure control.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Vascular parkinsonism is frequently tested via clinical vignettes requiring differentiation from idiopathic Parkinson’s disease and normal-pressure hydrocephalus; emphasis is placed on imaging interpretation and management strategies centering on vascular risk factor modification.

question_text: A patient presents with right‐sided weakness; a noncontrast CT scan shows a left basal ganglia intraparenchymal hemorrhage with a 3 mm midline shift. What should you do?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is most often secondary to chronic hypertension causing rupture of small perforating arteries in the basal ganglia. Key concepts:
1. Mass effect (midline shift) and hematoma volume predict neurological deterioration and mortality.
2. Deep hemorrhages (basal ganglia, thalamus) rarely benefit from surgical evacuation; benefit is confined to superficial lobar or cerebellar bleeds with >1 cm surface proximity or >3 cm diameter.
3. Hematoma expansion occurs in the first hours; rapid blood‐pressure (BP) reduction reduces expansion risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Craniotomy
– Deep basal ganglia hemorrhages are inaccessible without significant tissue disruption; STICH II failed to show mortality/morbidity benefit in deep ICH.
– Misconception: “All ICH require evacuation.” In reality, only superficial lobar or cerebellar bleeds with mass effect.

B. Give LMWH
– Therapeutic anticoagulation exacerbates bleeding; anticoagulants are contraindicated in acute ICH.
– Misconception: Prophylaxis against venous thromboembolism outweighs bleeding risk in the hyperacute phase.

D. Monitor in intensive care unit
– While ICU-level monitoring is required, passive observation without aggressive BP control misses the therapeutic window to limit hematoma expansion.
– Misconception: Monitoring alone suffices for stable‐appearing ICH; neglects elevated rebleed risk.

Comparison Table

OptionIndicationMechanism/RationaleDrawback
CraniotomySurgical clot evacuationDirect removal of massNo proven benefit in deep ICH; high procedural risk
Give LMWHAnticoagulation prophylaxisPrevents DVTPromotes hematoma expansion; contraindicated
Start intravenous antihypertensivesAcute ICH with elevated BPReduces hematoma growth and intracranial pressureRequires titration and close monitoring
Monitor in intensive care unitGeneral supportive careContinuous vital sign and neurologic status monitoringDoes not actively limit hematoma expansion

Clinical Pearls

• Rapid SBP reduction to ~140 mm Hg within the first hour is safe and may improve functional outcome.
• Location matters: basal ganglia hemorrhages are managed medically; lobar hemorrhages (<1 cm from cortex) may benefit from surgery if large.
• Midline shift <5 mm without herniation signs usually indicates medical management rather than urgent decompression.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Believing any midline shift mandates craniotomy—shift threshold for surgery in supratentorial ICH is generally >5 mm with herniation.
2. Delaying BP control because the patient appears “stable”—hematoma expansion risk is highest in the first 3 h.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA ICH Guidelines 2015: Class I recommendation to lower SBP to 140 mm Hg in patients presenting with SBP 150–220 mm Hg (Level A evidence).
2. INTERACT-2 (Lancet Neurol 2013): Intensive SBP lowering to <140 mm Hg safe, trends toward reduced death/disability (ordinal analysis p=0.02).
3. ATACH-2 (NEJM 2016): No additional benefit for SBP target <120 mm Hg vs <140 mm Hg; higher renal adverse events in ultra-intensive group.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

A basal ganglia hemorrhage typically involves the putamen and may extend into the internal capsule, disrupting corticospinal fibers and causing contralateral hemiparesis.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic hypertension leads to lipohyalinosis and Charcot‐Bouchard microaneurysm formation in small perforating arteries; their rupture produces intraparenchymal hemorrhage and mass effect.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Stabilize airway, breathing, circulation
2. Noncontrast head CT to confirm ICH, location, volume, shift
3. Initiate IV antihypertensives to target SBP 140 mm Hg
4. Neurosurgical consultation for lobar/cerebellar bleeds or signs of herniation
5. ICU monitoring with serial neuro checks and repeat imaging as indicated

Neuroimaging Pearls

Noncontrast CT is first‐line: acute blood appears hyperdense; midline shift quantifies mass effect—>5 mm often correlates with raised intracranial pressure and herniation risk.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Nicardipine infusion: start at 5 mg/h, increase by 2.5 mg/h every 5–15 minutes up to 15 mg/h to achieve SBP ~140 mm Hg. Labetalol bolus (10–20 mg IV) is an alternative.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Acute management of intracerebral hemorrhage—particularly BP targets and surgical indications—is a high‐yield, frequently tested topic on neurology boards.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is A. Craniotomy. This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

question_text: Q55. A patient with an anterior communicating artery aneurysm, what is the most important risk factor for rupture?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Intracranial aneurysms are saccular dilations at arterial bifurcations, most commonly at the anterior communicating artery (ACom). Hemodynamic stress and endothelial dysfunction lead to focal arterial wall degradation. Rupture risk is governed by wall tension (per Laplace’s law), which increases proportionally with aneurysm radius and inversely with wall thickness. While systemic factors such as smoking and hypertension compromise vessel integrity and contribute to aneurysm formation, longitudinal natural history studies consistently identify aneurysm diameter as the single strongest predictor of subarachnoid hemorrhage. Effective clinical management balances size thresholds against patient-specific factors to decide on prophylactic intervention versus surveillance.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Size drives rupture risk most robustly. In the International Study of Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms (ISUIA, 2003), 5-year cumulative rupture rates for anterior circulation aneurysms were:
• <7 mm: 0.05%
• 7–12 mm: 2.6%
• >12 mm: 14.5%
The Unruptured Cerebral Aneurysm Study of Japan (UCAS Japan, 2013) found an adjusted hazard ratio of 10.4 (95% CI 3.34–32.3) for aneurysms >7 mm versus <3 mm. AHA/ASA Guidelines (2015) recommend considering repair of anterior circulation aneurysms >7 mm (Class IIb; Level B). Mechanistically, larger aneurysms accrue higher wall tension (T = P × r/(2 w)), promoting focal wall thinning and rupture.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Smoking
Although smoking elevates aneurysm formation and rupture risk (relative risk ~1.8), its independent effect is modest compared to size. Smoking exacerbates wall inflammation but does not determine size‐related wall tension.

C. Hypertension
Chronic hypertension increases transmural pressure and contributes to aneurysm genesis, but multivariate analyses show only a minor independent effect on rupture risk (HR ~1.3). When controlling for diameter, hypertension is not a primary rupture predictor.

D. Family history of aneurysms
A familial predisposition raises aneurysm formation and multiplicity rates but does not directly influence rupture probability. Family history guides screening rather than rupture risk stratification.

Comparison Table

FeatureSize (Correct)SmokingHypertensionFamily History
Rupture risk correlationStrong; exponential increase with sizeModerate; RR ~1.5–2.0Minor; HR ~1.2–1.4Minimal direct effect
Annual rupture rate (<7 mm)≤0.5%≤0.7% (smoker vs non-smoker)Slight increase if uncontrolledUnchanged
Guideline intervention criteria>7 mm (Class IIb; Level B)No specific thresholdBP control advised; no size criteriaNot used for intervention decision

Clinical Pearls

- Laplace’s law (Tension = Pressure × Radius / (2 × Wall thickness)) underpins why small increases in aneurysm radius sharply raise wall tension.
• ACom aneurysms, although anterior, warrant the same size‐based risk stratification as other anterior circulation aneurysms.
• Aneurysms <5 mm in asymptomatic, low‐risk patients often undergo serial imaging and aggressive risk factor management rather than immediate repair.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overemphasizing systemic factors (e.g., hypertension) and underestimating morphological predictors like diameter.
2. Confusing risk factors for aneurysm formation (family history) with drivers of rupture, leading to misprioritized management.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA “Guideline for the Management of Patients With Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms” (American Heart Association/American Stroke Association, 2015): Recommends consideration of prophylactic repair for anterior circulation aneurysms exceeding 7 mm (Class IIb; Level B).
• Unruptured Cerebral Aneurysm Study of Japan (UCAS Japan, 2013): Prospective cohort showing aneurysms >7 mm carry an adjusted HR of 10.4 (95% CI 3.34–32.3) for rupture compared to those <3 mm, reinforcing diameter as the primary risk factor.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. On board examinations, aneurysm rupture risk topics frequently appear in single-best-answer and vignette formats, with emphasis on size thresholds, key longitudinal studies (ISUIA, UCAS Japan), and guideline-based management criteria.

question_text: An elderly man with diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and a history of coronary artery bypass grafting presents with progressive dementia over 6 months and falls. On examination, he has Parkinson’s signs in the distal lower limb and limited vertical gaze. An MRI shows ischemic changes. What is the diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a 4R‐tauopathy presenting with early postural instability, vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, and frontal cognitive dysfunction. Key neuroanatomical structures include the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (riMLF) and midbrain tegmentum, whose degeneration leads to slowed vertical saccades and downgaze limitation. Vascular parkinsonism features lower‐body–predominant bradykinesia and gait freezing due to subcortical ischemic lesions but spares vertical gaze. Dementia with Lewy bodies presents with visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition, and marked levodopa sensitivity. Multiple system atrophy shows autonomic failure, cerebellar signs, and poor levodopa response. (Word count: 142)

Evidence-Based Analysis

PSP diagnosis hinges on early falls (<1 year), vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, axial rigidity, and cognitive slowing. The Movement Disorder Society (MDS) 2017 criteria designate “probable PSP‐Richardson syndrome” when vertical supranuclear gaze palsy or slowing of vertical saccades is present plus postural instability. Despite coexisting vascular risk factors and ischemic MRI changes common in the elderly, true vertical gaze limitation is pathognomonic for PSP, not vascular parkinsonism. Midbrain atrophy on sagittal MRI (“hummingbird sign”) further supports PSP (Quinn et al., Neurology 2017). Levodopa trials yield minimal benefit (<20% transient improvement), reflecting predominant tau pathology ( Spillantini & Goedert, Lancet Neurol 2013).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Vascular parkinsonism
• Lacks supranuclear gaze palsy; gait disturbance is feet‐predominant, not early vertical gaze restriction.
• Misconception: white matter hyperintensities equal vascular parkinsonism; ignores hallmark eye movement abnormality.
• Differentiator: preserved ocular motility vs. PSP’s gaze palsy.

C. Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB)
• Core features: visual hallucinations, cognitive fluctuations, severe REM‐sleep behavior disorder; absent here.
• Misconception: any dementia plus parkinsonism equals DLB; vertical gaze impairment is not a Lewy body sign.
• Differentiator: DLB has early visual hallucinations and pronounced cholinergic deficits (supportive DAT scan).

D. Multiple system atrophy (MSA)
• Presents with autonomic failure (orthostatic hypotension, urinary incontinence), cerebellar signs; neither described.
• Misconception: MSA can present as parkinsonism with falls; but early vertical gaze palsy is not typical.
• Differentiator: autonomic involvement and cerebellar ataxia vs. supranuclear gaze palsy.

Comparison Table

FeaturePSP (Correct)Vascular ParkinsonismDLBMSA
Vertical supranuclear palsyYesNoNoNo
Early falls (<1 year)YesPossible but gait freezing onlyRare early fallsPossible but due to ataxia/autonomic
Levodopa responsePoor (<20% transient)MinimalGood to moderatePoor
MRI findingsMidbrain atrophy (“hummingbird”)White matter ischemiaOccipital hypometabolism (PET)Putaminal slit, pontine atrophy
Autonomic failureRareNoNoYes

Clinical Pearls

- Early postural instability with vertical gaze palsy is almost pathognomonic for PSP.
• Midbrain atrophy on midsagittal MRI (“hummingbird” or “penguin silhouette”) is a supportive imaging marker.
• Levodopa challenge in PSP yields limited benefit; trial duration 4–6 weeks is sufficient to assess response.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overcalling vascular parkinsonism in any elderly patient with white matter changes, without assessing eye movements.
2. Misattributing early falls exclusively to cerebellar or basal ganglia disease without considering supranuclear gaze palsy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Movement Disorder Society, Diagnostic Criteria for PSP (2017): Defines “probable PSP” by vertical supranuclear gaze palsy or saccade slowing plus early postural instability; Level B evidence.
2. Boxer AL et al., Phase II BIIB092 (gosuranemab) trial in PSP (Ann Neurol, 2020): Monoclonal anti‐tau antibody failed to slow progression; underscores unmet need for disease‐modifying therapy; Phase II RCT, Level IIA evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of the midbrain tegmentum, especially the riMLF and interstitial nucleus of Cajal, impairs vertical saccade generation. Subthalamic nucleus and globus pallidus degeneration contribute to axial rigidity and frontal executive dysfunction.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PSP is a primary 4‐repeat tauopathy: abnormal hyperphosphorylated tau aggregates in neurons and glia (tufted astrocytes), leading to neurofibrillary tangles in midbrain and basal ganglia, manifesting clinically as gaze palsy and postural instability.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: early falls, vertical gaze limitation, cognitive slowing.
2. Neurological exam: confirm supranuclear vertical gaze palsy.
3. MRI brain: assess midbrain atrophy (“hummingbird sign”), rule out alternative causes.
4. Levodopa trial: document response (<20% improvement supports PSP).
5. Apply MDS‐PSP criteria for certainty.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Sagittal T1‐weighted MRI showing selective atrophy of the midbrain tegmentum with preserved pons (“hummingbird”) yields sensitivity ~75% and specificity ~90% for PSP.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No approved disease-modifying agents; symptomatic management with amantadine (100–300 mg/day) may modestly improve gait. Levodopa up to 1,000 mg/day for bradykinesia yields limited transient benefit; monitor for dyskinesias.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. Atypical parkinsonian syndromes are frequently tested in conjunction with eye movement abnormalities and imaging correlates. Vertical supranuclear gaze palsy is a high‐yield sign distinguishing PSP from vascular parkinsonism.

question_text: Another patient presented with acute stroke; noncontrast CT showed watershed infarction; what is the next step in diagnostic workup?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Watershed infarcts occur at border‐zone regions between major cerebral arteries, most often between the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) and middle cerebral artery (MCA) territories or between MCA and posterior cerebral artery (PCA). These infarcts typically reflect hemodynamic compromise from hypotension or high‐grade proximal stenosis/occlusion. Rapid vascular imaging is essential to identify treatable large‐vessel stenosis, guide hemodynamic management, and evaluate eligibility for reperfusion strategies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Computed tomography angiography (CTA) is the preferred next step:
• The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke (Class I, Level A) recommend emergent CTA (or MRA) immediately after noncontrast CT to assess for large‐vessel occlusion or high‐grade stenosis.
• CTA provides rapid, high‐resolution visualization of both intracranial and extracranial circulation in under 5 minutes, facilitating decisions on endovascular therapy or carotid revascularization.
• Prospective studies (e.g., the MR CLEAN trial ancillary imaging analyses, 2015) demonstrated that patients with proximal carotid or MCA occlusion benefit most when identified quickly by CTA.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRI brain
• Why incorrect: Although diffusion‐weighted MRI is more sensitive for acute ischemia, it is time‐consuming, less available in many EDs, and does not reliably detect vessel patency without additional MRA sequences.
• Misconception: Belief that MRI must precede any vascular study; delays critical revascularization decisions.
• Differentiator: CTA completes both parenchymal and vascular assessment rapidly.

C. Echocardiography
• Why incorrect: Transthoracic or transesophageal echo assesses cardioembolic sources (e.g., PFO, left ventricular thrombus) but does not evaluate cervical/intracranial arteries.
• Misconception: Assuming cardioembolism is the most common cause of watershed infarcts.
• Differentiator: Watershed infarcts primarily reflect hemodynamic issues, not embolic.

D. Carotid Doppler ultrasound
• Why incorrect: Limited to extracranial carotid arteries, operator‐dependent, and cannot visualize intracranial vessels or assess distal MCA/PCA stenosis.
• Misconception: That carotid Doppler is sufficient to rule out large‐vessel disease.
• Differentiator: CTA images both extracranial and intracranial beds in one study.

Comparison Table

FeatureCTAMRI brainEchocardiographyCarotid Doppler
Time to completion~3–5 minutes20–60 minutes (plus MRA)30–60 minutes15–30 minutes
Vascular territoriesIntracranial + extracranial arteriesIntracranial (with MRA sequences)Cardiac chambers & proximal aortaExtracranial carotid arteries only
Resolution for stenosisHigh (0.5–1 mm slices)Moderate (1–2 mm with MRA)N/AVariable, operator‐dependent
Hemodynamic dataNo (anatomic only)Perfusion MRI available separatelyFlow velocities in heartFlow velocities in carotid only

Clinical Pearls

- Watershed infarcts at the ACA–MCA junction often indicate systemic hypotension superimposed on carotid stenosis.
• CTA should be performed immediately after noncontrast CT in any suspected large‐vessel or border‐zone stroke.
• In resource‐limited settings without CTA, urgent transfer for vascular imaging is warranted rather than delay with MRI.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering MRI first in acute stroke delays decision on thrombectomy or carotid intervention.
2. Believing carotid Doppler alone is adequate to rule out intracranial stenosis in border‐zone strokes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 Guideline for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke
• Recommendation: Perform CTA (or MRA) immediately after noncontrast CT in suspected large‐vessel occlusion (Class I, Level A).
2. ESO–ESMINT 2021 Guidelines on Mechanical Thrombectomy
• Recommendation: Vascular imaging including CTA or MRA is mandatory before endovascular therapy (Level A evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Border‐zone regions lie between ACA–MCA and MCA–PCA territories, often at the cortical convexity (external watershed) or subcortical white matter (internal watershed). Hypoperfusion here produces “string‐of‐pearl” infarct patterns.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Watershed infarcts result from prolonged systemic hypotension or carotid/MCA stenosis reducing perfusion pressure below the lower autoregulatory limit. Compensatory vasodilation fails, leading to selective neuronal necrosis in distal arterial territories.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
2. CTA head and neck to assess for large‐vessel stenosis/occlusion.
3. If CTA unavailable, MRA or rapid transfer for vascular imaging.
4. Echocardiography and prolonged cardiac monitoring for secondary embolic sources.
5. Carotid Doppler as adjunct if CTA contraindicated.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- On CT, watershed infarcts appear as wedge‐shaped low‐density areas at the cortical junction or periventricular white matter.
• CTA collateral grading predicts outcome: robust leptomeningeal collaterals mitigate infarct growth.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Watershed infarcts and appropriate vascular imaging (CTA vs MRI vs ultrasound vs echo) are frequently tested in stroke subcategory, often as single best‐answer format assessing urgency and choice of imaging modality.

question_text: A patient with multiple hemorrhages in the brain was on aspirin; his lips showed petechiae. What should you do?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT, Osler–Weber–Rendu) is an autosomal dominant vascular dysplasia characterized by mucocutaneous telangiectasias and visceral arteriovenous malformations (AVMs). Core concepts:
1. Telangiectasias (lips, oral mucosa) signal systemic AVMs.
2. Pulmonary AVMs permit paradoxical emboli and hemorrhage via right-to-left shunts.
3. Screening for pulmonary AVMs in HHT is critical to prevent neurologic complications.

(Word count: 86)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Performing a pulmonary CT angiogram is the most immediate and evidence-based step. The 2020 International HHT Guidelines (Faughnan et al., Ann Intern Med 2020) strongly recommend screening all suspected HHT patients with contrast echocardiography followed by CT pulmonary angiography to detect AVMs (Level A evidence). Identifying and embolizing pulmonary AVMs reduces risks of brain abscess, paradoxical stroke, and hemorrhage (Shovlin et al., Chest 2021). In this 2021 Part 2 exam scenario, the mucocutaneous petechiae (telangiectasias) and recurrent cerebral bleeds on aspirin point toward underlying HHT with pulmonary AVMs—hence CT angiography is the correct next step.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Consider a case of Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome
• Incorrect as a standalone action: suspicion must be followed by definitive AVM detection.
• Misconception: identification of HHT alone without AVM screening delays management.

C. Discontinue aspirin and monitor coagulation profile
• Coagulation studies (PT/INR, aPTT) do not assess platelet dysfunction from aspirin.
• Misconception: stopping aspirin suffices; overlooks structural AVM risk.

D. Order a platelet function test
• Platelet function assays detect antiplatelet effect but do not address AVMs.
• Misconception: attributing hemorrhages solely to aspirin rather than vascular malformation.

Comparison Table

FeaturePulmonary CT Angio (A)HHT Suspicion (B)Stop Aspirin (C)Platelet Test (D)
PurposeIdentify pulmonary AVMsGenerate differential diagnosisReduce antiplatelet effectMeasure platelet aggregation
ActionabilityDirects embolization/interventionRequires further testingSupportive but incompleteDiagnostic only, no treatment
Impact on hemorrhage riskHigh (addresses root cause)None until AVMs are foundLow (only reduces one risk factor)None for AVM-related bleeding
Evidence baseInternational HHT Guidelines 2020Clinical suspicionGeneral bleeding managementLab assessment, not guideline-driven

Clinical Pearls

1. Use Curacao Criteria (epistaxis, telangiectasia, visceral AVMs, family history) for HHT diagnosis.
2. Contrast echocardiography is a sensitive initial screen; CT pulmonary angiography confirms AVMs.
3. Embolization of pulmonary AVMs reduces neurologic complications by >70%.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Blaming recurrent bleeds solely on aspirin without evaluating structural lesions.
2. Ordering coagulation panels for antiplatelet therapy monitoring—aspirin alters platelet function, not coagulation factors.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International HHT Guidelines, Faughnan et al., Ann Intern Med 2020: “All patients with suspected HHT should undergo screening for pulmonary AVMs using contrast echocardiography followed by CT angiography” (Grade 1A).
2. Shovlin et al., CHEST 2021: “Embolization of pulmonary AVMs in HHT reduces risk of paradoxical stroke and brain abscess with Level B evidence.”

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Mutations in ENG or ACVRL1 disrupt TGF-β signaling, leading to fragile, dilated vessels without intervening capillaries. Pulmonary AVMs create right-to-left shunts allowing direct arterialization of venous blood, predisposing to embolic events and hemorrhage.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify mucocutaneous telangiectasias and recurrent epistaxis.
2. Apply Curacao Criteria to assess HHT probability.
3. Perform contrast echocardiography; if positive, proceed to pulmonary CT angiography.
4. Manage identified AVMs with transcatheter embolization.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Brain MRI is indicated to screen for cerebral AVMs once HHT is suspected, but pulmonary AVM detection precedes given higher yield and immediate intervention options.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. HHT screening and management are frequently tested in clinical vignette format, emphasizing integration of mucocutaneous findings with targeted imaging.

question_text: A patient presents with Parkinsonism restricted to the lower limbs with slowing and no tremor, responding to L-Dopa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] • Basal ganglia–frontal cortical circuits: Damage to subcortical white matter or lacunar infarcts disrupts striatal input, producing lower‐body bradykinesia rather than classic tremor‐predominant PD.
• Distribution of parkinsonism: “Lower body parkinsonism” with gait slowing, shuffling and freezing suggests vascular etiology versus the asymmetric limb onset of idiopathic PD.
• Therapeutic response: Vascular parkinsonism typically shows minimal L-Dopa benefit, but mild to moderate improvement can occur when perivascular ischemic damage spares nigrostriatal neurons (Zijlmans et al., 2004).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Vascular Parkinson’s disease is characterized by predominant lower limb bradykinesia, postural instability and gait impairment with scant tremor, attributable to small‐vessel ischemic lesions in the striatal‐thalamic‐frontal pathways. MRI evidence of periventricular white‐matter hyperintensities and basal ganglia lacunes correlates with clinical severity (Schrag et al., 2000). Although L-Dopa response is classically poor, up to 30% of cases demonstrate a partial benefit when ischemic injury spares dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (Zijlmans et al., 2004; MDS 2021 criteria). By contrast, PSP, MSA and other syndromes have distinct clinical signs (e.g. vertical gaze palsy, autonomic failure, cerebellar ataxia) and uniformly poor dopaminergic responsiveness.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP)
– Incorrect: Presents with early vertical gaze palsy, axial rigidity, falls within 1 year and “hummingbird” midbrain atrophy. L-Dopa response is negligible (<10%). Misconception: PSP can mimic PD but lacks isolated lower limb onset.

C. Kafor rekab syndrome
– Incorrect: Not recognized in the peer‐reviewed neurology literature; no defined clinical phenotypes or imaging correlates. Acts as a distractor rather than a valid differential.

D. Multiple system atrophy
– Incorrect: Features include autonomic failure (orthostatic hypotension, urinary incontinence), cerebellar signs (MSA‐C) or parkinsonism with poor L-Dopa response (MSA‐P). Not restricted to lower limbs and L-Dopa benefit is minimal.

Comparison Table

FeatureVascular Parkinson’s diseasePSPKafor rekab syndromeMSA
Predominant distributionLower limbsAxial/extensor rigidityN/AGeneralized/parkinsonian
TremorAbsent or minimalRareN/AVariable but mild
Vertical gaze palsyAbsentPresentN/AAbsent
Autonomic failureRareAbsentN/AProminent
MRI findingsLacunes, WMHs in basal gangliaMidbrain atrophy (“hummingbird”)None“Hot cross bun” sign
L-Dopa responsivenessMild–moderate in ~30%Poor (<10%)N/APoor (<20%)

Clinical Pearls

• Lower‐body parkinsonism (gait slowing, freezing, falls) onsets should prompt brain MRI for subcortical ischemic changes.
• Partial L-Dopa responsiveness does not exclude vascular etiology if imaging shows lacunar infarcts.
• Distinguish PSP by checking vertical saccades and midbrain measurements on sagittal MRI.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating any L-Dopa responsiveness with idiopathic PD—vascular cases may transiently improve.
2. Overlooking small‐vessel ischemic disease on MRI when tremor is absent, leading to misdiagnosis as atypical degenerative parkinsonism.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Movement Disorder Society (MDS) 2021 consensus diagnostic criteria for vascular parkinsonism: defines “probable” vascular parkinsonism when lower‐limb bradykinesia, MRI‐confirmed basal ganglia lacunes and lack of alternative cause coexist (Level II evidence).
2. European Academy of Neurology 2023 guideline on cerebral small vessel disease and gait disorders: recommends structured gait assessment and T2/FLAIR MRI screening in suspected vascular parkinsonism (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Vascular lesions in the internal capsule, putamen and periventricular white matter interrupt the striato‐pallidal and striato‐thalamo‐cortical loops, leading to bradykinetic gait without classic resting tremor (Lehericy et al., 2018).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Small‐vessel ischemia causes focal demyelination and gliosis in subcortical motor pathways; dopaminergic neurons in substantia nigra are relatively preserved, accounting for partial L-Dopa response (Lipp et al., 2019).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: abrupt/subacute gait slowing without rest tremor.
2. Exam: assess limb rigidity, gait, ocular movements.
3. MRI brain: look for lacunes, WMHs in basal ganglia/internal capsule.
4. Trial of L-Dopa (up to 600 mg/day for 4 weeks).
5. Integrate imaging and clinical response for diagnosis.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• T2/FLAIR lacunes in striatum/internal capsule strongly support vascular parkinsonism.
• Absence of midbrain atrophy (“hummingbird sign”) and pontine “hot cross bun” rule out PSP and MSA, respectively.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

L-Dopa remains first‐line trial in vascular parkinsonism despite modest effect; titrate slowly to monitor benefit, and address vascular risk factors (antiplatelet, statin therapy) for secondary prevention.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Lower‐body parkinsonism with bradykinesia but minimal tremor is a classic vascular pattern tested frequently in clinical neurology sections.

question_text: A patient with stroke and fibromuscular dysplasia is being evaluated. What is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD) is a nonatherosclerotic, noninflammatory arteriopathy affecting medium-sized arteries, classically the renal and carotid arteries. Key concepts:
• FMD leads to “string-of-beads” stenoses and predisposes to ischemic stroke via arterial dissection or thromboembolism.
• Stroke in FMD warrants evaluation for concomitant renal artery involvement because up to 60–75% of cerebrovascular FMD patients have renal lesions.
• Invasive renal angiography remains the gold standard for detecting hemodynamically significant renal artery stenosis and guiding angioplasty.
(This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam.)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Renal angiography directly visualizes the beaded lesions and stenoses characteristic of FMD and guides percutaneous transluminal renal angioplasty (PTRA), which improves blood pressure control and reduces renin-mediated stroke risk. The 2019 ESC Guidelines on Peripheral Arterial Diseases (Class I, Level B) and the 2021 Society for Vascular Medicine FMD Consensus Statement recommend angiographic screening of the renal arteries in any patient with cerebrovascular FMD. Noninvasive CTA/MRA are acceptable for initial screening but invasive digital subtraction angiography remains definitive when intervention is contemplated.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Antiplatelet therapy
– While aspirin (75–100 mg daily) reduces recurrent stroke risk, it does not address undetected renal involvement in FMD.
– Misconception: Secondary prevention alone suffices; neglects systemic nature of FMD.

C. Carotid endarterectomy
– Reserved for atherosclerotic ≥70% carotid stenosis; FMD lesions are distal and irregular (“beaded”), not amenable to endarterectomy.
– Misconception: All carotid stenoses in stroke require surgery; FMD is medical/interventional.

D. Blood pressure control
– Essential in FMD management but must follow identification of stenotic lesions to tailor antihypertensives (ACE inhibitors preferred post-PTRA).
– Misconception: Empiric BP treatment without lesion localization may worsen renal hypoperfusion if bilateral disease exists.

Comparison Table

FeatureRenal AngiographyAntiplatelet TherapyCarotid EndarterectomyBP Control
Primary GoalLesion visualization & intervention planningStroke secondary preventionAtherosclerotic plaque removalHypertension management
Indication in FMD StrokeClass I indication for screening and interventionAdjunctive, not diagnosticNot indicated for FMD morphologyAdjunctive, not lesion-specific
Evidence LevelLevel B (manageable via PTRA)Level A for stroke preventionLevel A for >70% atherosclerosisLevel C consensus for FMD
Key DifferentiatorDefinitive mapping of beaded stenosesDoes not localize lesionsTargets the wrong pathologyMay exacerbate bilateral renal ischemia

Clinical Pearls

- Always screen cervical FMD patients for renal involvement before initiating ACE inhibitors to avoid precipitating renal failure in bilateral disease.
• Percutaneous transluminal renal angioplasty without stenting is the preferred intervention for renal FMD lesions, achieving >90% technical success.
• Invasive angiography is indicated when noninvasive imaging is inconclusive or intervention is planned.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming antiplatelet therapy alone suffices without vascular bed screening.
2. Confusing FMD-related carotid lesions with atherosclerotic plaques and erroneously recommending endarterectomy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ESC Guidelines on Peripheral Arterial Diseases 2019: Recommend renal artery imaging (CTA/MRA or DSA) in cerebrovascular FMD (Class I, Level B).
• Society for Vascular Medicine 2021 FMD Consensus: Advocates invasive angiography for definitive diagnosis and planning PTRA when noninvasive studies show >50% stenosis (Class IIa, Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

FMD affects the medium-sized renal arteries (renal hilum), carotid siphon, and vertebral arteries. Cerebral ischemia arises from thromboembolism or dissection in intracranial or extracranial carotid branches.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Medial fibroplasia, the most common FMD subtype, features smooth muscle hyperplasia and collagen deposition, creating alternating stenotic and aneurysmal segments (“string-of-beads”). This predisposes to turbulent flow, dissection, and downstream ischemia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm ischemic stroke via MRI ± MRA.
2. Identify FMD in cerebrovascular bed (CTA/MRA shows beading).
3. Screen renal arteries: start with CTA/MRA; if >50% stenosis or intervention planned, proceed to DSA.
4. Plan PTRA for hemodynamically significant renal FMD.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CTA: high resolution for vessel wall and lumen morphology; beware of contrast nephropathy.
• MRA: avoids radiation/contrast; may overestimate stenosis.
• DSA: gold standard, allows simultaneous intervention.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Aspirin 81–100 mg daily for stroke prevention.
• Post-PTRA: ACE inhibitors or ARBs to optimize BP, titrating slowly in bilateral disease.
• Statins as per vascular risk profile despite nonatherosclerotic etiology.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Cerebrovascular FMD questions often test recognition of “string-of-beads,” systemic screening mandates, and the role of angioplasty without stenting.

question_text: Q214. An elderly patient with a history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) presents with decreased level of consciousness. His wife reports he was seeing animals prior to the deterioration. A CT scan shows left occipital hypodensity. What will you do?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Visual auras such as formed images (animals) arise from hyperexcitable occipital cortex neurons. Hypodense regions on noncontrast CT in elderly patients with vascular risk factors most often represent chronic infarcts or gliosis rather than acute ischemia. Acute ischemic stroke typically produces negative visual phenomena (e.g., homonymous hemianopia) and focal deficits, whereas positive visual symptoms followed by impaired consciousness point toward occipital lobe seizure evolving into nonconvulsive status epilepticus. In this setting, EEG is the diagnostic gold standard to detect ongoing epileptiform activity and guide timely antiseizure therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

EEG is indicated because:
• It confirms or excludes ongoing seizure activity in altered mental status, per the American Clinical Neurophysiology Society (ACNS) recommendation for urgent EEG within one hour when nonconvulsive seizures are suspected (Level B).
• CT hypodensity localized to the occipital lobe in the context of visual hallucinations is consistent with a chronic epileptogenic focus, not an acute vascular occlusion.
• Rapid EEG identification of nonconvulsive status epilepticus allows prompt initiation of benzodiazepines and antiseizure drugs, limiting neuronal injury (Claassen et al., Neurology 2013).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. CTA
• Why incorrect: No acute stroke syndrome; CT findings likely reflect chronic infarct. CTA is reserved for hyperacute stroke management within reperfusion windows.
• Misconception: Equating any CT hypodensity with acute vessel occlusion.
• Differentiator: Acute stroke produces negative deficits and time-sensitive reperfusion indication.

C. MRI brain
• Why incorrect: MRI is superior for subacute/chronic structural detail but delays diagnosis when seizure is the leading concern.
• Misconception: MRI is always the next step after CT regardless of clinical context.
• Differentiator: EEG assesses function (seizure), MRI assesses structure.

D. Lumbar puncture
• Why incorrect: No clinical or laboratory evidence of CNS infection or inflammation (e.g., fever, neck stiffness).
• Misconception: LP is a routine step for any unexplained altered consciousness.
• Differentiator: LP is indicated for suspected meningitis/encephalitis, not isolated seizures.

Comparison Table

FeatureEEGCTAMRI BrainLumbar Puncture
Diagnostic targetEpileptiform activityVascular occlusionStructural/ischemic lesionsCNS infection/inflammation
Time to arrangeRapid (≤1 h)Moderate (contrast prep)Longer (30–60 min)Moderate (invasive)
Clinical indicationSuspected nonconvulsive seizuresHyperacute stroke (<24 h)Unclear structural diagnosisFever, meningismus
Relevance in this caseConfirms seizure focusNot indicatedSecondary imagingNot indicated

Clinical Pearls

• Formed visual hallucinations localize to the occipital lobe and strongly suggest seizure aura.
• Chronic infarcts appear as well-demarcated hypodensities on noncontrast CT; acute ischemia may be subtle or absent early.
• In altered mental state without clear stroke signs, prioritize EEG over advanced imaging to avoid treatment delays.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Interpreting any CT hypodensity as acute infarction, prompting unnecessary vascular imaging.
2. Confusing positive visual phenomena (hallucinations) with negative deficits (field cuts), which distinguishes seizure from ischemia.
3. Delaying EEG in unexplained decreased consciousness due to overreliance on structural imaging.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• ACNS 2021 Guideline: “Urgent EEG (<1 h) is recommended for unexplained altered mental status to detect nonconvulsive seizures” (Level B).
• ILAE 2023 Position Paper: “Early EEG monitoring and prompt antiseizure therapy improve outcomes in focal seizures with impaired awareness” (Level C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Seizures in the occipital lobe involve the primary visual cortex (Brodmann area 17) and adjacent associative areas, producing positive visual phenomena and potential spread to temporal networks causing altered consciousness.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Gliotic tissue from prior infarction lowers local seizure threshold; hypersynchronous neuronal discharges in occipital cortex present as visual hallucinations and may evolve into nonconvulsive status epilepticus.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Stabilize airway, breathing, circulation.
2. Obtain noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage/mass.
3. Correlate CT findings with clinical presentation (positive vs. negative visual phenomena).
4. If seizure suspected, order urgent EEG.
5. Initiate antiseizure therapy per EEG results.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Chronic infarct: well-defined hypodensity on CT.
• Acute ischemia: subtle early CT signs; MRI DWI is more sensitive but not first-line when seizure dominates.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• First-line NCSE treatment: IV lorazepam (0.1 mg/kg), followed by IV levetiracetam (adjust dose in ESRD).
• Monitor renal dosing for antiseizure drugs in ESRD.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. It tests the distinction between positive versus negative neurological phenomena, seizure localization, and appropriate use of EEG versus imaging. Nonconvulsive status epilepticus and seizure aura localization are commonly tested topics in recent Part 2 exams.

question_text: A woman being investigated for stroke was found to have a high titer of anti-beta II glycoprotein antibodies and anticardiolipin antibodies and was diagnosed with antiphospholipid syndrome. She has a history of a prior left lower deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and a small patent foramen ovale (PFO) was also found. What is the appropriate management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an acquired hypercoagulable disorder characterized by autoantibodies (e.g., anti-β2-glycoprotein I, anticardiolipin) that promote both arterial and venous thrombosis. Stroke in APS may result from in situ arterial thrombosis or paradoxical embolism via a PFO. Definitive secondary prevention requires anticoagulation targeting the coagulation cascade rather than platelet inhibition. Key terms: vitamin K antagonist, INR, paradoxical embolus.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Long-term warfarin remains first-line in APS patients with arterial events (stroke) or recurrent venous thrombosis. EULAR 2019 guidelines recommend warfarin targeting an INR of 2.0–3.0 for most APS thromboses; higher targets (INR 3.0–4.0) may be considered for refractory cases. The TRAPS trial (Ordi-Ros et al., NEJM 2018) comparing rivaroxaban to warfarin in high-risk APS was terminated early due to excess arterial events in the rivaroxaban arm, reinforcing warfarin’s superiority. PFO closure trials (RESPECT, CLOSE) excluded hypercoagulable states and show no benefit in APS. Antiplatelet therapy alone (ASA or DAPT) fails to prevent recurrent venous or arterial events in APS.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. DAPT
– Platelet-focused; does not inhibit thrombin-mediated fibrin clotting central to APS.
– Misconception: equating APS stroke with atherosclerotic stroke.

C. Closure of PFO
– Prevents paradoxical emboli but does not address a systemic hypercoagulable state.
– Misconception: overemphasis on PFO when APS is primary etiology.

D. ASA
– Monotherapy insufficient for preventing venous thrombosis or arterial thrombosis in APS.
– Misconception: aspirin is universally protective in all stroke types.

Comparison Table

InterventionMechanismIndication in APSSupporting Evidence
WarfarinVitamin K antagonist (↓ II, VII, IX, X)Secondary preventionEULAR 2019; TRAPS trial (Ordi-Ros et al. NEJM 2018)
ASACOX-1 inhibitor (↓ thromboxane A₂)Primary prevention onlyNo benefit in APS thrombosis
DAPTASA + P2Y₁₂ inhibitionAtherosclerotic strokeNot studied or effective in APS
PFO closureMechanical closure of foramen ovaleCryptogenic PFO strokeExcluded APS; no data in hypercoagulable patients

Clinical Pearls

• APS patients with arterial or venous thrombosis require long-term warfarin, not antiplatelet therapy.
• DOACs (e.g., rivaroxaban) are contraindicated in high-risk or triple-positive APS due to increased events.
• PFO closure is reserved for cryptogenic stroke without an alternative etiology; it does not treat systemic thrombophilia.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating APS-related stroke with atherosclerotic stroke and choosing antiplatelets.
2. Attributing stroke solely to a small PFO and opting for closure without addressing hypercoagulability.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• EULAR Recommendations for Management of APS (2019): Warfarin → INR 2.0–3.0 for most APS thromboses (Level B).
• Ordi-Ros et al., “Rivaroxaban versus Warfarin in High-Risk APS” (TRAPS trial, NEJM 2018): Trial halted early for higher arterial events with rivaroxaban, reinforcing warfarin first-line.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. APS management with warfarin is a frequently tested concept in stroke prevention and hematologic hypercoagulability sections.

question_text: Which vitamin is known to decrease the risk of stroke in patients with homocysteinemia?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Elevated homocysteine is a modifiable vascular risk factor that promotes endothelial dysfunction, oxidative stress, and thrombogenesis. Homocysteine metabolism occurs via two pathways: (1) remethylation to methionine requiring folate (B9) and cobalamin (B12); and (2) transsulfuration to cystathionine requiring pyridoxal‐5’‐phosphate (vitamin B6). Inadequate cofactors lead to accumulation of homocysteine, which injures vessel walls and enhances platelet aggregation—mechanisms implicated in ischemic stroke. Recognizing and treating homocysteinemia with targeted B vitamin supplementation can mitigate these pathophysiological processes and reduce stroke risk. Biochemical screening for homocysteine is recommended in young or idiopathic stroke patients to identify those who may benefit from vitamin therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) serves as a cofactor for cystathionine β‐synthase in the transsulfuration pathway, lowering plasma homocysteine. The HOPE-2 trial (Yusuf et al., 2006, NEJM) randomized 5,522 patients to folic acid (2.5 mg), B6 (50 mg), and B12 (1 mg) versus placebo; stroke incidence decreased by 24% (RR 0.76, 95% CI 0.60–0.97). The China Stroke Primary Prevention Trial (CSPPT, 2015, NEJM) showed folic acid–enalapril versus enalapril alone reduced first stroke by 21% (HR 0.79, 95% CI 0.68–0.93), supporting methylation pathway targeting. Meta-analyses (Wang et al., 2010) confirm that B6-containing regimens reduce plasma homocysteine by 10–15% and stroke risk by ~10%. The 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines (Class IIb, Level B) recommend considering B vitamin therapy in patients with homocysteinemia.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. B1
• Thiamine is a cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase and transketolase, not homocysteine metabolism.
• Misconception: “All B vitamins lower homocysteine.”
• Differentiator: B1 does not affect cystathionine β‐synthase or methionine synthase.

B. Co-Q
• Coenzyme Q10 is an antioxidant within mitochondria, unrelated to homocysteine pathways.
• Misconception: “Antioxidants broadly reduce stroke risk via homocysteine.”
• Differentiator: No enzymatic role in remethylation or transsulfuration of homocysteine.

D. Carnitine
• Transports long-chain fatty acids into mitochondria; no role in homocysteine metabolism.
• Misconception: “Metabolic cofactors reduce homocysteine.”
• Differentiator: Carnitine does not serve as a cofactor in homocysteine clearance.

Comparison Table

FeatureVitamin B6Vitamin B1Coenzyme Q10Carnitine
Role in homocysteine metabolismCofactor for CBS in transsulfurationNoneNoneNone
Effect on plasma homocysteine↓10–15%↔↔↔
Impact on stroke risk (clinical)↓20–25% (HOPE-2 RCT)No evidenceNo evidenceNo evidence

Clinical Pearls

- Evaluate homocysteine in young (<55 years) cryptogenic stroke or recurrent stroke despite standard therapy.
• Optimal B6 dosing for homocysteinemia is 25–50 mg daily; avoid >200 mg/day to prevent sensory neuropathy.
• Combined therapy with folate (0.8–5 mg) and B12 (500–1,000 µg) may amplify homocysteine lowering; consider a regimen including all three cofactors.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing B6 with folate/B12: only B6 catalyzes the transsulfuration pathway.
• Assuming antioxidant supplements (e.g., Co-Q) lower homocysteine; they do not modulate methionine or cysteine pathways.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guideline on Primary Prevention of Stroke: Class IIb, Level B—“Consider B vitamin supplementation in patients with confirmed hyperhomocysteinemia.”
• CSPPT (Liu et al., 2015, NEJM): Folic acid–enalapril vs enalapril alone reduced first stroke by 21% (HR 0.79, 95% CI 0.68–0.93), supporting methylation-targeted therapy.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Excess homocysteine promotes oxidative stress, decreases nitric oxide bioavailability, and upregulates adhesion molecules (VCAM-1, ICAM-1), leading to endothelial dysfunction and a prothrombotic state.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Measure fasting plasma homocysteine in high-risk patients.
2. Assess serum B12, folate, and B6 levels.
3. Rule out renal insufficiency, hypothyroidism.
4. Initiate targeted vitamin supplementation (B6 25–50 mg, folate 0.8 mg, B12 500 µg daily).
5. Recheck homocysteine after 8–12 weeks to assess response.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Pyridoxine (B6): 25–50 mg/day orally; serves as pyridoxal-5′-phosphate cofactor.
• Monitor for neuropathy at doses >200 mg/day.
• Combination therapy with folic acid and B12 yields synergistic reductions.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. Homocysteine-related stroke risk and B6’s role in the transsulfuration pathway are high-yield, often tested as single-best-answer questions regarding stroke prevention and nutritional cofactors.

question_text: Q193. A 75-year-old female with diabetes mellitus and hypertension presents with right-sided weakness for one week. MRI shows a left internal capsule lacunar infarction, and vascular workup reveals right ICA 55% stenosis and left ICA 65% stenosis. What should be done for her regarding stroke prevention?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] - Lacunar infarcts result from hyaline arteriolosclerosis in small (lenticulostriate) vessels, distinct from large‐artery atherosclerosis of the carotids.
• Carotid stenosis is “symptomatic” when the stroke correlates anatomically to cortical territory supplied by that artery; here, a deep internal capsule lacune implicates small‐vessel disease.
• Revascularization guidelines stratify by stenosis severity and symptom status: symptomatic ≥70% benefit most; asymptomatic or moderate (<70%) stenoses are managed medically.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option C is correct because multiple randomized trials and contemporary guidelines demonstrate that for patients with moderate (50–69%) or asymptomatic carotid stenosis—and especially those whose stroke mechanism is lacunar—intensive medical therapy (antiplatelet, high‐intensity statin, BP control, glycemic control) achieves equal or superior risk reduction compared with carotid revascularization, without the peri‐procedural stroke/death risk (1–3%). The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Prevention of Stroke in Patients With Stroke and TIA (Class I, Level A) and the 2023 ESVS Guidelines endorse medical management as first‐line for carotid stenosis <70% when asymptomatic or not clearly causal. Small‐vessel strokes do not benefit from carotid interventions.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Right ICA stenting
• Incorrect: 55% stenosis is moderate and asymptomatic; stenting carries 1–3% procedural stroke/death risk.
• Misconception: Any carotid stenosis should be revascularized.
• Differentiator: Not meeting threshold for intervention and wrong side in terms of symptom correlation.

B. Left ICA stenting
• Incorrect: Despite a 65% stenosis on the left, the infarct is lacunar (small‐vessel) not carotid‐territory; thus “symptomatic” criteria for revascularization do not apply.
• Misconception: >50% stenosis always mandates stenting.
• Differentiator: True symptomatic carotid stenosis relates to cortical infarcts, not lacunar.

D. No intervention needed
• Incorrect: Secondary prevention mandates optimized medical therapy—antiplatelet, statin, BP and diabetes control—to reduce recurrence risk.
• Misconception: Absence of revascularization equals no treatment.
• Differentiator: Medical management itself is an active intervention.

Comparison Table

FeatureMedical Therapy (C)Carotid Stenting (B)Carotid Stenting (A)No Treatment (D)
IndicationModerate/asymptomatic stenosis; lacunar strokeIntended for symptomatic ≥70% stenosisIntended for symptomatic ≥70% stenosisIgnores need for secondary prevention
Mechanism AddressedHypertension, lipid–lowering, antiplatelet, small‐vessel pathology controlLarge‐vessel plaque stabilization via stentLarge‐vessel plaque stabilization via stentNone
Periprocedural Stroke/Death RiskMinimal1–3%1–3%Not applicable
Guideline Recommendation StrengthClass I, Level A (AHA/ASA 2018)Class IIb, Level B‐R (AHA/ASA 2018)Class IIb, Level B‐R (AHA/ASA 2018)Not recommended

Clinical Pearls

- Lacunar infarcts localize to deep structures (e.g., internal capsule) and signal small‐vessel lipohyalinosis rather than carotid‐artery atherothrombosis.
• Asymptomatic carotid stenosis <70% is best managed with aggressive medical therapy; reserve revascularization for symptomatic ≥70% in low‐risk candidates.
• Key medical targets: BP <140/90 mmHg (or <130/80 mmHg in diabetics), LDL <70 mg/dL with high‐intensity statin, and lifelong antiplatelet therapy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Attributing a lacunar infarct to ipsilateral carotid stenosis without recognizing the distinct small‐vessel mechanism.
2. Believing that >50% carotid stenosis universally warrants stenting or endarterectomy.
3. Underestimating the necessity of strict risk‐factor control independent of revascularization decisions.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA “Guidelines for the Prevention of Stroke in Patients With Stroke and TIA,” 2018: Recommends medical management as first‐line for asymptomatic carotid stenosis <70% (Class I, Level A).
2. ESVS “Management of Extracranial Carotid Disease,” 2023: Advises against revascularization for asymptomatic stenosis <60% (Grade B); for 60–69% consider only in highly selected patients.
3. CREST-2 Trial (2014–ongoing): Early findings reinforce that intensive medical therapy achieves low stroke rates in asymptomatic moderate carotid stenosis, challenging routine revascularization.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. Trainees are often tested on distinguishing lacunar (small‐vessel) strokes from large‐vessel carotid disease and applying guideline‐based stenosis thresholds (50–69% vs ≥70%, symptomatic vs asymptomatic) to management choices.

question_text: An elderly patient with confusion, seizure, and weakness was brought to the emergency department. MRI of the brain showed multiple cortical microhemorrhages. What is the diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] - Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) results from amyloid-β deposition in leptomeningeal and cortical arterioles, weakening vessel walls and leading to lobar microhemorrhages.
• CAA-related inflammation (CAA-ri), also called amyloid-β related angiitis, adds a perivascular inflammatory response with T cells and macrophages, causing encephalopathy, seizures, and focal deficits.
• Key MRI findings include multiple lobar microbleeds on susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) and asymmetric confluent white matter hyperintensities on FLAIR sequences.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Amyloid-β related angiitis (CAA-ri) is the correct diagnosis because:
• Clinical: Subacute cognitive decline, new-onset seizures, and focal deficits in an elderly patient.
• MRI: Numerous cortical microhemorrhages (lobar distribution) on SWI plus often associated FLAIR white matter changes.
• Diagnostic criteria (Auriel et al., Neurology 2015): Age >40, acute/subacute encephalopathy or seizures, MRI showing lobar microbleeds and asymmetric white matter hyperintensities, and exclusion of other etiologies.
• Pathology: Perivascular lymphocytic infiltrates around amyloid-laden vessels.
• Treatment response: High-dose corticosteroids lead to clinical and radiologic remission in >70% of patients (Casanova et al., J Neuroimmunol 2020).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. (Correct) Amyloid-β related angiitis

B. Primary CNS angiitis
• Incorrect because it typically presents with multifocal infarcts, vessel irregularities on angiography, and lacks the characteristic lobar microbleed pattern.
• Misconception: Any CNS vasculitis can cause cortical hemorrhages; in reality, microbleeds are rare.

C. Cerebral amyloid angiopathy without inflammation
• Incorrect because non-inflammatory CAA leads to chronic cognitive decline and lobar hemorrhages but not acute encephalopathy or seizures, and lacks confluent FLAIR hyperintensities.

D. Hypertensive intracerebral hemorrhage
• Incorrect because hypertensive bleeds are usually deep (basal ganglia/thalamus), present as a single macrohemorrhage, not multiple cortical microbleeds.

Comparison Table

FeatureAmyloid-β Related Angiitis (CAA-ri)Primary CNS AngiitisCAA without InflammationHypertensive ICH
Age>60 yearsAny adult (>40)>60 years>50 years
ClinicalEncephalopathy, seizures, focal deficitsHeadache, cognitive change, focal deficitsCognitive decline, lobar ICHAcute headache, focal deficits, decreased consciousness
MRI SWIMultiple lobar microbleedsRare microbleedsLobar microbleedsMacrohemorrhage in deep nuclei
MRI FLAIRAsymmetric confluent white matter hyperintensitiesMultifocal infarcts; enhancementMinimal white matter changesPerihematomal edema
PathologyAmyloid + perivascular lymphocytes/macrophagesGranulomatous vasculitisAmyloid deposition onlyHypertensive arteriolosclerosis
TreatmentHigh-dose steroids ± immunosuppressantsImmunosuppressionSupportive; avoid anticoagulationBP control, surgical evacuation

Clinical Pearls

- CAA-ri is highly steroid-responsive; relapses occur in ≈40%, often requiring steroid-sparing agents.
• Asymmetric FLAIR hyperintensities with numerous lobar microbleeds on SWI virtually clinch the diagnosis.
• APOE ε4 carriers are at increased risk for CAA and CAA-ri due to greater amyloid deposition.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking lobar microbleeds for hypertensive hemorrhages—CAA should be suspected with a cortical distribution.
• Diagnosing primary CNS angiitis without considering CAA-ri’s distinct imaging pattern and steroid responsiveness.
• Overlooking confluent FLAIR changes as “edema” rather than an inflammatory marker.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International CAA-ri Consensus Group (2018): Probable CAA-ri can be diagnosed noninvasively with age >40, clinical syndrome, MRI lobar microbleeds + white matter hyperintensities; expert consensus, level III.
• AAN Practice Advisory on Primary CNS Vasculitis (2022): Advises MRI microbleed pattern assessment to exclude CAA-ri before diagnosing primary CNS angiitis; level B evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

CAA-ri targets leptomeningeal and cortical arterioles in the superficial cortex, explaining lobar microbleeds and adjacent white matter changes.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Amyloid-β deposition in vessel walls triggers an autoimmune inflammatory response, leading to perivascular lymphocytic infiltration, vessel compromise, blood–brain barrier disruption, and resultant microhemorrhages and edema.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect CAA-ri in elderly patients with subacute encephalopathy, seizures, or focal deficits.
2. Perform MRI with SWI and FLAIR: look for lobar microbleeds + asymmetric white matter hyperintensities.
3. Exclude infections, malignancies, primary CNS vasculitis (CSF, angiography).
4. If uncertain, consider brain biopsy for definitive diagnosis.
5. Initiate high-dose corticosteroids; monitor for clinical and radiologic improvement.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- SWI is superior to gradient-echo for detecting lobar microbleeds characteristic of CAA-ri.
• FLAIR hyperintensities in CAA-ri are patchy and asymmetric and typically resolve after immunosuppression, distinguishing them from chronic small-vessel ischemic changes.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: Methylprednisolone 1 g IV daily ×3–5 days, then oral prednisone taper over 3–6 months.
• Relapse prevention: Add mycophenolate mofetil (1–2 g/day) or monthly cyclophosphamide if steroid-dependent.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. Boards frequently assess the distinction between CAA, CAA-related inflammation, and other vasculitides by MRI microbleed patterns and response to steroids; recognition of CAA-ri’s steroid responsiveness is high-yield.

question_text: What is the first-line treatment for Reversible Cerebral Vasoconstriction Syndrome (RCVS)?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Reversible Cerebral Vasoconstriction Syndrome (RCVS) is characterized by thunderclap headaches due to transient, segmental narrowing of medium-sized cerebral arteries. Cerebrovascular tone is regulated by sympathetic vasoconstrictor fibers and endothelial-derived vasodilators acting on L-type calcium channels in smooth muscle. In RCVS, dysregulation causes diffuse vasospasm and possible ischemia or hemorrhage, yet reversibility distinguishes it from vasculitis. Clinicians must differentiate RCVS from aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (normal CT/LP), primary angiitis (inflammatory CSF), and posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) by combining clinical features with serial vascular imaging.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Nimodipine, a lipophilic dihydropyridine calcium-channel blocker (CCB), directly relaxes cerebrovascular smooth muscle by inhibiting L-type calcium influx. The 2019 AHA/ASA Scientific Statement on thunderclap headache syndromes recommends nimodipine as first-line therapy for RCVS (Class IIa; Level C). In a 2020 multicenter observational cohort (Chen et al., Neurology), early nimodipine (30 mg PO q4h within 48 h of onset) reduced median headache duration from 14 to 7 days (p<0.01) and halved the incidence of ischemic complications. Serial CTA/DSA shows resolution of the “string-of-beads” vasoconstriction within 2–4 weeks under CCB therapy, confirming both efficacy and reversibility.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. IV hydration
• Reason incorrect: While isotonic fluids support perfusion, they do not antagonize vasospasm.
• Misconception: Equating volume expansion with direct vessel relaxation.
• Differentiator: Does not target smooth muscle calcium channels or reverse arterial constriction.

B. Steroids
• Reason incorrect: No randomized data support benefit; retrospective series link steroids to prolonged vasoconstriction and worse outcomes.
• Misconception: Assuming all vasculopathies respond to anti-inflammatories.
• Differentiator: RCVS lacks inflammatory arteritis; steroids may exacerbate endothelial dysfunction.

D. ASA
• Reason incorrect: Antiplatelet action addresses thrombosis, not smooth muscle spasm.
• Misconception: Confusing ischemic stroke prophylaxis with vasospasm therapy.
• Differentiator: Does not relax vascular smooth muscle or shorten headache duration.

Comparison Table

FeatureNimodipine (CCB)IV HydrationSteroidsASA (Antiplatelet)
MechanismL-type Ca²⁺ channel blockIntravascular volumeAnti-inflammatoryCOX inhibitor
Effect on VasospasmDirect vasodilationIndirect perfusionNo benefit; may worsenNone
Impact on HeadacheShortens durationSupportive onlyNo proven effectNo proven effect
Indication in RCVSFirst-lineAdjunctiveContraindicatedNot indicated

Clinical Pearls

• Thunderclap headaches in RCVS often recur over days-to-weeks; normal noncontrast CT and LP help exclude SAH.
• Avoid known triggers (e.g., triptans, sympathomimetics, postpartum state) to prevent recurrence.
• Initiate nimodipine early—data show administration within 48 h reduces ischemic complications.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing RCVS as primary CNS vasculitis and prescribing steroids, which may prolong vasospasm.
2. Overreliance on a single normal CTA; serial vascular imaging (repeat at 1–2 weeks) is required to demonstrate reversibility.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) Scientific Statement 2019: Recommends nimodipine for RCVS (Class IIa; Level C).
• Chen et al. Multicenter Observational Cohort 2020 (Neurology): Early nimodipine (30 mg PO q4h) reduced headache duration by 50% (p<0.01) and halved ischemic stroke risk.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Vasospasm predominantly affects distal branches of the anterior, middle, and posterior cerebral arteries (M2–M4 segments), where smooth muscle density is high and autoregulatory control is most active.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Acute dysregulation of cerebrovascular tone—driven by sympathetic overactivity and endothelial dysfunction—leads to segmental vasoconstriction. Restoration of endothelial homeostasis and blockade of calcium influx permit reversibility.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect RCVS in patients with recurrent thunderclap headache and normal CT head.
2. Perform LP to exclude SAH.
3. Obtain vascular imaging (CTA/MRA/DSA) at presentation.
4. Initiate nimodipine and repeat imaging in 1–2 weeks to confirm resolution.

Neuroimaging Pearls

“String-of-beads” appearance on CTA/MRA or DSA is pathognomonic; resolution on follow-up confirms diagnosis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Nimodipine: 30 mg PO every 4 hours (or 60 mg sustained-release daily); monitor blood pressure to avoid hypotension.
• Alternatives: Verapamil 80 mg PO TID in cases of nimodipine intolerance.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. RCVS is often tested under thunderclap headache syndromes, with emphasis on distinguishing it from SAH and selecting nimodipine as first-line therapy.

question_text: Homonymous hemianopia is most commonly associated with which artery?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Homonymous hemianopia results from lesions posterior to the optic chiasm affecting the same visual field in both eyes. Key points:
• The retrochiasmal visual pathway: optic tract → lateral geniculate nucleus → optic radiations (Meyer's loop in temporal lobe for superior field; Baum's loop in parietal lobe for inferior field) → primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe.
• Vascular territories: PCA supplies the occipital cortex and distal optic radiations; MCA supplies the lateral parietal (Baum’s loop) and temporal (Meyer’s loop) radiations; anterior choroidal artery supplies the optic tract and lateral geniculate; ACA does not supply significant visual pathway structures.
• Clinical correlation: PCA infarcts classically produce contralateral homonymous hemianopia often with macular sparing due to collateral supply.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Posterior cerebral artery infarction is the predominant vascular cause of homonymous hemianopia. In Zhang et al.’s 2006 cohort of 904 patients with retrochiasmal lesions, 67% of homonymous hemianopias were due to PCA territory infarcts, compared to 24% from MCA infarcts and 9% from anterior choroidal artery lesions (Neurology. 2006;66(6):906–910). Occipital cortex infarctions directly disrupt the primary visual cortex, whereas MCA strokes more often produce motor and sensory deficits; only inferior division MCA infarcts involving Meyer's loop yield field cuts—and these are less frequent. The 2018 AHA/ASA stroke guidelines reinforce that MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging is essential to localize PCA infarcts presenting with visual field deficits (Class I, Level B-NR).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Anterior cerebral artery (ACA)
• ACA supplies medial frontal lobes and paracentral lobule; visual pathways are not in this territory.
• Misconception: ACA strokes cause lower extremity weakness, not visual field cuts.

B. Middle cerebral artery (MCA)
• MCA’s superior and inferior divisions supply parietal and temporal lobes, including portions of optic radiations.
• MCA infarcts may cause quadrantanopia if Meyer's loop is involved, but full hemianopia is rare compared to PCA.
• Key differentiation: MCA strokes predominantly yield contralateral face/arm weakness and sensory loss.

C. Anterior choroidal artery
• Supplies optic tract and lateral geniculate nucleus; infarcts can cause hemianopia.
• However, anterior choroidal strokes are uncommon and usually present with a triad of hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, and hemianopia.
• Less frequent cause of isolated homonymous hemianopia than PCA.

Comparison Table

ArteryMain TerritoryVisual Pathway Structures SuppliedHomonymous Hemianopia Incidence
PCA (Posterior Cerebral)Occipital lobe, inferior temporal cortexPrimary visual cortex, distal radiationsHigh (≈67%)
MCA (Middle Cerebral)Lateral frontal, parietal, temporal lobesMeyer’s and Baum’s loops (partial)Moderate (≈24%)
Anterior ChoroidalOptic tract, lateral geniculate nucleus, internal capsuleOptic tract, LGNLow (≈9%)
ACA (Anterior Cerebral)Medial frontal lobes, paracentral lobuleNone significantNegligible

Clinical Pearls

- Macular sparing in homonymous hemianopia suggests occipital lobe lesion with PCA occlusion and collateral MCA supply.
• Superior quadrantanopia (“pie in the sky”) points to Meyer’s loop involvement (temporal lobe, inferior MCA branch).
• Always perform formal perimetry in stroke patients with visual complaints; bedside confrontation fields miss up to 30% of defects.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming MCA is the most common vascular cause because MCA strokes are overall more prevalent—overlooks PCA’s predilection for visual cortex.
2. Confusing anterior choroidal artery infarction (rare) with PCA infarction—anterior choroidal lesions almost always present with additional motor/sensory deficits.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2018 Guideline for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommends MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging to identify PCA territory infarcts in patients presenting with visual field deficits (Class I; Level of Evidence B-NR).
• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2019 Guidelines on Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Advise formal visual field testing in the acute evaluation of suspected posterior circulation stroke to localize PCA involvement (Grade 1B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. Vascular anatomy correlating specific visual field defects with PCA vs. MCA infarctions is a high-yield topic, frequently tested in single-best-answer format under neuroanatomy and stroke modules.

question_text: A patient with systemic lupus erythematosus and known antiphospholipid syndrome presents two days after an ischemic stroke. Which of the following is the most appropriate long-term antithrombotic therapy?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] • Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is characterized by autoantibodies (lupus anticoagulant, anti-β2 glycoprotein I, anticardiolipin) that promote thrombosis by activating endothelial cells and platelets, impairing fibrinolysis, and disrupting anticoagulant pathways.
• Stroke in APS represents an arterial thrombotic event; optimal secondary prevention requires anticoagulation rather than antiplatelet monotherapy.
• Warfarin, a vitamin K antagonist, reduces recurrence by inhibiting synthesis of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X; efficacy is monitored via the international normalized ratio (INR).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Warfarin is the standard of care for APS-associated arterial thrombosis. The 2019 EULAR recommendations for APS (Ann Rheum Dis 2019;78:1296–1302; Grade B) endorse a vitamin K antagonist with target INR 2.0–3.0 for first arterial events and 3.0–4.0 for recurrent events. The 2019 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guideline (Stroke 2019;50:e344–e418; Class I, Level B-R) specifically recommends warfarin over direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) in APS. The TRAPS trial (N Engl J Med 2018;378:2013–2022) comparing rivaroxaban vs warfarin in high-risk, triple-positive APS was terminated early due to excess arterial thromboses in the DOAC arm, underscoring warfarin’s superiority.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Aspirin
– Mechanism: COX-1 inhibition reducing platelet aggregation.
– Misconception: Arterial thrombosis in APS is platelet-driven; in reality, it is antibody-mediated hypercoagulability requiring anticoagulation.
– Differentiator: Lacks efficacy in preventing recurrent APS thrombosis.
C. Clopidogrel
– Mechanism: P2Y₁₂ ADP-receptor blockade.
