This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam.
CADASIL frequently tests as a scenario of genetic small vessel stroke requiring extrapolation of general stroke prevention guidelines. Expect questions on MRI patterns, NOTCH3 genetics, and antiplatelet management.

question_text: A young lady with SLE nephritis on dialysis presents with seizures and confusion. MRI shows venous thrombosis in the transverse sinus. What is your diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) results from occlusion of dural sinuses or cortical veins, leading to venous hypertension, decreased CSF absorption, and intracranial hypertension. The transverse sinus drains blood from the superior sagittal sinus to the sigmoid sinus; thrombosis here can present with headache, seizures, focal deficits, and altered consciousness. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is associated with a hypercoagulable state due to nephrotic-range proteinuria, antiphospholipid antibodies, and dialysis-related factors, predisposing to CVT. Differential diagnoses include neuropsychiatric lupus (lupus cerebritis), which manifests with diffuse CNS inflammation; posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES), characterized by vasogenic edema and hypertension; and herpes simplex encephalitis, which shows temporal lobe involvement on MRI. Imaging with MRI and MRV is essential to visualize thrombus and distinguish from other etiologies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

In CVT, MRI combined with MR venography demonstrates absence of flow in the affected sinus. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2011 guidelines (class I, level A) recommend immediate anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) even in the presence of intracerebral hemorrhage. The European Stroke Organization (ESO) 2017 guidelines reaffirm these recommendations, advising 3–12 months of oral anticoagulation, extending indefinitely for antiphospholipid syndrome. SLE-related nephritis and hemodialysis amplify thrombogenic risk via proteinuria-induced antithrombin loss and endothelial dysfunction. Seizures are due to venous infarction and cortical irritation. Management begins with LMWH (1 mg/kg subcutaneously twice daily), transitioning to warfarin with an INR target of 2.0–3.0 or a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) per RESPECT CVT trial (NEJM 2020), which showed rivaroxaban noninferiority to warfarin and reduced major bleeding. Early diagnosis and treatment decrease mortality to ~5% and improve functional outcomes (Coutinho et al., Lancet Neurol 2017).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Lupus cerebritis
• Incorrect because lupus cerebritis produces diffuse inflammatory lesions without focal venous occlusion on MRV.
• Misconception: attributing all neuropsychiatric SLE manifestations to “cerebritis” rather than specific vascular events.
• Differentiator: Absence of sinus thrombosis on MRV; presence of systemic inflammation and other NPSLE markers.

B. Posterior Reversible Encephalopathy Syndrome (PRES)
• Incorrect as PRES shows symmetric parieto-occipital vasogenic edema on FLAIR without venous thrombosis.
• Misconception: confusing seizures in hypertensive or renal failure contexts with CVT.
• Differentiator: Normal MRV; rapid reversibility with blood pressure control.

D. Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) encephalitis
• Incorrect because HSV encephalitis has temporal lobe T2/FLAIR hyperintensity, hemorrhagic necrosis, and CSF PCR positivity, not sinus occlusion.
• Misconception: assuming any seizure in an immunosuppressed patient is infectious.
• Differentiator: MRI distribution (temporal lobes); CSF pleocytosis and PCR.

Comparison Table

FeatureCVTLupus cerebritisPRESHSV encephalitis
Clinical presentationHeadache, seizures, focal deficits, altered consciousnessCognitive dysfunction, psychosis, seizuresHeadache, seizures, visual disturbanceFever, headache, focal deficits, altered mental state
ImagingMRV: absent flow in dural sinuses; hemorrhagic infarctsMRI: diffuse white matter hyperintensities; no sinus occlusionMRI FLAIR: vasogenic edema in parieto-occipital regionsMRI: temporal lobe T2 hyperintensities; hemorrhagic necrosis
Risk factorsSLE, nephritis, dialysis, antiphospholipid syndromeSLE flares, high anti-dsDNA titersHypertension, renal failure, immunosuppressantsHSV-1 exposure, immunocompromise
TreatmentAnticoagulation (LMWH → warfarin/DOAC)Immunosuppression (steroids, cyclophosphamide)BP control, withdrawal of causative agentAcyclovir

Clinical Pearls

- In CVT with hemorrhagic infarction, anticoagulation remains the cornerstone of therapy and is not contraindicated (AHA/ASA class I).
• Magnetic resonance venography is the gold standard for diagnosing CVT; CT venography is an excellent alternative when MRI is unavailable.
• SLE patients with confirmed antiphospholipid antibodies require tailored long-term anticoagulation to prevent recurrent CVT.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Overlooking CVT in patients with SLE and renal failure, attributing seizures solely to lupus cerebritis or PRES without MRV.
• Withholding anticoagulation in hemorrhagic presentations of CVT due to fear of bleeding, contrary to guideline recommendations advocating treatment.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- European Stroke Organization (ESO) Guidelines, 2017: Recommends LMWH acute anticoagulation (Level A) and 3–12 months of oral anticoagulation based on risk factors (Level B); indefinite therapy for antiphospholipid syndrome.
• RESPECT CVT Trial, NEJM 2020: Randomized, open-label study showing rivaroxaban is noninferior to warfarin for preventing recurrent thrombosis in CVT (HR 0.33; 95% CI 0.06–1.93) with fewer major bleeding events (Level I evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The transverse sinus is a major dural venous channel receiving blood from the superior sagittal sinus; thrombosis impedes cortical venous outflow, causing elevated intracranial pressure and venous infarction in adjacent parietal and temporal lobes.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

SLE-mediated nephrotic-range proteinuria leads to antithrombin III loss; antiphospholipid antibodies induce endothelial activation; hemodialysis causes repetitive microtrauma to endothelium. These factors converge to promote dural sinus thrombosis, venous congestion, and intracranial hypertension.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in SLE patient with headache, seizures, focal deficits
2. Obtain brain MRI with MR venography to detect venous occlusion
3. Screen for hypercoagulable states (antiphospholipid antibodies, protein C/S)
4. Initiate LMWH, transition to warfarin or DOAC based on risk profile
5. Monitor neurological status and repeat imaging for recanalization

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI shows an isointense to hyperintense signal on T1 and T2 in the thrombosed sinus (“cord sign”); MRV reveals absence of flow (“empty delta sign” on contrast-enhanced CT venography).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Start LMWH at 1 mg/kg SC q12h; after stabilization, transition to warfarin with target INR 2.0–3.0 for 3–12 months or a DOAC (e.g., rivaroxaban 20 mg daily) as supported by recent RCT data.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam. CVT versus PRES and NPSLE are high-yield differentials on board exams, often tested via seizure presentations with imaging correlates; emphasize MRV interpretation and anticoagulation management.

question_text: Patient had mild trauma as he cannot see the left side of the road. Presented with visual deficit and reported a similar headache at age 15 years occurring for about 24 hours. What is your diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] - Vertebral arteries supply the posterior circulation, including occipital lobes that mediate visual fields.
• Cervical artery dissection often follows minor neck trauma, with intimal tear leading to intramural hematoma, luminal compromise and embolism.
• Contralateral homonymous hemianopia (“cannot see the left side”) localizes to the right occipital cortex, fitting a posterior circulation ischemic event.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Vertebral artery dissection is the correct diagnosis because:
• Minor trauma preceded persistent neck pain/headache and acute left homonymous hemianopia, classic for dissection-induced occipital infarction (Schievink 2001; Kennedy et al. 2017).
• Imaging: CTA shows tapered stenosis or “string sign”; MRI T1 fat-suppression highlights intramural hematoma (Debette & Leys 2009).
• AHA/ASA 2019 guidelines (Class I, Level B-R) recommend early vascular imaging in suspected cervical dissection and 3–6 months of antithrombotic therapy.
• CADISS trial (Lancet Neurol. 2015) demonstrated no significant difference between anticoagulation and antiplatelet agents for preventing recurrent stroke in cervical dissection.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. PRES
• Typically presents with acute hypertension or eclampsia, seizures, and bilateral vasogenic edema on MRI rather than a focal homonymous field cut.
• Misconception: Any posterior visual symptom equals PRES; PRES shows symmetric T2/FLAIR changes, not trauma-induced focal deficits.

B. RCVS
• Characterized by sudden, recurrent thunderclap headaches over days–weeks and reversible, multifocal arterial narrowing on angiography without early focal deficits.
• Mistaken when acute headache and visual change occur, but RCVS lacks isolated visual field loss until late ischemic complications.

D. Occipital Lobe Infarction
• Explains the visual deficit but not the preceding trauma-triggered headache; infarction here is the consequence, not the primary diagnosis (the underlying pathology is dissection).

Comparison Table

FeatureVertebral DissectionPRESRCVSOccipital Infarction
TriggerMinor neck traumaHypertensive crisis, eclampsiaVasoactive substances, postpartumAtherosclerotic or cardioembolic
Headache patternGradual/severe neck painDull, global, with seizuresRecurrent thunderclap headachesOften minimal or stroke-related
Visual defectContralateral homonymous hemianopiaCortical blindness, blurry visionRare focal earlyContralateral homonymous hemianopia
ImagingCTA/MRA: intimal flap, stenosisMRI: posterior edemaAngiography: “string and beads”CT/MRI: focal occipital lesion
TreatmentAntithrombotic 3–6 monthsBP control, remove triggerCalcium channel blockersAcute stroke protocols

Clinical Pearls

- Always enquire about recent neck trauma in a patient with acute posterior circulation symptoms.
• Homonymous hemianopia localizes to the contralateral occipital cortex—differentiate central from ocular causes.
• CADISS trial supports aspirin as a safe, first-line therapy for cervical artery dissection.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing migraine aura or ocular pathology with true homonymous hemianopia without confirming central involvement.
2. Prematurely diagnosing RCVS based on headache pattern alone, without angiographic confirmation of reversible vasoconstriction.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guideline 2019: Class I, Level B-R recommendation for CTA/MRA in suspected cervical dissection and 3–6 months of antithrombotic therapy.
2. CADISS Trial (Lancet Neurol. 2015): No significant difference in stroke recurrence between anticoagulation and antiplatelet therapy in cervical artery dissection (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The optic radiations from the lateral geniculate nucleus traverse to the calcarine cortex in the occipital lobes. A right occipital lesion produces a left homonymous hemianopia, often sparing macular vision due to dual blood supply.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Intimal tear in the vertebral artery allows blood to enter the arterial wall, forming an intramural hematoma. This narrows the lumen, promotes thrombus formation, and can embolize to distal PCA branches, causing occipital infarction.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Recognize neck pain/headache + focal visual loss after trauma.
2. Exclude hemorrhage with non-contrast CT head.
3. Perform CTA/MRA of cervical and intracranial vessels.
4. Obtain MRI brain with DWI and fat-suppressed T1 sequences.
5. Initiate antithrombotic therapy and monitor.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CTA: look for tapered stenosis (“string sign”) and double lumen.
• MRI T1 fat-suppression: intramural hematoma appears hyperintense.
• Diffusion MRI confirms acute infarction in occipital cortex.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: aspirin 75–325 mg daily for 3–6 months (ESO 2018, Class IIa).
• Consider anticoagulation (warfarin or DOAC) if intracranial thrombus risk is high; no clear superiority over antiplatelet (CADISS).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2022 exam. Posterior circulation stroke due to cervical artery dissection is frequently tested as a clinical vignette highlighting mild trauma, ipsilateral neck pain/headache, contralateral homonymous hemianopia, and diagnostic use of CTA/MRA with emphasis on antithrombotic management.

question_text: A female patient taking oral contraceptive pills (OCP) had a cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT), and the thrombophilia workup was negative. For how long should she be on anticoagulation?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) is a venous thromboembolic event in the dural sinuses or cortical veins that can lead to intracranial hypertension and focal deficits. Key concepts:
• Provoked vs. unprovoked thrombosis: Transient risk factors (e.g., OCP use) classify CVT as provoked, guiding shorter anticoagulation.
• Risk stratification: Negative thrombophilia workup and removal of the precipitant (stopping OCPs) reduce recurrence risk.
• Anticoagulation duration: Balancing hemorrhagic risk with thrombosis recurrence, guidelines recommend finite therapy for provoked events (typically 3–6 months).

Evidence-Based Analysis

The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2017 guidelines on CVT management advise 3–6 months of anticoagulation for CVT provoked by transient risk factors (Class IIa, Level C). Stopping OCPs removes the inciting factor, and a negative thrombophilia panel indicates low baseline thrombosis risk. A meta-analysis of cohort studies (Coutinho et al., 2012) showed recurrence rates <5% after 6 months of anticoagulation in provoked CVT. Extended therapy beyond 6 months does not further reduce recurrences but increases bleeding risk. Therefore, 3–6 months strikes the optimal balance.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Lifelong
• Incorrect: Lifelong anticoagulation is reserved for unprovoked CVT with persistent risk factors (e.g., antiphospholipid syndrome). Extending beyond 6 months for provoked CVT yields no proven benefit and higher hemorrhage risk.
• Misconception: Equating venous thromboembolism (VTE) management of deep vein thrombosis in unprovoked cases with provoked CVT.

C. 1 month
• Incorrect: One month is insufficient; early discontinuation leads to >10% recurrence (Einhäupl et al., 2010).
• Misconception: Underestimating the time needed for sinus recanalization and endothelial healing.

D. 12 months
• Incorrect: Twelve months exceeds recommended duration for provoked CVT and increases cumulative bleeding risk without reducing recurrence.
• Misconception: Believing longer is always safer; ignores risk–benefit balance.

Comparison Table

OptionDurationIndicationGuideline Recommendation
3–6 months3–6 monthsCVT with transient riskAHA/ASA 2017: Class IIa, Level C
LifelongIndefiniteUnprovoked CVT/persistent RFAHA/ASA: only for persistent RF
1 month1 monthSubtherapeutic (too short)Insufficient for recanalization
12 months12 monthsOverextensionExceeds provoked CVT guidelines

Clinical Pearls

- Always classify CVT as provoked vs. unprovoked to determine duration.
• Discontinue transient risk factors (e.g., OCPs) before stopping anticoagulation.
• Monitor for recanalization on follow-up MR venography; most recanalize by 3–6 months.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Treating all CVT like pulmonary embolism: CVT provoked by OCPs rarely needs >6 months.
2. Failing to stop OCPs: Continuing the risk factor invalidates the classification as “transient.”

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2017 Guidelines for CVT Management: Recommends 3–6 months of anticoagulation for CVT provoked by transient factors (Class IIa, Level C).
• ESO (European Stroke Organization) 2017 Guidelines: Advises 3 months of Vitamin K antagonist therapy for provoked CVT (Grade 2B).
• CHEST 2016 (ACCP) VTE Guidelines: For provoked VTE, including CVT, recommends 3 months of anticoagulation (Grade 1A).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. Duration of anticoagulation in provoked cerebral venous thrombosis is frequently tested as a multiple-choice vignette, often contrasting transient vs. persistent risk factors and correct therapy length.

question_text: Q271. Which of the following is the correct mechanism of action of these medications?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Platelet activation and thrombus formation involve primary hemostasis (platelet adhesion, activation, aggregation) and secondary hemostasis (coagulation cascade generating fibrin).
1. Cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) in platelets synthesizes thromboxane A₂ (TXA₂) to amplify aggregation.
2. The P2Y₁₂ receptor on platelets binds ADP, stabilizing aggregation via G_i signaling and reduced cAMP.
3. The coagulation cascade converges on factor Xa to convert prothrombin to thrombin (IIa), which cleaves fibrinogen into fibrin.
Antiplatelet agents (aspirin, P2Y₁₂ antagonists) and anticoagulants (direct factor Xa inhibitors, direct thrombin inhibitors) target distinct steps in thrombosis, critical in stroke prevention.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Ticagrelor is a cyclopentyltriazolopyrimidine that reversibly and noncompetitively binds the P2Y₁₂ receptor on platelet surfaces, blocking ADP-induced G_i signaling, preserving cAMP levels, and inhibiting platelet aggregation. Unlike thienopyridines (clopidogrel, prasugrel), ticagrelor does not require hepatic bioactivation and offers more rapid onset and offset. The PLATO trial (NEJM 2009; Level A) demonstrated a 16% relative risk reduction in composite cardiovascular death, MI, or stroke compared to clopidogrel in acute coronary syndrome, validating P2Y₁₂ blockade. Current AHA/ASA guidelines endorse P2Y₁₂ inhibitors for acute coronary syndrome and select secondary stroke prevention scenarios.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Aspirin inhibits adenosine deaminase
• Incorrect: Aspirin irreversibly acetylates serine 529 of COX-1, preventing TXA₂ synthesis.
• Misconception: Confusing aspirin’s acetylation with unrelated enzymes.

C. Apixaban and rivaroxaban are direct thrombin inhibitors
• Incorrect: These are direct, selective factor Xa inhibitors, preventing prothrombin→thrombin conversion.
• Misconception: Equating all DOACs with dabigatran (true direct thrombin inhibitor).

D. Clopidogrel inhibits factor 7, 10, 11, 12
• Incorrect: Clopidogrel irreversibly blocks P2Y₁₂ ADP receptors on platelets.
• Misconception: Confusing antiplatelet thienopyridines with anticoagulant vitamin K antagonism or factor inhibitors.

Comparison Table

DrugPrimary TargetMechanismActivation RequirementReversibility
Ticagrelor (Correct)P2Y₁₂ receptorReversible, noncompetitive antagonismNo bioactivationReversible
Aspirin (A)COX-1 enzymeIrreversible acetylationNo bioactivationIrreversible
Apixaban/Rivaroxaban (C)Factor XaDirect competitive inhibitionNo bioactivationReversible
Clopidogrel (D)P2Y₁₂ receptorIrreversible antagonismHepatic CYP2C19 bioactivationIrreversible

Clinical Pearls

- Ticagrelor has a loading dose of 180 mg and maintenance 90 mg BID; monitor for dyspnea (~10% incidence) due to adenosine uptake inhibition.
• Factor Xa inhibitors (apixaban 5 mg BID; rivaroxaban 20 mg daily) require dose adjustment in renal impairment and have a specific reversal agent (andexanet alfa).
• Aspirin’s antiplatelet effect lasts for the platelet lifespan (~7–10 days), so bleeding risk persists until new platelets are generated.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing direct thrombin inhibitors (dabigatran) with factor Xa inhibitors (apixaban, rivaroxaban).
2. Assuming all P2Y₁₂ inhibitors (ticagrelor vs clopidogrel) have the same pharmacokinetics; ticagrelor is reversible and does not require hepatic activation.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• 2019 AHA/ACC/HRS Guideline for Atrial Fibrillation (Circulation 2019;Class I, LOE A): Recommends DOACs (apixaban, rivaroxaban) over warfarin for nonvalvular AF to prevent stroke/systemic embolism.
• AHA/ASA 2021 Update on Acute Ischemic Stroke and TIA (Stroke 2021; LOE B‐R): For minor noncardioembolic stroke or high-risk TIA, adding ticagrelor to aspirin within 24 h for 30 days reduces recurrent stroke (based on THALES trial).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Ticagrelor: rapid onset (~30 min), peak platelet inhibition at 2 h, half-life ~7–12 h; avoid in history of intracranial hemorrhage.
Apixaban/Rivaroxaban: predictable pharmacokinetics, no routine monitoring; rivaroxaban absorption enhanced with food at doses ≥15 mg.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam. Antithrombotic mechanism questions frequently test distinction between platelet‐directed agents (COX inhibitors, P2Y₁₂ antagonists) and coagulation cascade inhibitors (factor Xa vs thrombin inhibitors).

question_text: A 30-year-old male patient with a traumatic brain injury 5 days ago, intubated, and with respiratory settings within normal limits developed aphasia (features of vasospasm). What management, if given as prophylaxis, will improve or prevent further morbidity?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] Cerebral vasospasm is a delayed, sustained constriction of intracranial arteries following subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), leading to delayed cerebral ischemia (DCI). In traumatic brain injury (TBI) with associated SAH, blood breakdown products trigger endothelial dysfunction and smooth muscle contraction. Nimodipine, a lipophilic dihydropyridine calcium‐channel blocker, crosses the blood–brain barrier and preferentially relaxes cerebral vessels. Prophylactic administration aims to reduce DCI and poor functional outcome. Students should understand:
• Pathophysiology of blood‐induced arterial spasm (endothelin release, free radical generation)
• Role of L‐type Ca2+ channels in vascular smooth muscle contraction
• Distinction between prophylaxis (nimodipine in SAH) vs. acute ICP management (hyperventilation)

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. IV fluids
• Reason incorrect: While adequate volume status supports cerebral perfusion, hypervolemia alone has not been shown to prevent vasospasm or DCI. Misconception: “Triple‐H” therapy prophylaxis includes hypervolemia; in fact, induced hypertension (not simple IV fluids) treats established vasospasm.

C. Hyperventilation
• Reason incorrect: Lowers PaCO₂ and causes cerebral vasoconstriction, reducing intracranial pressure at the cost of CBF, which can exacerbate ischemia in vasospasm. Misconception: Any vasoconstriction is beneficial for ICP control, but in vasospasm it is harmful.

D. Antiepileptic drugs
• Reason incorrect: Seizure prophylaxis does not influence vascular smooth muscle or prevent vasospasm. Misconception: “Preventing seizures prevents secondary ischemia,” but this does not address spasm‐mediated DCI.

Comparison Table

InterventionMechanismEvidence for Vasospasm ProphylaxisRecommended Use
NimodipineL‐type Ca²⁺ channel blockade; neuroprotectionRCTs and meta‐analyses show reduced DCI and poor outcomeOral 60 mg q4h × 21 days in SAH patients
IV fluidsIncreases intravascular volumeNo RCT support for prophylaxis; risk of cerebral edemaMaintain euvolemia; avoid hypervolemia alone
Hyperventilation↓PaCO₂ → vasoconstrictionContraindicated prophylactically; worsens ischemiaShort‐term ICP control only
AntiepilepticStabilizes neuronal membranesNo effect on vasospasm or DCISeizure prophylaxis in TBI only

Clinical Pearls

- Nimodipine should be initiated within 96 hours of hemorrhage and continued for 21 days to reduce DCI and improve outcomes.
• “Triple‐H” therapy components differ: prophylaxis relies solely on nimodipine; induced hypertension (not hypervolemia) is used to reverse established vasospasm.
• Avoid prophylactic hyperventilation (PaCO₂ <30 mm Hg) in vasospasm risk—can precipitate ischemic deficits.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating prophylactic hyperventilation with vasospasm prevention; in reality it decreases CBF and worsens ischemia.
2. Believing seizure prophylaxis (e.g., phenytoin) mitigates vasospasm—anticonvulsants have no effect on vascular smooth muscle.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2012 Guidelines for Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage – Class I, Level A recommendation for oral nimodipine to prevent DCI and poor outcome.
2. Cochrane Review (Gedge et al., 2016) – Nimodipine reduces the risk of poor functional outcome (RR 0.82) in SAH patients; moderate‐quality evidence.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Nimodipine is a dihydropyridine calcium‐channel blocker with high lipophilicity allowing CNS penetration. Standard dosing: 60 mg po every 4 hours for 21 days. Monitor for hypotension; hold if systolic BP <90 mm Hg. IV formulations are not recommended due to risk of severe hypotension.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2022 exam. Cerebral vasospasm prophylaxis with nimodipine is a high‐yield topic on neurology and critical care boards, frequently tested via SAH vignettes asking about delayed ischemia prevention.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is A. Nimodipine. This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

question_text: In the case of a 60-year-old male patient with a 3.5-hour history of sudden left-sided flaccid weakness, severe dysarthria, and facial weakness, who presented to the ER with a normal CT brain scan and later developed intracranial hemorrhage after receiving IV tPA, what is the protocol violation in community-based rTPA stroke treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] Acute ischemic stroke results from sudden occlusion of cerebral arteries, leading to time-dependent neuronal injury. Thrombolytic therapy with intravenous alteplase (rtPA) is indicated within a 4.5-hour window to dissolve thrombi and restore perfusion. Candidate selection relies on neuroanatomical localization of deficits (NIHSS scoring) and exclusion of hemorrhagic or high-risk features via imaging and lab tests. Absolute contraindications include platelet count below 100 000/µL due to elevated hemorrhagic transformation risk, while relative contraindications—like minor non-disabling deficits—are weighed case-by-case. Recognizing these parameters ensures maximal benefit with minimized intracranial hemorrhage. Familiarity with AHA/ASA criteria and contraindication classifications is essential for safe community-based stroke management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer (platelet count of 45,000) represents an absolute contraindication to IV alteplase per current guidelines. The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Powers et al., Stroke 2018) assign a Class III (harm) recommendation against rtPA if platelet count <100 000/µL; thrombocytopenia sharply elevates risk of symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage (sICH). In pooled analyses (Hacke et al., Lancet Neurol 2008), patients with thrombocytopenia had a two- to threefold increase in sICH rates. Although the patient presented within the appropriate 3.5-hour window and had disabling deficits (NIHSS >5), administering rtPA in the context of severe thrombocytopenia directly violated protocol and contributed to hemorrhagic transformation. Other factors—such as time window compliance (3.5 h <4.5 h) and disabling deficits—were appropriate.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Low deficit
• Why incorrect: The patient had severe dysarthria and flaccid weakness, consistent with an NIHSS >5, indicating disabling deficit.
• Misconception: Equating all motor deficits as “minor” regardless of functional impact.
• Differentiator: NIHSS threshold >5 qualifies as disabling, justifying rtPA absent other contraindications.

B. Out of tPA window
• Why incorrect: He presented within 3.5 hours (<4.5 hours) of symptom onset, fitting the approved time frame.
• Misconception: Confusing the strict 3-hour window with the extended 4.5-hour window.
• Differentiator: Extended window up to 4.5 hours is evidence-based (ECASS III).

D. Recent major surgery
• Why incorrect: No history of recent surgery was documented.
• Misconception: Assuming any severe stroke patient recently underwent surgery.
• Differentiator: Recent (past 14 days) intracranial or intraspinal surgery would contraindicate, but not present here.

Comparison Table

FeaturePlatelet <100 000/µL (C)Low NIHSS Deficit (A)>4.5 h Window (B)Recent Surgery (D)
Contraindication TypeAbsolute (Class III, Harm)RelativeN/A within 4.5 hAbsolute if intracranial
Guideline ReferenceAHA/ASA 2018AHA/ASA 2018ECASS IIIAHA/ASA 2018
Risk of sICHHigh (>2× baseline)Low when truly minorN/A if treated in windowHigh if intracranial surgery

Clinical Pearls

- Always verify laboratory values (platelets, INR) before rtPA; automated stroke protocols may skip manual review under time pressure.
• Disabling deficits (NIHSS >5) justify rtPA even if motor function is the primary issue; document clearly.
• Extended window to 4.5 hours (ECASS III) applies only in selected patients without additional risk factors.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Ignoring thrombocytopenia: Students often overlook platelet count as a contraindication, focusing solely on imaging.
• Misjudging deficit severity: Motor weakness may seem “minor” if improving, but functional impairment dictates rtPA eligibility.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines (Powers et al.): Platelet count <100 000/µL is a Class III (Harm), Level B–R contraindication to IV alteplase.
• European Stroke Organisation 2021 Guidelines: Reinforce contraindication for thrombocytopenia <100 000/µL (Grade 1C) and endorse ECASS III window extension.
• EXTEND Trial (Ma et al., NEJM 2019): Supports perfusion-based selection to extend window up to 9 hours, but does not override absolute lab contraindications.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2022 exam. Students are frequently tested on rtPA inclusion/exclusion criteria, especially laboratory-based contraindications and extended time windows.

question_text: Q242. What is the management for a patient with a history of ischemic stroke who is contraindicated for tPA?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] Acute ischemic stroke results from arterial occlusion leading to an infarct core surrounded by a potentially salvageable penumbra. Reperfusion therapy aims to restore blood flow before irreversible neuronal injury. Intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is first-line within 4.5 hours but has contraindications (e.g., recent hemorrhage, surgery). Mechanical thrombectomy physically removes clot in large vessel occlusions (LVO) and is indicated when tPA is contraindicated or has failed. Key concepts:
• Ischemic penumbra and time‐dependent neuronal death
• Large vessel occlusion (e.g., proximal MCA/ICA) pathophysiology
• Reperfusion strategies: pharmacologic (tPA) vs endovascular

(Word count: 118)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Mechanical thrombectomy is a Class I, Level A recommendation in the 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for patients with anterior circulation LVO within 6 hours of onset and favorable imaging (ASPECTS ≥6). The MR CLEAN (2015) trial demonstrated a number needed to treat (NNT) of 7.4 for improved 90-day functional outcomes. Later DAWN (2018; NNT = 2.8) and DEFUSE-3 (2018; NNT = 3) extended the window to 6–24 hours for selected patients with perfusion–diffusion mismatch. In contraindicated tPA scenarios—recent surgery, hemorrhage risk, or beyond the window—thrombectomy remains the only proven reperfusion modality. Meta-analysis of HERMES collaborators confirms benefit across age and stroke severity subgroups.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. IV thrombolytic therapy
• Incorrect: Contraindicated by definition; risk of hemorrhagic conversion in high-risk patients.
• Misconception: Belief that every ischemic stroke patient qualifies for tPA.
• Differentiator: tPA has strict inclusion/exclusion criteria (e.g., no recent intracranial surgery).

C. Antiplatelet therapy
• Incorrect: Role is secondary prevention, not acute reperfusion.
• Misconception: Confusing chronic stroke prevention with emergent treatment.
• Differentiator: Onset of action too slow to abort evolving infarct.

D. Supportive care and rehabilitation
• Incorrect: Does not address acute vessel occlusion; only post-stroke management.
• Misconception: Underestimating the time‐sensitive nature of reperfusion.
• Differentiator: Lacks evidence for improving acute neurologic outcome.

Comparison Table

FeatureMechanical ThrombectomyIV tPAAntiplatelet TherapySupportive Care
IndicationLVO, tPA‐ineligible or failedAcute ≤4.5 h ischemic strokeSecondary preventionPost-acute management
Time windowUp to 6 h (extendable to 24 h)≤4.5 h from onsetChronicAnytime
MechanismEndovascular clot retrievalPlasminogen activationPlatelet inhibitionGeneral supportive measures
Key trials/guidelinesMR CLEAN, HERMES, DEFUSE-3NINDS, ECASS IIICAPRIE, CHARISMA—
Level of evidenceI, AI, AI, B—

Clinical Pearls

• Always obtain CT angiography after noncontrast CT to identify LVO.
• Aim for door-to-groin puncture ≤90 minutes to maximize penumbral salvage.
• General anesthesia may delay reperfusion; consider conscious sedation when feasible.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating antiplatelet loading with reperfusion—antiplatelets prevent recurrence, not acute infarct expansion.
2. Omitting vascular imaging post-CT scan—fails to identify thrombectomy candidates.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2019 Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommends thrombectomy for anterior LVO within 6 h (Class I, Level A).
• DAWN Trial (NEJM 2018): Extends thrombectomy eligibility to 6–24 h in patients with small core/large penumbra (Class I, Level B-R).
• DEFUSE-3 (NEJM 2018): Confirms benefit in 6–16 h window with perfusion mismatch (Class I, Level B-R).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Large vessel occlusions most commonly involve the proximal middle cerebral artery (M1 segment) or intracranial internal carotid artery, leading to contralateral hemiparesis, aphasia (dominant), and neglect (non-dominant).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thrombus in a major cerebral artery arrests antegrade perfusion, initiating the ischemic cascade: energy failure, glutamate excitotoxicity, and infarct core expansion. Mechanical thrombectomy rapidly restores flow to salvage penumbral tissue.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Rapid NIHSS assessment
2. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage
3. CT angiography/perfusion to confirm LVO and penumbra
4. Decision on thrombectomy eligibility (time, contraindications)

Neuroimaging Pearls

CT perfusion mismatch (Tmax >6 s volume versus infarct core) predicts penumbral tissue and thrombectomy benefit. Collateral scoring on CTA informs prognosis.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2022 exam.
Management of tPA-ineligible acute stroke with LVO is frequently tested as scenario-based questions focusing on time windows, imaging criteria, and guideline-based therapy.

question_text: Q235. In the scenario of a 65-year-old male with a history of diabetes and hypertension who presents to the ER with left-sided weakness lasting for 18 minutes, what is the 90-day risk of stroke?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] • Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) is defined as a transient neurological deficit without acute infarction.
• The ABCD² score (Age, Blood pressure, Clinical features, Duration, Diabetes) stratifies 2-, 7-, and 90-day stroke risk after TIA.
• Key variables: age ≥60 years (1 point), BP ≥140/90 mm Hg (1), unilateral weakness (2), symptom duration 10–59 min (1), diabetes (1).
• Total ABCD² ranges 0–7: low (0–3), moderate (4–5), high (6–7) risk categories.

Evidence-Based Analysis

An ABCD² score of 6 in this patient (age 1 + BP 1 + weakness 2 + duration 1 + diabetes 1) places him in the high-risk group. Johnston et al. (NEJM 2007) demonstrated that patients with scores 6–7 have a 90-day stroke risk of 17.8%. The 2018 AHA/ASA TIA guidelines (Class I, Level B-R) endorse using ABCD² for early risk stratification, noting that high-risk patients benefit from expedited imaging and dual antiplatelet therapy (POINT trial, NEJM 2018).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Low – Incorrect. Low-risk ABCD² (0–3) corresponds to <3 % 90-day stroke risk, but this patient scores 6. It reflects underestimation of his risk.
B. Moderate – Incorrect. Moderate (4–5) yields ~9.8 % 90-day risk; his 6-point score exceeds this threshold.
D. Very high – Incorrect. No “very high” category exists in standard ABCD² stratification; the uppermost defined tier is “high.”

Comparison Table

ABCD² ScoreCategory90-Day Stroke Risk (%)
0–3Low1–3
4–5Moderate~9.8
6–7High~17.8

Clinical Pearls

• TIA patients with high ABCD² scores (6–7) should receive brain MRI ± vascular imaging within 24 hours.
• Early dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) for 21 days reduces early recurrent stroke in high-risk TIAs (POINT, CHANCE trials).
• Carotid duplex and cardiac evaluation are urgent in high-risk patients to identify treatable sources.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Mistaking ABCD (4-factor) for ABCD²: omitting diabetes underestimates risk.
• Applying ABCD² to posterior circulation TIAs without symptom adjustment may misclassify risk.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2018 Secondary Stroke Prevention Guideline: endorses ABCD² for early risk stratification (Class I, LOE B-R).
• POINT Trial (NEJM 2018): early dual antiplatelet therapy in high-risk TIA (ABCD² ≥4) reduces 90-day stroke recurrence (HR 0.68; p=0.04).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. TIA risk stratification via ABCD² is frequently tested in both clinical vignettes and direct recall formats on neurology and internal medicine board exams.

question_text: A patient presents with left MCA occlusion within 3.5 hours from symptom onset and has a history of ischemic stroke 2 months ago. What is the appropriate management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] - The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the lateral cerebral cortex; large‐vessel occlusions produce severe deficits and large penumbras.
• Intravenous alteplase (IV tPA) within 4.5 h and mechanical thrombectomy (MT) within 6 h are class I interventions to salvage penumbral tissue.
• A history of ischemic stroke within 3 months is a relative, not absolute, contraindication to tPA; benefit often outweighs hemorrhage risk in large‐vessel occlusion (LVO).
• Bridging therapy (tPA + MT) maximizes early reperfusion and improves functional outcomes in anterior LVO.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option B is correct because:
• AHA/ASA guidelines (Powers et al. 2021 update) give Class I, Level A recommendation for IV alteplase in eligible patients within 4.5 h, even with a stroke 2 months ago (relative exclusion).
• Mechanical thrombectomy for anterior circulation LVO within 6 h (Class I, Level A) greatly increases recanalization rates (~70–80%) versus IV tPA alone (~30% for LVO).
• Trials such as MR CLEAN and ESCAPE showed that bridging therapy reduces disability at 90 days (OR ~1.7, p<0.01).
• Combined therapy addresses both microvascular and macrovascular occlusion, optimizing penumbral salvage.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. IV tPA alone
• Incorrect: Recanalization rates for LVO are low (~30%). Relies solely on fibrinolysis; MT needed for large clots.
• Misconception: tPA suffices for all ischemic strokes.

C. DAPT
• Incorrect: Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) is indicated for minor stroke/TIA prevention over 21 days, not acute LVO management.
• Misconception: All ischemic strokes benefit from DAPT acutely.

D. IV heparin
• Incorrect: No evidence supports unfractionated heparin in acute LVO; increases hemorrhagic transformation risk.
• Misconception: Systemic anticoagulation prevents clot propagation in hyperacute stroke.

Comparison Table

InterventionTime WindowRecanalization Rate in LVOKey ContraindicationsGuideline Strength
IV tPA + MT0–4.5 h / 0–6 h~75–80%Relative: stroke <3 monthsI, A
IV tPA alone0–4.5 h~30%Relative: stroke <3 monthsI, A
DAPTPost-TIA/minorn/aNot for acute LVOI, B (for minor stroke)
IV heparinNot recommendedn/aHigh hemorrhage riskIII, C

Clinical Pearls

- Prior stroke <3 months is relative, not absolute, contraindication to IV tPA; weigh risk/benefit in severe LVO.
• Always assess large‐vessel occlusion with CTA/MRA to plan for MT.
• “Door-to-needle” time <60 min and “door-to-groin” puncture <90 min are critical metrics.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Treating LVO with tPA alone due to underestimating clot burden.
2. Overgeneralizing DAPT indications from minor stroke/TIA to all ischemic strokes.
3. Misinterpreting relative vs absolute tPA exclusions, leading to underuse in high-benefit scenarios.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines 2021 (Powers et al.): Class I, LOE A for IV alteplase ≤4.5 h even with stroke 3 months prior; Class I, LOE A for MT ≤6 h in anterior LVO.
• CHOICE Trial (Stroke, 2023): Bridging therapy (IV tPA + MT) yielded higher 90-day functional independence (mRS 0–2) compared to direct MT alone (OR 1.5, p=0.02).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam.
High-yield for stroke management questions: they often test time windows, contraindications to tPA, and indications for mechanical thrombectomy.

question_text: A patient with CADASIL is being considered for prophylaxis against stroke. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] CADASIL (Cerebral Autosomal Dominant Arteriopathy with Subcortical Infarcts and Leukoencephalopathy) is a hereditary small-vessel disease caused by NOTCH3 mutations leading to vascular smooth muscle cell degeneration and arteriolar fibrosis. Key principles:
• Small vessel occlusion in deep white matter and basal ganglia produces lacunar infarcts, migraines, cognitive decline, and strokes.
• Vascular risk factors (especially smoking, hypertension) exacerbate endothelial dysfunction and accelerate ischemic injury in CADASIL.
• No disease-modifying therapy exists; management focuses on reducing modifiable stroke risks.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Smoking increases oxidative stress and endothelial damage, amplifying the small-vessel pathology in CADASIL. Observational cohorts demonstrate smokers with CADASIL suffer strokes ~5 years earlier than non-smokers. The 2018 AHA/ASA Primary Prevention of Stroke Guideline (Class I, Level A) and USPSTF 2020 Tobacco Cessation Recommendation (Grade A) both emphasize clinician-led smoking cessation as a cornerstone of stroke prevention.
Warfarin carries heightened intracerebral hemorrhage risk in leukoencephalopathy and microbleeds; no data support anticoagulation.
Aspirin’s benefit in CADASIL is unproven and may increase microbleed burden without reducing lacunar infarcts.
Abstaining from any intervention forfeits the only evidence-backed strategy to delay stroke onset in this population.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Anticoagulant (warfarin)
• Why incorrect: Elevated hemorrhage risk in leukoaraiosis; no RCT data supporting anticoagulation for CADASIL.
• Misconception: Confusing cardioembolic prophylaxis with small-vessel stroke prevention.
• Differentiator: Anticoagulation indicated for atrial fibrillation, not for genetic arteriopathy.

C. Aspirin
• Why incorrect: Limited observational data fail to show stroke risk reduction; may worsen microbleeds.
• Misconception: Assuming antiplatelet therapy universally benefits all ischemic stroke subtypes.
• Differentiator: Unlike smoking cessation (an upstream risk factor), aspirin acts downstream on platelets with unclear net benefit.

D. No treatment
• Why incorrect: Ignores established benefit of risk factor modification; misses an opportunity to delay first stroke.
• Misconception: Belief that genetic conditions are untreatable so management is futile.
• Differentiator: Even in monogenic disease, secondary prevention via lifestyle is impactful.

Comparison Table

FeatureSmoking Cessation (A)Warfarin (B)Aspirin (C)No Treatment (D)
MechanismReduces endothelial oxidative damageInhibits vitamin K-dependent clotting factorsInhibits platelet cyclo-oxygenaseNone
Evidence in CADASILObservational benefit; delays stroke onsetNo data; risk of hemorrhageNo proven benefit; risk of microbleedsN/A
Key BenefitLowers stroke risk; slows SVD progressionPrevents cardioembolic strokes (not relevant here)Secondary prevention in atherothrombotic diseaseNone
Main RiskNicotine withdrawal (manageable)Intracerebral hemorrhageIncreased microbleed burdenContinued risk factor exposure

Clinical Pearls

- CADASIL patients who quit smoking may delay their first stroke by 4–6 years compared to continuing smokers.
• Routine anticoagulation is contraindicated unless there is a separate cardioembolic indication.
• Discuss nicotine replacement therapy and behavioral counseling early in CADASIL clinics.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating small-vessel stroke prevention with anticoagulation—CADASIL pathology is non-embolic.
2. Overgeneralizing aspirin’s benefit from large-artery ischemic stroke to genetic small-vessel disease.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association/American Stroke Association, 2018 Primary Prevention of Stroke Guideline: Class I, Level A recommendation for lifestyle modification, including smoking cessation, in all high-risk populations.
• U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, 2020 Tobacco Use in Adults: Clinical Interventions Recommendation: Grade A—clinician-delivered interventions and pharmacotherapy for smoking cessation to prevent cardiovascular and cerebrovascular disease.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

NOTCH3 gene mutations lead to accumulation of granular osmiophilic material and loss of smooth muscle cells in small arterioles. This progressive arteriopathy causes chronic hypoperfusion, lacunar infarction, and leukoencephalopathy. Vascular risk factors potentiate this microvascular injury.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Smoking cessation: First-line involves nicotine replacement, varenicline, bupropion; referral to counseling improves quit rates by 50–70%.
• Warfarin: contraindicated absent cardioembolism; associated with symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage in SVD.
• Aspirin: reserved for conventional atherothrombotic risk; no CADASIL-specific indication.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam.
CADASIL stroke prevention questions often test recognition of modifiable risk factors versus inappropriate use of anticoagulation or antiplatelets in hereditary small-vessel disease.

question_text: A young female presents with a case about cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT). What is a possible risk factor?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] - The cerebral venous system comprises superficial/deep veins draining into dural sinuses (e.g., superior sagittal, transverse) that empty into the internal jugular veins.
• CVT occurs when a thrombus obstructs these venous channels, causing increased intracranial pressure, venous congestion, and potential hemorrhagic infarction.
• Virchow’s triad (hypercoagulability, stasis, endothelial injury) underlies CVT pathogenesis; systemic inflammatory conditions like Ulcerative Colitis (UC) drive hypercoagulability.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Ulcerative Colitis is a well‐established acquired prothrombotic state. Chronic gut inflammation elevates fibrinogen and factor VIII levels, activates platelets, and downregulates protein C/S. A 2020 meta-analysis (Kumar et al., J Neurol Sci) demonstrated a 3.5‐fold increased risk of CVT in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) patients. The 2018 AHA/ASA CVT guidelines classify IBD as an acquired thrombophilia warranting targeted screening (Class I, Level B). Prothrombotic conditions—particularly IBD in young women—account for up to 70% of CVT cases, making UC the correct risk factor among the options.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Hypertension (HTN)
• HTN damages arterioles leading to arterial ischemic stroke or intracerebral hemorrhage, not venous thrombosis.
• Misconception: assuming all cerebrovascular risk factors apply to venous events.
• Differentiator: CVT arises from coagulopathy/inflammation, not pressure‐induced vascular injury.

B. Diabetes Mellitus (DM)
• DM drives atherosclerosis and microangiopathy, predisposing to arterial infarcts.
• Misconception: conflating metabolic arterial risk with venous clotting.
• Differentiator: no direct effect on venous clotting factors or endothelial procoagulant activity.

D. Migraine
• Migraine causes headache via neuronal hyperexcitability and vascular dysregulation, without promoting thrombosis.
• Misconception: equating headache disorders with risk for thrombotic events.
• Differentiator: migraine lacks systemic hypercoagulability or venous flow obstruction.

Comparison Table

FeatureUlcerative Colitis (UC)Hypertension (HTN)Diabetes Mellitus (DM)Migraine
MechanismSystemic inflammation → ↑ coagulationArteriolar hyaline changeAtherosclerosis, endothelial dysfunctionNeuronal hyperexcitability & vasodilation
Association with CVTHigh (≈3.5× risk)None/rareNoneNone
Typical stroke subtypeVenous thrombosisArterial ischemia/hemorrhageArterial ischemia/microvascularNo structural stroke
Coagulation profile↑ Fibrinogen, ↑ factor VIII, ↓ protein C/SNo significant prothrombotic changeNo direct prothrombotic effectNormal coagulation

Clinical Pearls

- Young women with CVT should be screened for IBD, OCP use, pregnancy/postpartum state, and inherited thrombophilias.
• MR venography is the gold standard for CVT diagnosis; look for absence of flow in the affected sinus.
• Anticoagulation with low–molecular–weight heparin is indicated even if small hemorrhages are present, unless there is a contraindication.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Overlooking gastrointestinal history in CVT workup and missing IBD as a key risk factor.
• Attributing headache solely to migraine or tension headache without considering CVT in the differential.
• Failing to apply Virchow’s triad when evaluating venous stroke presentations.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Guidelines on Cerebral Venous Thrombosis (2018): Recommends evaluation for acquired prothrombotic conditions—including IBD—in all CVT patients (Class I, Level B).
• European Stroke Organization Guidelines (2021): Support direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) as alternatives to vitamin K antagonists for CVT and highlight long‐term thromboprophylaxis considerations in IBD patients (Level IIb).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Thrombosis of the superior sagittal sinus impedes drainage from cortical veins, leading to diffuse intracranial hypertension and potential bilateral hemorrhagic infarcts. Transverse sinus involvement may present with focal hemispheric signs.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

In Ulcerative Colitis, cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6) induce endothelial activation and tissue factor expression, shifting hemostasis toward thrombosis. Platelet hyperreactivity and impaired fibrinolysis further enhance clot formation in cerebral veins.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam. Risk factors for CVT—especially IBD—are commonly tested in vignette formats to assess recognition of prothrombotic conditions and guide appropriate hypercoagulability workup.

question_text: Q240. Why is tPA contraindicated in patients who have had a stroke within the last 3 months?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Intravenous tissue-type plasminogen activator (tPA) remains the cornerstone of acute ischemic stroke therapy within 4.5 hours of onset. tPA promotes fibrinolysis by converting plasminogen to plasmin and thereby lysing intravascular thrombi. However, reperfusion into ischemic tissue—where the blood–brain barrier (BBB) is already disrupted—increases the risk of hemorrhagic transformation. The integrity of microvessels may remain impaired for weeks to months following an initial stroke, especially in peri-infarct regions with fragile neovascularization. Stroke management protocols categorize contraindications as absolute (therapy always withheld) or relative (therapy may be considered if benefits outweigh risks). Recognizing the graded risk associated with each exclusion criterion is essential for making informed, guideline-based decisions about thrombolysis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Answer A correctly identifies “ischemic stroke within the prior 3 months” as a relative contraindication per the 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Class III: No Benefit or Harm; Level C-EO). The landmark NINDS trial (1995) and subsequent registries (e.g., SITS-MOST) outlined exclusion criteria that balanced thrombolytic efficacy against hemorrhagic risk. In subgroup analyses from IST-3 (Lancet, 2012), patients with a prior stroke <3 months had a symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage (sICH) rate of ~9% versus ~6% overall (OR ~1.5), underscoring elevated bleeding risk. Mechanistically, upregulation of matrix metalloproteinases (particularly MMP-9) and persistent BBB disruption post-infarct predispose to reperfusion hemorrhage. Clinicians must therefore weigh the modest benefit of reperfusion against the quantified risk of sICH when a recent stroke is in the history.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. It is an absolute contraindication
• Why incorrect: Guidelines classify recent ischemic stroke (<3 months) as relative rather than absolute; absolute exclusions (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage on CT) prohibit tPA under any circumstance.
• Misconception: Equating all exclusion criteria with absolute contraindications.
• Differentiator: Absolute exclusions have zero tolerance for variation.

C. It is safe to administer
• Why incorrect: Administering tPA within 3 months of a prior stroke markedly increases hemorrhagic transformation risk.
• Misconception: Belief that only time from symptom onset matters, not prior events.
• Differentiator: Safety profile is compromised by recent tissue vulnerability.

D. It is only contraindicated in patients over 80 years old
• Why incorrect: Age >80 is not a contraindication; in fact, tPA is approved for all adults up to 4.5 hours—with careful blood pressure control.
• Misconception: Confusing age-related exclusion in extended window trials (e.g., WAKE-UP) with standard eligibility.
• Differentiator: Age and recent stroke are distinct considerations in thrombolysis guidelines.

Comparison Table

OptionGuideline ClassificationHemorrhagic RiskKey Point
ARelative contraindicationModerately elevatedHistory of stroke <3 months increases sICH risk; clinician judgement required.
BMisclassification (not used)N/ARecent stroke is not absolute exclusion.
CNot recommendedHighIgnores enhanced BBB disruption.
DIrrelevant age-based exclusionVariableAge >80 is not an exclusion for standard window.

Clinical Pearls

- Always review the timeline of prior neurologic events; even “silent” infarcts on imaging can influence hemorrhagic risk.
• Relative contraindications demand individualized risk–benefit assessment; obtain advanced imaging (CT perfusion or MRI diffusion) if uncertainty exists.
• Blood–brain barrier integrity may remain compromised for weeks; infarct volume and location further modulate risk of hemorrhagic transformation.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Students often conflate “exclusion criteria” with absolute contraindications, leading to inappropriate refusal of tPA.
• Misremembering age cutoffs: age >80 is not an exclusion for the standard 0–4.5 hr window—only for certain extended-window protocols.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines (Stroke, 2019)
• Recommendation: History of ischemic stroke within 3 months is a relative exclusion to IV alteplase (Class III: No Benefit or Harm; LOE C-EO).
2. European Stroke Organisation Guidelines 2021
• Recommendation: Advise caution and individualized decision-making for patients with prior stroke <3 months; advanced imaging to exclude hemorrhage or large infarct (Level B).
3. IST-3 Trial (Lancet, 2012)
• Secondary analysis: Prior stroke <3 months associated with increased sICH (9% vs. 6.5%; OR ~1.5), supporting cautious use.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam.
Exclusion criteria for IV thrombolysis—especially timing of prior stroke—are frequently tested as single best–answer items, often in clinical vignettes emphasizing hemorrhagic transformation risk.

question_text: A 50-year-old developed progressive symptoms starting with sensory loss in the left lower limb, which then progressed to involve both lower limbs. The symptoms increase with standing, and the sensory level is at T10. MRI shows a T2-hyperintense long lesion in the conus with a hypodense rim on T1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] • Spinal dural arteriovenous fistulas (SDAVF) are the most common spinal vascular malformation, typically in males aged 40–60.
• Pathophysiology: an abnormal connection between a radiculomeningeal artery and a dural vein causes venous hypertension, cord edema and progressive myelopathy.
• MRI hallmarks: longitudinal T2-hyperintense signal spanning multiple segments (often conus), T1 hypointense “rim” from slow flow/hemosiderin, and dilated perimedullary flow voids.
• Clinical clue: symptoms worsen with maneuvers that increase venous pressure (standing, Valsalva).
(Word count: 103)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dural venous fistula produces chronic venous congestion leading to progressive, insidious myelopathy. MRI demonstrates a longitudinally extensive T2 lesion in the conus with a hypointense rim on T1 due to slow flow and hemosiderin deposition; perimedullary flow voids are often present (Rodesch et al., 1994). Symptom exacerbation on standing or straining reflects increased intrathecal venous pressure (Aminoff & Logue, 1974). Definitive diagnosis requires spinal digital subtraction angiography (DSA). Current consensus guidelines (Spetzler et al., J Neurosurg Spine 2018) recommend prompt microsurgical disconnection or endovascular therapy to prevent irreversible cord injury. No inflammatory markers or antibodies are present, distinguishing it from NMO, and the subacute progression is too slow for infarction. Acute hemorrhage or nidus seen in true AVM is absent.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. NMO
– Incorrect: Neuromyelitis optica causes longitudinal transverse myelitis but with acute relapsing course, serum AQP4-IgG positivity, and often optic neuritis. No flow voids or T1 rim.
B. Spinal Infarction
– Incorrect: Infarction is abrupt, painful onset with maximal deficit at onset; MRI shows restricted diffusion and “owl’s eye” T2 hyperintensity in anterior horns, not chronic hypointense rim or flow voids.
C. AVM of the spine
– Incorrect: Spinal cord AVMs have a compact nidus with acute hemorrhage risk, present with subarachnoid hemorrhage or high-flow signs, not insidious worsening with posture and without nidus or cord expansion patterns typical of SDAVF.

Comparison Table

FeatureDural Venous FistulaNMOSpinal InfarctionSpinal AVM
OnsetInsidious, progressiveAcute/subacute relapsingSuddenAcute hemorrhage or steal
MRI T2 signalLongitudinal conus edemaLongitudinal, centralFocal “owl’s eye”Focal nidus, variable edema
T1 hypointense rimYes (slow flow/hemosiderin)NoNoRare
Perimedullary flow voidsYesNoNoYes (nidus)
Response to postureWorse with standing/ValsalvaNo relationNo relationNo relation
Diagnostic gold standardSpinal DSAAQP4-IgG + MRIClinical + diffusion MRISpinal DSA

Clinical Pearls

• Always inspect T1 and T2 sequences for a hypointense rim and dilated dorsal flow voids when evaluating progressive myelopathy.
• Symptoms that worsen with standing or Valsalva suggest venous hypertension—key for SDAVF.
• Misdiagnosis as inflammatory myelitis and steroid treatment can exacerbate cord edema in SDAVF.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Attributing a longitudinally extensive lesion solely to demyelination and starting immunotherapy without vascular imaging.
2. Failing to identify subtle flow voids on MRI, leading to delayed DSA and irreversible spinal cord injury.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Spetzler RF et al., J Neurosurg Spine 2018: International consensus on classification and management of spinal vascular malformations recommends early DSA and microsurgical disconnection or endovascular occlusion (Level II).
2. Hurst RW et al., Neurology 2020: Systematic review found microsurgical treatment achieves >95% obliteration vs. 75–80% for endovascular approaches; early intervention correlates with better functional outcomes (evidence level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam. Spinal dural arteriovenous fistulas are frequently tested as a cause of subacute myelopathy with longitudinal MRI lesions, and distinguishing features (flow voids, T1 rim, posture-dependent symptoms) are high-yield for boards.

question_text: Q220. A patient with acute stroke on dabigatran for atrial fibrillation underwent thrombectomy and developed hemorrhage over the MCA territory. What should be administered?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor used in atrial fibrillation to prevent cardioembolic stroke. Intracerebral hemorrhage in the middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory after reperfusion therapy constitutes a life-threatening bleed requiring immediate reversal of anticoagulation. Knowledge of specific versus non-specific reversal agents and their mechanisms is critical in acute neuro-emergencies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Idarucizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody fragment that binds dabigatran with ~350-fold higher affinity than thrombin, neutralizing its anticoagulant effect within minutes. The RE-VERSE AD trial (Pollack et al., NEJM 2017) demonstrated rapid normalization of coagulation parameters and cessation of bleeding in nearly all patients. The 2016 ISTH guidance (level 1C) and the 2018 AHA/ASA acute stroke guidelines (class I, level B-NR) recommend idarucizumab for life-threatening hemorrhage on dabigatran. No other reversal agents have comparable specificity or efficacy for direct thrombin inhibitors.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Vitamin K
• Targets gamma-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, X; ineffective for direct thrombin inhibitors.
• Misconception: All anticoagulants respond to vitamin K.

C. Fresh frozen plasma
• Supplies coagulation factors but does not remove or neutralize dabigatran.
• Misconception: Volume replacement reverses all anticoagulants.

D. Protamine sulfate
• Binds and inactivates heparin and low-molecular-weight heparins; no affinity for dabigatran.
• Misconception: Protamine is a universal anticoagulant antidote.

Comparison Table

FeatureIdarucizumabVitamin KFresh Frozen PlasmaProtamine Sulfate
MechanismMonoclonal Fab binds dabigatranCofactor for γ-carboxylationReplacement of clotting factorsBinds heparin
Target AnticoagulantDabigatranWarfarin/VKAsVarious factor deficienciesHeparin/LMWH
Onset of ActionMinutes6–24 hours30–60 minutesMinutes
Indication for ReversalLife-threatening bleed on dabigatranVKA-related bleedingMassive bleed with factor deficitsHeparin overdose

Clinical Pearls

- Idarucizumab dosing is 5 g IV (two consecutive 2.5 g infusions) with no dose adjustment for renal function.
• Always obtain coagulation assays (e.g., dilute thrombin time) to confirm dabigatran activity when available.
• In DOAC-related hemorrhage, rapid reversal reduces hematoma expansion and improves outcomes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Selecting vitamin K or FFP for DOAC reversal delays appropriate therapy—only idarucizumab neutralizes dabigatran directly.
2. Assuming protamine sulfate reverses all anticoagulants; it is specific to heparin and its derivatives.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Pollack CV Jr. et al., RE-VERSE AD trial (NEJM 2017): Demonstrated complete reversal of dabigatran anticoagulation in 100% of bleeds; onset <5 minutes (level A evidence).
2. ISTH Guidance on DOAC Reversal (2016): Recommends idarucizumab for dabigatran-associated life-threatening bleeds (grade 1C).
3. AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (2018 update): Class I recommendation for idarucizumab prior to surgery or in hemorrhage (level B-NR).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

MCA territory hemorrhage often involves the lateral frontal and parietal lobes and can lead to contralateral hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, and aphasia when dominant hemisphere is affected.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Dabigatran directly inhibits thrombin (factor IIa), preventing fibrin formation. Accumulation in overdose or procedural contexts (thrombectomy) can precipitate hemorrhage by blocking clot stabilization.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Non-contrast CT shows hyperdense regions in MCA distribution. Serial imaging guides management of hematoma expansion.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Idarucizumab: 5 g IV over 5–10 minutes; monitor coagulation (dilute thrombin time, ecarin clotting time) post-administration.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam.
Reversal of DOACs, particularly specific antidotes like idarucizumab for dabigatran, is a high-yield topic on neurology and internal medicine boards, often tested in acute hemorrhagic stroke scenarios.

question_text: A young male patient presents with third nerve palsy. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the attached image of a Pcom aneurysm?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Cranial nerve III (oculomotor) carries motor fibers to four extraocular muscles and parasympathetic fibers to the pupil. The parasympathetic fibers run peripherally in the nerve, making pupillary function exquisitely sensitive to compressive lesions. A saccular aneurysm at the junction of the internal carotid artery and posterior communicating artery (Pcom) can enlarge and directly compress CN III, leading to an acute, pupil-involving third nerve palsy. Distal ischemic causes (e.g., microvascular infarction) typically spare the pupil. Recognition of this pattern on clinical exam and confirmation with vascular imaging (CTA/MRA/DSA) is critical for prompt neurosurgical or endovascular intervention.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Posterior communicating artery aneurysms account for approximately 20–25% of all intracranial aneurysms. When they compress the oculomotor nerve, patients present with ipsilateral ptosis, “down and out” eye position, and dilated pupil due to parasympathetic fiber involvement. A meta-analysis by McLaughlin et al. (Stroke, 2014) found that 85% of patients with Pcom aneurysm–induced CN III palsy experienced partial or complete recovery after timely clipping or coiling. The 2022 AHA/ASA Guideline for the Management of Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (Class I, Level B) recommends early repair of symptomatic aneurysms to prevent rupture and reverse compressive neuropathies. High‐resolution CTA or digital subtraction angiography confirms the diagnosis by visualizing the saccular outpouching at the ICA–Pcom junction.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRESS)
• PRES presents with headache, seizures, and visual disturbances due to vasogenic edema in parieto-occipital lobes on MRI.
• Misconception: PRES can cause “visual” symptoms, but it does not produce an isolated cranial nerve III palsy.
• Differentiator: MRI shows bilateral edema, not a focal vascular lesion compressing CN III.

C. Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS)
• RCVS features thunderclap headache and segmental arterial narrowing on angiography, often without focal neuropathies.
• Misconception: Sudden headache syndromes always implicate vascular etiologies compressing nerves.
• Differentiator: Angiography shows “string-of-beads” vasoconstriction; no cranial nerve compression.

D. Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection
• HSV encephalitis produces fever, altered mental status, and temporal lobe lesions on MRI, not isolated oculomotor palsy.
• Misconception: Viral infections can lead to any focal deficit.
• Differentiator: CSF pleocytosis and temporal lobe enhancement, without aneurysmal dilation.

Comparison Table

FeaturePcom AneurysmPRESRCVSHSV Encephalitis
PathophysiologySaccular aneurysm compresses CN IIIVasogenic edema from autoregulatory failureTransient segmental arterial spasmViral infiltration of temporal lobes
Key Clinical SignIpsilateral, pupil-involving CN III palsyHeadache, seizures, visual lossThunderclap headacheFever, confusion, seizures
ImagingCTA/DSA: focal ICA–Pcom outpouchingMRI: bilateral parieto-occipital T2 hyperintensitiesAngiography: “string-of-beads” narrowingMRI: temporal lobe T2/FLAIR hyperintensity
Pupillary InvolvementPresentAbsentAbsentAbsent

Clinical Pearls

• Pupillary involvement in third nerve palsy is a red flag for compressive lesions; microvascular palsies spare the pupil.
• The oculomotor nerve runs between the posterior cerebral and superior cerebellar arteries, making it vulnerable to adjacent aneurysms.
• Early endovascular coiling or microsurgical clipping often leads to full or partial recovery of nerve function.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating any acute headache with aneurysmal compression; isolated CN III palsy localizes lesion better than headache quality alone.
2. Assuming viral encephalitis can present with isolated cranial nerve palsies without encephalopathy or fever.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Heart Association/American Stroke Association. 2022 Guideline for the Management of Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage. Recommends early elective repair (Class I, Level B) of unruptured aneurysms causing cranial neuropathies to prevent rupture and reverse symptoms.
• European Stroke Organization. 2023 Guideline on Endovascular Treatment of Intracranial Aneurysms. Advises endovascular coiling for Pcom aneurysms <10 mm with symptomatic nerve compression (Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. Vascular compressive cranial neuropathies—particularly Pcom aneurysm causing third nerve palsy—are frequently tested as image-based vignettes in both neurology and neurosurgery sections of board examinations.

question_text: An elderly patient presents with temporal pain, jaw claudication, and visual symptoms, along with a high ESR. What is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA) is a large-vessel vasculitis affecting branches of the external carotid artery, notably the superficial temporal artery. Key features include:
• Granulomatous inflammation of medium/large arteries leading to luminal narrowing and ischemia
• Jaw claudication and temporal headache from ischemia of masticatory muscles and periosteum
• Ocular involvement (transient or permanent vision changes) due to ophthalmic artery ischemia
Rapid initiation of high-dose corticosteroids is critical to prevent irreversible vision loss; diagnostic biopsy should follow but not delay therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

IV methylprednisolone is the recommended first step in suspected GCA with visual symptoms. EULAR 2018 guidelines (Hellmich et al., Ann Rheum Dis 2018) advise 500–1000 mg IV for 3 days in ocular involvement, then switch to high-dose oral prednisolone. Immediate therapy before biopsy reduces risk of anterior ischemic optic neuropathy. ACR/Vasculitis Foundation 2021 recommendations reinforce prompt high-dose steroids and suggest tocilizumab as a steroid-sparing adjunct (Stone et al., NEJM 2017). Starting IV methylprednisolone addresses acute ischemia faster than oral prednisone, halting inflammatory arteritis and preserving vision.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Aspirin
• Why incorrect: Low-dose aspirin may reduce ischemic events but is adjunctive, not primary therapy.
• Misconception: Assuming antiplatelet therapy alone can prevent vision loss.
• Differentiator: Does not target granulomatous arterial inflammation.

C. Prednisone
• Why incorrect: Oral prednisone (40–60 mg/day) is standard when no visual symptoms; slower onset in acute visual threat.
• Misconception: Equating any corticosteroid route as equally effective in ocular involvement.
• Differentiator: Delayed peak concentrations vs. IV route.

D. Temporal artery biopsy
• Why incorrect: Biopsy confirms diagnosis but should follow, not precede, urgent steroid therapy.
• Misconception: Prioritizing tissue diagnosis over vision preservation.
• Differentiator: Diagnostic tool vs. therapeutic urgency.

Comparison Table

FeatureIV MethylprednisoloneOral PrednisoneAspirinTemporal Artery Biopsy
Route & DoseIV 500–1000 mg/day ×3 daysPO 40–60 mg/dayPO 75–100 mg/dayN/A
Onset of Action1–2 hours4–6 hoursDays (platelet inhibition)N/A
Indication in GCAVisual symptoms or threatened visionNo ocular involvementAdjunctive to reduce ischemic riskDiagnostic confirmation
Guideline Recommendation (LoE)EULAR 2018, LoE CEULAR 2018, LoE CEULAR 2018, LoE BShould not delay steroids

Clinical Pearls

• Jaw claudication has ~90% specificity for GCA.
• Always initiate high-dose steroids before temporal artery biopsy to prevent vision loss.
• Consider low-dose aspirin as an adjunct to reduce stroke risk in GCA.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Waiting for biopsy results before starting steroids, risking irreversible blindness.
2. Using only oral prednisone in acute visual symptoms, leading to delayed therapeutic levels.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• EULAR Recommendations 2018 (Hellmich et al.): For GCA with ocular involvement, start IV glucocorticoids (500–1000 mg/day for 3 days); then switch to oral prednisolone (LoE C).
• ACR/Vasculitis Foundation 2021: Endorses prompt high-dose steroids; tocilizumab added for steroid sparing (Level II evidence from Stone et al., NEJM 2017).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Inflammation of the superficial temporal artery (branch of external carotid) and its ophthalmic branch compromises blood flow to the optic nerve head, leading to anterior ischemic optic neuropathy.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Granulomatous infiltration of the arterial media and adventitia by multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytes leads to intimal hyperplasia, luminal occlusion, and downstream ischemia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion with headache, jaw claudication, visual changes, high ESR/CRP
2. Start high-dose corticosteroids immediately
3. Ultrasound “halo sign” or MRI angiography if available
4. Temporal artery biopsy within 2 weeks of steroid initiation for confirmation

Neuroimaging Pearls

Ultrasound of temporal arteries may show a hypoechoic “halo sign” reflecting vessel wall edema; FDG-PET can detect large-vessel involvement.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

IV methylprednisolone: 500–1000 mg/day for 3 days, then switch to oral prednisolone 1 mg/kg/day. Monitor for steroid side effects; initiate bone protection.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. Giant Cell Arteritis is frequently tested in rapid-recognition vignettes; questions often focus on immediate management to prevent vision loss and the role of temporal artery biopsy.

question_text: A young lady with two miscarriages and livedo reticularis is being evaluated. What laboratory test should be ordered?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] - Autoimmune hypercoagulability: Anti-phospholipid syndrome (APS) features autoantibodies (lupus anticoagulant, anti-cardiolipin, anti-β2-glycoprotein I) that activate endothelial cells and platelets, promoting thrombosis.
• Obstetric manifestations: Recurrent early pregnancy loss results from placental thrombosis and infarction.
• Dermatologic sign: Livedo reticularis arises from segmental cutaneous vascular occlusion.
• Diagnostic criteria: Sydney criteria require at least one clinical event (thrombosis or pregnancy morbidity) plus persistent antibody positivity ≥12 weeks apart.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Anti-phospholipid antibody testing is the definitive laboratory evaluation for suspected APS in patients with thrombotic events or recurrent pregnancy loss. The 2006 Sydney update (Miyakis et al., J Thromb Haemost 2006) mandates testing for lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin IgG/IgM, and anti-β2-glycoprotein I. APS is identified in up to 15% of women with recurrent miscarriages (Branch et al., Blood 1998). Although lupus anticoagulant prolongs aPTT in vitro, routine coagulation profiles lack specificity and sensitivity for APS. Early diagnosis allows initiation of low-dose aspirin plus heparin, reducing miscarriage recurrence by 70–80% (Empson et al., Lancet 2005).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Complete blood count
• Incorrect: Evaluates anemia or thrombocytopenia but does not detect antiphospholipid antibodies or hypercoagulability.
• Misconception: Belief that a normal platelet count excludes clotting disorders.
• Differentiator: APS diagnosis relies on serologic antibody panels, not cell counts.

C. Thyroid function tests
• Incorrect: Hypothyroidism can cause miscarriage but does not explain livedo reticularis or thrombotic risk.
• Misconception: Assuming all recurrent pregnancy losses are endocrine in origin.
• Differentiator: APS presents with cutaneous vasculopathy and requires antibody detection.

D. Coagulation profile
• Incorrect: PT/aPTT may be paradoxically prolonged by lupus anticoagulant yet does not confirm APS.
• Misconception: Interpreting prolonged aPTT as bleeding tendency rather than thrombosis risk.
• Differentiator: Specific antiphospholipid antibody assays are necessary for diagnosis.

Comparison Table

FeatureAnti-phospholipid Ab TestingComplete Blood CountThyroid Function TestsCoagulation Profile
Clinical purposeConfirm APS in thrombosis/pregnancyAssess blood cell linesScreen thyroid disordersMeasure PT/aPTT
Specificity for APSHigh (≥99% with combined assays)NoneNoneLow
Sensitivity for pregnancy loss85–90% for APS-related casesN/A20–30% for endocrine causesN/A
Diagnostic requirementPositive on ≥2 occasions ≥12 weeksSingle sampleSingle sampleSingle sample

Clinical Pearls

- Lupus anticoagulant often prolongs aPTT in vitro but indicates thrombosis risk in vivo.
• Confirm persistent antibody positivity ≥12 weeks apart to avoid false positives from transient infections.
• Combined low-dose aspirin and heparin therapy in pregnant APS patients reduces miscarriage rates by up to 80%.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overreliance on PT/aPTT: Not pursuing specific antiphospholipid antibody testing when aPTT is normal or paradoxically prolonged.
